post.title: Colin Stetson, New History Warfare Vol. 2: Judges
post.summary: If I stay totally still and keep my face totally blank, maybe nobody will notice. I twitch. I canâ€™t help it. It was an involuntary action; a muscle in my face pulled itself loose from my act. Will it give me away, will it throw me off balance? I am listening to New History of Warfare Volume 2, not for the first time, but for the first time all the way through. I first heard Colin Stetson yesterday. A dream of water shuffled onto my Spotify radio. It sent my brain flying in wild tangents of emotion. Listening to the album now, at my desk at work, is a dangerous undertaking. The music strikes me with terror, it has planted a ravenous seed of nausea in the pit of my stomach and,Â occasionally, it offers me a glimpse of something. Of a feeling that is, in some unexplainable way, above it all. I look around at my colleagues (silently typing, oblivious to what i am going through) and feel like I have been let in on a secret. Colin Stetson isnâ€™t for everyone. His music requires a certain mindset. I canâ€™t imagine it would be the kind of album that I would throw on every day. But it is the kind of album that I can see myself coming back to. A lot. Somehow, it captures the confusion of feeling that is life. The panic, the fear, the confrontation, the hatred, the sadness and theÂ ecstasy. And it does all this, with just one instrument. A sax. But this isnâ€™t the saxophoneÂ like youâ€™ve heard it before.Â Colin Stetson teases an orchestra of sounds out of his instrument. ItÂ writhes and it screams; shakes with tears and with hatred. It flares with emotion asÂ it talks to the listener in a voice that speaks another language, with words you donâ€™t understand but in a tone that you do. Then, with chilling dextrousness, Â it sheds this cloak of humanity Â and emerges as something cold and hard, thudding, scrapping, grinding; making the sounds of a hundred aching machines. I canâ€™t describe it. Youâ€™re going to have to listen.

post.title: Year In Review: Top 25 Tracks Of 2012
post.summary:
Words: Alison Potter, Emily Solan, Howard Gorman, Jack Thomson, Rajan Lakhani, Raman K, Saam Das, and Simon Opie
If you thought that end of year lists were history (winking smiley) by now then you'd be sorely wrong. We adopt an overly careful and considered approach when putting our lists together. We think the effort is worthwhile. Judge for yourselves below with our favourite songs of 2012 featuring everyone from big hitters like Bobby Womack and Arctic Monkeys to upcomers Mt. Wolf and LULS.
#25: Mammal Club - 'Painting' [Listen]
Good bands pop up all the time. But itâ€™s also important to reflect on those who slip out of our grasp. Newcastle experimentalists Mammal Club sadly called it a day in 2012 but gave us one of the most powerfully dynamic singles of the year in 'Painting'.
#24: Everything Everything - 'Cough Cough' [Listen]
From Mammal Club to one of their undoubted influences, Everything Everything. The band wowed us with their comeback single 'Cough Cough'. Complete with actual cough sounds, this was one of the most brilliantly inspired intros weâ€™ve ever heard.
#23 LULS - 'Swing Low' [Listen]
LULS emerged in 2012 in a cloud of mystery. Just like pretty much any other new band in 2012. What stood them apart was their ability to construct Wild Beasts-esque wide-eyed offerings like 'Young' as well as this storming indie anthem.
#22 The Vaccines - 'I Always Knew' [Listen]
Probably the best song written by a drummer since the days of Razorlight, this ode is filled with some of the most frank lyrics weâ€™ve heard all year, especially in â€œSo letâ€™s go to bed before you say something real/Letâ€™s go to bed before you say how you feelâ€.
#21 Ministry - 'Ghouldiggers' [Listen]
The death of Ministry guitarist Mike Scaccia just before Christmas adds a certain twist to the amusing lyrics of 'Ghouldiggers' - which discusses being worth more to the music industry when youâ€™re dead than alive, amid crunching riffs. RIP Mike.
#20 Twin Shadow - 'Five Seconds' [Listen]
The standout from George Lewis Jr aka Twin Shadow's latest album 'Confess' - an exciting, heady rush of a song, with an â€˜us against the worldâ€™ vibe.
#19 Rainy Milo - 'Bout You'
Weâ€™re expecting big things in 2013 for London songstress Rainy Milo, whose arresting, soulful vocals evoke the memory of Amy Winehouse. We hope that Rainy can match the latterâ€™s success, without the tragic ending.
#18 Bobby Womack - 'Please Forgive My Heart'
The song is heartbreaking in itself but when added to Bobby Womack's history, it's nigh on impossible to stop being emotionally floored by it. The burbling piano is understated, giving his extraordinary vocal prominence instead. The confessional nature of the lyrics are heightened as Womack desperately seeks redemption in the song for his past deeds.
#17 Oliver Tank - â€˜Up All Nightâ€™
Up All Night by Oliver Tank Oliver Tank is a magical talent who didnâ€™t quite take off in the way we had hoped over the course of 2012. Not his fault though, with gems like â€˜Up All Nightâ€™ making steady appearances. His beautiful brand of electronica hopefully wonâ€™t remain underappreciated for much longer.
#16 Foals - 'Inhaler'
The days of Foals' jerky math-pop seem a long, long time ago. Previewing their forthcoming new album, 'Inhaler' came as a surprise - seemingly adopting a Madchester vibe while channelling Rage Against The Machine. A juxtaposition which worked remarkably successfully.
#15 Palma Violets - 'Best Of Friends'
No, we're not talking reminiscing about those violet-flavoured sweeties we all loved but rather the south-east London five-piece that are causing a stir, particularly at the NME HQ. Looks like Rough Trade have picked up on the next big thing.
#14 Jai Paul - 'Jasmine'
Jai Paul continues to thrill and baffle in equal measure. He finally followed 'BTSTU' with a new track, 'Jasmine' - its growling intro subsiding into a smooth classic than a certain Bobby Womack would probably be proud of.
#13 Chairlift - 'Take It Out On Me'
Given the turmoil in the synthpop band, Chairlift's second album was a more emotional affair then their previous effort and when the melodies were at the forefront, the results were deeply affecting, best demonstrated by the astonishing 'Take It Out On Me'.
#12 PAWS - 'Sore Tummy'
If you liked the Smashing Pumpkins when they rocked the house and want to discover possibly the best UK drummer around right now then PAWS will thrill and delight. A track surprisingly absent from the vast majority of end of year lists.
#12 Purity Ring - 'Fineshrine'
Purity Ring nailed that bombastic electro-pop sound with their debut album, 'Shrines'. 'Fineshrine' is one of the many excellent examples of the Canadian duo at their striking best.
#11 Alt-J - 'Tessellate'
One half of our single of the month in October 2011 and indeed, Jack's top track of 2011 - the atmospheric and infectious 'Tessellate' stood out on its own upon its July 2012 single release. Alt-J rarely fail to mesmerise.
#10 Strangers - 'Shine On You'
We're still not quite sure how to write their band name but 'Shine On You' was the bandâ€™s finest offering to date. An anthem that should have bothered the upper echelons of the chart but sadly, didn't. Ride the wave of euphoria with arguably the biggest chorus of the year.
#8 HAIM - 'Forever'
They came to our shores in May 2012 as the buzziest band around and still managed to stun most of the UK music industry at The Great Escape festival. 'Forever' is where it all started for HAIM - the unique blend of folk, rock and RnB that saw them top the recent BBC Sound Of 2013 poll.
#7 Arctic Monkeys - 'R U Mine?'
A one-off stop gap single from the boys and a look on what possibly to come on album number 5. Emphasis is placed on guitars here rather than the crooning melodies we saw on 'Suck It And See', this 'Thunderbirds' referencing track excitingly hints at heavier things to come.
#6 Daughter - 'Smother'
Daughter capped off a terrific 2012 by signing for 4AD, who will be putting out the trio's debut album sometime this year. The beguiling 'Smother' signalled a wider scope and ambition than their previous recorded material, suggesting that the forthcoming record will be an alt-folk classic.
#5 Mt. Wolf - 'Life Size Ghosts'
We instantly fell in love with 'Life Size Ghosts', as did pretty much anyone else who listened to the track in 2012. Almost a year on, we remain in awe of the band's mix of pulsating beats, ethereal vocals and folktronica.
#4 Frank Ocean - 'Pyramids'
Ocean's statement about his personal life just ahead of the release of his 'Channel Orange' album was dismissed by some as publicity stunt. The subsequent critical acclaim threw out any such claims. The album's most ambitious track was 'Pyramids', lasting nearly 10 mins but holding the attention of the listener throughout.
#3 Plan B - 'ill Manors'
Plan B's effort at a protest song received more than his fair share of criticism. Yet 'ill Manors' describing more eloquently the emotions expressed by those who feel lost in today's Britain than any politician, expressed even more deeply in his feature film of the same name. One of the most important tracks of 2012.
#2 The xx - 'Angels'
Following on from their Mercury winning debut album was always going to be a challenge. At times, 'Coexist' did match its predecessor, such as on 'Angels' - Romy Madley-Croft's stunning, breathy vocals taking centre stage against their characteristically minimalist background. A wondrously sparse, haunting love song.
#1 BASTILLE - 'Flaws'
We were pretty surprised that BASTILLE didn't feature in the BBC Sound Of 2013. Then again, they've consistently and pleasantly surprised us over the last couple of years. 'Flaws' got a tweak for its 2012 re-release and sounded bigger than ever. Dan Smith and co. were at their most infectious with this synth driven single that highlighted their perfectly gauged harmonies.
Listen to the tracks in a Spotify playlist here, or in the embed above.- Â© copyright â€“ All rights reserved Â¦ FADED GLAMOUR

post.title: Jadeâ€™s Musical Inspiration #BPCreates
post.summary:
Once upon a time, I used to be a dancer. Not, like, professional or anything, but I did love to dance. It put me in a great community of women â€“ not like the kind who go to Juilliard and tear the competition down, but the kind that loves to celebrate each other, femininity, and womanhood. It made me feel powerful, earthy, and womanly â€“ not to mention, an hour of dancing is way fun and an hour of running sucks b*lls (no offense, runners). I use music in my writing most especially to set tone and mood. If thereâ€™s a particular note of angst, drama, melancholy, or swelling ache that I want to hit in my stories, I put on an appropriate song and play it over and over and over again until my writing hits the notes in the song. But the song I want to share with you is one that hasnâ€™t (yet) influenced my writing. Itâ€™s from my dancing days. And I share it with you because when the prompt mentioned music, this is the one that called from my heart. I had danced to it, and I always loved the way the notes trickled and rolled over my body, bending down my back, and spilling out my fingertips and toes. Itâ€™s this one: Red House Paintersâ€™ Song for a Blue Guitar.
I couldnâ€™t even tell you in words what this song speaks to me, I can only dance it. It makes me want to cry. And it makes me want to dance. I hope you want to dance it too. * Â Â * Â Â Â * Over the next few weeks we are looking atÂ how music can and does inspire our writing. Do you use music? Has a particular song inspired you? Leave the song, or a link to your writing playlist on Spotify, weâ€™ll be putting together a BPB Writing Playlist to share with you over the next few weeks.

post.title: La visiÃ³n de Tim Bray, co-inventor de XML, sobre el iPhone Subscribers Has The Strut On Programa GestiÃ³n de almacen
post.summary: Soy usuario iPhone y me molestan en demasÃ­a sus polÃ­ticas restrictivas de la Ã©poca de la prehistoria que van en contra de la libertad que hay en internet. Me molesta en demasÃ­a que hoy para que el iPhone estÃ© a su 100% haya que hacerle jailbreak porque por culpa de los caprichos de Steve Jobs hay aplicaciones geniales que no son aceptadas y no me queda mÃ¡s que decir amÃ©n ante las palabras de Tim Bray, quien fue el co-inventor del XML y que dejÃ³ Oracle para irse a trabajar bajo las filas de Google en Android. Hay dÃ­as que Spotify tiene mÃ¡s trÃ¡fico de Internet que toda Suecia Las redes P2P son una tecnologÃ­a genial donde las personas se transfieren la informaciÃ³n entre ellas sin usar servidores centralizados. BitTorrent, eMule, DC++ y muchos otros servicios utilizan estas redes que, segÃºn estudios, son las que mayor trÃ¡fico manejan en toda la red. Spotify, el nuevo servicio de mÃºsica a travÃ©s de streaming que estÃ¡ causando furor desde su lanzamiento, utiliza este tipo de tecnologÃ­a para hacerle llegar la data a sus usuarios y menos mal que asÃ­ lo decidieron porque lo que revelÃ³ Daniel Ek, el CEO de la compaÃ±Ã­a, en el SXSW es sorprendente: Algunos dÃ­as Spotify consume mÃ¡s ancho de banda de Internet que toda la capacidad que tiene Suecia como paÃ­s. Si en vez de haber elegido esta tecnologÃ­a hubiesen optado por alojar la mÃºsica y transmitirla a travÃ©s de sus servidores hubiera sido un verdadero desastre. AdemÃ¡s actualizÃ³ un poco la informaciÃ³n y revelÃ³ que actualmente tienen 7 millones de usuarios y 320 mil pagan suscripciÃ³n. Al parecer aunque el CEO actual de EMI dijo que este modelo no sirve, poco a poco nos vamos dando cuenta que asÃ­ es como el mundo escucharÃ¡ mÃºsica a travÃ©s tanto de nuestros ordenadores como de nuestros smartphones en el futuro -muy cercano-. SegÃºn Jack Dorsey Twitter funcionarÃ¡ en China y sÃ³lo es â€œcuestiÃ³n de tiempoâ€ Twitter es un fenÃ³meno mundial asÃ­ como los blogs lo fueron hace algunos aÃ±os. Todos los medios lo citan, se habla de una ruptura en la forma de comunicaciÃ³n gracias al funcionamiento e instantaneidad del servicio y nos logramos dar cuenta que esto es real durante el terremoto en Chile, donde funcionÃ³ como Ãºnico medio de comunicaciÃ³n durante las primeras horas. Lamentablemente en China esto no podrÃ­a suceder porque la mayorÃ­a de los usuarios (aquellos que no saben sobrepasar la censura impuesta) no pueden usar la red social, asÃ­ como muchas otras como YouTube o Facebook. Pero ayer en un panel de discusiÃ³n en Nueva York donde se hablÃ³ de activismo digital Jack Dorsey, creador de Twitter, respondiÃ³ que la red de microblogging podrÃ¡ operar en China aunque actualmente estÃ© siendo bloqueada. Esto comenzÃ³ a discutirse cuando Ai Weiwei, famoso artista que estÃ¡ en contra de la posiciÃ³n de su gobierno, le preguntÃ³ si podÃ­a prometer la disponibilidad de la red social en su paÃ­s. Estas fueron las palabras exactas de Dorsey: Yo dirÃ­a que sÃ­. Es sÃ³lo una cuestiÃ³n de tiempo. Pero parece que la respuesta no le cayÃ³ demasiado bien a Weiwei, quien asegurÃ³ que esa no es mÃ¡s que una respuesta "muy filosÃ³fica". Si consideramos que Google estÃ¡ teniendo problemas para operar en China y que hasta existe la posibilidad que se vaya la confianza que se le puede tener a Twitter no es muy grande, realmente. post.title: Goapele Mohlabane â€“ Closer
post.summary: Listen to Goapele Mohlabane - Closer using spotify. If you can't find the tune on spotify try Grooveshark. About Goapele MohlabaneGoapele (pronounced gwa-puh-LAY; born Goapele Mohlabane July 11, 1977), is an American soul and R&B singer-songwriter. Her name means to move forward in Setswana, a Southern African language. Early life: Goapele's South African father Douglas Mohlabane was an exiled political activist who struggled against the Apartheid System. Goapele's New York-born Israeli Jewish mother Noa had been attending protests since the age of 12. Noa attended Friends World College and was studying in Nairobi, Kenya, where she met and married Douglas. Goapele and her older brother DJ Namane Mohlabane were raised in a California South African exile community. Both of her parents inspired Goapele to become very involved in community affairs at a young age. She attended the Berkeley Arts Magnet School, where she led a pre-teen peer-support group. She also became involved in various groups and organizations that combated racism and sexism. In high school, she sang in the Oakland Youth Choir and became part of a music group called Vocal Motion. Upon high school graduation, she attended Boston's Berklee School of Music for a year and a half. Today, her music often highlights the need for political and socio-economic change. She says she has been influenced by many including Stevie Wonder, Etta James, Nina Simone, Billie Holiday, Aretha Franklin, Whitney Houston, Bob Marley, Portishead, Miriam Makeba, Prince, Sade, Caiphus Semenya, Zulu Spears, and Hugh Masekela. Goapele and boyfriend Theo Rodrigues have a daughter together, Bahia Osun (born May 2007). Career: Even Closer: Goapele returned to Oakland after her stint at Berklee College of Music, where she concentrated on writing and recording songs. In 2001, she self-released her debut album, Closer, which sold 5,000 copies. At the same time, she was building a devoted audience through her popular live performances in the San Francisco Bay Area. "Closer" peaked at #63 on Billboard's Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart. In 2002 she reworked Closer, adding five new songs. With the help of her family, she formed her own independent label, Skyblaze Recordings, to oversee her musical career. She released her first nationally distributed album, Even Closer, featuring the single "Closer," through Hieroglyphics Imperium Recordings. "Closer" was also featured on the soundtrack of the 2003 movie Honey. In 2004, Columbia/SME Records picked up Skyblaze Recordings for worldwide distribution and rereleased the album with additional tracks. She co-wrote and co-produced the entire album, which is a mixture of neo-soul, trip-hop, lieder, and jazz. She also toured North America with the band Spearhead. In 2004, Even Closer peaked at #24 on the Billboard Charts for Top Independent Albums. Change it All: Her second album, Change it All, featuring the single "First Love" and the song "Love Me Right," was released December 2005. The album featured production work from Jeff Bhasker, Mike Tiger, Amp Live, Sa-Ra Creative Partners, and Linda Perry. In 2006 the album peaked at #32 on the Billboard Top R&B/Hip Hop Album Charts and #2 on the Top Heatseekers while the single "First Love" reached #18 on the Hot Adult R&B Airplay. Goapele appeared on Soul Train to promote the album in May 2006, in what turned out to be the show's final new episode. She also appeared on The Orlando Jones Show, Jimmy Kimmel Live!, Late Night with Conan O'Brien, ABC View from The Bay and FOX Good Day Atlanta. Her first three releases have garnered praise from the likes of magazines such as Rolling Stone, Nylon, Interview, Marie Claire, Billboard, Essence, and Vibe. She has appeared on the covers of local Bay Area publications San Francisco Magazine, Diablo Magazine, East Bay Express, SF Bay Guardian, Mugshot Magazine, and City Flight, She was named the number-5 artist to watch in the July 2003 issue of Rolling Stone magazine, made the countdown on MTV's Top 10 Artists to Watch, and collaborated with ALDO Shoes' advertisement campaign in its fight against HIV/AIDS, which featured artists such as Avril Lavigne, Ludacris, Dave Navarro, Charlize Theron, Pink, Eve, Rosario Dawson, Eva Mendes, Bow Wow, Ziggy Marley, and Kelly Rowland. Break of Dawn: On July 10, 2009, Skyblaze Recordings leaked the single "Milk & Honey" (produced by Bedrock), the first single from her third studio album of the same title. However, in August 2011, she announced that the album would be titled Break of Dawn. The album is being recorded at the Zoo, home of Goapele's Oakland-based Skylight Studios and will feature production from Drumma Boy, Bedrock, Kanye West, Dan Electric, Mike Tiger, Bobby Ozuna (Raphael Saadiq, John Mayer, Erykah Badu), Malay (John Legend, Mary J. Blige), Jeff Bhasker (The Game, Kanye West, Ludacris, T.I), and other guest musicians. After many delays, the album was finally released on October 25, 2011. Victory: In celebration of the FIFA World Cup 2010 in South Africa Goapele released the single "Victory" featuring South African emcee Hip Hop Pantsula, a prelude to her upcoming musical project Victory, which was released in Winter 2010 and feature an array of artists from the African continent as well as throughout the Diaspora. The leading track was recorded in English, Setswana, and Xhosa and tries to draw attention to the need for education and resources to combat Africa's most crucial dilemmas. The album will also encompass philanthropy, political and social activism. Proceeds from the project will go to ANSA (Artists for a New South Africa) a non-profit organization working to combat HIV/AIDS, assist children orphaned by the disease, advance human and civil right, educate and empower youth and build bonds between the U.S. and South Africa through Arts & Culture. Collaborations: Apart from her solo work, she has collaborated with West Coast MCs such as Aceyalone, E-40, Zion-I, Mac Mall, and those involved in the Hieroglyphics Crew, Detroit based vocalist Dwele as well as Clyde Carson and Mos Def on the track "Different." Human Rights Work: She has performed at rallies, demonstrations and various political events around the world from Cuba to South Africa. On September 14, 2006, the California-based Ella Baker Center for Human Rights honored Goapele with its first ever Human Rights Cultural Hero Award during the Center's 10th Anniversary Celebration, titled "Tribute to a Dream." The following statement was issued by the Center regarding the award: " We are proud to name internationally acclaimed, Oakland-based singer-songwriter Goapele the first recipient of this award. But as successful as she is, Goapele remains deeply rooted in her home community and in the struggle for human rights. We first saw her sing at rallies and demonstrations when both she and Ella Baker Center were just starting out. Today, she is still here with us, side by side, looking forward to a better day for all of our people. " The Ella Baker Center for Human Rights is a non-profit strategy and action center. The stated aim of the center is to work for justice, opportunity, and peace in urban America. wikipedia More: Goapele Mohlabane Lyrics for Closer by Goapele Mohlabane: Closer to my dreams (its coming over me) I`m getting higher Closer to my dreams I'm getting higher and higher Feel it in my sleep Sometimes it feels like I`ll never go pass here Sometimes it feels like I'm stuck forever(ever) But I'm going higher Closer to my dreams I'm going higher and higher I can almost reach Sometimes you just have to let it go (let it go, let it go) Leaving all my fears to burn and die Push them all away so I can move on Closer to my dreams Feel it all over my being(my being) Close your eyes and seek what you believe The path is long(the path is long) But I'm moving home to my dreams (i'll be moving on) I`m getting higher Closer to my dreams I'm getting higher and higher, higher Feel it in my being(i can feel it all around me) I know that I could not go alone(no,no) I'm moving higher, higher(oh) I'm going higher, higher, higher(higher and higher) Closer to my dreams(higher and higher) I`m moving upward and onward and beyond all that I could see Stretching out my arms so I can reach I`m so close it`s like I can(just reach) I can feel my dreams Closer to my dreams I`m moving closer to my dreams Sometimes it feel like you`ll never grown change But you never choose to walk away.Music video with Goapele MohlabaneHere you can find videos from Youtube with Goapele Mohlabane - CloserGoapele Mohlabane - Milk and Honey en.wikipedia.org

post.title: TOUNDRA vs El Nerdo
post.summary: Ya queda poco para el Aloud Music Fest y nosotros apoyamos a muerte a este sello asÃ­ que hemos decidido entrevistar a varios de los grupos que forman parte de su cartel. Para empezar nos hemos quedado con los Toundra que han sacado un disco como IV y acaban de confirmar tambiÃ©n su presencia dentro del cartelazo del Primavera Sound. Pero antes de irnos todos en masa al Parc del FÃ³rum os queremos ver en la Sidecar, La [2] y Sala Apolo dÃ¡ndolo todo los prÃ³ximos dÃ­as 7, 8 y 9 de febrero. Nos contesta Esteban J. GirÃ³n, sin trampa ni cartÃ³n. Â¿AlgÃºn recuerdo musical de infancia? QuizÃ¡s tu primer disco...Hola! Lo primero, muchas gracias por esta entrevista! Un placer charlar con vosotros de manera virtual. Sobre los recuerdos musicalesâ€¦ tengo varios: jugar con mi padre a que Ã©l pinchase vinilos mientras mi hermana hacÃ­a playback con un teclado de juguete, yo con una guitarra de juguete y mi padre haciendo que tocaba la baterÃ­aâ€¦Mi primer disco fue el "Ballbreaker" de AC/DC y el segundo "Appetite for Destruction" de Guns 'n' Rosesâ€¦ ambos me los regalÃ³ mi padre. Sigo siendo un gran fan de AC/DC a dÃ­a de hoy. Â¿QuÃ© artista te hace reÃ­r?Martes y 13â€¦ Ãlex (baterÃ­a de Toundra e Ã­ntimo amigo) y yo somos bastante fans (Ã©l mÃ¡s). Â¿QuÃ© canciÃ³n te hace llorar?Esteban: Ninguna me hace llorar de manera inmediata. He llorado con muchas. "Let it be" de The Beatles cuando echo de menos a la familia suele sonar. "Asturias" de AlbÃ©niz en los dÃ­as en los que odio la ciudad. "Asturias" de VÃ­ctor Manuel en las noches de verano abrazado a mis amigos de infancia. Â¿iTunes o Spotify/ vinilo o mp3?Uso Spotify, tengo iPod y compro vinilos (tambiÃ©n CDsâ€¦ no sÃ© quÃ© os ha dado a todos con el CD. A mÃ­ me devuelve a esa Ã©poca en la que era adolescente y me compraba mis discos en este formato). Me comprÃ© "Kind Of Blue" de Coltrane en iTunes para estudiar el Ãºltimo examen de carrera y nunca he vuelto a usarloâ€¦ asÃ­ que supongo que creo que todos los formatos y sistemas pueden convivir. Â¿CuÃ¡l fue el primer concierto al que fuiste?Uno en el Colegio PÃºblico RamÃ³n de Campoamor de Navia donde estudiaba mÃºsica. Â¿El Ãºltimo concierto al que has ido?The Rippers y a Lagartija Nick a la Sala El Sol. Â¿QuÃ© bandas que te molan nunca has podido ver en directo?Led Zeppelin (mi banda favorita)â€¦ por razones obvias. Me encantarÃ­a haber podido ver a los Stones en forma (ahora son un chiste) y me encantarÃ­a ver a Extremoduro prontoâ€¦ yo quÃ© sÃ©, hay un millÃ³n de grupos que me encantarÃ­a ver. Si no hubieras sido miembro de Toundra...SerÃ­a mÃ¡s infeliz. Â¿Por cierto que te consideras?Me considero Esteban. Alberto de Astoria Records me dijo una vez "no eres un punk rocker ni un hardcoreta. Eres Esteban GirÃ³n y eso es mucho mejor que ser cualquier otra cosa. AdemÃ¡s, vas a ser el mejor siÃ©ndolo de todo el mundo". AprendÃ­ mucho de Alberto. Si tengo que elegir algoâ€¦ dirÃ­a que me considero miembro de mi familia. Eso es lo Ãºnico que siempre me voy a poder considerar. Describe a la gente de Aloud en cinco palabras.Trabajadores, talentosos, cabezones, catalanes y buenas personas. Nombra a la mejor banda del festival.LisabÃ¶. Â¿QuÃ© hay en tu mesita de noche?Ahora mismo el tomo 7 de "Los Episodios Nacionales" de Benito PÃ©rez galdÃ³s, una lÃ¡mpara. La mesa tiene un cajÃ³n donde guardo mi ropa interior. Por las noches suele haber un vaso de leche lleno y por las maÃ±anas un vaso de leche vacÃ­o. Â¿QuÃ© te hace levantar cada dÃ­a?Tener que llevar el vaso de leche vacÃ­o a la cocina. AdemÃ¡s de eso, me cuesta muchÃ­simo despertarme. Soy de tener mucho sueÃ±o acumulado ya que no paro nunca. Lo que me hace levantarme cada dÃ­a es que los mÃ­os se sientan orgullosos de mÃ­. Principales hobbies.Soy aficionado al fÃºtbol. Sigo a Real Madrid en la Liga EspaÃ±ola y al Arsenal en la Inglesa. Tengo dependencia emocional por estar con mis amigos, asÃ­ que paso el poco tiempo libre que tengo con ellos. Toda mi vida estÃ¡ estructurada para poder disfrutar de Toundraâ€¦ pero no olvidemos que tengo otro oficio y que no vivo de esto, asÃ­ que tengo la enorme suerte de pasar mi tiempo libre con grandÃ­simos amigos haciendo lo que mÃ¡s me gusta: tocar la guitarra. Â¿QuÃ© es para ti el Ã©xito?Ser feliz. Y por lo que veo no es nada fÃ¡cil. Tu mayor proeza y tu mayor fracaso.Mi mayor proeza es que creo que tengo mÃ¡s gente que me quiere mucho que lo que la inmensa mayorÃ­a de la gente suele tener. Mi mayor fracaso es no haberme ido aÃºn de EspaÃ±a a vivir algÃºn aÃ±o en otra cultura. Espero poder hacerlo algÃºn dÃ­a. Ahora las seis cuerdas siguen tirando mucho. Â¿CuÃ¡l es tu serie favorita?Matrimonio con hijos. Â¿PelÃ­cula que te cambiÃ³ la vida?Indiana Jones y el Arca Perdida. Libro de cabecera."El maestro y Margarita" de Bulgakov. Â¿QuÃ© conjunto musical te gustarÃ­a resucitar?Fugazi. Voy a morir sin verles, maldita sea. HÃ©roe de infancia.John Lennon. Referente actual.Mi padre Â¿Has viajado al extranjero para asistir a un concierto o festival?No. Aunque ya tengo mi entrada para ver a Neil Young en Biarritz el prÃ³ximo 18 de julio. Hicimos una gira europea este pasado aÃ±o y en este volvemos a la carreteraâ€¦ pero creo que eso no cuenta. Â¿Alguna locura que hayas cometido y que recuerdes con cariÃ±o?Hice un viaje a Bilbao hace unos veranos. LleguÃ© el viernes y no me dormÃ­ hasta el domingo a las 10 de la maÃ±ana. Todo sin sustancias ilegales. PrÃ³ximos proyectos profesionales...En 2013 componer "IV" de Toundra (o parte de Ã©l). Que mi empresa se asiente y gritar bien alto que le den a la crisis. Â¿QuÃ© te hace sentir el estado actual de crisis? Â¿Le ves soluciÃ³n?Varias cosas. En un primer lugar me da rabia e impotencia. Muchos de los valores o "verdades universales" mejor dicho con los que nos han educado no eran mÃ¡s que una gran mentira. El sistema no funciona y, ademÃ¡s, se encargan de que sÃ³lo se aprovechen los poderosos del mismo. Es un sistema sin sentido y los seguimos asumiendo. Por un lado hay una responsabilidad en los cargos polÃ­ticos y en los econÃ³micos enorme. Por otro lado, hay una responsabilidad ciudadana muy grande ya que creo que les dimos el completo sistema a estos inÃºtiles y sinvergÃ¼enzas cuando "todo iba bien"â€¦ y estaba bien claro que no iba nada bienâ€¦ que era imposible que aguantase. Hemos transformado a EspaÃ±a en un paÃ­s sin futuro ya que no hemos invertido en NADA. El Turismo no es una industria que dure hasta el infinito y hemos dejado de lado la agricultura, la pesca y la ganaderÃ­a porque, como vivimos en un sistema sin sentido, sale mÃ¡s a cuenta comprar la leche en Francia y tratarla en Asturias que coger la leche de las vacas asturianas que pastan en el campo de al lado de la fÃ¡brica. Hemos gastado el dinero que Europa nos dejÃ³ en comprar Mercedes en lugar de tractores, por ejemplo. No hay I+D y, para mÃ¡s cojones, somos un paÃ­s de gÃ¡rrulos donde nadie se quiere formarâ€¦ pero nadie quiere joderse los riÃ±ones a base de recoger patatas. Para eso que vengan los rumanos, no? Y luego habrÃ¡ problemas de inmigraciÃ³nâ€¦ Â¡de narices! Por otro lado, creo que lo que hay que hacer es demostrarles a los polÃ­ticos y cargos econÃ³micos que este, en rasgos generales, no es nuestro problema, que es el suyoâ€¦ que son ellos los que se hunden y nosotros no. No pagar ninguna deuda y comenzar de nuevo. Levantarse cada dÃ­a pensando "si no nos sacamos nosotros de esta crisis nadie nos va a sacar" y levantar la sociedadâ€¦ . Y para ello el estado de Ã¡nimo es muy importante. Estamos hundidos, con los brazos bajosâ€¦ lo que hay que hacer es empezar a botar y meterse en la pelea sin miedo a recibir unos cuÃ¡ntos golpes. No soy la persona mÃ¡s feliz del mundo, pero soy consciente (y lo practico cada dÃ­a) que si le hago el dÃ­a mÃ¡s fÃ¡cil a la gente que tengo a mi alrededor, algunas pequeÃ±as cosas irÃ¡n mejor en el mundoâ€¦ y muchas pequeÃ±as cosas hacen cosas enormes. PropÃ³sitos para 2013.Tocar mejor la guitarra. Mucho mejor. Â¿QuÃ© es para ti un NERD?Sinceramenteâ€¦ soy un paleto de pueblo a quien no le gusta mucho los anglicismos y tÃ©rminos modernos de la Cultura Occidental. En mi mundo interior supongo que es algo asÃ­ como un "empollÃ³n" de toda la vida, no? Yo fui empollÃ³nâ€¦ y muchoâ€¦ aunque mi aspecto no coincidÃ­a con la imagen que tenemos de "Nerd" todos. Tampoco voy a ir de guay, bebo Coca Cola como todo hijo de vecino. MuchÃ­simas gracias por la entrevista. Un placer y espero conoceros bien pronto! E

post.title: Nokia announces new Music+ premium streaming service
post.summary:
Nokia announced earlier today that they were rolling out a new extension to their existing Mix Radio service. Itâ€™s called Music+ and, for the relatively low price of â‚¬3.99 a month it enables unlimited skips and downloads on your Lumia device. The price is the equivalent of Â£3.40 over here, although we are hearing itâ€™ll be closer to a 1:1 conversion.
Although the price certainly is attractive, Iâ€™m not sure how wide the uptake of the service is. Iâ€™m not a Windows Phone user, so I couldnâ€™t say how useful the service is â€“ as a lot of my music is locally stored (and legitimately purchased!) I use Google Play Music on the go and Spotify Free at home. Iâ€™ve found that personalised radio services like Last.fm are good for discovery, but I wouldnâ€™t rely on it as my main source for music consumption. Are you a Lumia user? Are you going to upgrade? Let us know in the comments. More info â€“ TheNextWeb
Nokia announces new Music+ premium streaming service is original content from Coolsmartphone.com

post.title: INTERVIEW: Flosstradamus
post.summary:
The hip-hop genre has changed dramatically over the past few years. In the beginning, Debbie Harry of BLONDIE did the very first rap in the song â€˜Raptureâ€™ after hearing a group of local kids rapping around a park table.
From then hip-hop has evolved in many ways and one of them, is how artists today tend to mix the genre with modern pop and electronic melodies to create unique tracks that show just how far hip-hop has come. One of the artists who has taken the blogosphere by storm is FLOSSTRADAMUS, and their electronic melodies mixed with hip-hop flavor have caught the eyes of musos the world over.
J2K (Josh Young) and AutoBot (Curt Caveleri) have released some exciting tracks of late that make you want to just shut up and dance. But their latest project, a mixtape called Banned 2 has just been released and I chatted to AutoBot (aka Curt) about Banned 2 and Australia because FLOSSTRADAMUS will be hitting our shores soon and we need to be ready for awesomeness! So with Banned 2, what did the creation process involve? Josh and I, we have some downtime right now so we were like, alright lets do this, lets make another mixtape for the fans. So then we just uploaded like a little bit, did stuff to it, and gave something to the fans. Are there any artists you look up to? Yeah, Fatboy Slim, the Beastie Boys and I think thatâ€™s it. Of course there are lots of other influences, we also look up to our peers as well. Anyone in our circle thatâ€™s doing next level stuff, we look up to all of them. Like if anyone puts out a song thatâ€™s like next level stuff, I wanna start hurting them so (laughs).
Like a little competition? Yeah like a competition. But we play their songs in our sets for a reason, itâ€™s because we look up to them, but weâ€™re mates. Being an â€˜undergroundâ€™ act, are there any new up-and-comersâ€™ that you could recommend us? Alex Young, we got Jet and Johns, we got Huchi and Lil Texas. All of those people are people that have music, this creativeness that sound great in their own way. Jet and Johns have a track called â€˜Turn Upâ€™, and it has a cool little sound to it. Itâ€™s progressive like this new indian chant and itâ€™s pushing it to, sound almost like stadium sort of stuff. All of the people that have been putting stuff into this genre are really underground sounding, and itâ€™s next level. Also all the stuff Alex Young sends us, even the songs that are like not even put out yet that heâ€™s still doing, are so dope. How did you feel when you broke Twitter by getting users to reply to one of your songs? So we had broken Twitter by just uploading a tweet and getting people to send stuff back to you like messages and when we ended up finding out that we broke it, we were pretty excited. We were excited that it happened because it brings attention to us and thatâ€™s cool, but we were also disappointed because this project that weâ€™d worked weeks or months on, failed. So it was a fail â€“ win I guess.
Would you say the internet is a big part of Flosstradamus? 100 per cent! The internet is 100 per cent part of us because whether itâ€™s influences, getting samples it has everything and we use it to produce our music, distribute our music, everything is using the internet. If I donâ€™t have a connection, then itâ€™s the end of the world. Since youâ€™re coming to play in Australia again soon, what can we all expect from your live show? Smoke, strobes, and a bunch of underground exclusive songs like a bit of hard-style, maybe a bit of club music, and a bunch of American hip-hop artists that you guys probably havenâ€™t heard yet, but itâ€™s gonna be good. Whatâ€™s been your most exciting gig to date? Miami, it was the last show, from memory, that we did with DJ Slink and it was a good last show because it was just so memorable. It was super smokey in the crowd and you could see the lights from peoples iPhones, and it looked just like a sea of stars. That was pretty amazing, and the whole entire night was pretty amazing it was one of the best shows. I ended up, soaking wet with sweat [my shirt] was totally see through, it was amazing.
Still looking to top that? Yeah Iâ€™m still chasing that dragon. There have been good shows since then, but that was just, from beginning to end, it was a great show. Whatâ€™s the biggest difference youâ€™ve seen between Australia and the United States? Definitely the coffee! I love it out there itâ€™s super tasty. I havenâ€™t found coffee like Australia has. Iâ€™m like a coffee fiend, I was getting it every day so I was always finding good spots [for coffee]. Whatâ€™s next for Flosstradamus? Weâ€™re gonna get reppers, finish some of our songs hopefully. Putting out some new EPs as well as, publish something on iTunes and Spotify for people overseas so. Hopefully thatâ€™s what weâ€™re doing in the future, but thereâ€™s heaps of stuff, weâ€™ve got shows up until middle of spring or summer. Thereâ€™s a term in the states called â€˜making hay when the sunhinesâ€™ so weâ€™re just trying to do that, make the most of it. CatchÂ FLOSSTRADAMUSÂ live atÂ CANT SAYÂ Melbourne on Feb 15.Â MORE INFO HERE Words by Lauren Payne READ MORE INTERVIEWS HERE The post INTERVIEW: Flosstradamus appeared first on Purple Sneakers.

post.title: Â¡Hoy es el dÃ­a! El dÃ­a de viajar a Monte Perdido
post.summary: Cerrar los ojos disfrutar de la naturaleza. Sentir que estÃ¡s en medio de Monte Perdido. Notar que la luz te da en la cara, el clima, el sol, el aroma del bosque, el ruido de los animales que corretean a tu alrededor. Percibir como tu cuerpo se llena de energÃ­a, sentirte como si fueses la flora mientras haces la fotosÃ­ntesis. Abrir los ojos y observar que aun sigues dentro de la inmensa ciudad, en la parada del autobÃºs, esperando en la cola del INEM o en mi caso en la habitaciÃ³n, delante del ordenador mientras diseÃ±o. La mÃºsica de Ciencias Celestes provoca en mi una sensaciÃ³n de calma, alegrÃ­a y bienestar, que me llena de energÃ­a a la vez. En cada una de sus canciones Carlos Sadness nos transmite lo sencilla y bonita que es la vida, nos transporta a un mundo lleno de ritmos y canciones donde las letras hablan de lo sencillo que puede ser todo y de los mÃ¡s profundos sentimientos que surgen en nuestro interior. En esta ocasiÃ³n han sido sus letras las que me han inspirado para hacer el siguiente diseÃ±o. Â¿Por quÃ© no mostrar la naturaleza que todos llevamos dentro? Â¿Por quÃ© reprimir nuestros instintos?Â Â Â AquÃ­ os dejo el link para que escuchÃ©is Ciencias Celestes de Carlos Sadness en Spotify. Saludos y Creatividad antnO

post.title: Samsung's Music Hub to be expanded to other manufacturers' hardware
post.summary: Apple's ecosystem around its iDevices is a major advantage for the company, but key rival Samsung isn't blind to that. The Korean giant is making moves to close that gap, as on Sunday a Samsung SVP announced that the company is going to expand its Media Hub service beyond its Galaxy Note II and Galaxy S III devices, and to other companies' hardware, as well. Samsung SVP of Media Services T.J. Kang said that the company expects the cloud-based audio service, which combines a userâ€™s own library of tracks with Spotify-like streaming, radio and discovery features, to expand widely in 2013. That includes not just expanding geographically -- it's currently only available in six countries -- but hardware-wise, too. It would be easily to call Media Hub an iTunes rival, but limited to Samsung devices -- and only two, for now -- as it is, it's not much of a threat to become the Android iTunes. However, Kang said that the plan is for Music Hub to come to Samsungâ€™s own phones, tablets, smart TVs and potentially even other devices such as its Android-powered connected refrigerator, admitting at the same time that cross-device compatibility would make life easier for consumers. Earlier statements from Young Sohn, who started at Samsung in August as president and chief strategy officer -- and as one of the only president-level Samsung executives based outside of Korea -- indicated that he used iDevices in his private life and that Apple's ecosystem was "sticky." Those statements point to Samsung knowing it needs to push its ecosystem to a wider audience if it wants to truly compete with Apple. However, it's not as simple as just pulling the trigger. Kang said that a wider rollout of Music Hub -- and just for Samsung hardware -- depends on the company managing to sign some territory-specific music labels deals. It also, of course, depends on the release schedule for the companyâ€™s future devices Furthermore, Kang couldn't give a timeframe for availability on other manufacturersâ€™ hardware, instead simply saying that wider hardware availability was the companyâ€™s goal. Since Music Hub is available in Google Play, it would be simple for the company to push it to other manufacturers' devices. Of course, that could bring Samsung face-to-face with on of the big bugaboos of Android: fragmentation. The current version of Music Hub is the result of Samsungâ€™s acquisition of Silicon Valley-based mSpot in May of 2012. However, the company has some work to do on software: It is currently only rated at 2.9-stars in the Play Store.

post.title: Big Hairy Goal Update #1
post.summary:
It is time for an update to my Big Hairy Audacious Goals for 2013. What are your goals? Almost three weeks back I posted my BHAG for 2013, which can be seen as my stretch targets! It has been hectic over the last weeks, but still I feel I have been doing well and itâ€™s time for a small update! Runkeeper (my profile there) tells me that Iâ€™ve hadÂ 8 running exercises since 1st of January. The total kilometer count is 65,1km â€“ averaging 8,14km. My best run so far was when I tested my 10K form â€“ at 55:48 (10.75 km/h). Quite acceptable at this stage! Since running at a treadmill is close to dead boring I have now seen the first 8 episodes of Homeland and yesterday I enjoyed some fabulous music â€“ including TV on the Radioâ€˜s amazing Wolf Like Me. This piece of music is to me perfect for running and it keeps me going!
Now I am off to Amsterdam in a couple of hours â€“ to visit Integrated Systems Europe 2013 and to deliver a few presentations! Now enjoy the music! Get pumped! (You will find my Road Runner track list at Spotify! Music made for running!) PS! I do also have a few professional goals for this year â€“ which I might or might not share with youâ€¦ Later?!

post.title: Tendencias digitales para el 2013
post.summary:

Peer-to-Peer: casos como Etsy, las nuevas impresoras 3D o conceptos como el car-sharing (Whipcar) Personal data: de la informacion personal online al big data. Connected objects: cada vez surgen mas objetos que nos permiten monitorizar practicamente todo a nuestro alrededor (Nike+ Fuelband, termostato Nest) Keep it simple: Square, el nuevo modo de pago es un gran ejemplo de evolucion y simplicidadâ€¦ Revolution in retail: Tesco y los codigos QR, Starbucks & Square, The new ownership: Spotify, Hulu o Airbnb como nuevos modelos de negocio, donde la propiedad pasa a un segundo plano Online learning: edX (MIT, Harvard, Berkeley) y Coursera, la nueva formacionâ€¦. Human-Machine communication: Siri o Google Voice Seach, la nueva via de interacciÃ³n con nuestros mÃ³viles. The mobile gap: el 2013 como el aÃ±o del â€œmobile firstâ€ Think like a startup: los nativos digitales comienzan a liderar empresas y organizaciones, y Ã©stas evolucionan a modelos de ciclos de desarrollo de producto mas rÃ¡pidos y adaptadose a la nueva era digital.

post.title: Nokia Music+: Nokia startet Musik-Dienst
post.summary:
Nokia bindet die Liebhaber von Musik ein wenig an sich. Bereits im Mai 2012 stellte man das kostenlose Mix Radio vor.Â Mix Radio, der kostenlose Musik-Streaming-Dienst von Nokia, stand ab diesem Zeitpunkt fÃ¼r alle Anwender in Deutschland und der Schweiz mit seinen Ã¼ber 15 Millionen Titeln zur VerfÃ¼gung.Â Anders als bei Playlists-basierten Diensten, die auf Titeln der eigenen oder externen Musikbibliothek basieren, kÃ¶nnen HÃ¶rer mit Mix Radio neue Titel entdecken â€“ Ã¤hnlich Last.fm, oder die Radio-Funktion beiÂ rdio, SpotifyÂ & Co. post.title: A Quentin Tarantino Spotify Playlist
post.summary: â€œI said I want a Spotify Playlist!â€ Just a quick post today to try something new: A Spotify Playlist. The more observant readers amongst you will have noticed that I put a Spotify link at the bottom of each post I write, to allow those who have a Spotify account to easily play the record I am writing about. I have no clue as to whether anyone actually uses the link. But â€“ like me â€“ even if its not very useful to most people, at the very least it looks pretty. Or so I keep telling myself, anyway. So given my last article was about the new Tarantino film â€“ Django Unchained â€“ I thought I would put together a Tarantino playlist. If you have a Spotify account you can subscribe to the playlist and it will add itself to your song collection. Probably. Donâ€™t ask me how this stuff works â€“ I have trouble getting an electric toothbrush to work. I have taken my two favourite songs from each film, and if you wanted a quick fix of Tarantino soundtrack, then you could do a lot worse than to download this: Record #146: A Quentin Tarantino Spotify Soundtrack

post.title: paper 53 logo
post.summary: So, I've had an iTunes gift card for over a year and a half, but I never purchase music because I use Spotify and I never watch movies, well, because, well, I'm a Netflix junkie, so I decided to "splurge" on Paper 53. It's so adorable, and I know, from a designer standpoint, it's sort of awful since it costs extra money to get a color mixer and you can't change the thickness of your tools, but the calligraphy pen is so enticing, I had to get the whole set. I ended staying up until 2 AM making an "Idea" journal for logo ideas for the graphic design "company" I work for!

post.title: My Momma Heart: Splashed by that big, deep, wave of emotion.
post.summary:
â€œYou are never alone, you can always come back home.â€ -Jason Mraz, 93 Million Miles â€œJust know, that wherever you go, no you are never alone, you will always get back home.â€ â€“ Jason Mraz After a night of serene snowfall, I woke up to a chilly Saturday morn. Should I go to the gym or stay nestled under my comfy spread? After a few steps, my arthritis called, â€œGo to the gym. You always feel better.â€ So, off I went. Driving slow, of course, because the roads were quite icy. En route to the YMCA, I saw a dad and his three children pulling sledsâ€¦.thatâ€™s all it took. Be still my momma heart.
The big, deep wave of maternal emotion splashed hard. Tears welled and my heart skipped a beat. Those were the days, I thought. I wanted to roll down the window and scream, â€œEnjoy â€˜em while their young,â€ but I was desperately afraid he would call the cops on a crazy redhead heckling from her car. I got to the Y and it was closed. Oh my. I should have known. On my way home, I turned on the radio. A song played that took my breath away. It seemed the perfect theme for my morning drive, already full of nostalgia, pristine views, and thoughts of a child so far away. I pulled over and Spotifyâ€™d the song, bought it and listened to it over and over again. Most of the time I do pretty well with the fact that my dear Candace Rose is on other side of the world, but that snowy mornâ€¦that song on the radioâ€¦those children laughing and carrying their sledsâ€¦opened the floodgates. Oh, I want to make hot chocolate and sit with her, right now. Why, oh, why is she a million miles away from me? So, as the wave overwhelmed me, I gasped for air and made my way to the shore of Knowing. Knowing she was right in the center of Godâ€™s powerful plan for her life. Knowing without a doubt she was happy, safe, and wildly living her dream of wanderlust. Knowing she was unfolding like the rose for which she is named. Knowingâ€¦.that wherever she goes, she is never alone, and that she can always get back home. Right in the center of her Fatherâ€™s will. Her joy brings me joy. Maybe your momma heart hurts right now. I understand. Let this beautiful ballad wash over your pain. Jason says it well, â€œThe absence of the light is a necessary part.â€ We raise strong, independent children so they can go change the world. I just didnâ€™t know it would hurt so much. But then, thanks to modern technology, just minutes after I returned home, she called. God is so good to this momma. He knows, doesnâ€™t he? I sure do pray that God will provide your momma heart with whatever it needsâ€¦right now. The beautiful thing is that we can always go Home, too, canâ€™t we? Home to our Fatherâ€™s heart. WE ARE NEVER ALONE.

In todayâ€™s day and age, the possibilities you can create with music are virtually endless. Â That being said, thereâ€™s a lot of shit in our generationâ€™s music culture. Â But every so often, we stumble across a band or a musician that can change our lives.
So Iâ€™m super into post-rock, and Iâ€™m always looking for different styles of it. Â Today I stumbled across this band, El Ten Eleven on spotify. post.title: Nokia launches Music+ subscription service, sadly it requires Windows Phone
post.summary: Music means different things to different people. Some listen to music to elicit an emotionally response, others just want something on in the background while theyâ€™re doing menial labor. Whichever group youâ€™re a part of isnâ€™t really relevant though, everyone here has to admit that technology has changed the way music is consumed. People used to buy albums, then they bought digital singles, and now itâ€™s all about the streaming services. Google doesnâ€™t have one, Apple doesnâ€™t have one, but thatâ€™s OK since there are companies out there like Spotify. For those who donâ€™t know how Spotify works, itâ€™s like Netflix. You pay a monthly fee and you get to listen to whatever it is you want. If you stop paying money, then no more music for you. But thereâ€™s another company that doesnâ€™t get a lot of attention from the press regarding their music service, and thatâ€™s Nokia. â€œNokia Musicâ€ is easy to describe if youâ€™ve heard of Last.FM or Pandora. You pick an artist or musical genre, and then the service picks songs it thinks you might like. If thereâ€™s a song you donâ€™t like, you can skip it, but there are only so many times you can skip per hour. This service is free, but today Nokia is introducing a paid version called Music+. What do you get for 4 USD (4 EUR abroad) per month? Higher quality audio, unlimited skips, unlimited offline playlists, and thereâ€™s even a new web app. Why are we talking about Music+ here? Because we want Google to copy it. Google knows so much about us, where we are, who we talk to, what we search for, so why canâ€™t it predict what music weâ€™ll like? Countless services talk about their libraries of 20+ million songs, but who cares if you donâ€™t know which tracks are worth your time? Come on, Google, make us proud. post.title: Olive One
post.summary:
Olive, an audiophile device company, has set the next step on the path to convenient access to music via online streaming. The Companyâ€™s newest device is called the Olive One, it is a â€œdisk-shaped audio player with a built-in HD amplifier, single volume dial and 7-inch touchscreen to choose your musicâ€ (SOURCE)
IMAGE: Indiegogo The company has basically taken the popularity and ease of streaming music players you might find on a computer or iPhone (such as Spotify) and created a device with high-end audio components to please music fans and audiophiles. With hard-drive storage, you can also store your own music library. It also includes iOS, Android and Windows 8 apps which allows your handset to connect and work as a remote control to the device. The device is priced at $400 on Indigogo, and has been made possible via public funding and investments. I love the look of the Olive One, itâ€™s stylish and offers portability, connectivity, high quality sound and a world of music at your fingertips.

post.title: Laneway Festival Singapore 2013
post.summary:
Wow! As I said, my first time going to a music festival. Although I almost fainted due to the hot weather (it was over 30C with no shades, no clouds, bright hot sun shining on us since morning until the sunsetâ€¦was almost unbearable! I think it was one of the major issues since the water isnâ€™t freeâ€¦ Things got blurry for me once, so I had to sit down and put my head down to not faint. After that I just tried to take it easy and drink lots of water and covering my shoulders with my cardigan to not get sun burned, oh and apply sunblock over and over again haha..still I managed to burn my armâ€¦!
This is what it looked like last night when I got homeâ€¦PAIN!! Quickly applied aloe vera gel before going to bed and been re applying regularly so itâ€™s much better today =) The seats we had were good too, close enough to the stage, in between both of them so that we could sit. Never had to move. Took off my shoes and just enjoyed the company and stood up dancing whenever there was a song that called for it haha We stayed until around midnight..so 12-13 hours there
I had a blast. Of course, it wasnâ€™t perfect, but I had a great time =) I understand why people like music festivals like this. The feeling isâ€¦free..=) Like having a picnic with a lot of people at the same time, but with awesome live music playing and no one who thinks youâ€™re weird if you decide to stand up and shout and dance..Later on, think it was when Real Estate was playing, we laid down and listened to the music. It was really nice. The night sky was clear so there were plenty of stars. Never done that before..=) Watching Of Monsters And Men was without a doubt the highlight for me (no surprise there hehe). Theyâ€™re great live and really knows how to entertain and involve the audience. They were super popular as well, everyone moved closer to the stage for their performance and they even did one more song due to their popularity, which was highly appreciated since the running sheet for the bands are fixed and very tight. I really liked the other bands as well! Â Not all of them were my taste, but majority had a few songs I have on my Spotify now Oh, there were so many pretty people there as well..like wow!! =) Anyway, making a video so Iâ€™ll post it when itâ€™s done =)

post.title: The Coda
post.summary: To escape the cold that makes me feel old this week I took another trip up to Trumpet Mountain.I walked into the main hall and heard Clifford Brown practicing in a room inside.I stood outside and listened.The stuff he was playing was way,way past running down chord changes. "Brownie's been hanging out with Don Cherry and Don Ayler" I was shocked to hear these words come from none other than Gil Evans standing in front of me.Gil said he was on Trumpet mountain to talk to Miles about a new symphonic work but that nobody had seen him. "I'm glad I ran into you Matt Lavelle.I have some thoughts about you and that lady Alto Clarinet.You have been friends now a long time,isn't that your third Alto? Look,.when you sold the Bass I knew you weren't bullshitting but your still acting like your just friends.It's time for intimacy my friend.I'll tell you what you all ready know.The key is to get your articulation tight.You need to personalize and finalize that haunting thing you get from the horn.It's dark.Miles loves it and told me he was going to use that color someday." "Do me a favor and tell my friends Bones Malone,Howard Johnson,Bruce Ditmas,and of course my son Miles I said hello.I know you see them at that music store you work at.Sorry to hear that Music Row is done." Suddenly Clifford himself emerged from the practice room smiling. "Hey man!" Clifford and I shook hands right away,it was like we had known each other since forever even though we just met.He was still holding the horn off course. "Matt Lavelle.Your almost out the oven.I'm glad you came by.Here's how to put the cherry on top of your sundae.Articulation." There was that word again.Shit,I've heard guys whisper that around me before.Maybe I was drunk. "I'll tell you one thing about Wallace Roney and Wynton Marsalis,they can articulate there ass off! That was my deal,what made me have such a personal thing.That's the final step for you.As usual,just don't look to Miles,Wallace has better articulation then him anyway.Check out how Clark Terry works out of clarinet books..that's a way for you to unify your deal and become yourself.I never got down in Eb..you like it? You do have a lot to say,just try and say it better.You know how you are with those typos on your blog.Don Cherry gave me a copy of your "In Heart Only" the other day.Nice stuff man." "Now you have to go back and move Sam Ash from Music Row.You know Kenny Dorham worked at Manny's right?" ..... Indeed.What a trip to run into those guys.Before they left I listened to a record Brownie and Gil made together,and no it's not on Spotify son.I took there advice to heart.As they both said I now had to deal with moving the entire Sam Ash store on 48th to w34th st.Rockefeller Rent was to damn high so this long chapter of NYC culture gotta go.West 48th between 6th and 7th once had up to 30 different musical operations going down according to Paul Ash.I've had worse survival systems,way worse,so I'm in the trenches while we move.Moving stores is not new to me.I moved TOWER uptown once,and even Sam Ash across the street when our original brass building was condemned for structure damage.The Ash is after all where I get most of my material.I was on the fence about bringing my jam session back but I got a pep talk from a trumpet player who was truly touched by my thing to get people on common ground to celebrate the sound of life. Back on the home front I'm seeing that when it comes to music and NYC I'm one of those people who just cant let it go no matter how void of culture the city becomes.I'm not here to entertain in the great playground for the rich,I'm here to talk to the world even if it does take them 30 years to hear me.I just don't want the world to pass me by,a fate worse then death.NYC never stops asking you if you really have something to say.I've taken to studying and enlisting some Internet marketing since most of the world spends half of their lives online just like I am right now.If I wasn't here in NY I wouldn't be writing this blog.I would be writing some kind of free Jazz Science Fiction novels.Maybe I still will in my Art Studio in Tenor Town over in Cloudland.No matter what happens I just don't want to go down like Peter Parker and get forced out.Spidey's death still has me tossing and turning every night. My people here in the heights know me better than I know myself. After Snoopy the Chiwawa came running down the hallway to say hello to me for the 5th time today my man Rogelio asked me in Spanish: Rogelio:"Mateo..still with that FLU? I knew you weren't immune like you said." Mateo:"Just one day man,I declared war on the Gripe and won.Mad juice.My crazy dreams were worse than ever" Rogelio:"I told Mirella.When I heard that horn coming out of your room again I knew you were better" Coda: Never better,since ever day you wake is another chance to see the sun. It's just when you think you've lost,you've won. . . . . For Snoopy,with special thanks to Clifford,Gil,and Gretchen Parlato for her lyrics that helped me find a good Coda.Thanks as well to Esperanza Spalding who's music played while I wrote.Wish I could write like her.Been writing a lot as of late,might have to take a Hiatus in Clarinet City.Peace.
post.blogName: That Fat Eb feels Mahogany to me.Matt Lavelle

post.title: Bands to Watch - WALK THE MOON
post.summary: This weekend has been baller as hell. It started with a great show on Friday night. I went to see Cincinnati rockers Walk the Moon on Friday Night at Music Hall of Williamsburg with my buddy Rachel. This guys took down the effin' house. Seriously the energy that they brought to Music Hall of Williamsburg was unbelievable. They played through their entire premiere album, I Want! I Want! and went on to introduce us to some of their new tunes off their Tightrope EP. Highlights for me were definitely when they played my new fave song (of the moment) Tightrope (video below) and when they closed out the night with Anna Sun before coming back for a more than generous encore. I would have loved to hear that tantalizing new cover of Burning Down the House that they released on Spotify, but no worries because me and Rachel just sang it the whole way home. We decided it was our duty to give Brooklyn that performance in lieu of Friday's headliners. I have to say, we put that red wine to good use. Walk the Moon's sound is so cool and eclectic. So fun without being pretentious. I adore seeing artists who love being on stage (this is a follow-up to my blog from earlier this week). These guys were having so much fun, and Nicholas Petricca (who I've lovingly been referring to as "The Mayor of Bonertown" because dayum he's adorbs) sounds just as good on stage as he does in the studio. Very satisfying . . . VERY SATISFYING! And now I feel like such a dope because I didn't realize that they were from Cincy! Turns out I'd even met some of them back at the Fringe in 2010. Here is my favorite moment of realization: me: Did you realize you're friends with the singer of Walk the Moon on FB? 10:55 AMÂ God he is so fooiiinnneeeee 11:09 AMÂ Karim: !Â Â He took a clown workshop I taught at fringe.Â Â Â So yeah, that happened, apparently.

Trots vÃ¥ra olika musikaliska bakgrunder har vi mÃ¥nga likheter nÃ¤r det kommer till vilka instrument vi spelar. Det Ã¤r snarare â€tÃ¤nkandetâ€ som kan skilja sig. Vi kan alla ha olika idÃ©er om hur vi ska approacha en lÃ¥t eller i vilken riktning vi ska ta den, men nÃ¤r det kommer till att skriva texter, melodier och produktion Ã¤r vi alla delaktiga i praktiskt taget alla moment. Hur skulle ni sjÃ¤lva beskriva er musik? Vad inspirerar er till att skriva lÃ¥tar och vilka Ã¤r era influenser? - Vi Ã¤r vÃ¤ldigt inspirerade av de elektroniska ljuden frÃ¥n 70- och 80-talet och hur de brukade blanda organiska och elektroniska, nÃ¤stintill robotaktiga, ingredienser.Â Den elektroniska musikens pionjÃ¤rer, sÃ¥som Kraftwerk, Peter Gabriel och Jean-Michel Jarre, Ã¤r viktiga komponenter i Kate Boys inspirationslÃ¥da. Men mycket inspiration kommer Ã¤ven utanfÃ¶r musiken, film Ã¤r till exempel nÃ¥got vi alla delar en stor passion fÃ¶r. Det Ã¤r nÃ¥got med konceptet som kanske inspirerar oss mer Ã¤n specifika ljud och ord. Den dÃ¤r kÃ¤nslan nÃ¤r du trÃ¤der in i en vÃ¤rld och vill stanna dÃ¤r â€“ den kÃ¤nslan vill vi Ã¥stadkomma med vÃ¥r musik. Att du kan kÃ¤nna igen och hÃ¶ra att det Ã¤r oss pÃ¥ samma sÃ¤tt som du kan sÃ¤ga direkt om det Ã¤r David Lynch eller Stanley Kubrick som gjort en film.
Producerar ni lÃ¥tarna sjÃ¤lva? Hur bestÃ¤mmer ni er fÃ¶r vilka ljud ni ska anvÃ¤nda? - Ja, vi producerar lÃ¥tarna sjÃ¤lva. Efter att ha spenderat sÃ¥ mycket tid tillsammans i studion har det slutat med att vi hittat ett eget sÃ¤tt att tÃ¤nka gÃ¤llande vilka ljud vi ska anvÃ¤nda. Lite som kockar som jobbar i samma kÃ¶k, vi delar med oss av vÃ¥ra erfarenheter och smaker fÃ¶r att skapa nya recept tillsammans. Slutligen hittade vi ett sÃ¤rskilt recept som â€smakadeâ€ som oss. Vilka planer har ni fÃ¶r den nÃ¤rmsta framtiden? Blir det konserter eller en fullÃ¤ngdare snart? - Vi kommer definitivt att turnera och slÃ¤ppa ett album. Just nu arbetar vi med att skriva vÃ¥rt album samtidigt som vi hÃ¥ller pÃ¥ att planera vilka stÃ¤llen vi ska besÃ¶ka. FÃ¶r den nÃ¤rmsta framtiden sÃ¥ har vi videos och nÃ¥gra till singlar som slÃ¤pps snart. Hur gick det till nÃ¤r ni blev signade av IAmSound? Var det fler bolag som hÃ¶rde av sig och i sÃ¥ fall, varfÃ¶r valde ni just IAmSound? - NÃ¤rÂ Northern LightsÂ bÃ¶rjade sprida sig kontaktades vi av bolag.Â Vi respekterar och Ã¤lskar musiken pÃ¥ IAmSound â€“ samt vad de har gjort med sina artister â€“ vilket gjorde beslutet att ge ut vÃ¥r EP genom dem enkelt. Vad tycker ni om den elektroniska musiken fÃ¶r tillfÃ¤llet? - Det Ã¤r inspirerande att se hur elektronisk musik har kunnat utveckla en vÃ¤g in i nÃ¤stan alla genrer. Den stora utmaningen Ã¤r kanske att ge nÃ¥gonting tillbaka till den elektroniska musiken, genom att anvÃ¤nda fler riktiga instrument. Det finns sÃ¥ mÃ¥nga producenter dÃ¤r ute och datorerna Ã¤r bombarderade med nya instrument och sÃ¤tt att utveckla och producera musik. Det Ã¤r nÃ¤stan sÃ¥ att musikscenen laddar upp infÃ¶r en stor explosion av framtida hybrid-genrer. Det Ã¤r verkligen en tid prÃ¤glad av att alla har en chans att producera musik.
Finns det nÃ¥gra akter ni ser upp till eller som ni skulle vilja samarbeta med? - Det finns sÃ¥ mÃ¥nga artister som vi skulle vilja arbeta med, vi Ã¤lskar co-labs. Men vi skulle inte stanna vid musiker, vi skulle Ã¤ven vilja samarbete med personer som gÃ¶r annat Ã¤n att skriva lÃ¥tar â€“ designers, illustratÃ¶rer, fotografer eller bara slumpmÃ¤ssiga personer som tÃ¤nker utanfÃ¶r ramarna â€“ vi vill samarbeta med dem allihop. Blev ni Ã¶verraskade nÃ¤r er musik bÃ¶rjade sprida sig pÃ¥ nÃ¤tet? Hur betydelsefulla har nÃ¤tet och bloggar varit fÃ¶r er? - NÃ¤r vi fÃ¶rst delade med oss av videon till Northern Lights var det bara till vÃ¥ra vÃ¤nner. Tanken var att vi skulle marknadsfÃ¶ra den senare, men innan vi visste det tog den fart pÃ¥ egen hand. Det Ã¤r sÃ¥ inspirerande att se hur enkelt du kan nÃ¥ ut till lyssnare frÃ¥n hela vÃ¤rlden. EP:n innehÃ¥ller Ã¤ven ett par remixer, kan ni berÃ¤tta lite om dem? - Vi Ã¤r stora fans av Taken by Trees, sÃ¥ nÃ¤r vi hÃ¶rde hennes version Ã¤lskade vi att det var en sÃ¥ ny version av lÃ¥ten. Och Superhumanoids-remixen var sÃ¥ ambient, lÃ¥ngsam och kraftfull vilket blev bra kontrast till vÃ¥r version.Â Vi Ã¤lskar bÃ¥da och visste direkt att de skulle komma med pÃ¥ EP:n. â€” And hereâ€™s an English transcription for all you international readers: Can you tell us a bit about how you met and when you formed the KateÂ Boy?Â -Â Kate came to Stockholm to write some songs and we all met up on her 2nd last day. We went out for drinks since we wanted to meet before our session the next day, and ended up going straight to the studio that night. It was instantaneous, we wrote Northern Lights that first night. We spent the next 2 days in the studio and knew weâ€™d all have to continue our collaboration someway, somehow. How did the songs on the EP come about? Do you have any set roles in theÂ songwriting process? -Â We donâ€™t really have any set roles since we all like to be part of every step. Despite our different musical backgrounds, when it comes to which instruments we play we are very alike. Itâ€™s rather the â€thinkingâ€ that can differ. We can each hear different ways to approach our songs and which way we want to direct them in, but as to writing the lyrics, the melody and producing the track we are all hands-on on almost every level. How would you describe your music? What inspires you to write songs and who are your influences? - We are very inspired by the electronic sounds from the 70â€²s and 80â€²s and how they would mix organic and electronic, almost robotic ingredients. Electronic music pioneers like Kraftwerk, Peter Gabriel and Jean-Michel Jarre are very important components of the KATE BOY inspiration box. Also a lot of inspiration comes from things other than music. Film is something we all share a big passion for. Thereâ€™s something about the concept that inspires us more maybe than specific sounds or words. That feeling when you enter a world and you want to stay there. We want the same feeling with our music. To be able to hear or know that itâ€™s us, just in the same way you instantly know that itâ€™s a David Lynch or Stanley Kubrick movie. Do you produce the songs on your own? How do you come up with whichÂ sounds to use?Â - Yes we produce our own songs. After spending so much time together in the studio, weâ€™ve ended up sculpting a common way of thinking when it comes to which sounds to use. Itâ€™s like chefs working in the same kitchen, exchanging experiences and tastes to create new recipes together. Eventually we found a particular recipe that â€tastedâ€ like us, if that makes any sense. What are your plans for the near future? Will there be concerts or a full-length album soon? - We will definitely be touring and releasing an album.Â We are working on both right now, planning which places to visit and also writing our album. As for the near future, weâ€™ve got videos and more single releases coming soon. Can you tell us about how you got signed to IAmSound? Were there otherÂ labels trying to sign you as well (if so, why did you choose IAmSound)? - When Northern Lights started spreading we got approached from labels. We respect and love the music on IAmSound and what they had done with their artists, which made the decision to release our EP through them an easy one. What do you think of the current electronic music? - ItÂ´s inspiring to see how electronic music has evolved its way into almost every genre and seems to continue reaching out.Â Maybe the big challenge is to give something back to electronic music, by using more real instruments.Â Thereâ€™s so many producers out there, and the computers are bombarded with new instruments and ways to evolve and produce music.Â ItÂ´s almost as if the music scene is charging up for the big boom of new hybrid genres of the future. ItÂ´s really the era of where everyone who wants has a shot to produce music. Are there any acts you look up to or would like to collaborate with? - There are so many artists who we want to work with, we love co-labs. But we wouldnâ€™t stop at musicians, weâ€™d also love to collaborate with people who do things other than making the song â€“ designers, illustrators, photographers and just random out of the box thinking people â€“ weâ€™d like to collaborate with them all. Were you surprised when your music started to spread on the internet? How important has internet and blogs been to you? - When we first put out the Northern Lights video we originally only shared it with our friends, the plan was to promote it later on but it took off on its own before we knew it. Itâ€™s so inspiring to see how easily you can reach listeners from all over the world. On the EP thereâ€™s also a couple of remixes, how did those come about? - Weâ€™re big fans of Taken by Trees, so when we heard her version, we loved that it was such a fresh take on the song. And the Superhumanoids remix was so ambient, slow and powerful which made a great contrast to our version. We loved them both on first listen and knew theyâ€™d be on the EP. â€” HÃ¤r kan du lyssna pÃ¥ EP:n via Spotify:

post.title: Music Monday â€“ The Acoustic Sessions: Volume One by Casting Crowns
post.summary:
Need something new to listen to this week? Casting Crowns just released their new album of acoustic music, and it is fabulous. I say this with all due deference to Mark Hall, but I feel that this is the album they couldnâ€™t do at the beginning of their recording career. His vocals have matured over the years and are very good on this record. Check it out. Youâ€™ll be glad you did. If you use Spotify, listen below.

post.title: Just like the Arnie. I'm back. Plus, Stephon LaMar
post.summary:
Yes, after nearly a year, I'm back. And this time I'm back for good. Well hopefully. At the moment I'm finding that I have lots of free time being awarded to me. As you can maybe tell seen as I'm posting this at 2am on a Monday morning. Anyway I'll tell for why I've decided to make a return... So tonight I was replying to a friend who had tweeted a very attractive picture of herself (@isobel_end for those wondering, top lass). And I mentioned a two syllable damn, and she didn't know what I meant. You know, the ones that go: DAYYUMMM. If you don't then just google it. So that's what I did to look for an example to show my friend. I didn't find one but I came across this guy: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DcJFdCmN98s But that's not the guy who made me blog again. No, no, no it's much more exciting. Anyway so I scroll down afterwards and see that three guys have done a cover. Now normally I'm a bit sceptical about these YouTube covers done by people who think they can sing. Well turns out these guys can actually sing: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VfbQ4gww7aI
I clicked on the guys link at the end of the video and I was impressed. He sings a good range of music. Here are some examples: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=trbsLgaZhW0&list=UUwqwOenuHdSHpd8u2Ht3J1A
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ThVmjGqgk9Y&list=UUwqwOenuHdSHpd8u2Ht3J1A
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fe9TUQSJFTE&list=UUwqwOenuHdSHpd8u2Ht3J1A
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vxyX9rjIlb8&list=UUwqwOenuHdSHpd8u2Ht3J1A
I just realised most of them are covers, but he does do his own stuff.
I love his voice it's really got that quality to it. There's a demand for this kind of singing I think. It's the stripped back, acoustic-ness of the songs that I like. Anyway, I really like this guy so I wanted to share him with the world. I really want him to do well because he should do. Check out his YouTube channel, Twitter, Facebook and all that. I'll be listening to him on my Spotify account and I'll share that on Twitter too. He also has an EP out. Check it. https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/lamoureux-ep/id474780707
Peace.
@WJMonde

post.title: MEOW! Presents: The Best Films of 2012!
post.summary: January 27th, 2013 MEOW! Well, this is about a month late. Let's get right to it. Here are the best films of 2012 in the order of their release dates! 21 Jump Street (March 16th, 2012)--I've got two words for you: exploding. chickens. If you were able to crack at least a smile at those words, then you are in for one of the funniest comedies to be madeÂ in quite some time. Bernie (April 27th, 2012)--What an impressive gem by Richard Linklater, with a truly underappreciated performance by Jack Black, also known as the Dragon Warrior. It's on Netflix instant right now, so if you have that, give it a go. ParaNorman (August 17th, 2012)--From the clever usage ofÂ horror-movie stereotypes as Norman's team, to theÂ WONDERFUL messages of acceptance and tolerance for children of all ages, this filmÂ isÂ among the best of the stop-motion animation genre. Hopefully this film finds more of an audience soon. The Perks of Being a Wallflower (September 21st, 2012)--This film has it all and more in spades:Â bittersweetÂ cinematography,Â a pitch-perfect ensembleÂ led by Logan Lerman, and an eye-openingÂ direction and script written by Stephen Chbosky, who also wrote the 1999Â novel of the same title. If you ever come across this film in your life, watch it, and I swear, you will feel infinite. Magic. Looper (September 28th, 2012)--With a brilliant imagination by Rian Johnson, and two outstanding performances from Joseph Gordon-Levitt (his best film to date) and Bruce Willis (YIPPIE KAY YAY!), thisÂ is aÂ fantastic film of the sci-fi genre. How this film got snubbed for a Best Original Screenplay nomination is beyond me. Cloud Atlas (October 26th, 2012)--One of the most underappreciated films of all-time, let alone decade, this is an amazing experiment of ambitious, imaginative filmmaking. You know you love a film so much when you listen to most of the score's compositions on Spotify. Skyfall (November 9th, 2012)--Coming from someone who has only seen Quantum of Solace out of the 22 Bond films created at the time (crucify me now if you must), I was extremely impressed with Bond #23. Under the excellentÂ direction ofÂ Sam Mendes,Â containing moments that will make you proud to be a moviegoer, Skyfall is a terrificÂ tribute to a 50-year-oldÂ film icon. Rise of the Guardians (November 23rd, 2012)--I will never walk in as a skeptic to a Dreamworks film ever again. This is a roller coaster ride of breathtaking visual imagination, while alsoÂ being a poignant tribute to the child in all of us.Â And choose caution: if you are aÂ 90's kid, and/or areÂ able to let the moments of your ownÂ childhood flow right into your memory, you could very wellÂ tear up during the end credits. Bring a friend so that he/she can hug you. Your welcome. Silver Linings Playbook (November 23rd, 2012)--Who knew that a film about two people with mental illnesses falling in love with each other can be fresh, wonderful, and genuinely romantic? David O. Russell scoresÂ another touchdownÂ by writing and directing an involving (albeit predictable) romantic comedy, withÂ byÂ a fantastic ensemble led by Bradley Cooper andÂ Jennifer Lawrence. And now we cue my love letterÂ to the best film of 2012.... Wreck-It Ralph (November 2nd, 2012)--Even though the rest of the films on this list have given me hope for the future of cinema (no pun intended when it comes to LOOPER), no other film in 2012Â had made me happier to be who I am todayÂ than Wreck-It Ralph. Exploding with brilliance and creativity in nearly every frame, with an unapologetic heart of happiness and melancholy, I now understand how people felt back in 1939 when they saw The Wizard of Oz for the first time (ironically, there's a reference to that film, and it will blind-side you with its genius). It's as good as The Hunchback of Notre Dame when it comes to being the best thing Disney has ever produced, and it's up there with some of the best (animated) films that I've ever seen. I can't think of anything bad to say about it. It's truly a perfect film. Honorable Mentions: Chronicle, Jeff, Who Lives at Home, The Hunger Games, The Pirates: Band of Misfits, Moonrise Kingdom, Prometheus, Ted, Hope Springs Until next time, MEOW!
