post.title: Nokia intros Music+ subscription service with unlimited downloads, web listening
post.summary: Most of the bigger streaming music services have both a free tier for casual listeners and a paid level for truly committed music fans. Nokia doesn't want to be the exception to the rule. It's launching Nokia Music+, a paid version of its existing platform. Paying â‚¬4 per month ($4 in the US) gives perks that you'd normally expect from a more expensive alternative like Spotify or Slacker's premium tier: the upgrade ratchets up the audio quality, adds lyrics, allows unlimited skips in Mix Radio and enables as many downloads for offline play as the phone can hold. Aren't you suddenly glad that you picked up a 32GB Lumia 920? Not that you'll always need it to tune in -- Music+ adds web streaming for anything with a suitably capable browser. Nokia hasn't said just which countries beyond the US will get the more advanced service, but it should make a formal debut within the next few weeks. Filed under: Cellphones, Portable Audio/Video, Internet, Mobile, Nokia Comments Source: Conversations by Nokia Source: http://feeds.engadget.com/~r/weblogsinc/engadget/~3/WrqO_Mycdik/ drew peterson untouchable herman cain south carolina palmetto rob lowe sanctum the notebook duke basketball

post.title: Junior Review
post.summary: Greetings and welcome to my blog. My name is Lyna Luong and I am a visual artist at the Boston Arts Academy. I am currently a Junior at BAA and this post will be about my work this year. Starting off with my strongest skills, one of my strongest skills is to take time and work on a piece of work when I am motivated. I can do anything when I have the motivations. I am someone who needs something to push me when it comes to visual arts work. I do well when I go out and find things that are inspirational instead of receiving an idea and go and work on an art piece myself. This is not the same for other works. Itâ€™s just visual arts that I have to put more efforts in to find something inspirational to work off of. Another skill I have is that I tend to go super dark with whatever material I work with. Somehow, going dark makes me feel better than work lightly then go dark afterwards. Itâ€™s a skill because that is what I like and want to do. My art pieces reflects who I am, what I used to make the work, and how I use them. Nothing can stop me from doing what I want and how I want to do something because I have the ability and right to chose what I want to do and show off. If there is something that I want to improve, I would want to be better at finding inspirational ideas and the right motivations to create the content of my artworks. This is because I've been making art pieces that have other peopleâ€™s ideas in it and I donâ€™t want anyoneâ€™s help. However, if I donâ€™t get the help, I wouldn't know where to go. I need to find better confidence in my art pieces because I donâ€™t want anyoneâ€™s influences in my work. Another thing is that I am not a fan of critiques because I donâ€™t like them and I plan to keep them out of my way no matter what. Iâ€™ll accept them, but I may or may not consider them. Maybe that is something else I need to get better at. It might benefit me, but then sometime I would have questions like, â€œIf I take your ideas and critiques, would the work still be about me, or YOU?â€ Since sophomore year until now, I think there is a huge gap between the â€œsophomore meâ€ and the â€œjunior meâ€. Since the beginning of my junior year, I've been slowly moving away from being an art student to becoming an artist. I've been making progress, because the art pieces that I worked on during my junior year has my own ideas and own creativity in them. Instead of creating an art piece entirely off of the teacherâ€™s ideas, I also put my ideas in that piece as well to make it my work. . The process that I take to be make art work is very long and hard. First of all, if I want to start an artwork, I have to make sure that I am finished with my other commitments because that way I can devote myself in my artwork. Secondly, after I give myself time, I have find something that would be inspiring and motivating to work. This step is important for me because if I donâ€™t find something that would catch my interest, I may end up stopping in the middle of the process, and the art piece may also end up not finished. The third step of my process is to find a place where I can work, where it is quite, where no one can reach me or bother me, and a place where the atmosphere will make me work continuously. This is another important step because if I work in a place with other people, including family members and friends, it would be really annoying because I would not be able to focus on my work, and Iâ€™ll end up with nothing finished. Sometimes my room is the best working place because sometimes it would be quiet and no one could get in touch with me. When I say â€œno oneâ€ can get in touch with me, that means I would turn off my phone, get away where no one will know where I am (except my mother), and do my work. After finding â€œthe placeâ€ to work, I have to settle into the place I choose to work at. This is when I use my iPod to go onto Pandora, a radio site, or Spotify and put on a station to play. Music helps a lot with the process because it enhances my mood to work sometimes. Itâ€™s rare, but sometimes listening to music will give me ideas of what to do. After finding music, I would go and get something that is easy to nibble on because snacks prevents hunger from taking over my mind when focusing on my work. After everything I need is around, I would start working. There are days that I get a lot of work done and some days I donâ€™t. Thatâ€™s mostly because it all depends on my mood, the atmosphere around me, inspirations, and motivations. During the Fall of my Junior year, I've been trying to work bigger in my visual arts work. For example, for my American Gothic inspired work, I thought I would end up working with a small base that everyone had to start off with, but when I was finished with my work I found out that I had worked with a bigger board than I had planned. Trying to work bigger is not important for me, but since teachers say working bigger is good, I would try to do my best to so and experiment with it. For some unexplained reason, I like to work with small things. For example, drawing small figures, building small crafts, and doing small projects. Working big has been the biggest risk I've done in visual arts and I learned that working big could result in bigger pride. I was proud of myself when looking at My Invincible Flower, the American Gothic inspired work, because itâ€™s probably my biggest suitable accomplishment ever. For this semester, I've been in an art history class, and it was okay. I learned about arts in different time periods, in different styles, by different artists, and by different techniques. From art history, the only connections I've made in that class was when we were learning about the Baroque and the Romanticism time periods. This was because the Baroque had so many paintings with drama and movements, and when I was looking at them I felt something that can't be explained. I am very strict when picking an art piece to like and admire because I donâ€™t judge based on the techniques, the values, or other things that the school is teaching the visual students. Instead, I pick art pieces that makes a good impression on me when I first look at it. To be honest, thereâ€™s hasn't been one piece of artwork that I've seen that I liked, or admired. During art history class, some of the works made a little impression on me even though it wasn't enough to the point where I liked it. I donâ€™t know how to explain it, but the â€œThe Raft of Medusaâ€ by Gericault from the Romanticism period made me think of innocence people. The reason why I felt that way was because the story behind that painting is that there was a ship named Medusa, and on that ship were at least one-hundred people. Medusa was wrecked at one point and the people who were on the Medusa built a raft to survive on until someone saves them. When the raft was spotted, only fifteen people survived. The story was touching and that was pretty much the part that made a deep impression on me. It was like the Titanic. I guess for me, a fascinating art piece will need to have a touching story, a good first impression from the art work, and also the most important thing is that the artist of the work will have to fit my â€œideal artistâ€ because the artistâ€™s impression on me is also important. Below are some of the art works I've worked on this Year. (2012-2013) PSY'S SCREAMING HORSE Art Gallery AMERICAN GOTHIC INSPIRED Â ANGEL Â MY INVINCIBLE FLOWER Â PAK BOM UNNI SARANGHAEYO Â AMERICAN GOTHIC Â BAROQUE STYLE Â AMERICAN GOTHIC by LYNA

post.title: Musikmandag #58 - vind koncertbilletter til FROST
post.summary: Midt i vintermÃ¸rket knitrer et lille kÃ¸ligt musikalsk lys, som hedder FROST Festival. Det kribler gevaldigt i min festivaltrang og hungrende koncertlyst, som slet ikke kan vente til sommer! Den skÃ¸nne ide med FROST er bl.a. at fÃ¥ musikken og omgivelserne til at gÃ¥ op i en hÃ¸jere endhed, ved fx at udvÃ¦lge atypiske locations til et udvalg af koncerterne - heriblandt Zoologisk Museum, skÃ¸jtebanen ved ToftegÃ¥rds Plads, pÃ¥ Designmuseet og i en dieselkÃ¦lder i Sydhavnen. Jeg har vÃ¦ret sÃ¥ heldig, at fÃ¥ to billetter til en udvalgt koncert pÃ¥ dette Ã¥rs FROST Festival - som I kan lÃ¦se mere om lÃ¦ngere nede i dagens indlÃ¦g. FROST starter med en Ã¥bningskoncert d.8. februar og afvikles derefter frem til d. 2. marts. En del af arrangementerne er desvÃ¦rre allerede udsolgt, men her er et par af dem jeg kan anbefale; FOXYGENÂ er en indierock duo fra LA, og Ã©t af de bands som et flertal af musikmedier og blogs udnÃ¦vner til et stort gennembrud i Ã¥r - og ja, de er da ogsÃ¥ med pÃ¥ min listeÂ over bands jeg holder Ã¸je med i 2013. Lyden er retro-prÃ¦get og smÃ¥psykadelisk pÃ¥ en charmerende, ung og naiv facon. Deres lyd er en alsidig audiokollage, en aggressiv kombination af Nick Cave og The Brian Jonestown Massacre med melodiske passager i bedste David Lynch-soundtrack-stil. Jeg er, kort sagt, fuldstÃ¦ndig pjattet med dem! Foxygen spiller pÃ¥ Bremen d. 9 februar kl.23. Koncerten er gratis. FROST ON ICEÂ afholdes som et vaskeÃ¦gte vinter-rollerdisco pÃ¥ skÃ¸jtebanen ved ToftegÃ¥rds Plads, og akkompagneres af et DJ-set med danske WhoMadeWho. Bandet har tradition for alternative og ofte lidt skÃ¦ve konstellationer nÃ¥r det kommer til bÃ¥de koncerter og DJ-sets. I beskrivelsen af Frost On Ice stÃ¥r der blandt andet at de vil mixe live-elementer med medbragte tracks. Jeg glÃ¦der mig! Frost On Ice er d. 10 februar kl.17. Arrangementet er gratis. JACOB BELLENS + SCHULTZ AND FOREVER er desvÃ¦rre blevet udsolgt i mellemtiden, men jeg synes stadig at det er vÃ¦rd at nÃ¦vne de to dygtige, danske herrer som pt. er EP- og albumaktuelle. Jacob Bellens, som man kender fra I Got You On Tape, har netop udgivet soloalbummet 'The Daisy Age' der virkelig er melankolsk, stilfÃ¦rdigt og indimellem lÃ¦ngselsfuldt. Jacobs smukke og stÃ¸vede stemme folder sig fornemt ud og lyder alt andet end dansk - og det er isÃ¦r sangene 'Only For The Lonely' og 'Eight Arms To Hold You' der fremtrÃ¦der som de stÃ¦rke hÃ¸jdepunkter pÃ¥ albummet, der kan findes her. Schultz & Forever er kunstnernavnet som dÃ¦kker over den kun 18-Ã¥rige Jonathan Schultz. Hans stemme er helt unik, og han har et virkelig sÃ¦rligt talent for nÃ¦rvÃ¦r og indlevelse med sin musik, der vidst bedst kan beskrives som en blanding af folk og bedroom indie, i dÃ©t lydhjÃ¸rne der minder mig mest om The Tallest Man On Earth. Hans nyeste EP 'Celine' er ikke pÃ¥ Spotify endnu, men kan streames hos Soundvenue. Jacob Bellens og Schultz & Forever spiller pÃ¥ Copenhagen Piano d. 20 februar kl.20. Koncerten er udsolgt. NILS FRAHM + MIKAEL SIMPSON finder sted pÃ¥ Lousiana, hvor tyske Nils Frahm fremfÃ¸rer sine smukke og dragende klaverkompositioner med fantastiske Mikael Simpson som special guest. Nils Frahm gÃ¥r nok under den kategori man vil beskrive som klassisk kompositionsmusik, ikke en genre jeg normalt beskÃ¦ftiger mig med, men hans lydlandskab er sÃ¥ simpelt, poetisk og melodisk at det faktisk er svÃ¦rt ikke at kunne lide det.Â Hans nyeste abum 'Screws' har med tryllebindende effekt udgjort soundtrack til mange af mine vintersÃ¸ndage. Og Mikael Simpson - behÃ¸ver han egentlig en yderligere prÃ¦sentation? Jeg har fulgt ham siden han udgav 'OS2 + Lidt Ro' i 2002 hvor jeg startede pÃ¥ gymnasiet, og forelskede mig i hans tekster og kombinationen af elektroniske beats og hans blÃ¸de vokal. Jeg har set ham live sÃ¥ mange gange, at jeg ikke har tal pÃ¥ det - og han har aldrig skuffet! Hvis du ikke er sÃ¥ bekendt med Mikaels bagkatalog, er der netop udgivet en kompilation med hans bedste sange. Find den her. Nils Frahm og Mikael Simpson spiller pÃ¥ Lousiana d. 27. februar kl. 20. Koncerten koster 175 kroner. MARIAM THE BELIEVER kommer fra Sverige, og er ogsÃ¥ medÂ pÃ¥ min listeÂ over bands jeg holder Ã¸je med i 2013. Hendes stemme er rÃ¥ og dyb og hun har en vis eksperimenterende og utÃ¦mmet mystik over sin lyd, som minder om Jenny Wilson eller Taken By TreesÂ i bedste, svenske artpop-stil. Mariam The Believer spiller i KoncertkirkenÂ d. 28. februar kl.20. Koncerten koster 130 kroner. Men! Jeg udlodder to billetter til denne koncert, sÃ¥ hvisÂ du vil vÃ¦re med i lodtrÃ¦kningen skal du blot skriveÂ en kommentar med dit navn og din mailadresse herunder :) Jeg trÃ¦kker lod om en uge. Hver lÃ¸rdag under FROST inviteres der desuden til en gratis natkoncert pÃ¥ Bremen - som udover Foxygen - stÃ¥r pÃ¥ blandt andet Lars and The Hands Of Light og Egyptian Hiphop.Â Se hele programmet herÂ eller fÃ¸lg med pÃ¥ Facebook og Twitter lÃ¸bende under tagget #FROST13 :) Sangene fra mine musikmandage, som er tilgÃ¦ngelige pÃ¥ Spotify, kan findes pÃ¥Â en playliste, her. Rigtig glÃ¦delig musikmandag!

post.title: The Enterprise Cool Kids
post.summary:
No, this isnâ€™t a guest column by Aaron Levie. Though he and his startup Box, the poster child of the â€œsexy enterprise,â€ are definitely included in the bunch. â€œYou should definitely kick Aaron off the list. Just to mess with him,â€ Zendesk founder Mikkel Svane commented when he heard what we were writing. With VCs voting with their feet and eschewing consumer startups this play period, weâ€™re seeing a major shift of sentiment and momentum to enterprise startups. Perhaps the most major in a while, definitely as far as we can remember. Venture money that a year ago was going into consumer deals is now flowing into enterprise, as the Series A crunch and reticence about Facebookâ€™s lackluster IPO has dampened investor enthusiasmÂ for photosharing apps and their ilk. In contrast to Facebook, a series of stellar enterprise IPOs likeÂ Palo Alto Networks, Splunk and (perhaps the original enterprise cool kid) Workday have fired the collective entrepreneurialÂ imagination. â€œWe see entrepreneurs come in every other day telling us how theyâ€™re going to reinvent Splunk,â€ Sequoiaâ€™s Aaref Hilaly tells me. â€œThe successful enterprise IPOs serve as beacons for the companies that come after them.â€ Although the VC profits baseline has traditionally come from enterprise deals, they certainly werenâ€™t media darlings. Consumer startups, despite their high beta and tendency to be outliers, were the bell of the mainstream tech blog ball. â€œConsumer technology tends to create fewer winners. Its easier to keep track of what a Facebook or a Twitter may be doing than myriad enterprise software vendors,â€ NetSuite CEO Zach Nelson notes. â€œ[There it] may take decades to decide the actual winners.â€ But the hype is changing. Conversations about â€œthe next Instagramâ€ at Coupa, The Creamery or on Caltrain have been replaced with staid assessments about the future of Big Data, storage and the cloud. The mobile, social, local gold rush of 2011 has been put on pause, at least as far as consumer Internet is concerned. VCs areÂ staffing up with enterprise experts to handle the sharp shift in focus. Weâ€™ve even heard someone was working on something described only as, â€œa Path for enterprise.â€
While the phenomenon is recent enough that the exact flow of investment dollars from consumer to enterprise has yet to be captured in a study, the data points are beginning to pop up. For example 2012 was theÂ first year in First Round Capitalâ€™s history in which consumer companies were less than 50 percent of investment dollars, according to a report it published this week. Expect to see many more of these sorts of reports. And more enterprise coverage on TechCrunch. Enterprise startups are finally the cool kids. NÃ©e, sexy. â€œI would say the market is schizophrenic,â€ says Marc Andreessen, on why Workday > Facebook might not mean the end of investor interest in social. â€œRight now we are in an era where the market wants enterprise companies. I am just saying, â€˜Wait a year, that will flip again; wait another year after that, that will flip again.â€™â€ For now itâ€™s enterpriseâ€™s time to shine. Due to the ubiquity of mobile computing, the cloud and the Bring Your Own Device movement, the lines are blurring between enterprise startups and consumer startups.Â Is Google Apps an enterprise product? Is Dropbox? Is Evernote?Â With an increasing proliferation of these sorts of enterprisumer startups, weâ€™re a far cry from the IBM SAGE era, where the only computing customers were literally big businesses. In the past everything was top down. Large corporations and the government spent a lot of money on R&D, and technologies developed in that R&D like the mainframe/computer, the color TV and even the Internet would trickle down from large institutions to the mainstream user. Once these products hit the mainstream, the gravitational pull of the mainstream and its purchasing power slowly changed the adoption cycle from top down to bottom up. â€œConsumers can make buying decisions much more quickly than businesses can,â€ Andreessen points, â€œbecause for the consumer, they either like it or they donâ€™t, whereas businesses have to go through these long and involved processes.â€ He maintains that the reason the enterprise wasnâ€™t particularly appealing for many entrepreneurs between 2000-2008 was that consumer software was the only software that anybody could adopt.â€ This is no longer the case, as the enterprise world evolves from a sales-driven to a product-driven approach.
Â â€œThe user is now the buyer, and the center of gravity is no longer in IT, itâ€™s actually in the line of business themselves,â€ says Christian Gheorghe,Â CEO of mobile first metrics management startupÂ Tidemark, outlining the factors in that evolution. â€œThe cloud is not just a cost-based improvement, but a new computational platform. And mobile is surpassing the desktop.â€ â€œThe demand for â€˜consumer-gradeâ€™ enterprise technologies â€” from theÂ standpointÂ of having strong UX, being mobile, and platform agnostic â€” is anÂ irreversibleÂ trend,â€ says Levie. â€œTo the point that hard-to-use enterprise software will soon become more surprising than well-designed enterprise software (give it a few years).â€ â€œToday all the consumerized enterprise stuff is as easily usable by the small business as it is by the large business,â€ Andreessen explains. â€œIn fact, itâ€™s probably more easily usable by the small business than it is by the large business, because with a small business, itâ€™s like you can just use it. You donâ€™t have to go through a long process, you donâ€™t have to have a lot of meetings, you donâ€™t have to have committees, you donâ€™t have to have all this stuff. You can just start picking up and using it.â€ Because of this confluence of elements, an enterprise startupâ€™s â€œland and expandâ€ strategy has become more complex than having a huge sales force or wining and dining the CIO. It actually boils down to making a product that people want to use, as consumers are already using cloud products, and fall back on them when their older enterprise solutions fail. â€œThe Exchange Server is down? No problem, Iâ€™ll use Gmail. Email policy doesnâ€™t allow an attachment over 2 GB. No problem, Iâ€™ll use YouSendIt, Dropbox or Box,â€ Ron MillerÂ succinctly puts it.Â Boxâ€™s early business customers were CIOs who called into the company with concerns about security,Â irate that their employees were using the platform to covertly share files. Those calls eventually turned into deals. In fact, one could argue that consumer startup Dropbox was the best thing to ever happened to Box, familiarizing the layman with cloud file sharing. Box then innovated on the use case, by offering increased security and controls to appease CIOs and enterprise execs. â€œThe first generation of this new enterprise wave was replacement technologies at lower prices (like Salesforce and SolarWinds),â€ says Asana co-founder Justin Rosenstein, â€œbut the new wave is technologies that compete by being better products. The *new* inefficiency to compete against isnâ€™t just total cost of operations (through SaaS) or cost â€“ itâ€™s beating them with a better product.â€ Because adoption is getting easier and other related factors, weâ€™re seeing an onslaught of entrepreneurs building products for businesses that employees actually can use or want to use. Weâ€™re even seeing the emergence of companies like Okta, which are enterprise only, but still display the ease of a consumer startup. Not only is the number of companies that are taking their design cues from the consumer Internet increasing, it is rapidly becoming the norm.
â€œâ€˜Enterprise sexinessâ€™ has come from the increasing awareness that the new breed of vendors have gotten the consumerization thing right (especially with UI and mobile), and that the business models are known to be sustainable and viable,â€ says Workday co-founder Aneel Bhusri. â€œIndeed, in the case of companies like Asana and Cloudera, some of the founders themselves came from the consumer Internet.â€ That consumer background is helping the companies below get a lot more notice from VCs to consumers to the media because they know how to pitch themselves â€” and yes many of them have pretty cool products, specifically targeting millennials just getting situated in the workforce. PeopleSoft, Aolâ€™s HRM software, is as atrocious to use as its name sounds â€” Iâ€™d much rather be using Workday. While this list is by no means comprehensive (there are a ton of cool enterprise startups, and most people are vehementÂ favorites), here are just a few of the new guard that are fast becoming household names â€” through their focus on intuitiveness and design, awareness of mobile and fresh approaches to decades-old problems.Â â€The existing enterprise players are building software people tolerate,â€ as Rosenstein concisely puts it. â€œThe future players are building software people love.â€ Okta Okta is a single sign-on service for companies â€” â€œFacebook Connectâ€ for the enterprise. As a user, you can log in to your companyâ€™s admin page and access both private data hosted on your companyâ€™s server (intranet) and data from cloud products like Box, Salesforce and Google Apps. Administrators can easily manage the credentials across various applications and devices. Competitors: Salesforce has just launched Salesforce Identity to compete directly with Okta. Secret sauce:Â Okta is compatible with every web app you can think of. The startup has raised $52.5 million inÂ funding from Greylock Partners, Khosla Ventures, Andreessen Horowitz, FLOODGATE and Sequoia. Cloudera Cloudera is the solution de jourÂ for managing big data in a company, offering software, services and support for databases. When a user needs to analyze raw data to find a trend or to see if they can find valuable answers in unused data, Cloudera (built on top of Hadoop) allows them to complete more efficient queries. Competitors: MapRÂ and Hortonworks, but they are much smaller. For big companies, they can ask for custom solutions from IBM, but itâ€™s a lot more expensive. Secret sauce:Â Timing and it handles everything (software, development, supportâ€¦). Cloudera has big funding as well, having raised $141 million fromÂ Greylock, Accel, Meritech Capital Partners, In-Q-Tel and others. Box The original â€œsexyâ€ enterprise startup, BoxÂ allows you to store, manage and collaborate on your documents in the cloud. Founded back in 2006 (before Dropbox!), the company is helmed by the colorful Aaron Levie. Like Okta, Boxâ€™s main advantage is that it integrates well with many enterprise apps and offers security in addition to collaboration functionality. Interoperability is crucial: Users can find their files uploaded to Box in their favorite CRM apps, etc. Competitors: Microsoft SharePoint, consumer products, Dropbox, Google Driveâ€¦ Secret sauce: It was there first! Box effectively competes by constantly iterating on its product, focusing on enterprise even when Dropbox caught on, and good partnerships. Box has thus far raised $284 million from Draper Fisher Jurvetson, Scale Venture Partners,Â Andreessen Horowitz and others. GitHub Developers need a place to track and share their code changes, and GitHub, with social coding features that make it really easy for open source projects, is the repository of choice. GitHub is so popular that its version control technology, Git, is replacing SVN based on merit. GitHub offers premium subscriptions and self-hosted versions, and many companies and startups have switched to private GitHub repositories, some very early (Spotify). Competitors: Google Code for the social coding aspect, self-hosted repositories on an Intranet. Secret sauce: Git. Git is such an ace technology that developers couldnâ€™t resist adopting it, and GitHub is *the* best way to use Git. The runner up in the Bootstrapped Startup category at the 2011 Crunchies, GitHub eventually relented and took $100 million in Series A funding from Andreessen Horowitz last year. Zendesk Zendesk is user-friendly help desk software that allows companies to handle support requests in bulk. Zendesk is IPO-bound and, like enterprise pal Workday, might be another point of light in a series of lackluster tech IPOs. Competitors:Â Tons of companies are building desk software, and there are many open source apps for small and medium companies. Desk.com (formerly Assistly, acquired by Salesforce) and Tender Support are quite popular, but Tender Support doesnâ€™t have the same breadth of resources as Zendesk. Secret sauce:Â Zendesk was the first modern help desk, but Desk.com is gaining a lot of traction with Salesforce behind it. The company has plenty of money in the bank, having raised $85.5 million from Charles River Ventures, Benchmark Capital, Matrix Partners, Redpoint Ventures, Index Ventures, GGV Capital, Goldman Sachs and Silicon Valley Bank. Asana Taking the lessons they learned from an early stint at Facebook, Asana co-founders Dustin Moskovitz and Justin Rosenstein have built a beautiful and streamlined collaboration tool with a focus on to-do lists. The interface is flexible and easy to understand. In Asana, everything is a to-do item. The platformÂ doesnâ€™t try to do it all, but its design is very very intuitive, adhering humbly to its core goal ofÂ easing communications within a team. Competitors: Basecamp from 37signals, Do.com from Salesforce, and other communication tools that may make it useless (think Yammer) and many small alternatives (Producteev, Flow, etc.). For all these companies, the closest competitor might be basic emails. Secret sauce:Â The Asana product is relatively easy to use, and this is important for a latecomer to the collaboration software space. Pricing is friendly, too. For small companies, many of which have yet to switch to a collaboration tool, you can basically use it for free. Asana has raised over 38.2 million fromÂ Peter Thiel,Â Founders FundÂ BenchmarkÂ Capital,Â Andreessen Horowitz and angels like Ron Conway and Adam Dâ€™Angelo. GoodData GoodData is a less expensive data-analytics solution for large companies. Companies can integrate GoodDataâ€™s platform into their own cloud-based SaaS products (i.e. Salesforce, Zendesk) and then access operational dashboards, data warehousing and advanced data reporting. Competitors:Â IBM, SAP and Oracle. Secret sauce:Â Cheaper than competitors, GoodData integrates easily with Zendesk and Salesforce to track, aggregate and analyze data. Its simplicity and â€œout of the boxâ€ integrations make it ideal for small and medium enterprises. GoodData has $53.5 million in funding fromÂ Andreessen Horowitz,Â General Catalyst Partners,Â Tim Oâ€™Reilly and others. Atlassian â€œThe coolest thing to come out of Australia,â€ according to Accelâ€™s Ping Lee, Atlassian is low-cost project management software. It provides a series of enterprise web apps: Jira is a project-tracking tool focused on software development; Confluence is a more traditional collaboration and communication tool; and developers use many of its other smaller product offerings in their workflows. Finally, Atlassian acquired HipChat, a hip chat app. Competitors: Open source project management solutions and native apps compete with Jira. Confluence competes with Basecamp, Yammer, etc. HipChat competes with Campfire from 37signals. Secret sauce: Founded in 2002, Atlassian is not a kid anymore. Over the years, it has proved to be a reliable web app developer. The company has thus far raised $60 million in Series A solely from Accel Partners. Nimble Storage Nimble Storage is an online storage service for developers. It has found a way to provide a large storage capacity with 5x the performance and 5x the capacity as existing products from EMC and NetApp. Nimble Storage has a unique caching system based on the flash storage commonly found in PCs and mobile phones. The result is a great speed increase, comparable to putting an SSD drive in your old computer. That technology is patented for online data storage. Competitors: EMC, NetApp, Amazon S3 and other online storage solutions. Secret sauce: Improving read/write speeds is a great challenge for hosting solutions these days, and Nimble is faster than its competitors, yet costs the same. It has received $81.7 million in funding from Sequoia Capital, Accel Partners, Lightspeed Venture Partners and others. MobileIron MobileIron is a device management tool for system admins. Now that the BYOD trend is taking over businesses, admins have to find new ways to handle security settings and push mobile apps to employees â€” all of this across multiple phones, tablets and operating systems. MobileIron provides a single platform to manage all devices even though most of them are personal devices that employees bring to the workplace. Competitors: In-house solutions and restrictions, checking security settings one phone at a time or choosing not to care about security. Secret sauce: MobileIron makes it much easier for system admins to handle custom phone settings. If you convert one system admin, the entire company will switch to MobileIron. Since 2007, it has raised $96.8 million from Sequoia Capital, Storm Ventures and Norwest Venture Partners.
â€œThey are all basically new companies,â€ says Andreessen, who agreed with many of the â€œCool Kidsâ€ choices. â€œI think who is not on that list are all the existing companies that sell business software.â€ And being younger, more agile companies automatically makes them much more interesting. For anyone whoâ€™s read my post about SAP buying SuccessFactors, and misunderstood it, itâ€™s not SuccessFactors that was boring (itâ€™s not at all) but SAP â€” whose stock performance is positively reflecting its acquisitions of hipper players like SuccessFactors â€” itself. â€œThe joke about SAP has always been, itâ€™s making 50s German manufacturing methodology, implemented in 1960s software technology, delivered to 1970-style manufacturing organizations,â€ says Andreessen. â€œThe incumbency â€” they are still the lingering hangover from the dot-com crash.â€ â€œWe all secretly fear making the same mistakes as previous-generation enterprise software companies â€” bloating our products and building out costly sales operations,â€ says Zendeskâ€™s Svane. â€œThe new enterprise software companies that avoid these traps will be tomorrowâ€™s winners.â€ So I was wrong, at least on a macro level: Perhaps there is no more compelling story in technology today than the David versus Goliath tale of enterprise upheaval. â€œToday is the most exciting time in enterprise technology historyâ€¦â€ SuccessFactors CEO himself Lars Dalgaard shares, â€œand we get to have no excuses for building a delicious user experience for everything we launch. Our benchmark is more delicious looking than Apple, simpler than Twitter.â€
And investors, public and private, increasingly agree: Being that weâ€™re in a consumer rut, am I going to be writing about the enterprise for the next two years? The advantage of the consumer businesses is they tend to be much broader-based with a much larger number of customers and relatively faster adoption patterns. The advantage of the enterprise companies is that they have revenue numbers off the bat if theyâ€™re good, and thus they are not as subject to consumer trends, fads or behavior, which is why investors, having raised less money to invest in 2013 in the first place, are being cautious. â€œFolks have realized that businesses buy close to $300 billion worth of software ($285 billion according to Gartner in 2012),â€ says Rosenstein, â€œand that companies who exhibit those attributes have the potential to build *very* large businesses. This is compounded by the opportunity to grow very quickly, since the economics of scaling a software business have been forever changed by things like Amazon on the backend, and self-service sales on the frontend.â€ â€œThe businesses are good, which is nice,â€ Andreessen adds, â€œand then I think itâ€™s also sector rotation. We talk to a lot of the big hedge funds, mutual funds. Itâ€™s really funny. We are talking about big hedge funds, mutual funds â€” about six months ago they all started saying, well, you know, we really think there is going to be a rotation from consumer and enterprise and we are going to really get ahead of that. And I am like, yeah, you and 10 other guys in the last two weeks have told me the same thing. Itâ€™s like, good job, like you are way out ahead on the leading edge on this.â€ You have to give credit to the foresight of the Levies, Bhusris, Svanes of the world who took a bet on enterprise when it wasnâ€™t the new girl in school. And, especially, the Ellisons and Benioffs for building the school. In fact, there is a salacious rumor making the rounds that Levie actually has a picture of Ellison as his iPhone home screen. â€œNo comment,â€ he says. As DFJ partner Andreas Stavropoulos brings up, â€œInterestingly, enterprise companies like Box that are gaining traction now were started in 2004-2007 when it wasnâ€™t cool to be enterprise-focused. This shows some of the best innovations happen when most of the market is looking the other way.â€ â€œMy running joke has been, itâ€™s like little kids,â€ says Andreessen. â€œLike everybody out of the consumer pool, everybody into the enterprise pool. So everybody out of the wading pool, everybody into the hot tub.â€ And right now the enterprise is a pretty hot hot tub. Additional reporting by Romain Dillet, Alex Williams and Leena Rao. Images by Bryce Durbin.
Filed under: The Leader Tagged: Technology

post.title: The Enterprise Cool Kids
post.summary:
No, this isnâ€™t a guest column by Aaron Levie. Though he and his startup Box, the poster child of the â€œsexy enterprise,â€ are definitely included in the bunch. â€œYou should definitely kick Aaron off the list. Just to mess with him,â€ Zendesk founder Mikkel Svane commented when he heard what we were writing. With VCs voting with their feet and eschewing consumer startups this play period, weâ€™re seeing a major shift of sentiment and momentum to enterprise startups. Perhaps the most major in a while, definitely as far as we can remember. Venture money that a year ago was going into consumer deals is now flowing into enterprise, as the Series A crunch and reticence about Facebookâ€™s lackluster IPO has dampened investor enthusiasmÂ for photosharing apps and their ilk. In contrast to Facebook, a series of stellar enterprise IPOs likeÂ Palo Alto Networks, Splunk and (perhaps the original enterprise cool kid) Workday have fired the collective entrepreneurialÂ imagination. â€œWe see entrepreneurs come in every other day telling us how theyâ€™re going to reinvent Splunk,â€ Sequoiaâ€™s Aaref Hilaly tells me. â€œThe successful enterprise IPOs serve as beacons for the companies that come after them.â€ Although the VC profits baseline has traditionally come from enterprise deals, they certainly werenâ€™t media darlings. Consumer startups, despite their high beta and tendency to be outliers, were the bell of the mainstream tech blog ball. â€œConsumer technology tends to create fewer winners. Its easier to keep track of what a Facebook or a Twitter may be doing than myriad enterprise software vendors,â€ NetSuite CEO Zach Nelson notes. â€œ[There it] may take decades to decide the actual winners.â€ But the hype is changing. Conversations about â€œthe next Instagramâ€ at Coupa, The Creamery or on Caltrain have been replaced with staid assessments about the future of Big Data, storage and the cloud. The mobile, social, local gold rush of 2011 has been put on pause, at least as far as consumer Internet is concerned. VCs areÂ staffing up with enterprise experts to handle the sharp shift in focus. Weâ€™ve even heard someone was working on something described only as, â€œa Path for enterprise.â€
While the phenomenon is recent enough that the exact flow of investment dollars from consumer to enterprise has yet to be captured in a study, the data points are beginning to pop up. For example 2012 was theÂ first year in First Round Capitalâ€™s history in which consumer companies were less than 50 percent of investment dollars, according to a report it published this week. Expect to see many more of these sorts of reports. And more enterprise coverage on TechCrunch. Enterprise startups are finally the cool kids. NÃ©e, sexy. â€œI would say the market is schizophrenic,â€ says Marc Andreessen, on why Workday > Facebook might not mean the end of investor interest in social. â€œRight now we are in an era where the market wants enterprise companies. I am just saying, â€˜Wait a year, that will flip again; wait another year after that, that will flip again.â€™â€ For now itâ€™s enterpriseâ€™s time to shine. Due to the ubiquity of mobile computing, the cloud and the Bring Your Own Device movement, the lines are blurring between enterprise startups and consumer startups.Â Is Google Apps an enterprise product? Is Dropbox? Is Evernote?Â With an increasing proliferation of these sorts of enterprisumer startups, weâ€™re a far cry from the IBM SAGE era, where the only computing customers were literally big businesses. In the past everything was top down. Large corporations and the government spent a lot of money on R&D, and technologies developed in that R&D like the mainframe/computer, the color TV and even the Internet would trickle down from large institutions to the mainstream user. Once these products hit the mainstream, the gravitational pull of the mainstream and its purchasing power slowly changed the adoption cycle from top down to bottom up. â€œConsumers can make buying decisions much more quickly than businesses can,â€ Andreessen points, â€œbecause for the consumer, they either like it or they donâ€™t, whereas businesses have to go through these long and involved processes.â€ He maintains that the reason the enterprise wasnâ€™t particularly appealing for many entrepreneurs between 2000-2008 was that consumer software was the only software that anybody could adopt.â€ This is no longer the case, as the enterprise world evolves from a sales-driven to a product-driven approach.
Â â€œThe user is now the buyer, and the center of gravity is no longer in IT, itâ€™s actually in the line of business themselves,â€ says Christian Gheorghe,Â CEO of mobile first metrics management startupÂ Tidemark, outlining the factors in that evolution. â€œThe cloud is not just a cost-based improvement, but a new computational platform. And mobile is surpassing the desktop.â€ â€œThe demand for â€˜consumer-gradeâ€™ enterprise technologies â€” from theÂ standpointÂ of having strong UX, being mobile, and platform agnostic â€” is anÂ irreversibleÂ trend,â€ says Levie. â€œTo the point that hard-to-use enterprise software will soon become more surprising than well-designed enterprise software (give it a few years).â€ â€œToday all the consumerized enterprise stuff is as easily usable by the small business as it is by the large business,â€ Andreessen explains. â€œIn fact, itâ€™s probably more easily usable by the small business than it is by the large business, because with a small business, itâ€™s like you can just use it. You donâ€™t have to go through a long process, you donâ€™t have to have a lot of meetings, you donâ€™t have to have committees, you donâ€™t have to have all this stuff. You can just start picking up and using it.â€ Because of this confluence of elements, an enterprise startupâ€™s â€œland and expandâ€ strategy has become more complex than having a huge sales force or wining and dining the CIO. It actually boils down to making a product that people want to use, as consumers are already using cloud products, and fall back on them when their older enterprise solutions fail. â€œThe Exchange Server is down? No problem, Iâ€™ll use Gmail. Email policy doesnâ€™t allow an attachment over 2 GB. No problem, Iâ€™ll use YouSendIt, Dropbox or Box,â€ Ron MillerÂ succinctly puts it.Â Boxâ€™s early business customers were CIOs who called into the company with concerns about security,Â irate that their employees were using the platform to covertly share files. Those calls eventually turned into deals. In fact, one could argue that consumer startup Dropbox was the best thing to ever happened to Box, familiarizing the layman with cloud file sharing. Box then innovated on the use case, by offering increased security and controls to appease CIOs and enterprise execs. â€œThe first generation of this new enterprise wave was replacement technologies at lower prices (like Salesforce and SolarWinds),â€ says Asana co-founder Justin Rosenstein, â€œbut the new wave is technologies that compete by being better products. The *new* inefficiency to compete against isnâ€™t just total cost of operations (through SaaS) or cost â€“ itâ€™s beating them with a better product.â€ Because adoption is getting easier and other related factors, weâ€™re seeing an onslaught of entrepreneurs building products for businesses that employees actually can use or want to use. Weâ€™re even seeing the emergence of companies like Okta, which are enterprise only, but still display the ease of a consumer startup. Not only is the number of companies that are taking their design cues from the consumer Internet increasing, it is rapidly becoming the norm.
â€œâ€˜Enterprise sexinessâ€™ has come from the increasing awareness that the new breed of vendors have gotten the consumerization thing right (especially with UI and mobile), and that the business models are known to be sustainable and viable,â€ says Workday co-founder Aneel Bhusri. â€œIndeed, in the case of companies like Asana and Cloudera, some of the founders themselves came from the consumer Internet.â€ That consumer background is helping the companies below get a lot more notice from VCs to consumers to the media because they know how to pitch themselves â€” and yes many of them have pretty cool products, specifically targeting millennials just getting situated in the workforce. PeopleSoft, Aolâ€™s HRM software, is as atrocious to use as its name sounds â€” Iâ€™d much rather be using Workday. While this list is by no means comprehensive (there are a ton of cool enterprise startups, and most people are vehementÂ favorites), here are just a few of the new guard that are fast becoming household names â€” through their focus on intuitiveness and design, awareness of mobile and fresh approaches to decades-old problems.Â â€The existing enterprise players are building software people tolerate,â€ as Rosenstein concisely puts it. â€œThe future players are building software people love.â€ Okta Okta is a single sign-on service for companies â€” â€œFacebook Connectâ€ for the enterprise. As a user, you can log in to your companyâ€™s admin page and access both private data hosted on your companyâ€™s server (intranet) and data from cloud products like Box, Salesforce and Google Apps. Administrators can easily manage the credentials across various applications and devices. Competitors: Salesforce has just launched Salesforce Identity to compete directly with Okta. Secret sauce:Â Okta is compatible with every web app you can think of. The startup has raised $52.5 million inÂ funding from Greylock Partners, Khosla Ventures, Andreessen Horowitz, FLOODGATE and Sequoia. Cloudera Cloudera is the solution de jourÂ for managing big data in a company, offering software, services and support for databases. When a user needs to analyze raw data to find a trend or to see if they can find valuable answers in unused data, Cloudera (built on top of Hadoop) allows them to complete more efficient queries. Competitors: MapRÂ and Hortonworks, but they are much smaller. For big companies, they can ask for custom solutions from IBM, but itâ€™s a lot more expensive. Secret sauce:Â Timing and it handles everything (software, development, supportâ€¦). Cloudera has big funding as well, having raised $141 million fromÂ Greylock, Accel, Meritech Capital Partners, In-Q-Tel and others. Box The original â€œsexyâ€ enterprise startup, BoxÂ allows you to store, manage and collaborate on your documents in the cloud. Founded back in 2006 (before Dropbox!), the company is helmed by the colorful Aaron Levie. Like Okta, Boxâ€™s main advantage is that it integrates well with many enterprise apps and offers security in addition to collaboration functionality. Interoperability is crucial: Users can find their files uploaded to Box in their favorite CRM apps, etc. Competitors: Microsoft SharePoint, consumer products, Dropbox, Google Driveâ€¦ Secret sauce: It was there first! Box effectively competes by constantly iterating on its product, focusing on enterprise even when Dropbox caught on, and good partnerships. Box has thus far raised $284 million from Draper Fisher Jurvetson, Scale Venture Partners,Â Andreessen Horowitz and others. GitHub Developers need a place to track and share their code changes, and GitHub, with social coding features that make it really easy for open source projects, is the repository of choice. GitHub is so popular that its version control technology, Git, is replacing SVN based on merit. GitHub offers premium subscriptions and self-hosted versions, and many companies and startups have switched to private GitHub repositories, some very early (Spotify). Competitors: Google Code for the social coding aspect, self-hosted repositories on an Intranet. Secret sauce: Git. Git is such an ace technology that developers couldnâ€™t resist adopting it, and GitHub is *the* best way to use Git. The runner up in the Bootstrapped Startup category at the 2011 Crunchies, GitHub eventually relented and took $100 million in Series A funding from Andreessen Horowitz last year. Zendesk Zendesk is user-friendly help desk software that allows companies to handle support requests in bulk. Zendesk is IPO-bound and, like enterprise pal Workday, might be another point of light in a series of lackluster tech IPOs. Competitors:Â Tons of companies are building desk software, and there are many open source apps for small and medium companies. Desk.com (formerly Assistly, acquired by Salesforce) and Tender Support are quite popular, but Tender Support doesnâ€™t have the same breadth of resources as Zendesk. Secret sauce:Â Zendesk was the first modern help desk, but Desk.com is gaining a lot of traction with Salesforce behind it. The company has plenty of money in the bank, having raised $85.5 million from Charles River Ventures, Benchmark Capital, Matrix Partners, Redpoint Ventures, Index Ventures, GGV Capital, Goldman Sachs and Silicon Valley Bank. Asana Taking the lessons they learned from an early stint at Facebook, Asana co-founders Dustin Moskovitz and Justin Rosenstein have built a beautiful and streamlined collaboration tool with a focus on to-do lists. The interface is flexible and easy to understand. In Asana, everything is a to-do item. The platformÂ doesnâ€™t try to do it all, but its design is very very intuitive, adhering humbly to its core goal ofÂ easing communications within a team. Competitors: Basecamp from 37signals, Do.com from Salesforce, and other communication tools that may make it useless (think Yammer) and many small alternatives (Producteev, Flow, etc.). For all these companies, the closest competitor might be basic emails. Secret sauce:Â The Asana product is relatively easy to use, and this is important for a latecomer to the collaboration software space. Pricing is friendly, too. For small companies, many of which have yet to switch to a collaboration tool, you can basically use it for free. Asana has raised over 38.2 million fromÂ Peter Thiel,Â Founders FundÂ BenchmarkÂ Capital,Â Andreessen Horowitz and angels like Ron Conway and Adam Dâ€™Angelo. GoodData GoodData is a less expensive data-analytics solution for large companies. Companies can integrate GoodDataâ€™s platform into their own cloud-based SaaS products (i.e. Salesforce, Zendesk) and then access operational dashboards, data warehousing and advanced data reporting. Competitors:Â IBM, SAP and Oracle. Secret sauce:Â Cheaper than competitors, GoodData integrates easily with Zendesk and Salesforce to track, aggregate and analyze data. Its simplicity and â€œout of the boxâ€ integrations make it ideal for small and medium enterprises. GoodData has $53.5 million in funding fromÂ Andreessen Horowitz,Â General Catalyst Partners,Â Tim Oâ€™Reilly and others. Atlassian â€œThe coolest thing to come out of Australia,â€ according to Accelâ€™s Ping Li, Atlassian is low-cost project management software. It provides a series of enterprise web apps: Jira is a project-tracking tool focused on software development; Confluence is a more traditional collaboration and communication tool; and developers use many of its other smaller product offerings in their workflows. Finally, Atlassian acquired HipChat, a hip chat app. Competitors: Open source project management solutions and native apps compete with Jira. Confluence competes with Basecamp, Yammer, etc. HipChat competes with Campfire from 37signals. Secret sauce: Founded in 2002, Atlassian is not a kid anymore. Over the years, it has proved to be a reliable web app developer. The company has thus far raised $60 million in Series A solely from Accel Partners. Nimble Storage Nimble Storage is an online storage service for developers. It has found a way to provide a large storage capacity with 5x the performance and 5x the capacity as existing products from EMC and NetApp. Nimble Storage has a unique caching system based on the flash storage commonly found in PCs and mobile phones. The result is a great speed increase, comparable to putting an SSD drive in your old computer. That technology is patented for online data storage. Competitors: EMC, NetApp, Amazon S3 and other online storage solutions. Secret sauce: Improving read/write speeds is a great challenge for hosting solutions these days, and Nimble is faster than its competitors, yet costs the same. It has received $81.7 million in funding from Sequoia Capital, Accel Partners, Lightspeed Venture Partners and others. MobileIron MobileIron is a device management tool for system admins. Now that the BYOD trend is taking over businesses, admins have to find new ways to handle security settings and push mobile apps to employees â€” all of this across multiple phones, tablets and operating systems. MobileIron provides a single platform to manage all devices even though most of them are personal devices that employees bring to the workplace. Competitors: In-house solutions and restrictions, checking security settings one phone at a time or choosing not to care about security. Secret sauce: MobileIron makes it much easier for system admins to handle custom phone settings. If you convert one system admin, the entire company will switch to MobileIron. Since 2007, it has raised $96.8 million from Sequoia Capital, Storm Ventures and Norwest Venture Partners.
â€œThey are all basically new companies,â€ says Andreessen, who agreed with many of the â€œCool Kidsâ€ choices. â€œI think who is not on that list are all the existing companies that sell business software.â€ And being younger, more agile companies automatically makes them much more interesting. Our benchmark is more delicious looking than Apple, simpler than Twitter.â€

We talk to a lot of the big hedge funds, mutual funds. Itâ€™s really funny. post.title: Record shops are the ever-changing spectrums of lost dreams
post.summary: When the news hit that HMV was in receivership the other week, laments were sung all round. A part of High Street culture was going for good - the big ol' record shop. God knows we lost Our Price when it was taken over by Virgin, then Virgin got taken over by Zavvi, and that lasted about a week before Zavvi folded as well. I assumed that with Our Price/Virgin/Zavvi out of the way, HMV would easily maintain its place on the High Street, being without a similar gargantuan competitor. But presumably downloads and online shopping sounded the death knell and HMV, which hadn't done a great deal to fight its corner, was heading down the pan like the unwanted turd it had become. Music shops have a special place in my heart (and probably for many others of you). It was where we'd head on the way home from school when I lived in Colchester, to dream over record sleeves, looking forward to the day when our pocketmoney would stretch far enough. We had a bigÂ Our Price/Virgin in Culver Square, and then a smaller one near Marks & Spencers. There was also an Andy's Records, which seems to be a small East Anglian chain. And there was a place called Time Records (apparently Steve Marriott used to shop there when he lived in Essex) - I never went in there, though, as I was intimidated by what I thought was its impenetrable coolness. Time was near Mann's Music, where I got my first musical instrument - a recorder - and I've seen Graham Coxon mention it as the place he used to get guitar strings. When I moved to Birmingham, it amazed me to see the huge HMV and Virgin Megastore stood next to each other, like Tolkein's twin towers, herald gateway to the Pavillion shopping centre. HMV furnished record signings - I met the Manics, and saw Brett Anderson and Bernard Butler perform together (something I thought I'd missed by being too young when they split back in 1994). It was a place of magic and glamour. So when the news hit about HMV, there were many fond memories disappearing with it. No more wandering the 4 floors searching for gems. No more record signings, no more chances to meet my heroes. But to be honest, how many of those many floors were devoted to music? One. The rest was crappy DVDs and computer games (and never the DVD you wanted). The big HMV then closed, with the smaller branch in the Bullring being the sole store in the second city, but the store was taken over with ridiculous-looking, over-priced headphones. And the reality is, of course, that while people are happy to spend Â£150 on some very silly headphones which don't have particularly great sound, they're quite happy to pay bugger all for the music they're listening to. It's the appearance they're interested in - oh look, I'm a muso, I'm wearing big expensive headphones. Yeah well fuck off. If you're any expert you should be listening with Sennheisers. And you know what? I wear those in the studio - I ain't about to walk about in public wearing them. Because it looks fucking daft. Ok? Anyway..... HMV has found its saviour, so when I was shopping in town on Saturday (by "shopping", I basically went to Maplin's to get a headphone jack-to-headphone jack cable for our next gig - I also nearly bought some new shoes but didn't. This is thrilling, I know...), I thought, "HMV's been bailed out, they're open, so... Ah, "Wolf's Law", the new album by The Joy Formidable's out this week! I can pop into HMV to buy it!" And that's not such a silly plan, is it? When Suede went through its re-release gyrations in 2011 and put out new versions of their old albums, I made a rule of going to HMV to buy each one as they were released, and took a photo of the CD in the CD rack (yeah... I know....). I like flicking through the CDs to look for the one I want - I like the clank of the plastic cases. The Joy Formidable had been scheduled to do a signing in the HMV in Norwich (which was cancelled because... y'know...), so I thought the chances were high that they'd have the new album. But could I find The Joy Formidable? No! There wasn't even an index card thingymawotsit with their name on. And I felt sad - not just because I couldn't find the album I wanted, but because the magic of the record shop had gone. There were ugly DVDs stacked in front of the door, and gangs of geeky boys lurking round the tablets and headphones. The music is shoved up the back of the shop like an embarrassing deformed relative, like an in-bred Royal with special needs hidden in an attic. So I thought, fine, ok, HMV... you lose. I wended my way to Swordfish, which is one of the few independent record shops left in Birmingham. We used to have Plastic Factory (I think it was more vinyl-y), and Tempest, but both have gone (the staff in Tempest laughed in my face when I asked them if they'd sell my fanzine, so... didn't bother going back). Swordfish is more of a sort of older music fan's shop. It's very proggy. When we have Record Shop Day, lots of people on twitter get excited and bang on about how great Swordfish is, but I have trouble agreeing as it's terribly dusty and it smells, and there's not anything in there that I actually want. It appears to have been on the verge of closing down for a couple of years, as well. That said, I do like the big Elvis by the door, and 10 years ago it was pretty nifty with a huge quantity of Blue Note jazz and lots of freakbeak compilations (but... not anymore). I couldn't find an entry for The Joy Formidable in the rack, so I asked at the counter if they had "Wolf's Law". I got a no. The bloke at the counter didn't even need to look for it - he knew it wasn't there, and I wondered how many other people had asked him that day. Possibly quite a few..... This evening, I caved in and admitted defeat: I ordered online from Piccadilly Records, an independent shop in Manchester. While I was at it, I ordered the limited edition 7" by Teleman. Can't imagine Teleman being on sale *anywhere* in Birmingham, despite Pete & The Pirates having played here not that long ago (the singer from Pete & The Pirates is now in Teleman). I listened to "Wolf's Law" on Spotify, given no other choice, and it's a spectacular album - big, swooping songs, hair-standing-up-on-the-back-of-your-neck hugeness, tingle-inducing amazingness, and by the end - I had tears in my eyes. It's fabulous. And isn't it bloody tragic that a record of this magnitude isn't for sale in a shop where I live? What a sad state of affairs. Photo credits: first two pics of HMV stores from The Guardian website via filmcamera999. Third photo: Shropshire Star Fourth photo: Rex Features via Easy Living Fifth photo: The Hearing Aid (one assumes this was Record Shop Day - I have never seen a queue like *that* outside Swordfish myself). Sixth photo: Piccadilly Records Seventh photo: emusic

post.title: Samsung reportedly planning wider device availability for Music Hub
post.summary: Since Samsung first announced their Music Hub service, the global reach has been somewhat limited. Initially launching only in the UK, the U.S. soon followed, but one thing remained. Device exclusivity to Samsung devices, more specifically the Galaxy S3and then the Galaxy Note 2. Now though, a new report suggests that Samsung is looking towards expanding the reach of its music service, and go toe-to-toe with the likes of Google Play and the Amazon MP3 Store. TJ Kang, SVP for Samsung Media Services, in speaking with The Next Web said that Samsung plans to expand the availability of Music Hub. Initially taking in the Samsung range of connected devices, to include tablets, smartphones, Smart TV's and even refrigerators, the expansion wouldn't end there. Beyond this, Kang also acknowledged that the service could be seen on Android devices from other OEMs, stating it would be easier for Samsung, since consumers often own devices covering a broad range of manufacturers. Currently the Samsung Music Hub is available in six countries worldwide, but further global expansion is also reportedly on the cards for 2013. As you might expect this is subject to territory specific deals, but also Samsung's 2013 device release plans. No potential timeline was offered for making the service available beyond the walls of Samsung, but Kang did go on to say that such availability was the company's goal. So, perhaps the question we should be asking -- is there room for yet another music service fighting for our business? With Google Play and Amazon already established in selling music, and the likes of Spotify and Rdiooffering compelling streaming offerings, is there room for another? Currently Music Hub could be seen as more of a convenience for those who can access it, but surely to break through Samsung would have to offer something compelling. What about you guys -- would you use a Samsung music service in place of whatever you currently use? Hit up the comments below and share your thoughts with us. Source: The Next Web Via: Samsung reportedly planning wider device availability for Music Hub

post.title: Apps Worthy of a Place on Your Android Smartphone
post.summary:
At long last it's here. Review coming soon. After a seven week wait, I've finally taken delivery of a shiny Nexus 4 smartphone. At the time of writing, it's next to impossible to get hold of in a hurry, unless you're prepared to spend big money. So big in fact, it must be tempting for those with the patience to sell theirs on, at massive profit, and then buy another when the dust settles. I'm most definitely keeping hold of mine however and have begun the process of transferring my apps across. Since this is my third Android phone (HTC Hero and HTC Desire S RIP) I've amassed a lot of apps and I thought it might be a good idea to share with potential first time Android phone owners which applications have stood the test of time. Dropbox Â Folders and files available across my gadgets. Will open many of them too. Dropbox is an absolute must for any device. I run it on my phone, my iPad, a Linux based laptop and my Windows laptop. Sign up for free and you're given 2GB storage. Enough for a ton of documents and photographs and Dropbox will make them all easily available to you automatically across all your gadgets. Recent developments to the smartphone version introduced the ability to automatically upload your photos to your account, preserving precious memories and making them instantly available to you on your bigger connected screens. Having access to all my documents, PDFs, photos and other files makes this the first app I install on anything. Photos can auto-upload to Dropbox from your phone Google Play Music Â Google Music lets you store your tunes online and access them from anywhere I recently reviewed Google Music against Spotify and found a lot to like. I now use it daily and, like Dropbox, it gives me easy convenient access to my music and playlists across all my devices, without having to manage the collection separately in each place. Music is streamed, so a good internet connection is necessary to get the best out of it, but playlists, songs or entire albums can also be 'pinned' for offline access. A widget accesses basic controls from your homescreen One of the Nexus 4's limitations is that it has 16GB of storage and no possibility of expanding with a memory card. I've made a dedicated playlist for the phone that has all my favourites in and a local copy is stored, so when an internet connection is not available, I still have plenty of tunes to enjoy. A fantastic app, backed up by a nice store to buy new stuff.
SayIt Â Top Tip: Launch SayIt from SayIt to open settings Android has come a long way since my original HTC Hero. I loved it at the time, but there were certain things it didn't do well. More recent versions of the operating system have resolved most of my woes, back then I'd have to install lots of apps to make the user experience exactly how I wanted it. These days, there is really only one problem for me that has driven me to need an app to solve. Opening the menu reveals page after page of apps and quickly searching out the one I want, especially when on the move is frustratingly slow. That's where SayIt comes in and it very much does what it says on the tin. Add the widget and simply tap and say the name of the app you want and it opens within a moment. It's quick, useful and probably the only voice controlled application I can see myself using on a regular basis. Tap the other side of the widget and you're presented with a list of your most commonly opened apps. Useful for when talking to your phone seems inappropriate! Tap the left opens your popular apps, the right to launch an app by saying its name AVG Antivirus Free Â Like a Windows PC, a spot of anti-virus protection is advisable Apple is often cricised for it's vice like grip over what is allowed to be sold on their App Store. Whilst the headlines usually highlight the perfectly legitimate apps that have been kept out for some spurious reason, it does help that little can slip through to actally do your phone harm. With Google's Android, you're much more free to install whatever you like, which is great, but as with other freedoms in life, it's better done with some protection. AVG is well known in the Windows world for its excellent antvirus product and now they're offering to protect your phone too. Not only from viruses and malcious apps either; it will also protect you from going over your mobile data limits and give you some remote lock and wipe capabilities, should the phone fall into the wrong hands. Essential. AVG will help your phone stay at its best Whatsapp Â Pictures of lovely food only good if you'll be eating it soon I love texting as much as the next man/woman/teen-hidden-in-a-hoodie and have enjoyed unlimited texts in recent years. But, more recently I've been sending less and less. No, I've not gone all quiet, I've just moved to Whatsapp. Free for the first year and 69p per year after that, Whatsapp is a cross between text, instant messaging and picture messaging and it's becoming a phenomenon. After installation it neatly reads your contacts and shows you everyone who also has Whatsapp installed. Send them a message and a tick will appear when its delivered. A second tick will appear when its been read. Should your friend be present at the time, they'll show as 'Online' and 'typing' if they start a reply immediately. Suddenly, a text can become a realtime conversation! If you want a group chat, that's possible too and it's great fun. Picture mesages have always been expensive on mobiles, but with Whatsapp you can send them free and they'll only use the slightest sip of your data plan. This one could mark the end of traditional text messaging. Flipboard Â A magazine that's always up to date. This is the death of print. Smartphones, in spite of their comparatively small screens do a reasonable job of surfing the internet. Webpages are often optimised for mobile use and screen resolutions now rival that of laptops! But still, the screen is small and it's not always a pleasure to do; unless you install Flipboard that is. What Flipboard does is repackage the best of the internet into a sort of mobile magazine and any sense of compromise is gone. It's beautiful. Pick from Flipboard's curated websites by catagory (EG 'Technology' or 'Auto'), or choose your own using RSS feeds and you can 'flip' your way through the headlines, dipping into the ones that stand out to read the article, all making the best use of your screen. This was great on the HTC Desire, but if you have a big screen phone like the Nexus 4, wow it looks good! TV Catchup Â All the major channels and non-intrusive advertising. Beats those old Casios. Whilst it might seem old fashioned in this interactive day and age, sometimes it's nice just to kick back and watch some telly. YouTube and Netflix do a great job of providing video on demand, but it's TV Catchup I love giving live access to the major UK free to view terrestrial channels. It's free to download and use and all you have to do is skip past an advert each time you channel change. Picture quality will obviously vary on your connection speed and it will eat into your mobile data plan, but generally it's very watchable and again, with a modern mobile's quality screen, you won't find yourself squinting. Whilst the millions of apps that we can download from app-stores have definitely changed and improved the way we use our phones, there are a vast amount that may be only used a couple of times before bordom sets in or something better is released. The above apps for me have faced down the competition and won. Their new home on my Nexus 4 is assured and their widgets wil be swiped at regularly. If you've not tried any of them before, I strongly recommend a look. Jp Â Posted with Blogsy

post.title: Rage Against The Machine - Evil Empire
post.summary: Normal 0 false false false EN-GB X-NONE X-NONE MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 I am really struggling to start this blog - not because I do not have an idea of what I want to say, I know how I feel about this album.Â I just have to try to articulate how disappoint I was when this first came out.Â As you may have noticed before I did possibly the most lazy and quickest blog I have ever done for the debut album.Â That was because there was nothing new I could say that has not been said before. It would have just been adding another layer of praise to a giant statue of shining complements.Â It is as near to perfect a debut as I have ever heard.Â Now when I first heard this I was very excited, but apart from a couple of songs I was so disappointed. I mean it was crushing the amount of negativity that came out of me when this was released.Â So after being asked to go through their whole back catalogue (which I was planning to be honest) - this was the one I was most curious about to see if age and time has been kinder to it than my initial opinion. The production on this was handled by Brendan O'Brien & the band together - he was mostly associated with Pearl Jam at the time this was released. Coming back to this album the production is so minimal it makes the song stand on an edge. What at one time had sounded lazy and substandard to these ears has become a bonafide stone cold killer sound. The balance and split speakers for the bass and guitar just works so well on every track.Â Before listening to this I always said the only decent things off this album are "Bulls On Parade" & "People of The Sun".Â Now I have to change that opinion - the whole album is just astonishing.Â It takes up from the first album and goes further forward with the sound.Â The whole packing has become a sophisticated understated album which has no weak link. When I started to listen to this album today I was expecting to be giving this maybe a 4 or 5 at the most.Â But I think it is obvious that opinion has changed. It is without a single doubt a million times improved from those first listens way back in the distant memories of my youth. Rage Against The Machine are owed an apology, instead I will just give the album this mark instead....... 10 out of ten - This is proof that there is a god You can purchase from here You can listen to on Spotify here
