post.title: My first name ainâ€™t baby, itâ€™s Janet, Miss Jackson if youâ€™re nasty
post.summary:
Anyone born in the 1990s is probably looking at the title of this blog post rather blankly right now. Blinking politely and swiping the screen and moving on with disinterest, searching for a post about clothes, or London. Or something. Some, however, will feel a smile begin to creep slowly over their face. Find themselves sitting up in their chair just a little bit straighter. Tapping Nasty furiously into their Spotify search box and turning the volume up just a little too loudly for a Sunday evening. Ferocious shoulder popping and determined head nodding may occur, followed by an energetic dance routine around the living room that causes noticeable perspiration. Well, hello there. I see you too are partial to a bit of Janet â€“ Miss Jackson if youâ€™re nasty. My love for Janet began at an early age when I purchased my first album of hers on cassette tape (from Our Price, with voucher). Control, with its recognisable pillarbox red cover â€“ Janet in jaunty-black-blazer-and-leather glove-combo and side pony tail accentuated with an arty gold squiggle â€“ never left my Walkman and ensured I made full use of the autoreverse feature. I didnâ€™t have a bloody clue what â€˜Cause itâ€™s all about Control. And Iâ€™ve got lots of itâ€˜ meant, but as long as the power of her music reached my ears through spongy, orange headphones, I didnâ€™t care. SONGS Ultimately, Janet belted out smashing tracks that hold their own on any iPod in 2013 â€“ nasty grooves, synth-pop and pulsating dance rhythms. Control is a slice of delicious 1980s R&B flavoured with a sprinkle of pop and is produced by the legendary Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis. Thereâ€™s not a dud song on it. What Have You Done for Me Lately (ooo ooo ooo ooooo YEAH) still makes me smile and feel perplexed that someone as majestic as Janet would even allow those dancing feet anywhere near her couch. Nasty was the song that made me furious and empowered â€“ and want to dance. Give me a beat! screamed Janet as she reassured me that it absolutely was not OK to be disrespected by nasty boys. Letâ€™s Wait Awhile is in effect an innocent love song that tackles sexual abstinence, but I cannot listen to it without thinking of my big sister Jo and our friend Kelly in a home video, crooning seriously into the camera with hairbrush-microphones, hair gelled to the side and accompanying finger clicks â€“ and laughing until my belly hurts. To protect their dignity, I shall not post this video here. VIDEOS Speaking of which, thereâ€™s no doubt that Janet made truly classic music videos â€“ phew, could she dance. One of my all time favourites has to be When I Think of You. Watch and learn confident young starlets of today. Firstly, ensure itâ€™s choreographed by Paula Abdul, her of Straight Up fame (and later very embarrassing on X Factor). Set it in a colourful neighbourhood where everyone â€“ street sweepers, drunks, police officers, random people reading newspapers and small children â€“ can dance, proper FAME style. Style it with spectacular outfits from the 1980s â€“ tight stonewash double denim, tight vests, flippy dresses and waistcoats all with very large earrings. Youâ€™re the lead singer? Well, team an oversized shoulder-padded blazer with a corset, gloves and superfluous jewellery and ensure that your hair is by far the biggest thing in the video. Run aimlessly from room to room looking utterly gorgeous, slide down staircases and smile at waiters. Walk purposefully through the streets, occasionally falling meticulously in line with your chums, and sailors, to dance. Finally, make a fire hydrant burst dramatically and for no apparent reason and proceed to perform an amazing choreographed routine in the jet of water â€“ ensure that arm circling, hip wiggling and shoulder slamming are in time to the music. THAT is how you make a pop video.
FASHION Janet made me fall in love with fashion. She knew how to pair a baroque blazer with a flamboyant patterned shirt done right up to the top button and oversize earrings. She had HUGE hair that no scrunchie was ever going to hold. If it didnâ€™t have a shoulder pad, she wasnâ€™t interested. Gloves were not for keeping her hands warm, they were for FASHION. Do not even get me started on the Rhythm Nation era! Oh, that long-sleeved military jacket adorned with silver buttons and badges. The strength of the embellished baseball cap is breathtaking. Talk a walk through Shoreditch and you can bet your life thereâ€™s a Janet influence right before your very eyes. In fact, Iâ€™d bet the oversized â€™80s shirt Iâ€™m wearing on it. So, having a bad day? Feeling a bit miffed with someone or something? Been disrespected by a Nasty boy? Listen to the feminist catchphrase that is â€˜No my first name ainâ€™t baby, itâ€™s Janet, Miss Jackson if youâ€™re nastyâ€˜ and stand up tall â€“ mean business. Wear something gaudy, splashy and with shoulder pads. Dance. A lot. Take Control. Janet style.

post.title: Week 4 - Birthday Week, the World's Food and Django
post.summary: BELOW: Birthday Week, Film of the Week, Song of the Week, Quote of the Week and Overuse of the Week: of the Week. 25th Birthday Week - A World of Food After last weekends Sushi special in Leeds I carried on with the theme of foods from different countries throughout my birthday week. I understand to most people this section (maybe the whole blog) will not be interesting if you don't like food but how I see it is, everyone should 'Open up their minds to a world of different foods' and everyone has to eat. Monday - the mother cooked me a birthday Monday night English roast, which as always was amazing. Tuesday - the family went out to a Turkish restaurant called Zeugma's (http://www.zeugmaiki.com/userrestaurants/preview). Unbelievable food, especially the filo pastry with feta cheese filling starter. A highlight of the night was the Turkish music which my dad (mildly racist) seemed to abuse out loud constantly throughout the meal at a high volume as he 'couldn't hear a bloody thing' and commented 'this music is shit'. Although, he did try Halloumi. Wednesday - I went round to the sisters house to see the two nieces (secretly just wanted to play marriage time with Barbie and Ken), where the brother in law cooked a few Spanish Tapas dishes. Patatas Bravas, Garlic Bread, Mushrooms, Courgette and Spicy Chicken Skewers were on the menu. Very, very nice. Thursday - went to Chiquito's for a Mexican feast involving Chicken, Pepper and Choritzo Kebabs and Nacho's for starters. Want to hear a joke - What did the Mexican policeman say to the cheese thief? THAT'S NACHO CHEESE! Brilliant eh! Thanks to Sian for that one. After the meal I went to see the film: DJANGO UNCHAINED (see below in film of the week). Friday - the final meal of the week was at the local Indian restaurant called Bay of Bengal (http://www.bayofbengalsheffield.co.uk/). I would highly recommend anyone who likes Indian's to visit, it was delicious. I had the Muroogh Jalfrezi with Keema Rice and Nan. It was nice but I over-egged it with how much heat I can take, it was an eye watering experience. Then the snow came down which ruined the night out but this was a blessing in disguise as I had felt ill all day. This illness has carried on all weekend, with me leaving my bed for about 4 hours all weekend to fetch water and drugs (the medicinal type). Film of the Week: Django Unchained by Quentin Tarantino As you can see in the trailer above, its another classic by Tarantino. If you liked Pulp Fiction you will love this piece of genius which takes you back to a time when slave trade was common and so was the word 'N****r' which is widely used as you will see. It drags on at times and could cut about an hour out where Jamie Foxx is riding a horse but that adds to the dramatic side as it keeps you on your toes as to what will happen next.Â My highlight was the brilliant Samuel L Jackson who plays an interesting character who will have you in hysterics. He is in my top 3 actors for sure. Song of the Week - Safe and Sound by Capital City A song which was released in 2011 by a band I know little about. I found it via spotify which for anyone who enjoys music should download straight away and utilise the 'Play Artist Radio' which basically just sees that you like an artist and creates a random plalyist similar to Genius for Itunes but a lot lot better. Quote of the Week "I went to a karaoke bar last night that didnâ€™t play any 70â€²s musicâ€¦at first I was afraid, oh I was petrified." Stewart Francis

post.title: Nokia intros Music+ subscription service with unlimited downloads, web listening
post.summary: Most of the bigger streaming music services have both a free tier for casual listeners and a paid level for truly committed music fans. Nokia doesnâ€™t want to be the exception to the rule. Itâ€™s launching Nokia Music+, a paid version of its existing platform. Paying â‚¬4 per month ($4 in the US) gives perks that youâ€™d normally expect from a more expensive alternative like Spotify or Slackerâ€™s premium tier: the upgrade ratchets up the audio quality, adds lyrics, allows unlimited skips in Mix Radio and enables as many downloads for offline play as the phone can hold. Arenâ€™t you suddenly glad that you picked up a 32GB Lumia 920? Not that youâ€™ll always need it to tune in â€” Music+ adds web streaming for anything with a suitably capable browser. Nokia hasnâ€™t said just which countries beyond the US will get the more advanced service, but it should make a formal debut within the next few weeks. Filed under: Cellphones, Portable Audio/Video, Internet, Mobile, Nokia Comments Source: Conversations by Nokia

post.title: Una de niÃ±os prodigio: oda al Super Clan de Teresa Rabal

Por Mike Medianoche En Sufridores nos encantan los niÃ±os prodigio. Hoy vamos a recordar a los chicos y chicas del SÃºper Clan de Teresa Rabal, un puÃ±ado de niÃ±os y adolescentes que daban sus primeros pasos en el mundo del artisteo dentro del programa Se busca una estrella, el cual emitÃ­a Antena 3 televisiÃ³n entre los aÃ±os 1992 y 1993. Algunas de las componentes del Super Clan y sus estilismos de los aÃ±os noventa Se busca una estrella era el tÃ­pico programa infantil presentado por Teresa Rabal, quien como cabÃ­a esperar cantaba una canciÃ³n de su repertorio a la mÃ­nima ocasiÃ³n. AdemÃ¡s de los shows de la tÃ­a Teresa, dentro del espacio se emitÃ­an series de dibujos animados, como Popeye y su hijo o la enÃ©sima reposiciÃ³n de Pippi Calzaslargas. Pero lo mÃ¡s interesante de todo era cuandoÂ la artista que escribe notas de prensa en mayÃºsculasÂ no cantaba y cedÃ­a el escenario para las actuaciones de los miembros del citado SÃºper Clan, quienes ademÃ¡s le hacÃ­an las veces de bailarines, coristas e incluso azafatas a la artÃ­fice deÂ Veo Veo.Â El SÃºper Clan lo formaron los niÃ±os Mercedes Ortega, Pilar Valero, JosÃ© Antonio GimÃ©nez, Elisabeth DurÃ¡n, Sonia Herrero, y la mÃ¡s veterana televisiva de todos los miembros del SuperClan, Raquel Carrillo, quien ya era una pequeÃ±a estrella mediÃ¡tica gracias a ser compaÃ±era de Ana Chavarri en La Merienda o SuperGuay.
En alguno de los casos los chicos ya habÃ­an trabajado con anterioridad con Teresa, como ocurrÃ­a por ejemplo con Elisabeth y conÂ Raquel, quienes ya participaron con la Rabal en otros programas como La GuarderÃ­a. Los SuperClaners en acciÃ³n Cuando Teresa les cedÃ­a el escenario, los SuperClanersÂ interpretaban algÃºn tema propio, los cuales eran originales y exclusivos del programa. Eso sÃ­, para que la cosa quedase en casa, el autor de la gran mayorÃ­a de ellos era Eduardo Rodrigo, el marido y compositor habitual de Teresa.Â Por lo general, se trata de temas pop con raÃ­ces flamencas y un toque hiphopero a veces, que los chavales solÃ­an escenificar en riguroso playback con coreografÃ­as de Poty, que era el director general de coreografÃ­as de la cadena. Por norma general, Poty solÃ­a apostar porque los Superclaners tuviesen actitud rapera a la hora de interpretar su cÃ¡ntico, pese a que el tema pudiese sonar mÃ¡s cercano al sonido de Las Grecas que a la de MC Hammer, como se puede comprobar en esta actuaciÃ³n de Elisabeth y su hit Por Ã©l. Hay que destacar que habÃ­a algunos temas que sÃ­ que tenÃ­an aires mÃ¡s raperos que flamencos, como pasaba con el hit que interpretaba Raquel Carrillo â€œCÃ³mo mola la gramola de mi abuela, cÃ³mo mola la gramola del salÃ³nâ€. Recordemos que en aquella Ã©poca el tener un familiar mayor con marcha era tendencia, ya que ademÃ¡s de la abuela de Raquel y su molona gramola estaba la TÃ­a Enriqueta de Chimo Bayo o Wilfred y la ganga, que popularizÃ³ el hit Mi abuela. Se Busca una Estrella ademÃ¡s tenÃ­a mucho de Los 40 Principales, ya que cada semana se confeccionaba una lista con las canciones de los chicos del Super Clan, con votos que los espectadores emitÃ­an desde sus casas a travÃ©s del correo postal, realizÃ¡ndose ranking con los chicos y chicas segÃºn la popularidad de esos dÃ­as. AquÃ­ se puede ver uno de esos rankings con trozos de varias canciones, ademÃ¡s de una actuaciÃ³n de JosÃ© Antonio GimÃ©nez con su tema Cantar y cantar, muy rollo Joselito. Watch this video on YouTube. El programa tuvo mucha popularidad, y seis de los chicos grabaron un disco llamado SuperClan nÂº1, y fue debut y despedida, ya que jamÃ¡s hubo un volumen 2. Como correspondÃ­a, Antena 3 hizo una gran campaÃ±a para vender discos de cara a las Navidades, con un spot en el que los chicos decÃ­an mÃ¡s o menos â€œSomos el Super Clan de Teresa Rabal, nos llevas a tu casa esta Navidadâ€. Admito que no tengo este disco original (pero sÃ­ en mp3 gracias a La Ficha Rosa del Trivial, instigador de este post) asÃ­ que si algÃºn lector lo tiene por casa ya sea en CD o en vinilo y no lo quiere, o lo encuentra en un mercadillo, que sepa que me harÃ­a mÃ¡s feliz que Alicia Senovilla el sustituir a Ana Rosa durante el verano.Â Â Cuando Teresa Rabal fichÃ³ porÂ Telecinco para estar al frente de los programas MuÃ©vete y La Casa de la Guasa, tomando el relevo de Xuxa, se llevÃ³ con ella a Pilar, Elisabeth y Sonia, formando una nueva hornada de SuperClanersÂ a los que se sumarÃ­an otros artistas como Marta Castans, Chus Herranz, Patricia Cobos y el grupo maÃ±oÂ Ãšltima Cruzada. Â De hecho, aquel verano de 1994 hicieron una gira que dio su pistoletazo de salida en el teatro del mÃ­tico parque de atracciones TÃ­voli World. Por supuesto, a la cabeza del espectÃ¡culo estaba la anfitriona Teresa Rabal, esa seÃ±ora que me citÃ³ para una entrevista en la puerta de su circo y una vez allÃ­ saliÃ³ para decirme que no me podÃ­a atender porque la iba a entretener mucho y se volviÃ³ para dentro tan campante. Si alguien encuentra este disco en una tienda de segunda mano que me lo compre, por favor Entre los chicos del SÃºper Clan habÃ­a madera de artistas, y la mejor prueba de ellos es que la mayorÃ­a han continuado en el espectÃ¡culo.Â De quien mÃ¡s hemos hablado en este blog es sin duda deÂ Pilar Valero,Â quien formÃ³ parte del grupoÂ CalaÃ­tosÂ y despuÃ©s deÂ La DÃ©cada Prodigiosa. Posteriormente participÃ³ en la preselecciÃ³n eurovisiva con el grupoÂ JasterÂ en 2005 y recientemente ha sacado su tercer trabajo en solitario que lleva el tÃ­tulo deÂ CalaÃ­ta por tu amor, que se puede escuchar en Spotify, comprar en iTunes y en formato fÃ­sicoÂ a travÃ©s de su pÃ¡gina web. De hecho, esta misma semana acaba de estrenar su nuevo videoclip, Para ti candela, que ha rodado junto a Diego Otero, Mister EspaÃ±a 2012. Watch this video on YouTube. Raquel Carrillo, a quien ya entrevistamos por aquÃ­, se licenciÃ³ en periodismo y ha trabajado como periodista en la COPE, lo cual ha compaginado con su faceta como actriz de teatro y musicales e incluso llegÃ³ a grabar un trabajo discogrÃ¡fico con Solera Discos. JosÃ© Antonio GimÃ©nez tambiÃ©n continuÃ³ en la mÃºsica, participÃ³ en algunos programas de televisiÃ³n como Tu gran dÃ­a de TVE y ha trabajado como cantante en varias orquestas, segÃºn hemos descubierto por su Myspace.Â Elisabeth DurÃ¡n, en pleno boom teresista,Â participÃ³ en 1993 con 14 aÃ±os en el Festival de Benidorm con el temaÂ No te hagas ilusiones, compuesto, cÃ³mo no, por el maridÃ­simo Eduardo Rodrigo, y compitiÃ³ aquel aÃ±o en su categorÃ­a de canciÃ³n ligera junto a nuestras idolatradasÂ Marta y Loreto Valverde, quedando Elisabeth en tercera posiciÃ³n. Elisabeth continuÃ³ en el mundillo de la mÃºsicaÂ segÃºn vemos en su Â Myspace,Â y actualmente es corista de la eurovisiva Pastora Soler. Hablando de Eurovision, Elisabeth participaciÃ³ en la preselecciÃ³n para representar a EspaÃ±a en el Festival de Eurovision en el aÃ±o 2008 con la canciÃ³nÂ Esta es mi gente,Â con el cual pidiÃ³ el voto de esta manera. Watch this video on YouTube. Sonia Herrero, quien desde los seis aÃ±os estudiaba arte dramÃ¡tico segÃºn decÃ­a ella misma en una entrevista de 1994,Â actuÃ³ en 1996 en cuatro episodios en la segunda temporada deÂ MÃ©dico de FamiliaÂ encarnando a Sandra, una joven embarazada a la que atendÃ­a el doctor encarnado por Emilio AragÃ³n.Â Â TambiÃ©n tuvo pequeÃ±os papeles en series como Manos a la obra,Â Los negocios de MamÃ¡ con RocÃ­o DÃºrcal o la serie Abierto 24 horas con Pilar Bardem. Su Ãºltimo papel televisivo hasta la fecha fue en la obra La Malquerida de Estudio Uno enÂ 2006.Â De la Ãºnica que no he Â encontrado rastro es de la benjamina del SuperClan,Â Mercedes Ortega, y si buscamos por internet la Ãºnica pista parecida que hemos encontrado es una cantante canaria llamada Mercedes Ortega queÂ actuÃ³ en un acto benÃ©fico, pero Mercedes Clan era andaluza. De la Ã©poca de MuÃ©vete y La Casa de la Guasa, hay que destacar queÂ el grupoÂ Ãšltima CruzadaÂ participÃ³ tambiÃ©n en el Festival de Benidorm en 1993 apadrinados por Teresa Rabal y Eduardo Rodrigo en la categorÃ­a pop-rock. Patricia Cobos, que fue Miss Ãvila en 1997, continuÃ³ en el espectÃ¡culo yÂ participÃ³ en la preselecciÃ³n de Eurovision con el grupoÂ Â JasterÂ junto a la tambiÃ©n SuperClaner Pilar Valero (2005) Â y otras dos veces en el Festival de Benidorm con las formacionesÂ Karma (2001) y La DÃ©cada Prodigiosa,Â con quien ganÃ³ el certamen en 2006. TambiÃ©n fue corista de Alejandro Sanz y protagonizÃ³ con Ã©l el videoclip deÂ CorazÃ³n PartÃ­o.Â Chus Herranz, que ha hecho giras como corista de Raphael o Bustamante y Gisela, presentÃ³ el programa infantil Birlokus Club de Telecinco, y saliÃ³ en episodios de Yo soy Bea yÂ FÃ­sica o QuÃ­mica y en la pelÃ­cula BrÃ¡cula. Aunque su fuerte son los musicales, Â (Annie, Â Grease Tour, Hoy no me puedo levantar, o My Fair Lady con Paloma San Basilio, entre otros) lo que mÃ¡s nos gusta de ella es que era corista en la orquesta del Maestro Leyva en QuÃ©Â Apostamos y queÂ fue la morenaza queÂ acompaÃ±Ã³ a RamÃ³n en el escenario de Eurovision 2004 Â como corista y bailarina. Watch this video on YouTube. Â¿Y tÃº, querida lectora, eras seguidor del Super Clan de Teresa Rabal? Tweet

post.title: "Someone Like You" on Music Monday
post.summary: On Music Mondays you will find that I listen to a variety of music. I listen to everything from punk rock, to Christian Radio, to Country, to Classical...basically if the lyrics and sound is amazing, I'm in. I love music! I have internalized music my whole life. They've marked memorable moments in my life. So What's The Song? "Some One Like You " By Adele This is one of those songs that make you sound good belting out in the shower. Ugh, I love Adele. And the funny thing is, I didn't realize how long she's actually been around. I used to listen to this song in high school from the Movie My Best Friend's Wedding called "To Make You Feel My Love" and she did her own rendition of it in 2008. I think she sings it better. Anyway, my all time favorite line in this song is "We were born and raised in a summer haze" , just makes visualize running thru a field of sunflowers and daisies. Such beautiful, visual lyrics. If you don't have spotify, listen on Youtube and read the lyrics: "Someone Like You" I heard that you're settled down That you found a girl and you're married now. I heard that your dreams came true. Guess she gave you things I didn't give to you. Old friend, why are you so shy? Ain't like you to hold back or hide from the light. I hate to turn up out of the blue uninvited But I couldn't stay away, I couldn't fight it. I had hoped you'd see my face and that you'd be reminded That for me it isn't over. Never mind, I'll find someone like you I wish nothing but the best for you too Don't forget me, I beg I remember you said, "Sometimes it lasts in love but sometimes it hurts instead, Sometimes it lasts in love but sometimes it hurts instead" You know how the time flies Only yesterday was the time of our lives We were born and raised In a summer haze Bound by the surprise of our glory days I hate to turn up out of the blue uninvited But I couldn't stay away, I couldn't fight it. I'd hoped you'd see my face and that you'd be reminded That for me it isn't over. Never mind, I'll find someone like you I wish nothing but the best for you too Don't forget me, I beg I remember you said, "Sometimes it lasts in love but sometimes it hurts instead." Nothing compares No worries or cares Regrets and mistakes They are memories made. Who would have known how bittersweet this would taste? Never mind, I'll find someone like you I wish nothing but the best for you too Don't forget me, I beg I remember you said, "Sometimes it lasts in love but sometimes it hurts instead." Never mind, I'll find someone like you I wish nothing but the best for you too Don't forget me, I beg I remember you said, "Sometimes it lasts in love but sometimes it hurts instead, Sometimes it lasts in love but sometimes it hurts instead Other music that is a must on my playlist: What's on your Spotify Playlist or what are you listening to on Itunes or Pandora these days? Link it up or comment below: Every Monday! *Come back and share til Wednesday! Linky is open til Midnight Wednesday! :)* Get the code for your own post: get the InLinkz code Author: Heather Wife, Mother of Two Boys, Coffee Addict, Pinterest obsessed, an aspiring writer balancing every day life of raising a family and blogging about it. If you like what you just read, consider casting a one click vote ;)

post.title: American Gods, Shakespeare's Sonnets, Les Miserables, Game of Thrones
post.summary: It's been a long time since my last update, but this is not because I haven't been reading. I've been dabbling, with four books on the go at once. A lot of people say to me, "I can't do that. Don't you get confused?" Well, no, not when one is a weird sprawling fantasy, one is poetry, one is an enormous classic and the other a thriller, or a book of geek wisdom. I tend not to read more than one book in each genre at a time, but of course it takes longer to finish any one of these books. The main book that has taken up my attention the last couple of weeks is my third reading of American Gods. As I may have mentioned before, I rather love Neil Gaiman as a storyteller, as well as a master of the English language. American Gods, being a messy sprawling epic, takes several reads to fully appreciate, and on my first attempt I confess I only liked it, didn't love it. It's complicated, with a lot going on, and it makes more sense every time. When you know what's going on in the overall shape of the plot, you can pick up on details that made no sense or impression the first time around.Â It was only on my most recent reading of American Gods that I noticed the character who just does not stick in the memory. Just as Shadow will look away from him and forget what he looks like, I would think, "that's odd - I expect his identity will be cleared up later," turn the page and not notice when the book provides no answer - his memory-erasing powers coming off the page and affecting even this reader. Now I've noticed his presence, I want to know who he is. I feel I ought to know, but the internet provides no answers, only pet theories. Also, when I knew what Mister Wednesday's overall intentions are, I found myself looking out for the moments when events digress from his plan, wondering just how different American Gods could have been had Shadow made different choices along the way.Â I recently found an excellent Complete Oxford Shakespeare in three volumes second-hand in a charity shop in Hythe. Each volume is a reasonable sized book, and what's more unusual for a Complete Shakespeare, the print is a good size, fond and clarity for actually reading! I decided to read through all of the sonnets in order and have just passed #100. Everybody knows the famous ones - #18 and #130, and #116 if you're a fan of the Sense and Sensibility movie with Kate Winslet - but it's a different experience to read in sequence. I don't know if the order the sonnets are published in is Shakespeare's or someone else's, but they read rather as one long poem in many verses than individual poems. Sonnets in the sequence share themes and imagery, and sometimes don't even stand alone well, following on from the previous sonnet with a "So" or a "But" or an "Or." Â It might not be common knowledge that only sonnets #127-154 are written about a woman, and even these are far from traditional love poems ("My mistress' eyes are nothing like the sun," indeed!) The majority of the sequence, including "Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?" are actually addressed to a beautiful young man. Whether or not the poems are autobiographical, the nature of the relationship and the identity of the "fair youth" are, as most details about Shakespeare's life, all unknown, but the sonnets chart the complexities of love, the ups and downs of human relationships over a stretch of time, and perhaps the unhealthy power of infatuation - let me reiterate that Shakespeare wrote 126 sonnets to this chap!Â (There's an idea for a scholarly essay!) I'm one of those people who likes to insist upon reading a book before seeing a film or TV adaptation based upon it, but I did not manage to read more than a few chapters of Les Miserables before seeing the film of the stage musical. Nor had I been to see the stage show, so all I knew was that Jean Valjean was on the run from the law after having spent many years imprisoned for stealing bread, that it is set during the French Revolution, and that a lot of characters die. I also, of course, knew several of the songs reasonably well. I know the rest of them now, having listened to the soundtrack on Spotify a couple of times - although it is a travesty that on Highlights of Les Miserables, the song I felt to be the highight, "Do you hear the people sing?" was missing. Of course, there are other versions available, from various London and Broadway soundtracks.Â The performances were fantastic, with an excellent cast of actors with decent singing skills - although I preferred the chorus numbers to the solos, probably because of the harmonies and the power in a crowd of voices. I understand that the songs were recorded live on set rather than overdubbed in a studio later, which was a brave decision and added a level of authenticity to the film. Anne Hathaway's raw, anguished rendition of "I dreamed a dream" was haunting. The song is often used to show off a strong voice, while the movie took a different approach. Film acting and singing requires different things to acting and singing in a theatre. On the stage, actors have to make their emotions and words as big and clear as possible so as to fill the entire theatre and leave no one in any doubt about what is going on. The camera, on the other hand, gets right in close to the actors, allowing for more subtlety of expression, and I defy you to find many classically-trained singers who can hold a tune (especially that long "shame" in "I dreamed a dream") while a blubbering, snotty mess.Â Where Les Mis fell down a little was, I felt, a result of compressing a 1200-page brick of a book into two and a half hours. The film rushed through some of the characters who would have benefitted from more screen time - Hathaway's "Fantine" is hardly in it, although the time she does spend on the screen is incredible. Some plot points could benefit from more elaboration, and I loathed the romance, if you can call it that, between Marius and Cosette. They see each other twice, speak once, and all of a sudden, they have found the reason for living and can't bear to be apart. I'm sure the novel will have handled it better - it had better, with 1200 pages. In the film, the love story felt forced and was particularly jarring when in the middle of the student revolution-planning-meeting,Â ("Red! The blood of angry men.Â Black! The dark of ages past.Red! The world about to dawn.Black! The night that ends at last.")Marius would go off all mushy about his "love."Â "Red! I feel my world on fire.Black! My world if she's not there.Red! The colour of desire!Black! The colour of despair."You don't even know her!Â There is a time and a place, son, and this is not it - let's see if you survive your protest on the barricade before deciding to live happily ever after with this girl you saw this afternoon. I wish them a long, long life together. This bit contains a Season one/A Game of Thrones spoiler After reading George R R Martin's Song of Ice and Fire series last year, I have debated with myself whether or not to watch the HBO series, Game of Thrones. Eventually I borrowed the first season from a friend, but even as I put on the first DVD, I wasn't sure whether or not I would want to watch it. I had images in my mind of how the characters and places should look, and also I was a bit anxious about getting caught up in that story world for a second time. It is one of those stories that grabs the imagination and doesn't let go, which is both exhilarating and sometimes a bit scary when it comes to be time to face the real world again. These doubts were gone before the first set of credits after the prologue. It was interesting to relive the beginning of the story knowing what was to come. Reading the book, I had liked Eddard Stark, set up to be the hero, well enough - he's a decent chap with honour and values, but not the most exciting character in literature. But Sean Bean excels in the role, and I felt that Ned was an admirable, solid man, a good egg in a basket of bad apples - sorry for the mixed metaphor! - who held the world of Westeros together. It is, after all, after his death that everything starts to fall apart. I also started noticing the number of times one character would say "We will speak about X subject when we meet again." Of course, this is a guarantee that they will never meet again. Putting faces to names changed the way I viewed some of the characters. Many of the worst villains of the book actually evoked some pity in me, notably Queen Cersei and even the ghastly Joffrey. On the other hand, designated heroes irritated me when on screen, notably Jon Snow. I had expected Daenerys Targaryen to have that effect, but in fact she grew on me as her character evolved.

post.title: The Rite of Spring - 100 Years On
post.summary: With the climate as it is in arts and music now, it is difficult to imagine the full extent of shock and rage unleashed on the night of May 29th, 1913. At the ThÃ©Ã¢tre des Champs-Ã‰lysÃ©es, Stravinsky's Le Sacre du Printemps, The Rite of Spring, was receiving its first staging. It is no exaggeration to say what followed changed the course of 20th century music. In the third chapter of his book The Rest Is Noise Alex Ross sets the scene brilliantly, recalling how even Diaghilev was nervous at rehearsals when he became aware of the content. Technically this music is remarkably difficult to get right, its rhythmic complexities doubled with the composer's writing for instruments on the edge of their capabilities. Difficult for dancers too, which would only have heightened the tension at the famously scandalous premiere. Since the Rite's reception history is well documented, it is interesting to look at how Decca have stolen a march on their competitors by issuing two sets to mark the anniversary. The first is a potentially grueling but probably ultimately fascinating 20CDs of alternative versions of the ballet, moving from Eduard van Beinum's 1946 Concertgebouw recording through to Gustavo Dudamel's 2010 offering with the SimÃ³n BÃ³livar Orchestra. The second is a rather more palatable four discs that offers six versions, from Pierre Monteux in 1956 through to Esa-Pekka Salonen in 2006, together with an audio documentary that takes us back to the night in Paris. The recordings chosen for this smaller release could have been more varied, however, for they weigh down heavily on the side of the digital era. Not that any of those recordings are bad, but they are quite similar, and show how although technical prowess in orchestral performance is probably at an all time high, there is a propensity on the part of conductors and studio engineers to highlight technical brilliance over musical expression. I would have preferred to have heard Ernest Ansermet, who knew Stravinsky well, along with Sir Colin Davis and Claudio Abbado, whose versions are on the bigger set. Boulez is the right inclusion, though, and the detail he secures in his reading is remarkable, coupled with a composer's understanding of how the piece works. The big version that is missing from this set, of course, is the composer himself â€“ for Sony hold the rights to that particular version. Thanks to Spotify, that was the obvious place to start, and the speed of his own interpretation is striking. The intensity is remarkable too, with a terrifying climax to the Round Dance and in the Chosen Victim, where the sheer weight of percussion is given a sharp, brassy edge. Time and again Stravinsky pushes the music forward with a ferocious inevitability, portraying the terrible fate of the dancer chosen to dance herself to death. After hearing the composer's own thoughts, the documentary is a good place to begin the Decca listening. Written and narrated by Jon Tolansky, it brings together some interesting strands of fact and comment on the ballet and its first performance. It begins by recounting Stravinsky's vision of a girl dancing herself to death as the culmination of a pagan ritual â€“ the inspiration for the ballet â€“ and progresses to interviews with Sir Colin Davis, Bernard Keeffe and Valery Gergiev, as well as Dame Monica Mason, who danced as the Chosen One in Sir Kenneth Macmillan's revival of the ballet in 1962. Given the technical difficulties, it would have been good to have heard from an orchestral player too, though there is some discussion on how Stravinsky's revision is much easier to follow, the composer having changed the rest values in the orchestral parts. Gergiev talks about how 'you have to imagine why it could be so scandalous', and that you have to look at 'not technical qualities but human ones, and a spiritual strength'. Those comments alone do much to explain why his version, for me, goes back to the heart of the ballet and what Stravinsky wanted to hear and see. There is an authenticity to the melodies that brings out their primal origins, especially in the melodic inflections of the woodwind, and the orchestral sounds are a little less polished, as you might expect in a pagan ritual rather than an orchestral showpiece. For that reason Gergiev trumps many modern versions, the rough-hewn edge to the St Petersburg Philharmonic meaning that performance might not always be immaculate but that the music lives and breathes with real meaning. Chailly and Salonen are very fine versions but could be admired rather than loved, the sleek machines of the Concertgebouw and LA Philharmonic Orchestras doing their job but not always conveying the manic, unhinged tale that is unfolding. The oldest version on the four discs is from Pierre Monteux, who conducted the premiere back in 1913. His 1956 recording is fascinating for that reason and many more, and he feels more in control of the music. His Auguries of Spring is a bit less ferocious, but very precise, and there is an incredibly vivid separation of Stravinsky's orchestrations three minutes in to the second part. The sound is very good, too. Antal Dorati and the Detroit Symphony Orchestra are up next, in revolutionary Mercury Living Presence stereo, the ideal climate for an orchestral spectacular such as the Rite. The sound is indeed big, chrome plated even, but the rush of strings in the 'Ritual of Abduction' is a thrill, as is the seething mass of sound in the 'Dance of the Earth', over which the trumpets sound their fanfares. The otherworldly chill at the start of the second part is as disconcerting as any version, while the end is truly an eruption, Dorati showing off his balletic prowess in a reading that never has a dull moment. An advantage of this Decca release is the price, with these six versions and documentary weighing in for little more than that of a full price CD. The care lavished on the issue is good, too, with incisive notes from Nigel Simeone. Through listening to so many versions the sense of scandal in Paris comes rushing back, the sheer boldness and rebelliousness of Stravinsky's approach taking no prisoners and laid bare once again â€“ as no doubt he would have wanted it to be on its 100th anniversary. It will be interesting to see how other record companies observe the landmark nearer to May â€“ but with what they have available, Decca have certainly done the Rite and its recorded history justice.

post.title: Inspirations
post.summary:
Some days I wish I had gotten a job somewhere other than Penn, where I was an undergraduate a mere 7 months ago, but today is not one of those days. The nonfiction writing class Iâ€™m taking is probably my favorite class at Penn so far and my staff ID allows me access to some of my favorite study spots from my time as an undergrad.Â Iâ€™m sitting in a comfortable couch on the 25th floor of a highrise dorm with a cup of coffee and an amazing view of the city.Â The sky is practically cloudless, with a few wispy white formations here and there, and I can see for miles. Iâ€™ve got Bruce Springsteen playing on Spotify and Iâ€™m feeling productive.Â These are my favorite days. For class this week weâ€™ve had to read some Susan Orlean, including excerpts from â€œThe American Man, Age 10â€³ and Iâ€™ve found it far more inspiring than I had expected.Â In her section ofÂ The New NEW Journalism she talks about how vulnerable she feels when she begins writing her pieces because sheâ€™s never 100% sure itâ€™s a good idea or that it will be a success.Â The more I think I really want to be a writer, the more scared I am that itâ€™s a bad idea and that I wonâ€™t be very good but if Susan Orlean feels that way then maybe itâ€™s a good sign that Iâ€™m feeling this way.Â Being 22 is all about vulnerability it seems. Thereâ€™s so much that has yet to be determined but this fact also allows for so many opportunities.Â No matter what we desire in this world, itâ€™s probably going to take hard work and now is the time to find our passions and hunt them down.Â Itâ€™s scary and leaves us very vulnerable but Iâ€™m starting to think I need to stop fighting it and just embrace the possibility. In addition to my reading, I was able to spend a good amount of time this weekend playing around with my camera and Photoshop.Â Iâ€™m quickly learning you canâ€™t have one without the other; Mastering my camera means incorporating some Photoshop skills into the mix so Iâ€™ve decided to work on them both at the same time. For some nice camera and Photoshop tutorials, Iâ€™ve turned once again to my idea farm: Pinterest.Â My first post on this blog was about my love for Pinterest but I canâ€™t even link to it here because Iâ€™m slightly embarrassed by my fan girl tone. Speaking of Pinterest,Â I found this quote the other day and it really stuck with me.Â Buying an expensive DSLR camera doesnâ€™t exactly fit in with my goal of putting away money in savings but I feel justified when I read this:
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Source: pinterest.com via Jessica on Pinterest
Â Â Iâ€™m taking about 100 pictures per week and theyâ€™re not all prolific pieces of art but Iâ€™d rather have too many pictures than not enough. This weekend it snowed in Philadelphia and for some reason I decided to let my cat out in the backyard to see how he liked it. Strangely enough, he really really liked it. He was pouncing on the powdery drifts and leaving his little paw prints everywhere. I had initially resisted the idea of buying a cat leash, for fear of labeling myself as a total cat lady, but I think I may need to reconsider after this weekend. Here my Photoshop and camera skills collide to capture the momentous occasion in Macâ€™s life: I would apologize for the amount of Mac photos I post but Iâ€™m sure some of you who have cats understand the difficulty that is getting your cat to sit still long enough to be photographed. I permit those of you with and without cats to judge me for the cat leash thing but Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™m not the only one whoâ€™s considered it. At the very least maybe I can get some cute cat photos out of it.

post.title: Currently listening, Jan 2013
post.summary:
1. Matthew E White â€“ Big Inner LP The Guardian havenâ€™t stopped praising Matthew E White since his debut record came out, and tempting though it is to be dismissive of such hype, itâ€™s a really brilliant LP â€“ a soulful and immaculate record with incredible arrangements and a near uncategorisable spectrum of influnces, from country, jazz, folk, gospel and soul to glimpses (if Iâ€™m right) of acid house. A genuine marvel. 2. Sexy Fi â€“ Nunca Te Vi De Boa I shanâ€™t try too hard to categorise Sexy Fi either; weird, tropical, funky, jangly, noisy pop music from Brazil. No idea who they are but really like this record! Here it is on Spotify. 3. Traams â€“ Peggy Easily the best new band I saw last year, their live sets are dominated by long, heavy, teutonic jams â€“ like Big Black channeling Neu. This song proves they can do short songs with brilliant â€˜ooh-oohâ€™ choruses, too.
4. Yo La Tengo â€“ Fade LP Iâ€™ve never listened to any Yo La Tengo records. Iâ€™ve no idea why or how Iâ€™ve managed this. This is their new one. It suggests Iâ€™ve rather missed out â€“ beautifully realised, fuzzy indie rock. 5/6. Kimbra â€“ Vows LP / Dawn Richard â€“ Goldenheart LP Two records I discovered, again, through positive Guardian album reviews. Kimbra specialises in joyful electronic pop and Dawn Richard in stylish but unshowy râ€™n'b. Both are great. 7. Masta Killah â€“ All Natural Like most Wu-afilliated records these days, Masta Killahâ€™s latest is a mixed bag, but it boasts a couple of decent songs â€“ the best by far is this, which finds the rapper deconstructing his vegetarianism. Brilliant.
8. Gerry Read â€“ Jummy LP Iâ€™m always looking for house music which endures across a full LP, and Gerry Readâ€™s subtle, shifting, four-to-the-floor house music is the closest Iâ€™ve found to what I like in a long time. 9. Viv Albertine â€“ The Vermilion Border LP If Iâ€™d have listened to this a lot more in 2012 it would have featured quite highly in my records of the year list; itâ€™s fucking brilliant â€“ a smart, sassy, sexy LP from the former Slits guitarist. This should percolate far and wide, if thereâ€™s any justice.
10. Keel Her â€“ You Would Be So Grossed Out If I Did That Still not many official releases from the unbelievably prolific, and now Brighton-based, Keel Her (she releases new tracks online all the time); but her recent single â€˜Riot Grrrlâ€™ is her best release yet. A proper recording of this slightly wonky acoustic song is the (terrific) b-side.
11. Stealing Sheep â€“ Into the Diamond Sun LP I saw Stealing Sheep live loads in 2010 and 2011, and once last year, and while they were terrific every time, their sets seemed pretty similar, meaning that by the time their debut LP came out last year, I thought I had figured them out, and didnâ€™t get round to buy a copy. Consequently, I didnâ€™t spot how bloody great it is â€“ much more joyful, tuneful and poppy than I remember them being live, and a really great summer record. Really glad I finally figured that out.

Roku â€œâ€¦RokuÂ (IPA: /ËˆÉ¹oku/ pronounced â€œrohÂ kooâ€)[2] is an American, privately held, consumer electronics company that sells home digital media products. The company is based in Saratoga, California.[3]Â Roku manufactures a variety of digital media receivers that allow customers to access internet streamed video or audio services through televisions. This includes subscription-based services as well as services that are available through the receiver free of charge. Company profile The company was founded in October 2002, by ReplayTV founder Anthony Wood. Roku means â€œsixâ€ in Japanese, a reference to the six companies Wood has launched. Legacy products Rokuâ€™s consumer products line-up included:
RokuÂ SoundBridge, a network music player SoundBridge Radio, a network music player with built-in speakers and subwoofer, AMâ€‘FM receiver, volume-ramping alarm clock, preset buttons, SD slot and headphone jack PhotoBridgeÂ HD1000, a system for displaying images on a high-definition television, as well as streaming MPEG video. The unit has four card readers on the front and can read from Memory Stick, MultiMediaCard, SD Memory Card, SmartMediaÂ Card, CompactFlash Card type II.
Roku also produced:
the BrightSign solid-state media player, designed to drive HD displays in a retail environment.
Rokuâ€™sÂ audio products did not use internal storage but rely on Wi-Fi or Ethernet to stream digital audio over a network, either from Internet radio or a computer attached to the same network. RokuÂ introduced the Radio RokuÂ Internet radio directory in August 2007. Radio RokuÂ provides a directory of Internet stations, accessible from a web browser or from SoundBridge players. Digital video player On May 20, 2008, RokuÂ announced the first Netflix Internet video streaming receiver box, the RokuÂ DVP. The NXP-powered device runs Linux.[4]
The XD/S has HDMI and component output for high-definition video on new and older televisions.
Prior to Autumn 2010, three versions of the RokuÂ DVPÂ were available: the RokuÂ SD, HD, and HD-XR.[5]Â The Roku SD only streams standard definition (SD) content.[6]Â The Roku HD streams both SD and HD (720p) content.[7]Â The RokuÂ SD and HD both have an Ethernet connection and built in 802.11g Wiâ€‘Fi compatible with wireless B, G, and N routers.[8]Â Their third box was the RokuÂ HD-XR, which streams both SD and HD (720p and 1080p) content, has built in dual-band 802.11n WiFi support, and has a USB port on the back.[9] In 2010, RokuÂ revamped its lineup of devices: the revised HD is the basic model of the line, offering 720p resolution, 802.11g WiFi reception (as well as an Ethernet connection), and an HDMIÂ output. The middle of the line, the XD, adds 1080p resolution (if channel programmers provide it), an enhanced remote with replay capabilities, and single-band wireless N WiFi. The flagship XD|S offers the same feature set as the XD but also adds component video and optical audio outputs, dual-band wireless N, and a USB port for playing videos, photos, and music (USB Playback Support is available as of February 1, 2011).[10][11] On July 20, 2011, Roku updated its product lineup with three new boxes, each in the same price range as before. However, the Ethernet connection and remote with motion control for games are available only on the XS model.[12][13]Â The RokuÂ Game Remote uses Hillcrest Labsâ€™ Freespace motion control technology, so users can control games with natural gestures.[14]Â The Netflix application was revamped for the RokuÂ 2 HD, RokuÂ 2 XD and Roku 2 XS. The current models now provide the option of subtitles, when the program provides this aid.[15] On October 29, 2012, the feature â€œRokuÂ Searchâ€ was added. This feature allows users to search movie and TV show titles, actors and directors for multiple services on RokuÂ such as Netflix, Amazon Instant Video and HBO Go. The feature is only available on RokuÂ 2, RokuÂ Streaming Stick, Roku LT and HD, due to technical constraints on earlier models.[16] Feature comparison

â€¡ The Bluetooth module is for the game remote. â€ The comÂ­ponÂ­ent video connector on the RokuÂ XDS (2100X) is a nonstandard 3.5mm connector and a proprietary adapter cable, which is sold separately, is effectively required to use this.[28]
Also see Rokuâ€™s product comparison table. Â Online Roku channels Content on the RokuÂ DVPÂ is provided by RokuÂ partners, and are identified using the â€œchannelâ€ vernacular. Each separate channel supports content from one partner though some content partners have more than one channel. Users can add or remove different channels from the RokuÂ Channel Store. In May 2011, Roku stated the DVPÂ had over one million viewers and had delivered 15 million channel downloads. Both on-demand content and live streaming are supported by the devices. For live TV streams, Roku supports Apple HLS (HTTP Live Streaming) adaptive streaming technology. The primary movie channels which are available on Roku in the U.S. market are suppressed in Canada. Service creation for Roku Player The Roku is an open-platform device with a freely available SDK that enables anyone to create new channels.[29]Â The channels are written in a Roku-specificÂ language called BrightScript, a scripting language the company calls â€œsimilar to Visual Basicâ€.[30] Developers who wish to test their channels before a general release, or who wish to limit viewership, can create â€œprivateâ€ channels that require a code be entered by the user in the account page of the RokuÂ website. These private channels, which are not part of the official RokuÂ Channel Store, are not reviewed or approved by Roku.[31] There is a NDKÂ (Native Developer Kit) available, though it has added restrictions â€“ see RokuÂ developer question â€œHow do I develop games for Roku?â€[30] Services listing Partial list of services currently available through the Roku Channel Store.[32][33] Free channels

post.title: Sunday to Sunday
post.summary: Normal 0 false false false MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 Sunday 20th January 2013 Up early to get ready â€“ shave, poems for Scratch Tyne rehearsal. Saw Jenni for an hour but she was tired so didnâ€™t come along. It was an interesting session. Got some feedback on new work and saw some wonderful performances. Hardly any snow in Newcastle. Threat of more this evening though. 8.15pm bus home. Felt dizzy and drained after walking in the snow. Pork pies, peanut butter on toast. Bovril, Vimto. 10.25pm. Monday 21st January 2013 Knew the moment I rolled up the blind and looked out at all the white â€“ cars, walls, paths and roads â€“ that thereâ€™d be no Lamplight Open Mic tonight. I phoned Leisureworks and it was greed that weâ€™d give it a miss. Loads of schools s closed. Hope it clears a bit later in the week. Looking forward to slams on Thursday and Friday. Spent a lot of time on my own writing today, found prep for workshops hard going. Itâ€™ll all come clear in the morning. The house is like an oven but the temperature drops like a stone soon as you switch the heating off. Avoiding clichÃ© â€“ thereâ€™s an exercise we can revisit. I want to find the time to read but canâ€™t seem to settle into it. Years on the net has made me impatient. Need to get used to not using the computer so much. Havenâ€™t been across the doorstep today. I bet tomorrow is hilarious. At least I donâ€™t need to be out first thing. Watched an episode of Lewis this evening. Going to try to read in bed for a while. 10.20pm. Tuesday 22nd January 2013 After a pretty lethargic day at the computer a good edit session downstairs at the old drop-leaf table. I didnâ€™t go to Durham today, no V8 buses and still very snowy in Moorside. Wrote to a photographer in Tel Aviv this afternoon in hopes of being able to use one of her image for a book cover. Fingers crossed. Listened to Adam Ant is the Blueblack Hussar in Marrying the Gunnerâ€™s Daughter on Spotify this afternoon. Apart from one or two tracks I thought it was pretty good. Enjoyed listening to the really early White Sox era material as well. Was good to talk to Mam and Ernie today. Think I nailed a poem this evening. 10.28pm. Wednesday 23rd January 2013 A seven oâ€™clock check of Go North eastâ€™s website led me to believe the bus would be at the top of Derby Drive at ten past eight. Half an hour later I was dodging cars and lorries as I walked up the main road to Consett. And then the Durham bus was quarter of an hour late. Waddy session went well regardless. A couple of new recruits in. Six hour round trip.Didnâ€™t do much this evening. Watched some music videos, listened to some eighties rock, read a few political articles. Do I need to be specific, I donâ€™t think so. Too tired to work on the book this evening. 10.54pm. Thursday 24th January 2013 A good end to a rather lethargic day. SLAMalgamate was a great spoken word event. Pleased there was such a great turnout for it. 14 slammers reduced to eight to four to Jeff Potts and AJ Mckenna. Both did extremely well but AJ had the edge. I bought AJâ€™s pamphlet A Lady of a Certain Rage. It was a spoken word slam so not strictly all poetry but poetry came out on top. I did the scores and time-keeping and filmed the whole event. Jenni did a great job of hosting it. Rowan McCabeÂ got a shockingly low score for what I thought was one of the best poems of the night. Looking forward to seeing him do it again in the near future. On the way home me and Jenni stopped off at the chippy in Gateshead. I got a pie. And some juice for tomorrow morning. Thanks to Jenni for putting on great night. 11.50pm. Friday 25th January 2013 At last check before leaving Gateshead this lunchtime I had over fifty birthday greetings from Facebook friends. Jenni bought me some lovely things: tickets to see the band Zombie Killers at Washington Arts Centre next month; Look Around You â€“ a comedy science DVD, a gift voucher for carveries at The Goose and six bottles of Juice Burst black currant drink which taste like raw jelly chunks; a vinyl to mp3 turntable and Self Loathing Ostrich Tragedy â€“ Stephen Barnabyâ€™s book of fifty word epics; a pair of Stewie socks that say I HATE THIS PLACE â€“ made me laugh out loud; got a tin to save my book pennies in and some sweetie supplies for my emergency food tin plus a great alliterative birthday card and an â€˜I Am 5â€™ badge with a skateboarder on it. We had a mega meat six veg lunch at the Goose and a swift train journey to Edinburgh. Nowhere near as cold as forecast. Checked out the performance space at National Library of Scotland and it looks ok. 5.05pm. Good night at the slam. Only did the first round but thatâ€™s okay. It was more literary than I expected but enjoyable. Good to see Graeme Hawley do a couple of pieces. Had a chat with Kevin Cadwallender about poetry and workshops and doing what feels best for your own piece of mind. We got conflicting directions for the bus station and got there only a few minutes before it was due to leave. Havenâ€™t eaten anything since Goose carvery which is pretty impressive for me. Relieved to find a toilet onboard. 10.50pm. Saturday 26th January 2013 HUGE THANKS TO EVERYONE who sent me birthday wishes yesterday. Me and Jenni had a great time in Edinburgh at the National Library of Scotland Burns Night Grand Slam. Saw some amazingly talented poets in action and got to take to the stage briefly myself, as did Jenni with her haiku and limmerick competition pieces. Well done to everyone involved and conratulations to Rachel Amey, a worthy winner. Great to hear Graeme Hawley read again, lovely chat with Kevin Cadwallender and some of the slammers afterwards, and Sophia Walker dropped by too. Had a little bit of a late night panic trying to find the bus station for our 10.45pm coach home but made it with a few minutes to spare. Had a lengthy creative discussion on the way back and were scoffing pizza and chips from Clayton Street Chippy in Newcastle by 1.35pm this morning. No snow on the ground in Edinburgh - think the forecasters were telling fibs. Whereas a day later, back in Moorside, still can't get moved for the stuff. Cheers! Dropped my case off around twenty past three this afternoon then back into Consett for food shopping. A lazy day at home with Jenni. Read Stephen Barnabyâ€™s chapbook this morning, a bit of AJ Mckenna this evening. Too tired to form a cohesive paragraph. Pleased I donâ€™t have to go outside tomorrow. Bed soon. 10.45pm. Sunday 27th January 2013Â Lovely to have a visit from Mam and Ernie this afternoon â€“ although for Jenni it did mean temporarily changing out of her tiger suit. Got a great belated birthday present: a hand made book press. Been after one of these for months. This will be great for glueing up perfect bound book and flattening pamphlets. Bit of a catch-up day today. Next poetry gig for me is a double-header with Jenni back in Edinburgh on 6th February at Kevin Cadwallenderâ€™s Tenor Bull 10 Red. 9.03pm.
post.blogName: STEVE URWIN 2013 - SCRIBBLES FROM THE BRINK OF INERTIA

post.title: Nokia Music+ Streaming Service
post.summary:
In an effort to better compete with Spotify and other music services, Nokia announced on Sunday it is expanding its free music streaming service with an enhanced paid version of its existing Nokia Music platform.
Nokia Music â€” the ad-free service launched in September, exclusively to Lumia smartphone users â€” will now offer a monthly subscription option called Nokia Music+ for about $3.99, depending on location. Spotify's subscriptions range from $4.99 to $9.99.
Although the service already allows you to download up to four one-hour mixes of music, which are playable offline, Nokia Music+ will remove the limit. It also allows you to access the service via a web app, so you can play it on your computer or smart TV, and features unlimited skips. The app is also available for download from the Windows Phone Marketplace.
"It's the only smartphone music service out there offering access to millions of songs out of the box without the need to sign up, sign in, or suffer adverts in between enjoying the music," said Jyrki Rosenberg, VP Entertainment at Nokia, in a statement on the company's blog. â€œPeople love Nokia Mix Radio â€” in fact, many people are amazed that we can offer it for free. When you add in the ability to skip songs and save playlists for offline uses like the tube, you have something unique."
The company said Nokia Music+ will roll out in the next few weeks, but it's unknown at this point when it will come to the U.S.

post.title: SingalongSundays
post.summary: So at the beginning of the week i thought i had the perfect song for this week but just an hour ago i heard this song and it has been on repeat. Okay..don't judge it because of the stupid trend #YOLO i know most people hate it or like it, itsÂ controversialÂ but this song is great and catchy. I would think that this is going to be a song circling for a while since it's been on SNL (SaturdayÂ night live). This weeks song is: YOLO by The Lonely Island ft. Adam Levine and Kendrick Lamar By far my favourite song from The Lonely Island and also this was a great collabaration from Adam Levine and Kendrick Lamar who are both great at rapping and singing. I give this a 9/10 (: If you didn't like this song and wanted to know my first choice before this well it was: Already There by John West ft. Big Sean Problem with this song is that the only good version of this song that you can hear is the music video because there are no lyric videos on youtube, its not on itunes or spotify but if you guys get the chance to hear it let me know what you think.Â The closest i can get is this remix: 10/10 Enjoy (:

post.title: Carpe Noctem
post.summary: Toda seÃ±orita debe cultivar su vida social. Continuamente tengo que inaugurar pantanos, pasearme por ferias caritativas o subastar mis clÃ­nex; pero lo que mÃ¡s me gusta son las reuniones nocturnas,tambiÃ©n muy importantes. Por ello, es frecuente verme en los locales con mÃ¡s glamour de mi ciudad. Mi sÃ©quito de amigas siempre me acompaÃ±a para hacer el conocido efecto grupo: si ves en conjunto a un grupo de chicas siempre parecen mÃ¡s espectaculares que viÃ©ndolas una a una. Evidentemente ellas son las Ãºnicas beneficiadas, ya que yo brillo con luz propia. Todas mis noches son especiales, pero aquella fue legenâ€¦ daria. El ritual de preparaciÃ³n de la noche empezÃ³ a primera hora de la maÃ±ana. La manicura, pedicura y acupuntura siempre son bÃ¡sicas para una buena velada. Mis ratones habÃ­an estado hasta la madrugada cosiÃ©ndome algo bonito, y Rosalina caminÃ³ hasta el alba con mis Jimmy Choo nuevos para darlos de sÃ­. DespuÃ©s de verme varios videoclips de BeyoncÃ© para aprender pasos rompepistas y revisarme toda la actualidad â€“mi misiÃ³n en la vida es romper el tÃ³pico de que las rubias son tontas- se me hicieron las 9 de la noche, y tenÃ­a que salir. HabÃ­amos quedado a las 00:00 y por alguna razÃ³n lleguÃ© a la 1. Cuando una chica va con tiempo siempre pasa algo para que acabe llegando tarde. Para mi sorpresa una de mis amigas venÃ­a con un vestido muy parecido al mÃ­o, pero no pasÃ³ nada: siempre llevo un modelito de repuesto en el bolso, asÃ­ que se lo di y le dije que se cambiara.Â A otra la mandÃ© directamente a casa, no sin antes llamar a Plain Jane para que transformara a esa chica con potencial en una mujer con poder. Kim Kardashian se retrasÃ³ un poco por intentar entrar en una 38 con su pandero. Pese a todo no se lo tuvimos en cuenta. Bueno, un poco sÃ­ y le tocÃ³ ser la amiga simpÃ¡tica. Primero dimos un par de vueltas en mi Hummer rosa hasta coger el puntillo mientras veÃ­amos a los pobretones hacer botellÃ³n a la intemperie y le tirÃ¡bamos cacahuetes.Â Litros y litros de champagne con virutas de oro â€“mano de santo para la resaca- resbalaban por nuestra delicada garganta. Muchos se nos acercaban a pedir vasos, pero como comprenderÃ©is no voy a dejar beber por el Santo Grial a nadie. TambiÃ©n observamos como las mÃ¡s chonis se acercaban a fotografiarse. Como me sentÃ­a generosa le comprÃ© a una un par de paquetes de clÃ­nex para que se sacara unos eurillos esa noche para sus gastos. Otro embarazo no deseado que se evita gracias a la Pepis. Una alfombra roja por toda la carretera nos guiaba hasta la discoteca. No sabÃ©is el frÃ­o que se siente cuando conduces sobre asfalto al estar acostumbrada a estos caprichitos. Cuando llegamos los paparazzis se abalanzaron sobre nosotras con sus flashes, pero Mariano Di Vaio me agarrÃ³ por mi cintura de avispa â€“nacÃ­ sin costillas flotantes- y los apartÃ³ a la vez que decÃ­a: -Dientes, dientes, que es lo que les jode. Una vez dentro fuimos a la zona VIP, Very Important Pepis, a tomar otra botellita. La cuestiÃ³n es que no sÃ© si fueron las burbujas, que en los anuncios siempre se ven muy activas, o que me la bebÃ­ yo entera, que del subidÃ³n me salÃ­ del reservado y me mezclÃ© con la plebe. Fue como viajar en el tiempo, ya que toda la ropa era de temporadas pasadas. Me sentÃ­a en el armario de mi abuela. Botas por las rodilla, pantalones cortos rojos, zapatos blancos de punta, chaquetas toreras de licra (Hello?), collares de bolas, chalecos, camisetas masculinas con escoteâ€¦ Â Incluso habÃ­a chicas que salÃ­an de vaqueros, lo que hacÃ­a difÃ­cil diferenciarlas de los hombres. Pese a todo, yo me sentÃ­a en mi salsa, una salsa cuyo ingrediente principal era el alcohol -consumido de manera responsable por supuesto- y bailaba con unos y con otros. EmpecÃ© con el tango de Roxanne. Pero pocos me supieron seguir, asÃ­ que pasÃ© al estilo â€œme atuso el pelo mientras me muevo lentamente porque sÃ© lo sexy e irresistible que soyâ€.Â Los chicos se me acercaban a puÃ±ados â€“chÃºpate esa efecto Axe- y me daban vueltas y mÃ¡s vueltas, por lo que tuve que ir al baÃ±o a tomarme una Biodramina. AprovechÃ© para retocarme y hacer amigas, porque otra cosa no, pero el baÃ±o de mujeres tiene mucha actividad social. Cuando me reincorporÃ© a la fiesta se me acercÃ³ un chico que comenzÃ³ a bailar como si se estuviera tocando a sÃ­ mismo. LlamÃ© a seguridad rÃ¡pidamente. Pervertidos a mÃ­ NO. Al rato un oriental se me acercÃ³ ofreciÃ©ndome algo: -Oooooh gracias! Nunca me habÃ­an regalado tantas rosas, gafas, gorros y llaveros que no cumplen la normativa de seguridad de la UniÃ³n Europea. -Un eulo. -Yo Pepis, encantada. -No seÃ±olita, si tÃº quelel compral yo vendel pol 1 eulo. -Â¡Pero quÃ© desfachatez! Con todo lo que apoyÃ© al cine japonÃ©s viendo Mulan. No me quise calentar, y me fui a dar una vuelta. Miraba a mi alrededor puntuando a los chicos â€“ninguno pasaba del notable raspadete- cuando vi a un 9, claramente desubicado. Me insinuÃ© como sabemos hacer las mujeres, que es ponerse a bailar provocativamente â€“pero elegante a la par- con una desconocida, en una competiciÃ³n clara por llamar la atenciÃ³n, digna de un documental de la 2: â€œalgo quiere la coneja cuando mueve las orejasâ€. Mi 9 se dio cuenta enseguida, y se fue acercando bailando tambiÃ©n. Pero no sÃ© si tenÃ­a algÃºn tic nervioso que lo hacÃ­a como si pegara al aire, y mientras se acercaba el 9 pasÃ³ a 8, a 7, y finalmente a 6. AsÃ­ que antes de seguir la cuenta atrÃ¡s me curÃ© en salud y fui a pasarle mi lista Spotify Premium al DJ. No me lo podÃ­a creer, Â¡era Mario Vaquerizo! Le dije que me encantaban sus bragas, que eran las mismas que tenÃ­a yo, y que poca gente las llevaba con tanta masculinidad. Estuve un buen rato bailando con Ã©l. PaquirrÃ­n llegÃ³ con su retraso, pero puntual, y yo me volvÃ­ a bajar a la dance floor cual Madonna. Lo bien que se lo puede pasar una sola. Vi un montÃ³n de abrigos y bolsos camuflados por las esquinas de la discoteca, asÃ­ que los recogÃ­ y los dejÃ© todos en un sitio que ponÃ­a ropero, que ellos se hicieran cargo. De nada. De repente anunciaron una actuaciÃ³n especial de unas gogÃ³s con serpientes. Me alejÃ© no fuera a ser que mi bolso fuera familiar de alguna, no sin antes advertir a esas muchachitas de que se habÃ­an olvidado la ropa en el camerino. Por ahÃ­ habÃ­a tambiÃ©n una despedida de soltera que llevaban esas diademas con pililillas que en alguna ocasiÃ³n se usan para sacarte el pelo de delante de la cara cuando estÃ¡s por casa. No hay diademas con genitales femeninos porque parecerÃ­a un hachazo. Los pies me empezaron a doler, necesitaba alcohol rÃ¡pido. Una mano saliÃ³ de entre la multitud y me dijo: -Â¡TÃº! -Y yo! -Vivamos el momento! Me gustaba su sentido del humor asÃ­ que bajÃ© la guardia unos segundos. Se me acercÃ³ y me dijo que era la mÃ¡s guapa de toda la discoteca â€“el primer chico que lo dice de verdad- y que sabÃ­a que no era digno de mi belleza -algo cierto tambiÃ©n pero Â¿quiÃ©n lo es?-. Me empezÃ³ a mirar cada vez mÃ¡s fijamente, lo que me hizo ponerme nerviosa y saquÃ© mi polvera por si tenÃ­a alguna virutilla de oro entre los dientes. Eso no era, pero el chico continuaba, Â¿serÃ­a miope? A mÃ­ la tÃ©cnica de ligar haciendo sentir incÃ³moda a la chica hasta que no tiene mÃ¡s remedio que liarse con Ã©l nunca me convenciÃ³ mucho, pero no se podÃ­a negar su efectividad. Se me fue acercando y me susurrÃ³ al oÃ­do: -Te voy a matarâ€¦ Un escalofrÃ­o recorriÃ³ mi espinazo. Se me fue toda la tonterÃ­a de golpe y ya tenÃ­a mi spray antiviolador apuntando a sus ojos de enajenado cuando aÃ±adiÃ³: -â€¦.del gusto No hubo marcha atrÃ¡s despuÃ©s de esa frase ya se habÃ­a sentenciado: contigo no, bicho.Â Me fui, lejos, arrastrando los pies y desorientada, muy desorientada. Me apoyÃ© en la barra, mojÃ¡ndome entera, como es costumbre, y un chico me invitÃ³ a una copa que aceptÃ© y huÃ­ con ella como alma que lleva el diablo. Al darle el primer sorbo me saliÃ³ mi primera urticaria en los labios. Era garrafÃ³n. Lo escupÃ­ rÃ¡pidamente y sin querer alcancÃ© con mi saliva a una chica que no sabrÃ­a decir si bailaba o intentaba mantenerse en pie. El caso es que se girÃ³ hacia mÃ­ con cara de pocos amigos. -Tampoco te pongas asÃ­, que esa chaqueta es sintÃ©tica por mucho estampado de leopardo que tenga. LevantÃ³ su mano y yo sÃ³lo pude cerrar los ojos esperando la inminente colisiÃ³n. 3 segundos. 5 segundos. 10 segundos. No pasaba nada. Cuando abrÃ­ los ojos mi Mariano Di Vaio estaba sujetando a esa bÃ¡rbara. Le dije â€œSÃ¡lvameâ€ y me sacÃ³ en brazos como el caballero que es. Supongo que la moraleja de todo esto es que no importa de la clase social que seas siempre y cuando vuelvas a casa con los de la tuya. O que el garrafÃ³n saca lo peor que llevamos dentro. O que los chicos mÃ¡s raros son los que se acercan primero. O que no hace falta mÃ¡s que una misma para pasÃ¡rselo bien. O que ante cualquier adversidad, lo mejor de todo es mantener la calma y quitarse la camiseta.

post.title: Chapter 8-10
post.summary: That's right! I have written chapters 4-10 in two days! Today, I started on chapter 8 and just finished chapter 10! Okay, so I know there is a lot to add in and edit etc but there was loads more to do when I neared the end of the last part! This part of the novel is 12 chapters long! I can't believe I'm almost there! I've got to be over half way through the whole book now! It took many months to write the first part of the novel - okay, so it was the hardest bit to write and we knew it would be before we even started it...but still...many months! It has taken me about 2 weeks to write this part! And this part is longer! The first part is 9 chaps and this is 12! This isÂ definitelyÂ a very proud moment for me :) I'll be able to finish the next to chapters easily! I could finish them tonight but I am a bit emotionally exhausted Â after writing three very hard-hitting and emotional chapters. It's always felt like I've gone through the ordeals I describe, myself. Can I carry on tonight? I'm not sure. I guess I could give it a try... And now, I have decided you need some music to keep you all happy :) I am very happy at the moment (especially because of the gorgeous weather we had today! Clear blue skies and fresh windy air!) and want to spread the happiness :) http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0gTmSG7id9c I was there!!! :) Now go and listen to the rest of their music on spotify/youtube/however you can! NOW! :) M. x

post.title: Towers and Future History - Bandcamp vs. Soundcloud
post.summary: There are a number of low-cost or no-cost audio streaming sites available to Indie bands. The most popular are Spotify, Soundcloud and Bandcamp. The bands prefer thatÂ everyone use Spotify, because artistsÂ  are paid with each play of their music (although a VERY small amount per play). Â But not every blog reader wants Spotify installed on a personal computer or feels comfortable with programs executing from a website. Â  Â Â Â Â  As a blog reader, there are advantagesÂ to Soundcloud. Sometimes the waveforms are interesting or useful in navigation through a song.Â Â And a simple â€œmouse clickâ€ is all that is required to jump to a different segment in a song, as compared to bar dragging required by Bandcamp.Â Â Best of all, if you start a Soundcloud song, it automatically pauses any partially played Soundcloud song you may have been sampling on the same page.Â Â Â Â  But Bandcamp certainly has its place.Â  Consistently, it provides high resolution streaming.Â  And sometimes bands select Bandcamp over the alternatives.Â  As two examples, in mid-2012 our Indie obsessiveness was directed atÂ two songs by bands from Toronto, Canada (Towers) and Melbourne, Australia (Future History).Â  The songsÂ are included below. Â At least temporarily, they areÂ free and legal for downloadingÂ (although Towers would appreciate a tip). Surrounded By Faces by Future History Bear by Towers

Estaba encendido, los ojos le brillaban aunque no lo suficiente como para echÃ¡rseme a llorar tal que hizo hace un mes, intentÃ© calmarle, que se diera cuenta de lo que tenÃ­a, me hablÃ³ de su desahogada economÃ­a, pero no todo es economÃ­a en esta puta vida, Mariano, que no te enteras, que un tÃ­o fuerte como un roble no puede estar pelando patatas en su casa, que el personal empieza a pensar cosas raras, peligrosas...y por dedicarte a pelar patatas en tu casita puedes acabar arruinÃ¡ndote la vida. Me fui poco despuÃ©s, no sin antes despedirme de Ã©l y no sin que volviera a enseÃ±arme por el mÃ³vil su tesoooorooo... Es hermosa. Estaba tan cansado que no tardÃ© en meterme en la cama con el tercer tomo de las Obras Completas de Dostoyevski y un especial de Sir Tim OÂ´Theo que hizo los primeros honores, es un fantÃ¡stico tebeo, se nota que tiene un guionista ex-profeso...A Dosto lo leÃ­ como dicen que hacia Ã©l con la Biblia, abriÃ©ndola al azar, y caÃ­ en la entrevista entre Stavroguin y SchÃ¡tov de Demonios...me sigue gustando este tÃ­o, creÃ­a que no iba a hacerlo y volviÃ³ a atraparme como cuando era un chaval que buscaba respuestas en los libros. Me dormÃ­ leyendo el Ãºltimo capÃ­tulo de Los Hermanos Karamazov. Y hoy, aÃºn renqueante, le ha tocado el turno a un viejo conocido que el viernes discutÃ­Ã³ con su mujer y todavÃ­a anda de fiesta, o eso cree Ã©l, que no sÃ© quÃ© fiesta puede ser cuando uno estÃ¡ en ese estado, a no ser que estar de fiestaÂ sea sinÃ³nimo de olvidarte de todo, que fijo es asÃ­, pero engaÃ±ada la cabeza engaÃ±ado tu cuerpo, y tu sueÃ±o, y tu salud, y todo lo demÃ¡s...aunque nada es gratis, todo pasa factura, y mientras solo sea a ti no va mal, peor es cuando para pagar la cuenta tienes que meter por medio a tu mujer y a tus hijos...no solo tendrÃ¡s que aguantar tu mirada en el espejo cuando despiertes del sueÃ±o que creÃ­ste haber robado. Y asÃ­ han pasado los minutos del dÃ­a, que los hay tan de esa manera que se transforman en horas, y al salir a la noche ha sido como si deseara un apagÃ³n... Y sentir la negra lluvia sobre mi cabeza.

post.title: Rise
post.summary: First, some background music. I recommend "Disparate Youth" by Santigold, "Settling It Off" by Peter Wolf Crier, or "Die Slow" by Health. All are on YouTube and Spotify. But really, just pick a song that inspires you. It's cool, I can wait... OK, ready? Set. Go. You might find that life will take you on some unexpected paths. Life is going to throw you curveballs. Serious curveballs. Plans will be destroyed. Hopes and dreams quashed. I don't mean for this to depress or scare you. I mean for it to prepare you. To inspire courage in you when the proverbial ish hits the fan in your life. Because it's inevitable. What isn't inevitable is how you react. You can curl into a ball and let life kick your ass, or you can fight back. I highly suggest the latter. You might find yourself abandoned and isolated in the dead of winter, with nobody returning your phone calls, curled into a ball on the floor of an empty house, in a city you despise, with nothing but your loyal dog and a music collection you've been building since you were twelve to keep you from completely losing it. You might be hours away from your friends and family. You might hit bottom. Then you might fall through and realize that wasn't bottom. But eventually, you'll find your bottom. And it will be beautiful. It will be the most pure, innocent, inspiring place you've been since childhood. Because once you're there, you can only go up. And if you play your cards right, you'll be able to turn it into an opportunity to build the life you've always wanted. The life you've always dreamed of, instead of the life you've always settled for. "You will pay for your new soul." - Trail of the Dead At times, you might find yourself thinking that there is no hope. That's where you'll be wrong. And that's when I want you to remember this email. At that moment I want you to remember me. I want you to remember that as long as you are still breathing, then there's some life left in you, and it's your duty to fight with all you have to make it the best life possible. If you need to, email me. Call me. I'll give you my number. Because sometimes we find ourselves in the most bizarre circumstances where a complete stranger is the only one we can fathom asking our most personal questions. In your darkest moment, whenever that happens to come, I want you to conjure the warrior inside yourself, rise up, and show the world what you're made of. Fight back. Fight with gusto. Fight like your life depends on it. Because it does. And then, you might find yourself. Cheers, Chris chris@apptitudenola.com @chrisboyddotnet New Orleans, Louisiana, US

post.title: What is Hip? Tell Me Tell Me if You Think You Know
post.summary: Itâ€™s pretty easy to understand the purpose of the recent viral Facebook poll, â€œ100 Influential Albumsâ€ from the perspective of the creator. The quiz has links to buy all of those listed through Amazon, and the data mining of personal information is a goldmine. But Â the motivation behind those taking the quiz to me is much more telling. These sorts of quizzes and polls are becoming increasingly popular on the social networks as the sheer numbers of people willing to share just about anything about themselves publicly becomes a virus of its own. But why are we so drawn to these public displays of hipness? Many I imagine do so merely out of curiosity. Wanting to know what these records are and whether we may have missed something that we â€œshould haveâ€, thus filling in an empty spot in our own cultural landscape. But one could find countless other lists that could help one accomplish this. Rolling Stone has itâ€™s 500 Best Recordings of All Time, as does NME with theirs, â€œ100 Best Albums Of All Timeâ€ How about 100 Best Lists of 100 Best Albums of All Time? Google that, I havenâ€™t the time. I believe that these polls work because of our need to be hipper than others. In the social world of Facebook, Twitter and Yelp where we share every last sound, bite and image that we experience, the only thing that makes us feel like an individual is doing, hearing seeing or tasting something that no one else (or any of our friends) have. The fact that I may own even 20 out of these 100 should make me feel better, because thatâ€™s better than 45% of others who have taken the poll. These numbers matter. To know that having only 1/5th of these recordings puts me above 45% of others? Thatâ€™s validation. Imagine how good one could feel if they had say 60 or 70 percent of these? So maybe the tendency would be to work the numbers. I mean who â€œownsâ€ records anymore? Sure I have heard and once owned â€œTrout Mask Replicaâ€œ, but with music streaming services like MOG and Spotify amongst others, we can all â€œownâ€ them all, or more accurately own none of them. But boasting your personal numbers is not enough reason for many. No, the hipness level continues to rise above your percentile score, when you shout from your social mountain top that the list itself sucks. How on earth can â€œClap Your Hands Say Yahâ€ be on this list when thereâ€™s no mention of Charles Mingusâ€™s, â€œAh Uhmâ€œ? No metal bands? Câ€™mon. No Sgt. Peppers? I am hipper than the list itself. Did I take the quiz? Yes. Did I agree with the list? Some of it. How did I do? Well show me yours and Iâ€™ll show you mine. At least I wonâ€™t try and sell you something.
