post.title: LIVE VIDEOS AND WE WHERE BEST IN 2012
post.summary: (blog in swedish HERE) Â Hey freaks and metal heads! J.B here. Hope all is good and ya had a great weekend. I had a great week. Saw our pals in Mass Murder Agenda and Corroded live the other day and saw Entombed and Candlemass deliver some true evil yesterday. Fuckin awesome. Much is going on and has happened in the MMI camp. First of I wanna take you through the BEST OF 2012 charts we have climbed up on. FRONT ROW FOREVER in Portugal: BEST ALBUMS 2012: Lean back relax and watch the world burn At SECOND place. BEST VIDEOS 2012: To a blood red sky At SECOND place. Thtank YOU Renata and Front Row Forever. Much respect comes your way. Hope youÂ´ll enjoy the next album as much if not even more. CLOSE-UP MAGAZINE in Sweden: Erik Sandberg, writer for Close-Up Magazine, put together his chart for the magazine and BEST ALBUMS 2012: Lean back relax and watch the world burn landed at place SEVEN. This is actually the second time MMI lands a spot in their Best years chart. Fist time around was in 2001 with the debut album "Mention" then by Martin Larsson. ROCKNYTT.NET: Rocknytt is the largest news site in Scandinavia on Rock/Metal with over 44 000 followers. So its a GREAT honor to be on the writer Sven MÃ¶rÃ©nÂ´s charts this round. BEST ALBUMS 2012: Lean back relax and watch the world burn landed at place FIVE. BEST SONG 2012: We Are The Walking Dead. Thank YOU for loving the album Sven. Rocknytt ROCKS! POLAND... SEAMS YOU DIG US! post.title: 100 Influential Albums
post.summary: You donâ€™t necessarily need to be a grandfather to check your record collection and tot up how many of the 100 Influential albums youâ€™ve managed to amass over the years. In fact, I know people half my age who have a much more comprehensive catalogue than mine. When I spotted that a Facebook â€˜friendâ€™ had completed the exercise and arrived at an impressive 75, I just had to have a go. I carefully scrolled through the 100 and checked the boxes for those I have. My sum total? 33. A little voice tells me to scurry over to Spotify for a sample of the 67 titles that have passed me by. But itâ€™s the louder voice I pay attention to. Itâ€™s telling me that a high proportion of the shortfall will not be worth the effort, and itâ€™s best to let sleeping discs lie. Clap Your Hands Say Yeah (Photo credit: Dale Harvey)Who knows why I donâ€™t have a copy of S.F. Sorrow by The Pretty Things, anything by Public Enemy, or how Iâ€™ve never applauded Clap Your Hands Say Yeah. Although my music collection is both substantial and eclectic, there are obviously a lot of releases that have passed me by for some reason or other. If anyone has a copy of The Modern Dance by Pere Ubu, Iâ€™d be really interested to learn in which way it was influential. Iâ€™d never heard of it before seeing the list.

post.title: Rise
post.summary: First, some background music. I recommend "Disparate Youth" by Santigold, "Settling It Off" by Peter Wolf Crier, or "Die Slow" by Health. All are on YouTube and Spotify. But really, just pick a song that inspires you. It's cool, I can wait... OK, ready? Set. Go. You might find that life will take you on some unexpected paths. Life is going to throw you curveballs. Serious curveballs. Plans will be destroyed. Hopes and dreams quashed. I don't mean for this to depress or scare you. I mean for it to prepare you. To inspire courage in you when the proverbial ish hits the fan in your life. Because it's inevitable. What isn't inevitable is how you react. You can curl into a ball and let life kick your ass, or you can fight back. I highly suggest the latter. You might find yourself abandoned and isolated in the dead of winter, with nobody returning your phone calls, curled into a ball on the floor of an empty house, in a city you despise, with nothing but your loyal dog and a music collection you've been building since you were twelve to keep you from completely losing it. You might be hours away from your friends and family. You might hit bottom. Then you might fall through and realize that wasn't bottom. But eventually, you'll find your bottom. And it will be beautiful. It will be the most pure, innocent, inspiring place you've been since childhood. Because once you're there, you can only go up. And if you play your cards right, you'll be able to turn it into an opportunity to build the life you've always wanted. The life you've always dreamed of, instead of the life you've always settled for. "You will pay for your new soul." - Trail of the Dead At times, you might find yourself thinking that there is no hope. That's where you'll be wrong. And that's when I want you to remember this email. At that moment I want you to remember me. I want you to remember that as long as you are still breathing, then there's some life left in you, and it's your duty to fight with all you have to make it the best life possible. If you need to, email me. Call me. I'll give you my number. Because sometimes we find ourselves in the most bizarre circumstances where a complete stranger is the only one we can fathom asking our most personal questions. In your darkest moment, whenever that happens to come, I want you to conjure the warrior inside yourself, rise up, and show the world what you're made of. Fight back. Fight with gusto. Fight like your life depends on it. Because it does. And then, you might find yourself. Cheers, Chris chris[AT]apptitudenola.com @chrisboyddotnet New Orleans, Louisiana, US

post.title: Chromebook (late 2012) Review
post.summary: When I won an original Series 5 Chromebook a couple of years ago I wouldn't have expect to use it as much as I did, but the quick boot time made it a handy device for quick browsing session or email. My main problem was that although it was relatively light, it was still too bulky to slip into a bag without noticing it in the same way as a tablet, so I didn't often take it out the house. With the new 2012 ARM-based model, Samsung have trimmed off enough weight to make it a truly portable device, so with the added temptation of 100gb free Drive space, it felt like a worthy upgrade. Samsung's Chromebook design has changed a lot in a short time, from the glossy black toy-like Series 5 to the premium feeling 550, with this model they've gone back to plastic but it still feels like a premium machine, largely due to it's thin, clean profile. I wouldn't feel ashamed getting this out in a cafe full of Macbooks, and much prefer it to the original. Performance has increased significantly from the original Series 5, previously I'd found Flash and high-performance HTML5 apps out of the question, but now they run smoothly and there's no lag with a few tabs open. I can't think of many scenarios where it wouldn't be enough power to get the job done. There's a few compromises that come with the lower price, most notably the screen, which is slightly smaller and doesn't seem as clear. It's not inappropriate for a device of this price, but if Samsung could fit a larger, higher-res screen into the same profile, I'd happily pay a bit more. Battery life isn't as insanely long as the original but can still make it through a few hours, much more than an equivalent Windows netbook. Connection options are more up to date this time round, with HDMI output replacing VGA, and one of the USBs updated to version 3.0. The touchpad feels more responsive and the keyboard is still great, but I'd have liked to see backlit keys added. Chrome OS itself has come on leaps and bound since I first got the Series 5 Chromebook when it was just a single window of Chrome. I had mixed feelings about the Aura window management when it first rolled out, improvements like the Android-esque app launcher have made it feel more like a fully fledged, modern operating system. There's still weak areas - media playback is basic and file management is clunky - these aren't a huge problem on a cloud-based OS, but improvements in these areas could still go some way to improving the overall experience. The concept of a cloud-based OS has also become more realistic in the past year, largely due to Google's additions to it's own web app suite, such as Play Music, Drive and offline Docs. Offline support in external apps is still poor and some users will still miss certain native apps (for me Spotify is a sore loss, but a web version is rumoured to be in the works). I hope that Chrome's new packaged apps, NaCl and ever improving HTML5 will help fill these gaps. It's still hard to say if or when Chrome OS will become a true replacement to a traditional OS, but for many people it could already be close enough, and it's a handy secondary laptop if your main machine is too heavy to carry around. In making the new model cheaper and lighter without sacrificing much functionality, Samsung have made a near-perfect piece of hardware for Chrome OS and it's a great time to give it a go.

post.title: Childhood television classics
post.summary:
Many of my posts are deeply nostalgic and self-indulgent under the guise of exploring some worthy and interesting subject. This one makes no attempt to hide. Iâ€™ve often been startled when people with little experience of classical music announce that certain tunes, sometimes quite surprising ones, are â€˜famousâ€™. The reason of course is almost inevitably that they have been used in television, movies, or ads. Sometimes pieces of music borrowed in this way capture the imagination so effectively that they set down strong memories that last decades. Looking back, Iâ€™ve tried to pull up some of these moments from my own musical pre-history, from the years before I was consciously exploring composers and compositions. Some of them are genuinely famous, but some attached themselves to me in a more personal way and are otherwise pretty obscure. Iâ€™ve limited my selection to television and completely avoided movies because thatâ€™s such a huge subject and, for me at least, TV is particularly about childhood. Iâ€™ve been intrigued to consider what, if anything, each piece evokes to explain its use in its TV context. Iâ€™m sure some were simply random choices by people at the BBC, but others were undoubtedly deliberately picked for mood, evocation or more specific connections. I wonder what I would use if making these programmes.Â Iâ€™d be very interested to hear anyone elseâ€™s views and memories! 1. Crown Court â€“ JanÃ¡Äek I have memories of this slightly eccentric daytime drama from way back in early childhood. It was shown on Granada TV from 1972 to 1984, and featured court cases in the fictional town of Fulchester acted out for judgement by real studio juries of local people. The theme music from JanÃ¡Äekâ€™s Sinfonietta (4th movement) must be one of the earliest pieces of music to really make a mark on me, and listening now it seems absolutely perfect for the context. Hereâ€™s the full movement on Spotify, and in a performance conducted by Rafael Kubelik:
The show itself is just beautifully dated and yet timeless: small town cops and robbers 1970s style!
2. The Sky at Night â€“ Sibelius An inspired choice; Sibelius at his most grandiloquent, evocative not just of Finnish lakescapes but absolutely of worlds beyond. The piece is At the Castle Gate from the incidental music to PellÃ©as et MÃ©lisande. Patrick Moore launched the programme in 1957 and itâ€™s run ever since. Interestingly Sibelius died that same year, just a few months after the first Sky at Night. Was this theme used from the beginning, or was it introduced in response to the composerâ€™s death? I donâ€™t know. Here is the full piece. This meant so much to me as as child! For me Patrick Moore was always, first and foremost, The Man Against Astrology, and to this day I have slightly overcharged reactions on that subject.
The full movement:
3. The Great Philosophers â€“ Shostakovich In the autumn of 1987 the notable philosopher, Wagner scholar and all round comedy intellectual Bryan Magee presented The Great Philosophers, his second series of 15 hour-long dialogues on the history of western philosophy. Brutally austere television of the highest calibre. The music chosen was the trio from the second scherzo of Shostakovichâ€™s eighth symphony, which is surely notable for the breadth of musical knowledge it implies in ever coming across it. Shostakovich was the master of these really nasty grotesque little militaristic scherzos, a natural development in the Soviet era of one part of 19th century symphonic tradition. But this trio creates an interesting mood that I canâ€™t quite find words for. I wonder if Bryan Magee picked it himself. Hereâ€™s the whole scherzo on Spotify, and also a version accompanied by a great collection of old photos. The Great Philosophers part doesnâ€™t start until just over half way through.
And a taste of the programme itself â€“ A. J. Ayer on Frege and Russell:
4. Ludwig â€“ van Beethoven I donâ€™t believe Iâ€™ve yet met anyone as an adult who remembers the cartoon Ludwig. But Iâ€™m sure there was a day in 1977 when absolutely everyone was squealing about it at school â€“ not exactly a water cooler moment, but the nine year oldâ€™s equivalent. Ludwig was a charming, peaceful, creative, strangely abstract egg-like character who mysteriously appeared in the forest and solved problems to assist the animals and birds. The 25 episodes were narrated by Jon Glover (voice of the birdwatcher), who watched and commented as useful and playful objects, such as umbrellas, telescopes and tennis rackets, emerged from the Ludwig-egg. The series was created by father and son team Mirek and Peter Lang. I guess it was considered too surreal to commission any more. Itâ€™s all now available at www.iLudwig.co.uk And of course, there was continual accompaniment with the music of Beethoven (arranged by Paul Reade), most strikingly the finale of the first symphony. Because of Ludwig, Iâ€™ve always been surprised to find that not everyone thinks this movement is â€˜famousâ€™.
Here it is on Spotify, and here are two samples of the magical world of Ludwig:
5. The Onedin Line â€“ Khachaturian Digging deep into the past again brings back The Onedin Line, a mercantile family saga set in 19th century Liverpool, of which nearly 100 episodes were screened between 1971 and 1980. This was definitely too grown up for me, but I have hazy memories of the general mood, period style and striking music. Khachaturianâ€™s Adagio of Spartacus and Phrygia, from his 1954 ballet about the Thracian gladiator, had nothing nautical in intent, but thatâ€™s almost hard to believe so sweepingly oceanic it feels. I wonder what he made of this, use or abuse?
This is more what the composer had in mind (plus the whole piece is here) :
6. Reilly, Ace of Spies â€“ Shostakovich More Shostakovich, and again from the eighties. His cheesy but charming Romance, from The Gadfly, was used in the 1983 miniseries about the life of Sidney Reilly, a British spy active around the time of the first world war with a legendary reputation for espionage and seduction. Both the series and the tune were extremely popular at the time, and I think I even recall it being played on Top of the Pops, though that could be a false memory myth. Spotify link here. There are some intriguing links behind all this. The Gadfly was a 1955 Russian film based on a novel by the fascinating Irish writer and revolutionary Ethel Voynich, who apparently had personal connections with the real Reilly.
7. Castrol GTX â€“ Mahler Music in TV ads is another huge subject, but I canâ€™t resist including just one, especially as itâ€™s a great example of the â€˜wow thatâ€™s famous!â€™ moment â€“ fantastic looks when this jolts the unexpected awake in the concert hall. And itâ€™s a piece that certainly wouldnâ€™t be famous if it werenâ€™t for Castrol GTX, as its cryptic beauty is buried deep in one of Mahlerâ€™s least performed works, the 7th Symphony. Hereâ€™s a performance of the complete 2nd movement. It was used in many variants and arrangements over the years of the campaign, but the early ads leaning on the mystery of the opening bars are the best.
8. The Open University â€“ Salzedo I almost overlooked this, but in a way itâ€™s the most important of all for me, despite being only five bars of music. Back in the 1970s, before 24 hour TV and technologies as basic as video recording, Open University students were condemned to actually tune in at specific obscure times of day and night to catch lecture broadcasts. As a child I would occasionally dip into bits and pieces of incomprehensibly exotic arts and sciences, probably mostly when I should have been asleep, which exerted a magical intellectual pull towards adulthood and the whole outside world. Individual courses probably had their own theme music, but what I clearly recall is the generic OU jingle that accompanied a twisty animated logo before and after every broadcast. The music is by little known English composer Leonard Salzedo, from his Divertimento for 3 trumpets and 3 trombones (1959).Â Salzedo was by profession a ballet conductor, and as a composer he is best known for The Revenge of Frankenstein. Very very rarely (probably to fill unscheduled gaps) the whole piece was played. Normally just the first ten second phrase. But it was enough â€“ mysteriously conjuring up a powerfully expectant sense of aloof,Â abstract brainpower. Here it is: http://www.televisiontunes.com/Open_University.html. (And here you can download the ringtone.)

post.title: Mumford & Sons â€“ I Will Wait
post.summary: Listen to Mumford & Sons - I Will Wait (4,62 min) on spotify. I Will Wait can be found on the album Babel (Deluxe Edition) which were released 2012, track nr: 3About Mumford & SonsMumford & Sons are an English folk rock band. The band consists of Marcus Mumford (vocals, guitar, drums, mandolin), Ben Lovett (vocals, keyboards, accordion, drums), "Country" Winston Marshall (vocals, banjo, guitar, resonator guitar), and Ted Dwane (vocals, string bass, drums, guitar). Mumford & Sons formed in December 2007, emerging out of West London with other artists such as Laura Marling, Johnny Flynn and Noah and the Whale. Mumford & Sons recorded an EP, Love Your Ground, and performed in small to moderate venues in the UK and US to expose audiences to their music and build support for an eventual album. Their debut album, Sigh No More, was released in the UK and Ireland in October 2009, and February 2010 in the United States. The album reached number one in Ireland, Australia and New Zealand and eventually peaked at number two on the UK Albums Chart and the Billboard 200 in the US. The band's second studio album Babel was released in September 2012. The album debuted at number one in the UK and US, becoming the fastest selling album of 2012 in the UK, and the second-biggest selling debut in 2012 in the US. The band gained popularity throughout 2010, performing for larger audiences and making their first network television appearances in the US. On 1 December 2010, the band received two Grammy Award nominations, one for Best New Artist and the other for Best Rock Song ("Little Lion Man"). The ensuing live performance at the Grammy ceremony in February led to increased airplay and popularity for singles from Sigh No More. The band won the ARIA Music Award for Most Popular International Artist in 2010, and the Brit Award in 2011 for Best British Album. Furthermore, in 2011 they received a European Border Breakers Award for their international success. History: Early years: 2007-2008: Mumford & Sons was formed in December 2007 by multi-instrumentalists Marcus Mumford, Ben Lovett, Winston Marshall, and Ted Dwane. Band members variously play guitar, drums, keyboard instruments, bass guitar, and traditional folk instruments such as banjo, mandolin,and resonator guitar. The band name originates from the fact that Marcus Mumford was the most visible member, organizing the band and their performances. Lovett indicated that the name was meant to invoke the sense of an "antiquated family business name". A handful of similar bands were increasing their visibility in West London around the same time, giving rise to the label "West London folk scene". Mumford downplays that characterisation as an exaggeration--Mumford & Sons and a few other folk acts just happened to be operating in the same general area at the time. In an interview with the Herald Sun, Marcus Mumford said, "It's not folk really. Well, some of it is, and it's certainly not a scene. Someone got over-excited about a few bands who live in a hundred-mile radius and put it in a box to sell it as a package. It's a community, not a scene. It's not exclusive." Having developed in the same musical and cultural environment, Mumford & Sons' sound has been compared to that of artists such as Noah and the Whale, Johnny Flynn, and Laura Marling, for whom Marcus Mumford used to drum. In early 2008 the band began working with manager Adam Tudhope, who, as part of management company Everybody's, also represents Keane and Laura Marling. It was through Tudhope's connection that Mumford & Sons were exposed to their future A&R at Island, Louis Bloom, who began monitoring the band. Bloom told HitQuarters that they were still at a fledgling state and not yet ready for a label deal: "There was no one there for it, just a few friends, and they needed time to develop. Over the next six months I kept going to see them and they were literally picking up fans every time." In February 2008, the band completed an extensive UK tour with support from Alessi's Ark, Sons of Noel and Adrian, Peggy Sue, Pete Roe, The Cutaway and others. June marked the band's first appearance at the Glastonbury Festival. Mumford also toured Australia with Laura Marling, whose disinclination to interact with audiences encouraged Mumford into the spotlight. The experience helped inform his attitude toward Mumford & Sons audiences, which is to interact frequently and to try to create a comfortable, casual atmosphere. Mumford & Sons' first project was an EP entitled Love Your Ground which took a year to complete and was released in November 2008 on Chess Club Records. Sigh No More: 2009-2010: Throughout 2008 and into 2009, Mumford & Sons performed in small to moderate venues in the UK and US, exposing audiences to Love Your Ground tracks and other material that would eventually become Sigh No More. The band finally recorded Sigh No More with Markus Dravs, who had produced albums with artists such as Arcade Fire. At the time, band members did not even own their own instruments--Dravs initially turned them away when they showed up at the recording sessions empty-handed. The only track from Love Your Ground to be included on Sigh No More was "Little Lion Man". The band told the Herald Sun that they self-financed the album to avoid the artistic and technical compromises that sometimes befall studio-financed projects. They toured again in support of Laura Marling in 2009, and Mumford & Sons were contributing musicians to her 2010 album I Speak Because I Can. In August 2009, Mumford & Sons signed a licensing deal to Island Records in the UK, to Dew Process in Australia and New Zealand, to Glassnote Records in North America and Cooperative Music in the rest of the world, and through its own label Gentlemen of the Road. Dew Process boss Paul Piticco signed the band after having seen it at a US gig in 2009 and having appreciated its "honest" approach and unique sound. Their debut album was released on 5 October 2009 with "Little Lion Man" as the lead single. Dave Berry of XFM named "Little Lion Man" his record of the week, and in another interview with the band, Berry said "Screw 'of the week', it's my favourite track of the year." BBC Radio 1 DJ Zane Lowe made "Little Lion Man" his "Reaction Record" on 27 July 2009, before naming it the "Hottest Record in the World" the following evening. In their first performance on US network television, the band played their single "Little Lion Man" on CBS's Late Show with David Letterman on 17 February 2010. This appearance was followed by a performance of "The Cave" on The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson on 26 February 2010. Mumford & Sons have been commercially successful in Australia and New Zealand. The single "Little Lion Man" has been popular--by January 2010, it had topped the Triple J Hottest 100 list for all of 2009. Its margin of victory was the largest in the history of the chart. In November 2010, the band won an ARIA Music Award for Most Popular International Artist.Sigh No More first reached number 9 on the New Zealand charts in October 2010, and subsequently topped the chart in January 2011 due to strong popularity of singles from the album. In a March 2010 interview, Ray Davies announced that Mumford & Sons will be appearing on his forthcoming collaborations album. Marcus confirmed this in an interview the same month, stating, "I am more excited about that than I have been about anything before in my life". Mumford & Sons performed the track "Days/This Time Tomorrow" along with Davies on 12 February 2010 on Later... with Jools Holland. In December 2010, Mumford & Sons earned Grammy Award nominations for Best New Artist and Best Rock Song ("Little Lion Man"). While they did not go on to win an award, the band performed their single "The Cave" at the Grammy ceremony. The performance earned positive media attention and boosted visibility for Sigh No More--US sales increased by 99% in the period following the ceremony in February 2011. The album subsequently peaked at number two on the UK Album Chart and the Billboard 200 in the US. On 7 December 2010, in collaboration with Dharohar Project and Laura Marling, Mumford & Sons released an EP album recorded in Delhi, India. The album was recorded in a makeshift studio with traditional Rajasthani musicians and features four collaborations, including multicultural mash-ups of Marling's spirited "Devil's Spoke" and Mumford & Sons' "To Darkness." Sigh No More is certified 2x Platinum in the US and 4x Platinum in the UK. Railroad Revival Tour: In April 2011 the group joined Old Crow Medicine Show and Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros on the inaugural Railroad Revival Tour, which was inspired by the Festival Express tour across Canada in 1970 that included Buddy Guy, Janis Joplin, The Grateful Dead, and The Band. Traveling exclusively in vintage rail cars, the three bands performed in six "unique outdoor locations" over the course of a week starting in Oakland, California. Ketch Secor of Old Crow told American Songwriter that "It's like we left all our baggage at home and just brought our instruments," often writing new songs while on the train. "We were just on these old rattling rails. It was a railroad odyssey that would have made Woody and Doc tip their hats and blow their whistles," he says. They appear in the musical documentary Big Easy Express, directed by Emmett Malloy, being made of the trip which premiered March 2012 at the South by Southwest Film Conference and Festival (SXSW Film) in Austin, Texas--winning the Headliner Audience Award. Babel: 2011-present: Mumford & Sons continued to grow in popularity in 2011, winning several major awards and headlining larger shows and festivals. In February 2011, they received a European Border Breakers Award for their international success. They received a Brit Award for British Album of the Year with Sigh No More and performed "Timshel" at the ceremony. UK sales of the album subsequently increased by 266 percent. While touring the United States in early 2011, the band began writing songs for the follow-up album. Keyboardist Ben Lovett credited the creative atmosphere of Nashville, Tennessee with easing the songwriting process. While performing in Kansas City, Missouri on 3 June, the first stop of their US Tour, the band announced they had been recording a new album, initially set to be released in late 2011. They then performed several new tracks from the forthcoming album, the title of which was not revealed. Mumford & Sons played at the Glastonbury festival on Friday 24 June 2011, and then embarked on a North American tour on which they frequently performed songs from the upcoming album. They recorded two songs for Andrea Arnold's adaptation of Wuthering Heights, one of which (entitled "Enemy") is featured during the closing credits. In June 2012, Mumford & Sons contributed the song "Learn Me Right" with Birdy to the Pixar film Brave, which came to be called "Not with Haste". On 16 July 2012, Mumford & Sons officially announced the details of their second studio album Babel, including the release date of 24 September 2012 and a track listing of 12 songs. A deluxe edition containing three exclusive songs was also announced. A week later, the album became available for pre-order. The lead single "I Will Wait" premiered on Zane Lowe's BBC Radio 1 show on 7 August. On 29 August 2012, Mumford & Sons recorded their concert at Red Rocks Amphitheatre in Colorado. The Concert was later released on DVD, Vinyl and on iTunes as "Road to Red Rocks". The performance of "I Will Wait" from the concert was released ahead of the DVD on 9 September as the band's official video for the song. On 22 September 2012, the band performed two songs from the new album, "I Will Wait" and "Below My Feet", on Saturday Night Live. Babel debuted at number one on the UK Album Chart and the US Billboard 200. It became the fastest selling album of 2012 in the UK, selling over 158,000 copies in its first week, and was the biggest selling debut of any album in 2012 in the US, selling 600,000 in its first week, and over a million worldwide. The first phase of a 2013 tour in support of Babel was released in November 2012. In December 2012, Winston Marshall told NME that the band already have begun rehearsing and writing for their next album. Marcus Mumford stated that the band may experiment with electric guitars and synthesizers for the album. Musical style and influences: Mumford & Sons use bluegrass and folk instrumentation, such as a banjo, upright bass, mandolin and piano, played with a rhythmic style based in alternative rock and folk. Much of Mumford & Sons' lyrical content has a strong literary influence, its debut album name deriving from Shakespeare's Much Ado About Nothing. The track "Sigh No More" includes lines from the play such as Serve God love me and mend and One foot in sea and one on shore. The song "Roll Away Your Stone," whose title is most probably a reference to Biblical story of Lazarus (though it may also reference the myth of Sisyphus), alludes to Macbeth; the song includes the line Stars hide your fires / And these here are my desires which borrows and pares down Macbeth's line in Act 1 Scene 4: Stars, hide your fires, / Let not light see my black and deep desires. In an interview, Mumford was quoted as saying, "You can rip off Shakespeare all you like; no lawyer's going to call you up on that one." Additionally, "The Cave" includes several references to The Odyssey, also referencing Plato's "Allegory of the Cave", from The Republic. More specifically, the song references G.K. Chesterton's book St. Francis of Assisi, in which Chesterton uses Plato's Cave as a way of explaining how St. Francis views the world from God's perspective. In addition, the song "Little Lion Man" appears to be a retelling in dramatic monlogue form of Chretien de Troyes' Yvain, the Knight of the Lion which is the story of a knight who goes mad after betraying a promise to his wife to return to her. "Here's the elevator pitch on Mumford & Sons: U2 meets Old Crow Medicine Show at Bruce Springsteen's house. They have Old Crow's rootsy instrumentation and vintage wardrobe, and they share the Boss' heart-on-the-sleeve sincerity and world-conquering ambition. From U2 the band takes a melodramatic sense of musical dynamics, and singer-lyricist Marcus Mumford models Bono's strategy for rendering spiritual longing in terms that are accessible to a post-Christian world." --Danny Duncan Collum, U.S. Catholic Both "Timshel" and "Dust Bowl Dance" draw heavily from the John Steinbeck novels Of Mice and Men, East of Eden and The Grapes of Wrath. Mumford, in an interview, even compared touring to a Steinbeck adventure: "Steinbeck talked about how a journey is a thing of its own, and you can't plan it or predict it too much because that suffocates the life out it. That's kind of what touring is like. Even though there's a structure--you know what towns you're going to, and that you'll be playing a gig--pretty much anything can happen." In the documentary Big Easy Express, Marcus Mumford recognizes the Old Crow Medicine Show influence: "I first heard Old Crow's music when I was, like, 16, 17, and that really got me into, like, folk music, bluegrass. I mean, I'd listened to a lot of Dylan, but I hadn't really ventured into the country world so much. So Old Crow were the band that made me fall in love with country music." Mumford acknowledges that "the band inspired them to pick up the banjo and start their now famous country nights in London." Ketch Secor, Old Crow front-man, concurs: "Those boys took the message and ran with it." Emmylou Harris was . . ". . among the gateway artists who helped Mumford and bandmates Ben Lovett, Ted Dwane and Winston Marshall discover their love for American roots music. It started with the 'O Brother, Where Art Thou?' soundtrack . . That eventually led them to the Old Crow Medicine Show and then deep immersion in old-timey sounds from America's long-neglected past." wikipedia Pictures of Mumford & SonsShow more imagesMore: Mumford & Sons Mumford & Sons besÃ¶ker Sverige Music video with Mumford & SonsHere you can find videos from Youtube with Mumford & Sons - I Will WaitThe single 'I Will Wait' is now available from iTunes : tinyurl.com Order the new album 'Babel' at www.mumfordandsons.com Video directed by FRED & NICK Follow Mumford & Sons Facebook www.facebook.com Twitter: twitter.com www.mumfordandsons.com

post.title: Playlist Sunday 2/27
post.summary:
I am always listening to music and searching for new music and etc. So every Sunday I am going to (try to) post a â€œplaylist.â€ I will talk about some songs or artists I am listening to and then link you to the songs or albums on Spotify. Which by the way letâ€™s talk about how great Spotify is. I have premium but even free Spotify is brilliant. If you do not have it I 110% suggest you get it asap. FREE MUSIC! Who doesnâ€™t love that? On to the music! Jillette Johnson
If you have never heard of her, I am not suprised, but you are missing out. Her songs are amazing and they all carry a strong message. She is on tour with Kris Allen (from American Idol) right now, so go check her out if you can. Her EP Whiskey & Frosting is available on Spotify here. Â Be sure to check out her songÂ Torpedo. Mumford & Sons
I know you have all heard of them; Little Lion Man and I Will Wait. But their entire album Babel is phenomenal. I encourage you to stray from the normal radio played songs and check out the entire album. And one of the songs (Hopeless Wanderer) inspired the new name of my blog. You can listen to it on Spotify here. Be sure to check out the songsÂ Broken Crown and Hopeless Wanderer.Â Chad Sugg
Chad is a Youtube artist. Here is his channel filled with covers and his original music. He collaborates with many other popular youtube artists including Alex Goot. Bonus: he is a super nerd and not afraid to show it, which is pretty rad. His original lyrics are brilliant. His latest album Was can be found on Spotify here. Be sure to check out the songÂ 25Â andÂ Time Machine.Â Action Item
My friends in Action Item have released a new album this month called Resolution. It is a new direction for them and it is a good direction. I was a little nervous because I new it was going to be different but I was impressed. The first track on the album,Â Where We Left Off, was a brilliant move andÂ is the perfect way to set the tone for the album. The album is not yet available on Spotify but you can get it on iTunes here. And you can listen to the song Brave on their youtube channel here. They are on tour right now with Paradise Fears and others, so try and make it out to one of the remaining show. (Iâ€™ll be at the show in Chicago this Friday, February 1st) Be sure to check out the song Brave.Â Honorable Mentions: The Les Miserables Soundtrack F**k You Over by The Summer Set The Pitch Perfect Soundtrack What are you listening to at the moment? Let me know! I am always looking for new music. Until next time, stay weird.

post.title: Ass Kicking Workout Music
post.summary: It's different from person to person - but I'm definitely one of those who is in need of great music. All. The. Time. Not least at the gym, when I'm kind of in my own world where there's only two things in sight: WORK and WORK HARD. And to be able to find that extra motivation to Â run that final mile, not to stop halfway, do that extra rep or even to get started, in addition to dedication, energy and lots of will, MUSIC is everything I really need. So since motivational music is so important to me, I wanted to share some of my favorite tracks with you!Â To open the following links, you need a music program called Spotify (which you can downloadÂ HERE, for free.) To play music on your phone through the app though, you need to buy a premium membership which is like $10 per month if I remember it right. But I can tell you it's totally worth it. Otherwise you can just search the tracks up on youtube or wherever you'd like. Remix) Michael Calfan â€“ Resurrection - Axwell's Recut Radio Edit Maroon 5 â€“ Payphone - Cutmore Remix Skrillex â€“ Bangarang - feat. post.title: What Goes On
post.summary: [28/01] Can the two-decade-long wait finally be over? Last night, during their Brixton gig, My Bloody Valentine revealed their long-awaited new album could be out in 'two or three days'. It's been hanging in the air ever since Kevin Shields promised an album back in the nineties, after Loveless. Apparently the new album has already been mastered last December, following the remastering of Isn't Anything, Loveless and assembling the EPs collection earlier in 2012. Expectations are high, as the wait has been agonisingly long and Loveless near impossible to ever top. Meanwhile, warm yourself up for it with one of the many B-side gems unearthed for last year's EPs collection to the right. [27/01] March will be busy on new albums with Depeche Mode announcing the release of theirs on the 26th. Delta Machine will be backed by 'Heaven' - the first single to be taken from the album. "With this release we've completely shifted our idea of how to create an album," says Dave Gahan of the follow-up to 2009's Sounds of the Universe. Â Iggy and The Stooges make another return after 2007's The Weirdness. But this time James Williamson returns since the seventies, after Ron Asheton's passing away. Iggy has been busy going solo in the meanwhile, with Preliminaires in 2009 and a more recent covers album. But it's time to crank the volume up again, as 'old-time' and 'raw' Stooges is promised once again. Beware, it's mortally titled Ready To Die. [22/01] The young and the old unite in Mod fashion, as Miles Kane revealed five songs off his forthcoming album will feature Paul Weller. It'll be his second album following the 2011 debut, Colour of the Trap. Expect release sometime in the spring and a preceding EP, scheduled for February. Kane promises some 'crackers'. Â "It feels like a really special album", says Liam Gallagher of the new Beady Eye album currently in progress. Recordings are taking place in London with Dave Sitek (TV On the Radio, producer for Yeah Yeah Yeahs), who's revealed there's a 'healthy dose of psychedelia' in the music. The younger Gallagher has described his band's work as 'out there', 'heavy', 'majestic' and that they're certainly experimenting. Our kid takes the praise further by indicating this should've been the follow-up to ...Morning Glory. Well-well. Â The Stone Roses reunion still doesn't appear to be all about glorifying the past and grabbing some quid. Brett Anderson, of all people, revealed that the Roses have indeed recorded new material: "I spoke to Mani a couple of months ago - I saw him at a party - and he said they'd written a couple of songs." Brett himself would 'love to hear' some new stuff from the reunited Roses. Â An uproar has circulated the mega-retailer HMV for the past few weeks. Actually, doubts around the chain's ability to continue have been brewing up for a couple of years. Debts are now of colossal size and administration has finally arrived. HMV has been cynically looking for rescuers, from wealthy musicians to companies, to give a helping hand while an aggressive pricing policy has disenchanted customers. Reactions were furious, when it was announced that gift vouchers (you know, those people usually give as presents for x-mas) are void from the new year. 4000 jobs are at risk (and probably some opportunists are holding their breaths) as major labels (Universal, Warner, Sony) are looking to assemble a rescue package. Â Some sad news as Wilko Johnson announced a farewell tour. The former Dr. Feelgood man is diagnosed with terminal cancer and has refused any treatment to give all he still has for touring. God's speed to the pub rock legend. Â Hear Ian Skelly's psychedelic (to the right) solo-project while The Coral announce an indefinite break. The scouse group had recorded some half of a new album with John Leckie to follow up the majestic Butterfly House, but have suddenly agreed to put it to a rest. The break is rather from The Coral, than each other - everyone else featured on Ian's debut. [18/01] More promises for the new year as The Strokes revealed plans to release a new album later this year. The five-piece have been working in the studio for some time now, Albert Hammond Jr. has described the new material as 'incredible'. It'll be the follow-up to the fourth album from 2011, Angles, their weakest yet. Here's to hoping the new one will top that. New track 'All That Time' will precede the release. Â After the KLF deleted all their albums in 1992, following their split, they will now become available again on Spotify, iTunes and Amazon. The electronic madmen's albums will all be up for purchase download and streaming. Â The fairytale story of the now 70 year old cult figure Rodriguez continues, as dates become bigger and bigger after 2012's brilliant documentary Searching For Sugar Man. Last year he played 13 dates across the UK and is now set for festivals including Glastonbury, Coachella and Primavera. "The offers are becoming obscene. We're kicking around ideas. I even suggested to the booking agent that we do a marijuana tour and go to all 16 states that have decriminalised weed", the singer replied on whether he'll continue touring. Read my previous entry on his story, the documentary and, of course, the music. Â Meanwhile, hear the new experimental side project of Echo & the Bunnymen's Will Sergeant and Les Pattinson to the right. [14/01] Last week began in quite some fashion, with Suede announcing a new album and giving one song away for download on Monday, only for David Bowie to do the same the very next day. Both have been on a recording hiatus of nearly ten years, both promised new albums by March and both even went back to their old producers of their vintage era. Suede had reunited in 2010 and began rather tentatively with intimate live performances, soon escalating their shows to arena-sized dates of magnitude the band hadn't yet experienced. Naturally, Bernard Butler wasn't invited to the party, he added jokingly "I'll be chucking peanuts in the front row". It was, in effect, a celebration of the magnificent early material that Bernard Butler was a crucial part of - anything from the latter two albums, Head Music and Positivity, were all but omitted. Finally a trio of successive London dates dissected each of the first three albums in order. Relative silence followed, with Brett Anderson drifting between the reunited band and his solo project, implying that a new album would only be considered, if it was 'really good'. That certainly has risen expectations, as cryptic messages finally led up to the announcement last Monday. With Ed Buller (producer of the first three albums) back on board, the new album would be called Blood Sports, first to be revealed, 'Barriers' - a large-scale song, harking back to the old days with Brett's melodic swoon and Oakes' familiarly trebly guitars, mixed with modern elements, certainly Osman's bass and Gilbert's drums seem to have gone along with the times. For more info and dates (and a forum of amiable loyals) to keep you up to date, www.suede.co.uk While Suede had been brewing it up, Bowie kept everyone in the dark; indeed, suggestions and rumours were moving around of late that the living legend would never return to music, or even stay out of the public limelight altogether. A health scare in 2004 and more problems recently backed these stories up, but the Thin White Duke had actually been tinkering on the new stuff for about two years now, incredibly keeping complete silence in front of fans and media praying for just about anything from the rock idol. Tuesday was Bowie's 66th birthday and everyone was treated to his new song in over ten years, 'Where Are We Now', a reflective, slow number, connecting his past to the present. Producer Tony Visconti (long-time producer for Bowie since Space Oddity) was 'surprised' to find this particular song to be revealed first, as the rest of the album would 'rock' and that this was supposed to be the only somber one of the lot. The new album will be titled The Next Day, news on the revamped www.davidbowie.com Johnny Marr goes solo! Although, didn't the guitar legend already do that as Johnny Marr & the Healers? Well, apparently not. After an impressive body of work beyond The Smiths, including Electronic with Bernard Sumner, Modest Mouse, The Cribs and even a late appearance on Hans Zimmer's score for the motion picture Inception, it's finally time for creative seclusion. New album The Messenger is on it's way with a UK tour to boot; check out the single, as Johnny keeps it simple, but cool. For more info, merchandise and some serious guitar-love, go to www.johnny-marr.com

post.title: Something I Made Earlier
post.summary: Hey Blogosphere! (Okay, Iâ€™m never going to use that word again) So, I got kind of bored writing about actual real-life things, so I decided to give story-writing a go. I joined this website called Wattpad â€“ which is sort of like Spotify but for reading â€“ in some attempt to get any feedback about my writing. Itâ€™s basically a website where people can share their work and comment on other peopleâ€™s stories. But yeah, I wrote this short story â€“ called â€˜Picture Perfectâ€™ â€“ mainly because I wanted to get it out of my head. For those of you who know me, youâ€™ll probably be able to recognise my sense of humour reflected in my writing style. This is hopefully the first of many short stories to come. Anyways, hereâ€™s the link â€“ if you have any comments/criticism then please feel free to broadcast them. Enjoy! http://www.wattpad.com/story/3561455 Tom

post.title: The Farm - All Together Now
post.summary: Again, back to the netherland of men with guitars before it was hip. They never split up as such, always around for charity gigs and general Mersey reminiscence nights - the last day of the Anfield Kop, for instance - but the trajectory of the Farm's moment in the spotlight was a pronounced high entry followed a year or two later by a steady but steep decline - Spartacus a number one album, a couple of much played top ten singles and from then on only an undistinguished cover of Don't You Want Me would break the top 30. Given they'd already been together for seven years by the time of their first hit that plateau would look quite pronounced as a graph. Peter Hooton never had the strongest voice, nor did their particular shuffling jangle stand out much when everyone was doing much the same, but they were among the first of the bands whose fervent following largely belied their press attention, though that itself was sizeable in the aftermath of football's post-Italia '90 cool and the rise of male street fashion as something to properly discuss. In fact All Together Now would be back in the charts a month later in a rewritten and consequently diluted form to celebrate Everton's FA Cup final appearance, odd for a group led by a Liverpool fanzine writer but fitting given the theme not just of anti-war but of togetherness across the divide, taking the 1914 truce (and surely the use of Pachelbel's Canon, a work by a German composer not published until 1919, was more deliberate than it may appear) as a focal point for thoughts of rememberance and representation across class and national divides. It's a fairly immoveable topic, which may explain why Atomic Kitten's World Cup tie-in cover changed some key words. YouTube iTunes Spotify Amazon (Spartacus)

Melkein voisin ahdistua siitÃ¤ etten oo saanut mitÃ¤Ã¤n aikaan. Melkein. Tai no kÃ¤ytiinhÃ¤n me Ikeassa eilen! Haha, Barcelonan Ikea... tÃ¤smÃ¤lleen sama pohjapiirustus ku Vantaan samaisessa. Tamara oli ihan liekeissÃ¤, mittaili jokaikistÃ¤ lipastoa ja "kokeile tÃ¤tÃ¤ patjaa! Kokeile nyt! EIKU MENET SIIHEN KUNNOLLA MAKAAMAAN ETHÃ„N SÃ„ MUUTEN VOI TIETÃ„Ã„ ONKSE HYVÃ„! A que es bueno, sÃ­ no? Onkohan nÃ¤it liiloina? MÃ¤ kÃ¤yn kysyy." Ja meitsi kulki perÃ¤ssÃ¤ ihan poikaystÃ¤vÃ¤nÃ¤. Parkkihallissa Tamara kysy ettÃ¤ "haluutsÃ¤ ajaa himaan?" "Ei mul ole ajokorttia..." "C'mon, se on maailman helpointa. TÃ¤mÃ¤ tÃ¤ssÃ¤ on kytkin, tÃ¤mÃ¤ on..." No en ajanut kotiin tÃ¤llÃ¤ kertaa. Mutta hÃ¤n kuulema aikoo opettaa mut ajamaan. Okei, missÃ¤ vakuutukset... "mÃ¤ kÃ¤yn nopee, venaatsÃ¤ tÃ¤Ã¤l?" jaaa kakskyt minuuttia. Sama homma "sano vaa ku lÃ¤hetÃ¤Ã¤" "no mÃ¤ oon nyt valmis!" "noni, hyvÃ¤, mÃ¤ kÃ¤yn viel kÃ¤yttÃ¤Ã¤ koiran nopee ja ei vittu oota mÃ¤ soitan mummolle nopeesti." Normal. Tultiin kotiin ja tehtiin illallista, Tamaran mies oli kanssa ja se kyseli multa ihan vitusti Suomesta ja kaikkee vaikeeta. Hahaa "joo, kyl varmaan... Joo niin taitaa olla, nyt mÃ¤ en oo ihan varma..." HÃ¤n myÃ¶s tiesi hyvin paljon historiasta ylipÃ¤Ã¤tÃ¤nsÃ¤ ja jotain ihan ihme faktoja Suomen ja VenÃ¤jÃ¤n vÃ¤leistÃ¤. JÃ¶sses. Niin ja mies on kyllÃ¤ aina mies. "Kasviksia? Estas de broma? MissÃ¤ liha?" Jumalauta turpa rullalle, se tekee sulle hyvÃ¤Ã¤ ja nyt syÃ¶t. Tiistaina on meidÃ¤n tyttÃ¶jengin (JUGONAS!) ensimmÃ¤inen miitti. Apua... mÃ¤ en kestÃ¤. NÃ¤in innokkaina me odotetaan meidÃ¤n treenejÃ¤. Kuva on otettu baarista mut hei, pikkujuttuja. Koska mun elÃ¤mÃ¤ssÃ¤ ei tapahdu mitÃ¤Ã¤n mistÃ¤ kertoa ni mÃ¤ jatkan sunnuntaihommia eli Spotify Premiumia ja sitruunasorbettia (taas) ja mitÃ¤ nÃ¤it nyt on. post.title: In love with...
post.summary: Ã„r sjukt kÃ¤r. Ã„r sÃ¥dÃ¤r kÃ¤r sÃ¥ det nÃ¤stan gÃ¶r ont nÃ¤r jag tÃ¤nker pÃ¥ det. Blir helt pirrig i magen och ibland mÃ¥r jag till och med illa. Helt sjukt. Det enda mina dagar har bestÃ¥tt av sedan fredag har varit musik. Musikmusikmusik. Det Ã¤r det enda jag kan tÃ¤nka pÃ¥, mer Ã¤n vanligt alltsÃ¥. Har fÃ¥tt vÃ¤rldens uppenbarelse och har insett hur sjukt underbart det egentligen Ã¤r!! Och just lyssnar jag enbart pÃ¥ 3 band. De 2 klassikerna Red Hot Chili Peppers och The Killers, och det lite nyare Imagine Dragons.Â Â Om nÃ¥gon frÃ¥gade mig om 2 saker jag skulle ta med mig till en Ã¶de Ã¶ skulle det fÃ¶r tillfÃ¤llet vara min mobil och min Music Angel speaker. KÃ¤rlek sÃ¤ger jag bara! Nedan ser ni pÃ¥ fÃ¶rsta bilden mitt livs glÃ¤dje och pÃ¥ andra bilden min aktuella spellista pÃ¥ Spotify. Â IÂ´m in love. It hurts so bad when I think about it. I get all nervous and sometimes I even feel sick. So strange. For three days my life has been filled with only music. Music music music. ItÂ´s the only thing I can think about, and wen I do, I just wanna cry! Suddenly I realised how amazing it really is! ItÂ´s so wonderful!Â At the moments I listen only to 3 bands. The 2 classics Red Hot Chili Peppers and The Killers, and my new favorite Imagine Dragons.Â Below you can see the love of my life, and also my current Spotify list!

post.title: CÃ³rdoba
post.summary: I just love Sundays so much. Sunday is the day that I podcast a sermon, and I listen to the Word of God. It's the day I take a million notes of just thirty minutes of information, and I love it.Â I am also forced to eat a lot of food.Â PepÃ­ makes-what seems to be-a feast every Sunday. First world problems, right? And to top of today, she made FAJITAS! She even had chips (Doritos), hot sauce, and guacamole. Needless-to-say, I was stoked. As I write this blog, I'm am listening to my Christian playlist on spotify, and it is seriously making me happy. I don't know why this is the first time I've played it since I've been here in Spain. If anything, I've really needed my Jesus music. For those of you who don't know, which is most everyone, I've been struggling here. Everyone says this experience will the best decision of my life, but so far, it hasn't had that effect on me. I guess I'm so used to my everyday life in Texas, that it's taking some major adjusting for me. Things just come so easily for me back at home. Now I'm faced with new decisions, and I'm always trying to think ahead as for what is best for me. In Lubbock, it's so easy to say no to going out to places you have no business going to, but here, these places are the norm. It's part of the lifestyle, yet my lifestyle at home is completely different. I find myself choosing to stay in at our apartment rather than going out a night. Call me weird, but I don't enjoy spending time enclosed in bars. If I had it my way, I would be exploring the city...THERE'S SO MUCH TO SEE! But I'm in a foreign country, and I don't speak the language all that well. So clearly, I have no business walking around a city at night alone. I mean, I'm a girl. And girls are typically bad with directions. For all I know, I could end up in Timbuktu! haha. Of course, I was lucky enough to also get sick this week. Starting last Sunday I came down with flu-like symptons, and my body decided to milk it for all its worth: fever, chills, cough, sore throat, constant headache...the whole nine yards. I enjoyed it so much...NOT. Thankfully, I have an awesome host mom who has been force-feeding both me and my roommate noodles and soups, hoping to get us back on our feet asap. One of the many things I will never take for granted again is wifi. I know this sounds completely ridiculous. But wifi is the only way I'm able to communicate with people from home. And right now, my family and friends are the only ones who are keeping me sane. The fact that I am able to talk with them keeps me from being too homesick. I've never been one to miss home a whole lot; I'm pretty independent. No matter where I am, I'm always able to find my place. However, I guess my place here just hasn't set in yet. I'll keep being patient, though. Anyway, enough with the sad stuff. This past Friday, we were able to go as a class on another day excursion to CÃ³rdoba, a city that used to the capital of Al-Andulus. The day started off similar to the last excursion...rainy. Regardless of the bad weather, though, we all had a good time. We visited the cathedral there, which used to be a mosque, called La Mezquita. This mosque, at one time, was considered the most important sanctuary in Western Islam. Inside there are over 900 columns and the architecture displays double-archways made of red brick and white rock, which gives the room a candy-cane look. This mosque was so huge it is considered a 8th, 9th, 10th century piece of work. It was built in four stages. Then in the early 13th century, Christian conquerors built a cathedral inside the Mezquita. In the following years, as new kings took the throne, they added different Christian architecture to the cathedral and mosque. Now, it is forbidden for Muslims to pray at the Mezquita. It is solely a place for Christian worship. After we toured through the Cathedral of CÃ³rdoba, my history class made our way through the Jewish quarter of the city, and stopped at the Jewish Synagogue there. It is one of the most significant synagogues in Spain, built in 1350. It was extremely small, but back then it would be packed. We learned that the women could not stand on the ground floor with the men, so they had a special place upstairs designated for them, but it was extremely small. I couldn't take a good picture while I was inside. So I found this one online. Â This is the loft where the women would stand. I'm so thankful that I can worship in spacious places with or without men when I choose. And it doesn't matter where I talk to God or receive the word because it's all about my relationship with Christ. He hears me from wherever I am. The stars I see here in Spain are created by the same God who made the stars at home. Just because I'm in a different location doesn't mean I'm alone. I've still got my God, my family, and friends. For lunch, some of us students dared to go with our professor to one of the local restaurants. While I was looking through the menu for something that sounded good, he told us that he took the liberty to order for us. Immediately I was worried. In class he always talks about the strange food he tries, and I'm definitely not a adventurous food-eater. Oh my goodness...he ordered the BEST Spanish food I have had since I've been here! Seriously, fried eggplant with honey? It was delicious! I don't even know what I ate, which is probably for the best. But all was edible! :) So, all-in-all this week has been rough because I'm sick, but there have definitely been good things, too. -We started dance class, where we are learning the traditional Sevilliana dance. -I was able to carry a pretty decent conversation with my tutor the other day. Thank goodness he talked slow. -I made a 100 on my first Spanish test. Tomorrow I have another one. -We visited a new town. -I actually liked some Spanish food. -And I've had a really good Sunday! Now, all I need to focus on is feeling 100% and figure out what my plans are this coming weekend when I'm in BARCELONA! Thanks, everyone, for your prayers! I really appreciate it! Feel free to email, iMessage, Facebook, or skype me! XOXO

post.title: MÃºsica Anuncio Red Bull 2013 "World of Red Bull"
post.summary:
Parece que fue ayer, pero ya han pasado tres meses desde que os comentÃ© el penÃºltimo anuncio de la marca de bebidas energÃ©ticas y estimulantes del Toro Rojo. Hoy hago lo propio con World of Red Bull 2013, su spot mÃ¡s reciente.
El vÃ­deo en sÃ­ no tiene mucho de novedoso con respecto al anterior que os menciono arriba, aunque os volverÃ¡ a dejar sentados frente a la pantalla los 60 segundos que dura. En Ã©l, Red Bull vuelve a replicar imÃ¡genes de parajes de bella factura, una fotografÃ­a espectacular y deportistas de diversas disciplinas extremas realizando acrobacias y acciones al lÃ­mite, amÃ©n del ya famoso y mÃ­tico salto desde la estratosfera (o 'tratosfera', que decÃ­a Chiquito en el anuncio de CampofrÃ­o) del austrÃ­aco Felix Baumgartner en Octubre del pasado aÃ±o. Todo unido para ver el mundo desde la perspectiva de Red Bull y la de los amantes de los deportes de riesgo mientras afrontan hazaÃ±as que desafÃ­an a las leyes fÃ­sicas.
Lo que si cambia es la canciÃ³n del anuncio, que en esta ocasiÃ³n corre a cargo del multiintrumentista Sufjan Stevens y su "Redford (For Yia-Yia & Pappou)", incluÃ­da en su tercer Ã¡lbum Michigan, con temas que hacen referencia a las personas o lugares del estado norteÃ±o de los EEUU. AdemÃ¡s, "Redford" inspirÃ³ el nombre del protagonista (Redford Stevens) de las letras de las canciones del Ã¡lbum conceptual, Undun, de la banda de hip hop alternativo The Roots, en el que Sufjan hacÃ­a labores de producciÃ³n. (vÃ­a)
"Redford (For Yia-Yia & Pappou)" de Sufjan Stevens Descargar en: iTunes Escuchar en: Spotify

post.title: Diario de un Adicto: 2 Meses con el Google Nexus 4 by LG
post.summary:
16Â de Noviembre de 2012Â a las doce de la noche.Preparas Google Chrome en tu ordenador para que refresque Google Play cada 10 segundos.Y, Â¿Por quÃ© haces esto? Pues porque eres un friki y quieres ser de los primeros en tener la nueva maravilla de Google: El Nexus 4 fabricado por LG. Los minutos comienzan a correr.Llega la una de la maÃ±ana de ese dÃ­a 16 y la pÃ¡gina de Google sigue mostrando un escueto mensaje:Â DISPONIBLE PRÃ“XIMAMENTE. Llegan las 2 y todo sigue igual.Sigues leyendo Tapatalk temeroso de que ''salte la liebre'' y un club de foreros enfervorizados te deje sin tu juguete.
-Dormir es de cobardes te dices a ti mismo. AÂ las 4 de la maÃ±ana te sientes estÃºpido;llevas 4 horas delante del ordenador y no hay ni rastro.Te vas a dormir.Sabes que por la maÃ±ana el mÃ³vil asomarÃ¡.Pones el despertador a las 8:30.Te despiertas a las 8:15.Saturas tapatalk de tanto consultar foros.Chrome explota de tanto refrescar Google Play.LLegan las 9:00 de la maÃ±ana y todo sigue igual.Y cuando te vas a echar otra cabezada(es lo que tiene trabajar por la tarde) dan las 9:15 y apareceÂ el mejor mensaje del aÃ±o Â Â la confirmaciÃ³n.
AÃ‘ADIR AL CARROÂ se puede leer.
Tras 15 minutos de problemas tÃ©cnicos en Google Play,el telÃ©fono estÃ¡ comprado.Una semanita mÃ¡s de nervios yÂ acojoneÂ en foros y aquÃ­ lo tienes:
Lenguaje de la caja Google Play,completamente minimalista.
Tras posar los ojos sobre Ã©l,maravillado con el diseÃ±o,lo sacas de la caja.Las sensaciones en la mano son de robustez y empaque.Se siente 'premium' como se suele decir.Y por 350â‚¬.Â¡QuÃ© engaÃ±ado todo este tiempo desembolsando barbaridades en Galaxys e Iphones! Por lo demÃ¡s,el diseÃ±o es minimalista,destacando otros dos detalles: la pantalla es curvada por los laterales facilitando el deslizamiento de los dedos a la hora de hacer gestos desde los bordes.Se siente una sensaciÃ³n especial por asÃ­ decirlo.Ya no mirarÃ¡s al resto de telÃ©fonos igual cuando Â lo tengas en la mano y sepas de lo que hablo.El otro detalle es la parte trasera con ese psicodÃ©lico efecto de discoteca o ''textura hologrÃ¡fica'' la cual le da un efecto sorprendente y moderno al terminal.La pena es que al estar hecha de cristal(a lo Iphone 4),Ã©sta parte del terminal es propensa a Â sufrir araÃ±azos o resquebrajamientos.En mi caso no tengo ninguna queja de durabilidad.Eso sÃ­,le he puesto una carcasa rÃ­gida transaparente al telÃ©fono por si acaso.De hecho el telÃ©fono se me ha caido al suelo dos veces y no ha habido ni el mÃ¡s mÃ­nimo rasguÃ±o en parte alguna del terminal(y soy insistente buscÃ¡ndolos).Sigue impoluto.Bendita carcasa.
Enciendes el telÃ©fono:
Sparky presidiendo mi Nexus.
En ese frontal tan caracterÃ­stico Nexuniano(es Â casi calcado al frontal del Galaxy Nexus) se abre ante nosotros una pantalla LCD IPS Â HD de 4'7'' con una resoluciÃ³n de 1280x720 pixeles con matriz rgb completa(Nada de Pentiles a lo Samsung) con una DPI de 320.Lo primero en lo que te fijas viniendo de la pantalla HD del Galaxy Nexus y el Galaxy S3 es en la nitidez por el uso de la citada matrix RGB en vez de Pentile.Los textos se ven sublimes dando la sensaciÃ³n de leer texto impreso.En cuanto a los colores son muy realistas lo cual para mi es un punto a su favor.Avisados quedaÃ­s los que esteÃ­s acostumbrados los colores hipersaturados de las pantallas AMOLED(GALAXY S,S2,S3 etc..) de que la pantalla nos os va a parecer tan viva por asÃ­ decirlo como las pantallas de los citados telÃ©fonos.Los negros son de lo mejorcito que se puede ver en pantallas LCD y los blancos son blancos inmaculados.Gran nivel en este aspecto.Los Ã¡ngulos de visiÃ³n son bastante buenos aunque ligeramente por debajo(quizÃ¡ ni lo notes) de las pantallas de HTC One X,Galaxy S3 e Iphone 5.Tampoco es que vayas a mirar al mÃ³vil de lado Â¿O si? Para el uso en exteriores hay que decir que la pantalla es muy reflectiva por lo que si no subimos el brillo a un nivel alto o al mÃ¡ximo puede que cueste verla.AÃºn asÃ­ me cuesta mucho menos ver en exteriores la pantalla del Nexus 4 Â que lo que me costaba ver la del Galaxy S3 Â y la del Galaxy Nexus. En resumen una de las mejores pantallas del mercado,eso sÃ­ por detrÃ¡s de la del HTC One X(la mejor del mercado probablemente).Y como esto avanza muy rÃ¡pido habrÃ¡ que ver que opino cuando salgan Â elÂ Sony XPERIA Z,el HTC M7,Oppo Find 5Â y una oleada de telÃ©fonos con pantallas FULL HD.Pero esa es la tendencia de 2013 y nostros estamos hablando de lo que se puede comprar en el mercado(Ya se que nuestro Nexus lleva agotado desde que saliÃ³).
En cuanto al sonido,el altavoz suena bastante alto siempre y cuando no lo tapes mucho ya que como suele ser habitual estÃ¡ en la parte trasera.No he tenido llamadas perdidas por no escucharlo en este sentido.En cuanto a su calidad para reproducciÃ³n,pues,es un altavoz de mÃ³vil como tantos otros.Puedes usarlo en alguna ocasiÃ³n esporÃ¡dica pero como siempre digo,si quieres disfrutar del audio, conÃ©ctale unos auriculares.En mi caso lo uso con unos Brainwazz M1 con los cuales la calidad de sonido es bastante buena(de serie) y bordea el excelente(con DSP Manager)..El sonido es un poco bajo y falta algo de fuerza en bajos y agudos.Recomiendo usarlo con DSP Manager.La calidad de audio con ese programa y una buena ecualizaciÃ³n es sublime.Bajos contundentes y medios y agudos claros y nÃ­tidos y sin distorsiones y volumen mÃ¡s alto.En definitiva el audio de serie serÃ­a un 7'5/10 y el audio modificado 9/10.Tener en cuenta que los auriculares que useÃ­s influyen mucho.
NOTAS COMPLETAMENTE SUBJETIVAS CON DISTINTOS AURICULARES
MÃšSICA QUE SUELO ESCUCHAR: ROCK/METAL ANGLOSAJÃ“N Y HIP HOP/RAP ANGLOSAJÃ“N
BRAINWAZZ M1: Â Â 9/10 HEADDIRECT RE0: Â 8'5/10 XEARS MAESTRO MH700 PRO: Â Â 7'5/10 MONSTER UR BEATS :6'5/10 (NO ME GUSTAN)
EXPERIENCIA DE Â USO
LO BUENO
Configuras tu cuenta Google,conectas a tu red WIFI,vinculas tus redes sociales y ahÃ­ estÃ¡s,en el escritorio.Dejas que se descarguen tus apps de Google Play y lo primero que notas es la fluidez del terminal.El procesador Snapdragon S4 Pro a 1.5 GHz con GPU Adreno 320 hace un trabajo encomiable moviendo Android,en este caso la versiÃ³n 4.2, sin atisbo alguno de lag(Y mira que Android 4.2 tiene lag que ni la todopoderosa Nexus 10 lo mueve al 100%) y con una respuesta instantÃ¡nea.Una gozada.Â¿Y la multitarea? Puedes abrir tantas aplicaciones como desees sin preocuparte de que el terminal se muestre tosco o poco fluido.Esto es gracias a los generosos 2gb de RAM que lleva el pequeÃ±Ã­n de Google y LG.Te sorprenderÃ¡s al ver que el movil te abre al instante una aplicaciÃ³n que no usas desde el dÃ­a anterior.Generalmente solo acabarÃ¡s cerrando aplicaciones si ves que te consumen baterÃ­a y poco mÃ¡s.No os imaginaÃ­s la diferencia que hay con respecto a un Galaxy S3,HTC One X,Galaxy Nexus o una Nexus 7 en este aspecto.Como la noche y el dÃ­a.Hasta me cuesta volver a usar mi querida Nexus 7 pese a que termino cayendo en sus redes.Eso sÃ­,toca bajar la expectativa de rendimiento. Videos HD,webs complejas,streaming de mÃºsica,juegos avanzados como NFS Most Wanted o GTA Vice City.Da igual lo que le eches encima que el terminal se mueve como un rayo.Y olvidaros de los benchmarks,no sirven para mucho.La fluidez de uso es la mejor de un Android y en mi opiniÃ³n por primera vez se supera al Iphone en este aspecto. En cuanto a Android 4.2 no voy a extenderme sobre sus virtudes ya que han sido tratadas en multitud de webs.Solo dirÃ© que es la versiÃ³n mÃ¡s fluida de Android y que Google Now es una autÃ©ntica revoluciÃ³n.
LO MALO Eso si,se hace necesaria la actualizaciÃ³n a Android 4.2.2 por parte de Google cuanto antes ya que Android 4.2 no es precisamente la versiÃ³n mÃ¡s libre de bugs que haya habido. Sobre todo en cuanto a baterÃ­a,el peor aspecto del Nexus 4.El terminal puede aguantarnos 24 horas seguidas pero poco mÃ¡s.La duraciÃ³n dependerÃ¡ del uso de cada uno.En mi caso mi media actual son 3h de pantalla con uso mixto en WIFI y 3G,con 2 cuentas de correo(Gmail y Hotmail),Whatsapp,Twitter,Google Reader,Google Now(consume bastante baterÃ­a),un rato de Spotify,navegaciÃ³n web,consulta del algÃºn foro en Tapatalk y alguna partida a NFS Most wanted(15-20 minutos).Y con este uso me dura entre 12 y 18 horas.Consigo apaÃ±arme pero se torna tirando a insuficiente.Se dice que en futuras versiones del OS de los de Mountain View el consumo de baterÃ­a sera mejorado.A ver si es verdad. Por ahora no queda otra que jugar con kernels para intentar llegar a las ansiadas 5-6 horas de pantalla y mejorar el consumo en espera.MÃ¡s teniendo en cuenta que la baterÃ­a no es extraible per se.Es cierto que con un destornillador y un poco de cuidado puede cambiar uno mismo la baterÃ­a(cosa que no es para nada facil en Iphone 5 y HTC One X por ejemplo),pero esto no es ideal para aquellos que necesiten usar intensivamente el telÃ©fono y gusten de llevar una segunda baterÃ­a encima.A cambio tenemos una calidad de construcciÃ³n de calidad en el diseÃ±o del telÃ©fono empleando cristal en su parte trasera.Lo tomas o lo dejas.Yo aÃºn asÃ­ lo tomo. Otra pequeÃ±a tara del terminal de cara a los mas jugones es el thermal throttling.Esto consiste en que cuando el telÃ©fono detecta un calor excesivo por parte del procesador(jugando a juegos 3d normalmente) se reduce la velocidad mÃ¡xima a la que trabaja la cpu para prevenir el deterioro de Ã©sta por funcionar a temperaturas excesivas prolongando la vida de la cpu y evitando fallos de funcionamiento.El tema es que la CPU del Nexus 4 aplica el thermal throttling bastante pronto por lo que en una sesiÃ³n de juego de 20-30 minutos se reduce la velocidad de la cpu y en algunos juegos esto se traduce en una bajada aparente del rendimiento del juego.La soluciÃ³n es que LG mejore los drivers del kernel del telÃ©fono evitando que el terminal se caliente tanto y por ende el thermal throttling no actÃºe tan pronto.Como siempre tenemos kernels personalizados en XDA Developers que se encargan de estos problemas.Puedo decir que usando varios de estos kernels no he tenido problemas de rendimiento en sesiones prolongadas de juego ni calentamiento excesivo del telÃ©fono. Sobre la ausencia de ranura de micro SD,un par de cuestiones:
1.A ser posible compra el modelo de 16 gb(350â‚¬) en vez del de 8gb(300â‚¬),sobre todo si pretendes instalar juegos.En el futuro lo agradecerÃ¡s.
2.Â¿HabrÃ­a sido ideal sacar un modelo de 32gb por 400-450â‚¬? Desde luego.Pero por el motivo X o Y la capacidad mÃ¡xima son 16gb.Para el usuario al que le guste llevar toda su mÃºsica,fotos y videos en almacenamiento local es un dealbreaker total y por tanto no le recomendaria Ã©sta maravilla.Pero los tiempos cambian,el almacenamiento local empieza a ser sustituido complementado por los servicios en la nube.En vez de tener miles de fotos en el telÃ©fono,podemos dejar la esenciales en el movil y el resto subirlas a Dropbox para acceder a ellas desde cualquier lugar.En vez de llevar toda nuestra mÃºsica,podemos subirla a Google Music y acceder cuando deseemos(y escuchar sin conexiÃ³n las pistas que mas queramos en ese momento para no gastar tarifa de datos) o en Spotify.Y para vÃ­deos pues tenemos youtube y el propio Dropbox por ejemplo.En mi caso concreto me administro perfectamente con 16gb por lo que no lo voy a contar como un punto negativo.Para el que no pueda amoldar su pensamiento a la Nube o quiera mas de 16gb le toca mirar a otro lado.
LO BUENO OTRA VEZ Recibes siempre el primero durante dos aÃ±os la Ãºltima versiÃ³n de Android lo cual es uno de los filones de los terminales Nexus.Recordad que en Mayo-Junio se presenta Android 5.0 o 4.3 Key Lime Pie y los poseedores de un Nexus son los primeros en la linea de Salida.No obstante,mientras todos los fabricantes estÃ¡n actualizando sus telÃ©fonos a Android 4.1.2,los poseedores de Galaxy Nexus,Nexus 7,Nexus 10 y Nexus 4 ya estÃ¡n disfrutando Android 4.2.1.Poco mÃ¡s que decir.
No eres un nexus si tu software no es modificable hasta el extremo.Y he aquÃ­ la gran virtud del Nexus 4.Â¿No te gusta que el movil se caliente oÂ Quieres ahorrar baterÃ­a? cÃ¡mbiale el kernel.Â¿Esta semana te aburre Android Stock? PuÃ©s cÃ¡mbiale la Rom.Â¿Quieres instalar Ubuntu Mobile?Pues espera 1 mes o 2.Y asÃ­ podrÃ­amos continuar con miles de ejemplos.Es el terminal ideal para la comunidad,los aficionados a la tecnologÃ­a,a los que les gusta decidir como quieren usar su dispositivo y personalizarlo al 100%,a los que no quieren seguir los dictados de una compaÃ±Ã­a concreta.Esa es la filosofÃ­a de los terminales Nexus y hasta cierto punto de Android,pese a que fabricantes como HTC se empeÃ±en en cerrar sus terminales al mÃ¡ximo para que instalar roms o modificiar el terminal sea un proceso farragoso.Mientras Ã©sto no cambie seguirÃ© siendo fiel a los terminales Nexus.Please Google don't follow the Apple way.
CONCLUSIONES
Google da un golpe en la mesa ofreciÃ©ndonos un terminal potentÃ­simo,bonito,modificable a un precio nunca visto en la gama alta.Un escaparate perfecto para las nuevas versiones de Android.Una nueva bara de medir para los terminales estrella del resto de fabricantes que tendrÃ¡n que justificar mÃ¡s que nunca los 600â‚¬ de media que valen sus propuestas ofreciendo prestaciones interesantes.Todos ganamos.
Mi nota para el Nexus 4 es de 9'5/10

post.title: Asaf Avidan â€“ One DayReckoning Song
post.summary: Listen to Asaf Avidan & the Mojos - One Day / Reckoning Song (Wankelmut Remix) - Radio Edit (3,56 min) on spotify. One Day / Reckoning Song (Wankelmut Remix) - Radio Edit can be found on the album One Day / Reckoning Song (Wankelmut Remix) which were released 2012, track nr: 1About Asaf Avidan28-year-old Avidan is a folk singer/songwriter; His vocal - sounding very much like the legendary Janis Joplin - is unmatched; and he sings primarily in English. "A genius... A new Messiah" (Rolling Stone Mexico) and "The most interesting voice in the Israeli music scene" are just some of the accolades he has received. He nowdays tours and records with his band, The Mojos. - Ran Nir (bass), Joni Snow (drums), Roi Peled (lead guitar), and Hadas Kleinman (cello); Avidan started writing in the wake of a painful breakup, eventually producing his first EP, "Now That You're Leaving", released in June 2006. It was produced independently and has sold out its initial print of 1,000, and has recently been signed to a U.S. publishing deal. Avidan began playing solo in bars, accompanying himself with his guitar and harmonica, and slowly gathered a loyal following. In January 2007 he assembled The Mojos, and took his music on another, rockier, path. Nowdays The Mojos are performing to sellout crowds and a major hype has arisen in the Israeli media. Avidan's 2nd release, a full LP titled "The Reckoning", recorded with The Mojos, was released in late May 2007. In June 2008, his album, "The Reckoning", went to the No.#01 Sales Charts in Israel on it's 2nd week of release; It has sold more then 2.5 times then the album in 2nd position, securing him a Gold Certified Album. last.fm Pictures of Asaf AvidanShow more imagesMore: Asaf Avidan Asaf Avidan's officiella homepageTopplistorna: Mando Diao etta Music video with Asaf AvidanHere you can find videos from Youtube with Asaf Avidan - One Day/Reckoning Song Conserts with Asaf Avidan PALAIS DES FESTIVALS & DES CONGRES in Cannes(2013-01-26)Tivoli in Utrecht(2013-03-06)Melkweg in Amsterdam(2013-03-23)De Effenaar Eindhoven in Eindhoven(2013-03-24)L'ATELIER in Luxembourg Ville(2013-03-26)Ancienne Belgique in Brussels(2013-03-27)L'Ouvre-BoÃ®te in Beauvais(2013-03-29)Le Cargo in Caen(2013-03-30)Le Liberte in Rennes(2013-04-02)La Nef in AngoulÃªme(2013-04-03)Le Bikini in Ramonville-Saint-Agne(2013-04-04)Le Transbordeur in Villeurbanne(2013-04-06)L'Olympia in Paris(2013-04-09)Le Splendid in Lille(2013-04-10)Laiterie in Strasbourg(2013-04-12)La Vapeur in Dijon(2013-04-13)GRAND CASINO BASEL in Basel(2013-04-14)Les Docks in Lausanne(2013-04-16)Cabaret Aleatoire in Marseille(2013-04-18)THEATRE LINO VENTURA in Nice(2013-04-19)Jahrhunderthalle in Frankfurt Am Main(2013-05-03)Tonhalle MÃƒÂ¼nchen in Munich(2013-05-09)Forum Bielefeld in Bielefeld(2013-05-30)PLEIN AIR in Marmande(2013-06-30)Parc de Valmy in ArgelÃ¨s-Sur-Mer(2013-07-09)Prairie de Landaoudec in Crozon(2013-08-04)L'Olympia in Paris(2013-09-22)

post.title: Nokia outs Music+ subscription app for Lumia range
post.summary: Nokia has updated its Music app for Lumia phones with a new premium subscription option it is calling Music+. For just â‚¬3.99/$3.99 a month, users of the existing Nokia Music streaming service can upgrade to Music+, which gives them unlimited skips in the Mix Radio portion and unlimited downloads for offline playback. The service also brings in audio at a higher quality and karaoke-style lyric sheets for the song users are currently listening to. Users will also be able to stream music from a web browser, making Music+ a suitable Spotify alternative on both desktop and mobile. Mix Radio stays intactNon-premium subscribers will still be able to access the 17m tracks already available through Mix Radio, which brings over 150 specially curated playlists and the opportunity for users to create custom playlists from the library. Jyrki Rosenberg, VP Entertainment at Nokia, told the Nokia conversation blog: "It's the only smartphone music service out there offering access to millions of songs out of the box without the need to sign up, sign in, or suffer adverts in between enjoying the music. "When you add in the ability to skip songs and save playlists for offline uses like the tube, you have something unique. "This is for people who care enough about music to pay something for more quality and choice, but don't want to pay â‚¬9.99 monthly." The new Music+ app will roll out in the next couple of weeks throughout the US and European territories.
