post.title: Nokia introduces Music+ streaming service for $3.99 a month
post.summary:
Headed to the Lumia
Nokia has announced a paid subscription plan for its free Mix Radio service in order to take on Spotify, RDIO, Slacker, and more.? Dubbed Music+, Nokia will be charging?â‚¬3.99 (or $3.99 USD) a month for access to unlimited music skipping, downloads, higher streaming quality and lyrics. Customers can also access the service without their phone, using Nokia's web app.? â€œNokia Music is great for discovering new music, and weâ€™ve found that thereâ€™s a core of users that want even more of it. This is how Nokia Music+ came about," said Jyrki Rosenberg, VP Entertainment at Nokia.?"By introducing features like infinite skips and unlimited downloads, weâ€™re opening the doors?for unlimited music discovery at only â‚¬3.99 per month." Nokia confirmed to Pocket-lint that users will not be able to search for specific songs to download, as with?Spotify. But they can add up to three artist names into a playlist and Music+ will build up around 50 tracks, which can be saved offline. Users' local tracks from their own library can also be played through the app. Music+ will provide more info about the artist, and show you related playlists featuring that performer. Nokia says the service will roll out over the next few weeks, but hasn't yet detailed to which countries.?
Read
Tags: Nokia Music+ Music Lumia
Â
Nokia introduces Music+ streaming service for $3.99 a month originally appeared on http://www.pocket-lint.com on Sun, 27 Jan 2013 18:10:00 +0000

post.title: Check It Out
post.summary: CHECK IT OUTÂ is the catchphrase byÂ AsfalttisoturiÂ (Asphalt soldier) andÂ Karri KoiraÂ (Karri the Dog) on last Friday night! Asfalttisoturi and Karri Koira are two of the most popular Finnish rappers. and Asfalttisoturi won theÂ national rap championshipÂ last year. Me and dozen of my friends attendedÂ a rap gig in 45 Special in Oulu. The night wasÂ sold outÂ with 300 tickets and the place was more than crowded.Â In the picture I lookÂ happy as a hippo, and it totally describes my mood on that night too! Special events like this is one of my favorite ways toÂ add luxury to dull winter months! We got there quite early and reservedÂ spots right in the front row! This became rather a long wait as the gig began aboutÂ half an hour late but it was all worth it in the end.Â Asfalttisoturi andÂ Karri KoiraÂ areÂ insanely funny peopleÂ and I was cracking up throughout the night. I also like these guys for how they stand out from others rappers byÂ not having bad manners or using harsh language. Also the message in their songs hasÂ high morale. . There was an unexpected turn in the show when someone managed toÂ steal Asfalttisoturi's T-shirt on the stage. Quite a bit ofÂ sweet-talk and promise of a free CDÂ were needed before the shirt was returned.Â All's well that ends well!Â I also checked out Asfalttisoturi's shoes! It is a really fast and accurate way toÂ define quality men, I have noticed.Â AsfalttisoturiÂ totallyÂ passed my testÂ but he is already married so it was nothing personal in this case. All in all it wasÂ a great night and awesome start for the weekend!Â Here is a link toÂ K.O.I.R.A. on Spotify. Karri K.O.I.R.A. & Asfalttisoturi - Amerikankotka LiitÃ¤Ã¤ (American Eagle Glides)

post.title: U2 acusa a Google de hacer dinero con la piraterÃ­a
post.summary: â€œGoogle le ha dado mucho a la civilizaciÃ³n en tÃ©rminos de conocimiento, son ingeniosos, pero estÃ¡n haciendo dinero redirigiendo al pÃºblico hacia pÃ¡ginas que contienen piraterÃ­aâ€, ha dicho el portavoz de la cÃ©lebre banda durante su participaciÃ³n hoy en una charla del Mercado Internacional del Disco y la EdiciÃ³n Digital (MIDEM) en Cannes (Francia). Ha sido en el mismo foro donde hace un aÃ±o exacto el propio McGuiness acusÃ³ a Google de no hacer nada para desincentivar ese tipo de resultados en sus bÃºsquedas. â€œMe gustarÃ­a ver algo de acciÃ³n por su parteâ€, ha aÃ±adido hoy. Entonces desconfiÃ³ tambiÃ©n de la intervenciÃ³n de los polÃ­ticos, temerosos de aplicar medidas por el riesgo a resultar â€œimpopularesâ€, aunque hoy se ha sentado junto al comisario europeo de Mercado Interior y Servicios, Michel Barnier, para discutir sobre el diÃ¡logo emprendido por Bruselas en el Ã¡mbito de los derechos de autor. â€œCelebro mucho esta iniciativaâ€, ha dicho McGuiness, que ha insistido en que, pese al crecimiento de los servicios legales de suscripciÃ³n musical como Spotify o Deezer, Ã©stos no representan de momento mÃ¡s que un medio â€œpuramente promocionalâ€ incluso para una gran banda como U2 y que â€œGoogle sigue siendo el gran distribuidorâ€. Barnier, por su parte, ha apostado por estudiar la forma de garantizar el acceso de todos los europeos por igual a servicios y contenidos digitales legales, independientemente del territorio, coordinando las distintas leyes reguladoras sobre patentes y derechos de autor. post.title: Nokia to launch Music+ with unlimited streaming and downloads
post.summary: If you've got a Nokia Lumia smartphone, you'll probably be familiar with the Nokia Music app. It let's you stream hours of music playlists under variousÂ categories, like Jazz, 70's, Dance and so on. You're limited in the number of skips you're allowed if you don't like a particular track and you can download up to four playlists at any one time to listen off-line. And it's all free. Now the company has announced it will be releasing Nokia Music+, a subscription service that lets you download unlimited playlists, gives you unlimited skips and it'll all be in ad-free higher quality. Basically, Nokia is trying to take on other subscription services like Spotify. So, it's all down to cost really. Nokia says it will be charging 3.99 Euro a month in Europe, which is pretty competitive. There are no more pricing details yet, but we expect the UK price to be Â£3.99 because...well, that's just the way it is. Nokia says it will be rolling out Music+, which can be accessed on computers as well as phones, "in the next few weeks". (Source:Â official Nokia blog)

post.title: BEN HOWARD Live in Copenhagen
post.summary: Hey ho people! This post is to introduce Ben Howard in l'alternativamusical! For those who already know him; here's a review of his show in Copenhagen (the 18th december), for those who don't, just listen and meet a great musician besides a soulful voice.Â http://troest.nu/ben-howard-store-vega-december-18/So, it's been a month already since this beautiful rainy Tuesday evening. The concert (sold out of course) was host in VEGA, a well-known musikkens hus! The warm-up was supported by Monica Heldal (a 21 year oldÂ NorwegianÂ singer-songwriter, with sweet voice and harmonies) it was a correct starting point, with her slowÂ travellingÂ folk gently emerging (though I found her somehow cold and she didn't win the crowd over directly... she offered a proper performance). After this, Ben Howard and his excellent band (India Bourne, Chris Bond & irish-looking musician!?) took the stage for a lovely top gig. Down here you can see the set list ! (from India Bourne's)Â It was their last show, after almost one year touring around the UK and Europe, and they played in complete harmony, with both excitement and nostalgia feelings arising. The songs of his album Every Kingdom (2011) as well as the new EP Burgh IslandÂ (2012) were combined, therefore the mix of acoustic and electric instruments, folk and rock sounds, happy and sad lyrics, joyful and darkened moments... So it started with calm Everything. "Every kingdom, must one day come to an end". The audience listened expectantly (to stress here I think he deserves more than feminine hysterical yells... jejejej). Then, melancholicÂ Black Flies followed by more cloudless Old Pine.Â Another bright tune is Diamonds.Â Happy-hearted after this. Simply sunny. No secrets for him with the guitar. Check Under the Same Sun for some skilled air tapping.Â Another great version was Only Love, one of the most famous songs he has, andÂ the crowd sang along with them. After this one, he moved to the newest album, to play Burgh Island and Esmerelda. You can notice this change, to somehow a darker music, intense and deep notes and his voice putting the finishing touch.Â Who can resist the sound of his voice when he turns the shouting mode on?! (min 03:15). SOULFUL. Silence. Â Â Finally, the last three tracks; The Wolves, Keep Your Head Up, and The FearÂ made the audience go wild! *You can also appreciate the nice lighting and visuals which moved from blue moon to red sun depending on the mood of the song. Â Â "I been worryin' that my time is a little unclearÂ I been worryin' that I'm losing the one's I hold dearÂ I been worryin' that we all live our lives in the confines of fear.Â Oh I will become what I deserve" After the public's ovation, they played Oats in the Water and finished with Promise. Beautiful and peaceful melodies to calm down and enjoy what has been the end of a great night.Â On the whole, it was a wonderful concert, and my advice for you is to undoubtedly attend one of his gigs if you have the opportunity. His live performance is even better than the records; an excellent show served with simplicity, creating such a charming atmosphere. *I link here Ben Howard's Playlist on Spotify

post.title: Nokia Introduces Nokia+ Music Service: Unlimited Music At â‚¬3.99
post.summary: Nokia has just announced the launch of their new music service the Nokia Music+ service. This service will let you enjoy all the songs in the Nokia store for a monthly subscription which isÂ â‚¬3.99. Awesome, right ? As you would expect, the service will allow unlimited streaming, skips and downloading of music using this service. In other words, it clearly kicks out the need for Spotify on the go. Besides, you get the same for almost one third of the price.Â Nokia Mix Radio usersÂ neednâ€™t worry. The service still remains free and you can continue using it as usual. Nokia Music+ offers music at higher quality, although they didnâ€™t quite mention the exact bit rate. Lyrics will also be available with the songs you download from the store and the service can also be enjoyed on desktop or smart TVs through the web app.Â The service will be rolled out in a few weeks time.

post.title: BLADE Release New Recordings
post.summary:
Blade has a significant meaning in and vision on nowadays Hardcore which I will try to elaborate in this article. This write-up begins with a review of their newest record and ends with an earlier recorded 7 inch release. There are also has some discography details.
BLADE obviously takes influences from 90's metalcore. You can hear that from first listen. Although it needs to be said that it's definitely not repetitive or similar sounding to the bands the are inspired by. I hear a lot of All Out War heavy hitting riffs in their sound for example, maybe some Morning Again metal-melody but definitely also Congress and Earth Crisis sounds are involved. Not that it's a reincarnation of the H8000-area sound somewhere else in Belgium (Limburg), definitely not. They do it right and with this I mean they continue to set an updated trend of that metallic hardcore that emerged in the 90's with Integrity and Ringworm up to this very day in 2013.
They just released Â their newest recordings (recorded this winter), under the nameÂ "Armed With Abstinence". That you canÂ buy a download or hard copy CD from on several places. Support real hardcore, music and bands byÂ getting aÂ legal copy!
As a package deal (CD and Shirt) http://seventhdagger.bigcartel.com/product/blade-armed-with-abstinence-package
As a CDep: http://revhq.com/store.revhq?Page=search&Id=SDAG040
Or as a LEGAL download on various sites: iTunes Spotify Last FM Amazon Rhapsody Interpunk
They already had three titles released before this: respectively a demo CD-r, a split 10 Inch and a 7 Inch.
Firstly their demo 2007 which was self-released on a CD-r. In my opinion, this ain't bad but too heavy on the Integrity trip. A little bit to much of Integrity to be original and progressive. Although I hear it's the best time-period that they are inspired from. Namely the "Humanity Is The Devil" period. I guess this DIY release is almost nowhere to be found.
So consequently they gave these exact same songs a decent release later on a 10 Inch split vinyl with Goldust shortly after in the same year 2007. The 10 Inch vinyl exists in two versions; black (/100) and colored vinyl (/400) in a gatefold sleeve. You can listen to these tracksÂ here.Â The label that released this is BreakxOut Records from Hamburg in Germany. You can still order this from some distro's, even on colored vinyl. I see them for sale atÂ Good LifeÂ webstore andÂ Demons Run Amok distribution on eBay.
As it appears I already have the third release of earlier (2009) BLADE in my collection but never came to write about it before. Look at the typical nineties artwork (fire-spitting dragon fighting knights in harnesses) in a beautiful, warm and hazy lookingÂ color-scheme.
I interpret it as such; the ethical mission started by 90's hardcore and continued nowadays by Blade couldn't be symbolized more with this imagery. Good versus evil fightingÂ each otherÂ as well on the inside and outside of people. Outside as in this music or message they try to bring forward in the contemporary Hardcore landscape. Even if demons appear bigger than us we gather to fight them still. In the formation of a Straight-Edge band they voice their anger and discontent. But they also express regret about the current hardcore scene. They still want to bring a decent message with intelligent content, which is a bit forgotten nowadays. As it's all about sensation, being though and not thinking about good and right so much anymore.
BLADE "Lambs To The Slaughter" 7 inch
The title track of this 7inch features Hans from LIAR fame on vocals and was released by Ugly And Proud Records. The track "Lambs To The Slaughter" has a faster intro with loads of melody also and is a protest against warfare. And shows musical influences taken from Ringworm and Integrity.
The lyrical writing style is like the nineties writing style; dark, symbolicÂ and showing the wrongs and rights of things. An approach to ethical side of things happening in our world. Also showing a deeper conscience of human nature and intelligence overall.
And they aren't shy in saying they are Straight-edge too. Straight-edge pride and ethics in theirÂ song-texts. The fact that they are still straight-edge combined with this style of music is a real powerful message and maybe a tribute to the mighty edge-metal as it truly was and should remain up to this day. Thanks Blade!

post.title: Consumo colaborativo
post.summary:
Aunque nos avisan por todas partes de que los recursos de la tierra son finitos, la mayorÃ­a de nosotros nos comportamos como si no lo fueran, gastando y consumiendo sin tener en cuenta la gran cantidad de recursos y materias primas que son necesarias para mantener nuestro modo de vida y, en muchos casos, sin prestar atenciÃ³n a la ingente cantidad de basuras y desperdicios que generamos cada dÃ­a. Son muchos tambiÃ©n quienes se dan cuenta de que esta forma de consumo es perjudicial para nosotros, para nuestro planeta y para nuestro futuro. Uno de los mÃ©todos que se han ideado para intentar cambiarlo es el denominado consumo colaborativo, un mÃ©todo que se ha reforzado con la crisis econÃ³mica, ya que tambiÃ©n nos permite ahorrar.
QuÃ© es y cÃ³mo nace SegÃºn los expertos, el consumo colaborativo podrÃ­a definirse como un cambio en los hÃ¡bitos de consumo tanto a nivel cultural como econÃ³mico que estÃ¡ haciendo que nos movamos desde el consumismo individualizado a nuevos modelos de intercambio, alquiler, trueque o uso compartido, cambio que estÃ¡ siendo favorecido por la tecnologÃ­a y, sobre todo, por las redes sociales. El tÃ©rmino consumo colaborativo apareciÃ³ por primera vez en un artÃ­culo del mismo tÃ­tulo escrito por Ray Algar en 2007, en el boletÃ­n Leisure Report, pero no se popularizÃ³ hasta 2010, cuando apareciÃ³ un libro publicado â€œLo que es mÃ­o es tuyo, el auge del consumo Colaborativoâ€, momento en el que la idea comenzÃ³ a calar en la sociedad. Sistemas de consumo colaborativo
A partir de ahÃ­ nacieron sistemas de consumo colaborativo que cada vez nos resultan mÃ¡s populares en determinados aspectos de nuestra vida: - Vivienda: intercambio de casas, o el couchsurfing, alojamiento compartido, huertos compartidos, etc. - Transporte: Bike-crossing, carpooling, carsharing, etc. - MÃºsica: Spotify o Grooveshark, etc. - Finanzas: Trueque, bancos de tiempo, etc. - Bienes de consumo: bookcrossing, intercambio de ropa, etc.
Consumo colaborativo es una entrada publicada en Despilfarro

post.title: Nokia intros Music+ subscription service with unlimited downloads, web listening
post.summary: Most of the bigger streaming music services have both a free tier for casual listeners and a paid level for truly committed music fans. Nokia doesn't want to be the exception to the rule. It's launching Nokia Music+, a paid version of its existing platform. Paying â‚¬4 per month ($4 in the US) gives perks that you'd normally expect from a more expensive alternative like Spotify or Slacker's premium tier: the upgrade ratchets up the audio quality, adds lyrics, allows unlimited skips in Mix Radio and enables as many downloads for offline play as the phone can hold. Aren't you suddenly glad that you picked up a 32GB Lumia 920? Not that you'll always need it to tune in -- Music+ adds web streaming for anything with a suitably capable browser. Nokia hasn't said just which countries beyond the US will get the more advanced service, but it should make a formal debut within the next few weeks. Filed under: Cellphones, Portable Audio/Video, Internet, Mobile, Nokia Comments Source: Conversations by Nokia

Toevallig botste ik op het nieuwste nummer van Zazie, â€œLes contrairesâ€. Het volledige album verschijnt dit voorjaar. Gisteren op Spotify haar hele oeuvre erdoor gejaagd. En dat bracht me terug bij â€œRoseâ€, het nummer dat ze schreef voor de Belgische film â€œMa vie en roseâ€ van Alain Berliner. De film heeft me destijds (1997) erg ontroerd. Het vertelt het verhaal van een jongen die eigenlijk liever jurkjes draagt. De ouders weten niet hoe daar mee om te gaan, maar oma begrijpt het allemaal. De kranten stonden aan het begin van dit schooljaar vol van dergelijke verhalen. Ik heb op VRT een fijne collega, die me keer op keer vol trots over haar twee zonen praat. Dat haar ene zoontje, die intussen een puber wordt, alles weet over de laatste modecollecties. En dat hij vast wel een homo zal zijn. Allicht, maar gender en identiteit hoeven niet per se Ã©Ã©n op Ã©Ã©n seksueel georiÃ«nteerd te zijn. Het komt vast goed met die kerel. Meer nog, hij maakt het vast uitstekend. Mensen die wat grijs is, inkleuren zijn de gelukkigste mensen ter wereld. HoedanookÂ â€œRoseâ€ is een keitof nummer, zoals veel van die nummers van Zazie. Wat meer Franse muziek beluisteren, neem ik me voor. â€œRoseâ€, Zazie & Dominique Dalcan, beluister je hier. Een clip van de film â€œMa vie en roseâ€, zie je hier.
Je lis tous les romans Ã lâ€™eau de rose. Jâ€™en souligne des passages au crayon rose. Le bonheur mâ€™obsÃ¨de Ã la nÃ©vrose. post.title: Will Nokiaâ€™s Music+ Premium Service Be Enough To Dent Lumia Sales? Unlikely.
post.summary:
Nokia has had its free Nokia Music service for a while, allowing free music streaming on its Lumia handsets in the US since last September. But the service allowed for only a limited number of song skips and playlists. Now itâ€™s announced the impending launch of Music+, a premium music streaming service which will afford an infinite number of skips and unlimited downloads to Nokiaâ€™s Mix Radio service. Music+ will â€œroll out in the next few weeksâ€ and pricing will vary by region. In Europe it will be â‚¬3.99/month ($5.37) though the official US pricing has not been announced yet. This makes it more expensive than Pandora One, but close to the lowest Spotify Premium subscription. Since Nokia Music is not ad-supported, this presents the challenge of wooing consumers with more features alone, such as the infinite song skips, unlimited playlists, offline use, higher quality streaming, lyrics and desktop access via the Music+ site. However, is this extra service going to be enough to lure people towards the Nokia Lumia handsets on which its offered? Itâ€™s unlikely given the strong winds at the backs of Samsung and Apple right now. Speaking to Nokiaâ€™s Conversationâ€™s mouthpiece Jyrki Rosenberg, VP Entertainment at Nokia, said â€œWe spend a lot of time listening to how people use the service and have even managed to half the amount of skips per songs played, which is a combination of our systems and musicologists understanding and shaping Nokia Music around the users.â€ Yes but unfortunately the fate of the Nokia will not be down to musicologists but to the myriad other winds buffeting Nokia, not least the launch of the Blackberry 10 this week.

post.title: 20 Random Facts About Me
post.summary: We've all seen these floating around in the last couple of days, and I thought I would have a little go too. No video, just 20 little facts about little old me... 1. My degree is in Commercial Music, but as yet, I have no plans whatsoever to have any kind of career in music. I'm aiming to get into journalism - slightly unrelated but my course is very business-y, so the skills crossover is pretty decent. I don't regret doing a degree in music though; I've had the best six years of my life studying it at both college and uni, and I met my wonderful boyfriend through doing it too, so I wouldn't change it for the world. 2. I cannot stand cheese. The only kind I can stomach is mozzarella on pizza (even then, sparingly) and cream cheese frosting for cakes. Otherwise, get it the hell away from me! 3. I've been blogging for around five years. I had a blog originally in 2008 and kept it for a year or so, before starting another, giving up completely when I moved out - and now I have this one! Not so much of a noob after all... 4. I moved in with my boyfriend after we'd been together for six months, when I was 18. Crazy soon, yes, but for us, it felt right. Everything fell into place at the right time and it was the right thing for us to do. We've been living together for nearly three years now and I couldn't imagine it any other way! 5. I cannot stand wearing jeans, leggings or any other kind of trouser. I wear them two days a week for work, and nothing else, unless they're slobby jogging bottoms or pyjamas. They don't suit me and I hate feeling restricted. Dresses all the way! 6. When I was six, I had a disastrous haircut that's scarred me for life. It was the first time I was allowed to choose my own hairstyle, so I did what every six year old did in 1997 and asked for a Posh Spice shoulder-length bob. However, I somehow wound up with a David Beckham bowl cut. Oh the irony... Subsequently I threw an enormous tantrum, throwing bottles and combs all over the salon, screaming, crying and kicking the hairdresser. Oops. 7. I moved from London to Aberdeenshire when I was 15. My parents bought a house in the middle of the countryside and I had to move from South East London to the back of beyond! My mum and brother moved a week before my Dad and I, so I could go to my secondary school graduation. We actually drove up straight after the graduation, with the car piled high, and me in my ballgown. How 80s movie of us. 8. One of my favourite sandwich kinds is Marmite and Quavers. Don't knock it til you've tried it. 9. My favourite album is Blue by Joni Mitchell. If you've never heard it, I urge you to get on Spotify now! Utter perfection. 10. I am the worst decision maker ever. Even when it comes to deciding inane things like what kind of biscuits to buy or what kind of bubble bath to use. 11. My boyfriend's grandmother gave me her beautiful pink vintage Raleigh bicycle a few months ago, but until I learn how to ride in the road and take one hand off to indicate, it's having a period of rest in the spare bedroom. 12. I can't swim. When I had lessons at primary school, I was too concerned with the fact that the instructor couldn't swim (seriously) and too preoccupied with my hatred of the smell, the humidity and the general grossness of public swimming baths to apply myself properly. It's something I really want to learn, but I'm a bit embarrassed to take lessons. 13. I'm a singer, and I play the guitar and piano a little, and used to write songs. See, there is a reason my degree is in music! If you'd like to listen to anything, there's some songs up here: soundcloud.com/laurajaynemusic. Don't judge me. 14. Both Prince William and Prince Harry told me that they'd marry me when I was a little girl. I was in Windsor for the day, when I was about seven, and it was the same day Prince Harry was enrolling at Eton. We stumbled across the press crowd and they spotted me in the crowd. When they asked me what I wanted to be when I was grown up, I said 'princess'. So, charming as they were, they told me one of them would marry me. Wills, you liar. Harry, call me. 15. I love Coronation Street. And Emmerdale. They're my guilty secret - I watch them when my boyfriend's asleep, or on the ITV player. It's a bit of an addiction. 16. I'm a complete homebody. When I was 17/18, I was WILD and was out drinking and partying all the time, I was hardly ever at home. My uncle owned a pub in the next village and my friends and I were there for three or four days at a time. It's so weird, because now I hardly ever go out clubbing, and I don't enjoy being drunk at all anymore. I just love a sociable cocktail, a bit of a dance and then home. Clubs are generally full of loud, obnoxious people wanting to get smashed and that's not really my scene anymore. My boyfriend has tamed me! Now I love being at home, in cosy clothes, making our own cocktails, or drinking tea(!), watching films and enjoying our own company. 17. I got into the third year of a university course without a single A-Level, which I think is quite an achievement. I have GCSEs, of course, and good ones at that, and I had a HND in Music, but normally A-Levels are a huge stipulation. Now I have an A-Level in English, which I completed at night classes last year whilst studying for my degree. That's dedication. 18. I'm such a wimp. I can't watch any scary films, creepy TV shows etc. When I'm at home alone, every noise creeps me out and makes me jump, and I have to sleep with a nightlight on if my boyfriend isn't home. 19. I collect vintage china. I have a small collection of beautiful teacups and saucers, a teapot, milk jugs, and a beautiful cake stand. Although I love my tea in an enormous Starbucks mug, sometimes there's nothing nicer than having tea and cake in a tiny, delicate little cup. I'm planning to extend my collection once we have our own kitchen, and much more storage! 20. My boyfriend really is my very best friend. Definitely. I tell him everything, we talk about everything and we just have so much fun. I'm not one for massive soppiness but honestly, every day is better than the last with a boy like mine. I'm happier now than I've ever been, and I'd say that's probably all down to him :)

post.title: Will Nokiaâ€™s Music+ Premium Service Be Enough To Dent Lumia Sales? Unlikely.
post.summary: Nokia has had its free Nokia Music service for a while, allowing free music streaming on its Lumia handsets in the U.S. since last September. But the service allowed for only a limited number of song skips and playlists. Now itâ€™s announced the impending launch of Music+, a premium music-streaming service that will afford an infinite number of skips and unlimited downloads to Nokiaâ€™s Mix Radio service. Music+ will â€œroll out in the next few weeksâ€ and pricing will vary by region. In Europe it will be â‚¬3.99/month ($5.37), though the official U.S. pricing has not been announced yet. This makes it more expensive than Pandora One, but close to the lowest Spotify Premium subscription. Since Nokia Music is not ad-supported, this presents the challenge of wooing consumers with more features alone, such as the infinite song skips, unlimited playlists, offline use, higher quality streaming, lyrics and desktop access via the Music+ site. However, is this extra service going to be enough to lure people towards the Nokia Lumia handsets on which its offered? Itâ€™s unlikely, given the strong winds at the backs of Samsung and Apple right now. Speaking to Nokiaâ€™s Conversationâ€™s mouthpiece Jyrki Rosenberg, VP Entertainment at Nokia, said: We spend a lot of time listening to how people use the service and have even managed to half the amount of skips per songs played, which is a combination of our systems and musicologists understanding and shaping Nokia Music around the users. Yes, but unfortunately, the fate of Nokia will not be down to musicologists but to the myriad other winds buffeting Nokia, not least of which will be the launch of the BlackBerry 10 this week.

post.title: MUSIC/ART: Steed Lord
post.summary: Steed Lord is a self sufficient music and visual art collective from Iceland, based and working in Los Angeles. It consists of Kali, Demo and Mega. On top of producing and promoting three (incredible) albums, they also create all of their own music videos, model, DJ, design and are a part of WeSC's WeActivist program. Their newest album, The Prophecy Pt. 1 is my favourite yet, but each album is incredible in it's own right. It's a shame they don't receive more exposure, but they do seem to have a loyal cult following. Tour dates are mainly US/Icelandic, but I'm hoping for a couple of shows in the UK at some point this year. Spotify | Youtube | FacebookÂ | steedlord.com

post.title: Historia de un ignorante, ma non troppoâ€¦ Carmina Burana, de Orff, transcripciÃ³n para piano de Eric Chumachenco
post.summary:
El Ãºltimo artÃ­culoÂ de esta bamboleante serie musical tratÃ³ sobre una obra originalmente escrita para cuarteto de piano (piano, violÃ­n, viola y cello), el Cuarteto de Piano nÃºmero 1 de Johannes Brahms, en la transcripciÃ³n para orquesta (o sea, orquestaciÃ³n) de Arnold SchÃ¶nberg.
Esto de las orquestaciones es algo bastante habitual en el mundo de la mÃºsica, y casi todos los grandes compositores han realizado alguna en su vida. Se trata de tomar una obra para un instrumento solista (piano, violÃ­n, etc), o para pocos instrumentos (generalmente un trÃ­o o cuarteto), y, manteniendo la lÃ­nea temÃ¡tica de la obra original, reescribirla para una orquesta completa, con las posibilidades sonoras que esto permite. Viene a ser lo mismo que partir de una novela y, tras escribir el guiÃ³n con su temÃ¡tica, hacer una pelÃ­cula de ella. Del mismo modo que una pelÃ­cula adaptada a partir de una novela puede parecerse bastante al libro original,[1] y enriquecerle gracias a la potencia visual que el SÃ©ptimo Arte permite, o bien resultar en un bodrio irreconocible donde lo Ãºnico que queda es el nombre del libro, el del protagonista y poco mÃ¡s,[2] similares efectos ocurren con las diferentes transcripciones que se han hecho a lo largo de la historia. El resultado se puede parecer al original mucho, bastante, algo o casi nada, segÃºn la habilidad o la intenciÃ³n del arreglista.
En el artÃ­culo antes citado sobre el Cuarteto de Piano nÃºmero 1 de Brahms, SchÃ¶nberg fue absolutamente fiel al espÃ­ritu y a la mÃºsica original; hay otras ocasiones en que a duras penas reconoces el material de partidaâ€¦
En cualquier caso, lo que le parece al ignorante de turno, o sea, a mÃ­, es que orquestar, o sea, utilizar los recursos de una orquesta completa para representar la mÃºsica escrita para unos pocos instrumentos, o para uno solo, es relativamente sencillo, esâ€¦ cÃ³mo dirÃ­a yo, ir hacia delante, aÃ±adiendo contrapuntos e instrumentos al material original. Pero, queridos y aguerridos lectores de esta impertinente serie musical, resulta que tambiÃ©n se puede transcribir una obra musical â€œhacia atrÃ¡sâ€, por asÃ­ decirlo, es decir, reescribir una obra originalmente escrita para orquesta sinfÃ³nica y dejarla â€œen el chasisâ€ para ser interpretada por muchos menos instrumentosâ€¦ o uno solo: Un piano. De cola, pero un piano solo. Ã‰ste es el caso de hoy.
Carl Orff
La obra origen es nada menos que Carmina Burana, de Carl Orff. Pero Orff, si viviera, no deberÃ­a sentirse dolido porque alguien posterior haya tomado su obra y arreglado para piano o para lo que fuera (y lo digo porque precisamente la Carmina Burana de Orff ha sufrido muchos de estos arreglos, algunos de ellos como para poner los pelos de puntaâ€¦).
Efectivamente, las transcripciones musicales han sido usadas desde el principio de lo que venimos en llamar â€œmÃºsica occidentalâ€. Bach reutilizaba su propio material, o el de otros, transcribiÃ©ndolo para varios instrumentos diferentes; lo mismo hacÃ­an Vivaldi, Mozart, Haydn y todos los grandes. El motivo era no sÃ³lo ahorrarse buena parte de la creaciÃ³n de las lÃ­neas melÃ³dicas, que supongo que ahorrarÃ­a tiempo y neuronas, sino, en muchos casos, adaptar las obras a las habilidades o capacidades musicales de los patronos de los mÃºsicos. Si el Duque o PrÃ­ncipe de turno, protector de un mÃºsico barroco cualquiera, sabÃ­a tocar, por ejemplo, la bandurria, una de las obligaciones bÃ¡sicas del compositor era proporcionar mÃºsica de bandurria para que su amo y seÃ±or se luciera comme il faut tocÃ¡ndola ante sus invitados. Y esto se podÃ­a conseguir de tres maneras: componiendo mÃºsica original para bandurria (o bandurria y orquesta, o cuarteto de bandurria, etc), o bien trayendo mÃºsica compuesta por otros para dicho instrumento o, por fin, adaptar mÃºsica, bien del propio mÃºsico o de cualquier otro, para bandurria.
Hace algunos artÃ­culos ha salido por aquÃ­ el Quinteto de Guitarra nÃºmero 4, â€œFandangoâ€ de Boccherini, que es un ejemplo paradigmÃ¡tico de ello: el Duque de Osuna, protector de Luigi Boccherini, era un consumado guitarrista (o eso dicen las crÃ³nicas pagadas por el propio Duque). No habÃ­a mucha mÃºsica para guitarra por ahÃ­, asÃ­ que Boccherini compuso hasta doce Quintetos de Guitarra, ninguno de ellos original, puesto que fueron todos transcripciones para guitarra de otros cuartetos o quintetos suyos, para el guitarrÃ­stico disfrute de su seÃ±or.
Desde mÃ¡s o menos la Ã©poca de Beethoven, las cosas cambiaron. El ascenso de la burguesÃ­a y la consecuente pÃ©rdida de poder de la nobleza o la realeza (cuando no perdÃ­an, directamente, la cabeza) cambiÃ³ los parÃ¡metros de la mÃºsica. Para poder subsistir no les quedÃ³ a los mÃºsicos mÃ¡s remedio que buscar otros clientes, a falta de mecenas: las Salas de Conciertos. Esto llevÃ³ a la mÃºsica a la revoluciÃ³n romÃ¡ntica: las obras perdieron complejidad y ganaron en sencillez. Se impusieron los estribillos pegadizos, fÃ¡ciles de recordar por el gran pÃºblico, a costa de perder riqueza contrapuntÃ­stica y estilÃ­stica. Â¡HabÃ­a que comer! Pero, sin embargo, seguÃ­a habiendo clientes (no ya Reyes, Duques o Barones en el absolutista sentido del Siglo XVIII, sino mÃ¡s bien burgueses acomodados, industriales ricos o, tambiÃ©n, aristÃ³cratas con posiblesâ€¦ y buenas rentas) que deseaban mÃºsica que se pudiera ejecutar en sus casas, para su deleite y el de sus amigos. Ya no se podÃ­an permitir mantener ellos solos a los mÃºsicos, pero sÃ­ compraban sus partituras; si el compositor conseguÃ­a varios de estos clientes, tenÃ­an el sustento asegurado. Todo ello, sin olvidar las grandes obras sinfÃ³nicas o de cÃ¡mara que les daban, ademÃ¡s de dinero, la fama necesaria para poder vender sus servicios a buen precioâ€¦
Y nuevamente volvemos al problema original, Ã©se que tenÃ­a Luigi Boccherini: conseguir mÃºsica fresca para las habilidades especÃ­ficas de sus clientes para que estos les siguieran encargando mÃ¡s mÃºsica o comprando sus partituras. PodÃ­an componer obras originales (y lo hacÃ­an). Pero una soluciÃ³n obvia para muchos fue transcribir sus propias obras, o las de otros, escritas para orquesta de cÃ¡mara, sinfÃ³nica o lo que fuera, al instrumento que los clientes demandaban, en muchÃ­simas ocasiones, para piano. PrÃ¡cticamente todos los compositores de la Ã©poca (siglo XIX) lo hacÃ­an. Franz Liszt, el extraordinario pianista que revolucionÃ³ la tÃ©cnica de interpretaciÃ³n al piano, lo hizo muchas veces, y no descarto traer aquÃ­ alguna vez alguna de sus sorprendentes transcripciones para piano solo. Johannes Brahms tambiÃ©n lo hizo, especializÃ¡ndose en la transcripciÃ³n de sus propias obras para cuatro manos, es decir, para piano interpretado simultÃ¡neamente por dos pianistas, lo que permitÃ­a al profesor interpretar la obra junto con el alumno, cada uno su parte, o bien a dos hermanos o hermanas, madre e hija, etc. Por ejemplo, Brahms transcribiÃ³ sus Danzas HÃºngaras, o el propio Cuarteto nÃºmero 1 del artÃ­culo anterior, para cuatro manos. Ya sabÃ©is: Â¡HabÃ­a que comer!
En una palabra, aunque pueda resultar extraÃ±o, es bastante habitual que se reescriban obras orquestales para su ejecuciÃ³n por un TrÃ­o, un Cuarteto o, directamente, por un piano solo.
Dicho todo lo cual, y a pesar de ello, no deja de sorprender que alguien se haya atrevido a transcribir para piano una obra tan terriblemente poderosa como Carmina Burana, de Carl Orff. Hace eones dediquÃ© un artÃ­culo a tan magna obra, haciendo hincapiÃ© en su nutridÃ­sima plantilla: Una orquesta pobladÃ­sima, con la cuerda completa (ocho contrabajos, etc, hasta diecisÃ©is primeros violines), madera cuÃ¡druple, metal al gusto, percusiÃ³n de todo tipo y tamaÃ±o, dos pianos (dos), tres solistas (soprano, tenor y barÃ­tono), coro mixto con tantos cantantes como se puedan encontrar e incluso coro de niÃ±os. FÃ¡cilmente doscientos intÃ©rpretes en acciÃ³n, quizÃ¡ mÃ¡s. Yâ€¦ Â¿todo eso se puede transcribir para piano solo? Pues sÃ­. Se puede. Parece increÃ­ble, pero se puede. Al menos, Eric Chumachenco lo ha conseguido. GrabÃ³ el disco en 1992, y en 1995 participÃ³ con esta obra en los â€œVeranos pianÃ­sticosâ€ de Munich, aÃ±o dedicado a Carl Orff. Cuentan las crÃ³nicas que obtuvo un gran Ã©xito. No me extraÃ±a. Nada. Â¡QuÃ© pena no haber estado allÃ­!
Eric Chumachenco
En fin. No sÃ© mucho de Eric Chumachenco. Aunque su apellido es obviamente ruso, naciÃ³ en 1964 en Philadelphia, USA.[3] Hijo del gran violinista NicolÃ¡s Chumachenco, quien en la actualidad es el Director Musical de la Orquesta de CÃ¡mara Reina SofÃ­a de Madrid, Eric tuvo una infancia muy â€œmusicalâ€, que para algo todos enÂ su familia eran mÃºsicos de renombre; tras peripecias varias que no vienen a cuento (en realidad, es que no las conozco), en la actualidad da clases nada menos que en el Mozarteum de Salzburgo, donde Mozart vigila desde donde estÃ© que no se cometan desmanes, asÃ­ que manco no debe ser el hombre. Y poco mÃ¡s. Fue realmente un compaÃ±ero de trabajo el que, hace diez o doce aÃ±os, me puso en la pista de esta versiÃ³n del Carmina Burana. Me costÃ³ encontrar el disco (creo que fue en Praga o Budapest o algo asÃ­), pero lo encontrÃ©. Y me encantÃ³.[4] A alguien mÃ¡s le ha debido encantar, puesto que la obra entera se encuentra en YouTube.
No voy a contar ni una palabra mÃ¡s acerca de Carmina Burana, ni tampoco de Carl Orff, el autor de la obra musical estrenada en 1937. Ya lo hice en el artÃ­culo correspondiente, que quedÃ³, desde miâ€¦ ignorante, sÃ­, punto de vista, bastante completo, apoyÃ¡ndose en la interpretaciÃ³n de la Orquesta de la Universidad de California en Davis, y que sugiero que, si no recordÃ¡is, volvÃ¡is a leer. Y sobre la versiÃ³n pianÃ­stica de Chumachenco, interpretada por Ã©l mismo, tampoco hay mucho que contar: sÃ³lo dejarse llevar por laÂ exuberanciaÂ de la mÃºsica de Orff y la suprema habilidad del pianista ruso para mantener su fuerza tras sustituir a tanto mÃºsico y cantante por un mero piano. Espero que os guste como a mÃ­ me gusta.
.
Vamos ya con la obra. EstÃ¡ contenida en tres videos, de entre 8 y 20 minutos, que contienen de dos en dos las distintas partes de que consta la obra. NingÃºn problema de particiÃ³n. Los videos son de fotos de diversas iglesias medievales, muchas de ellas romÃ¡nicas, de las que reconozco alguna espaÃ±ola (como la inigualable de San MartÃ­n de FrÃ³mista), pero la mayorÃ­a deben ser francesas y, sobre todo, inglesas o escocesas, debido a la presencia habitual de cementerios colindantes donde la lÃ¡pida es vertical, y no horizontal, y la tumba estÃ¡ cubierta de cÃ©sped: esta forma de enterramiento no es nada comÃºn en la Europa del Sur.
En el primer video contiene las dos primeras partes de la obra, Fortuna Imperatrix Mundi (Fortuna, Emperatriz del Mundo) y Primo Vere (La Primavera). Y comienza con el poderoso arranque de la obra, el famosÃ­simo O Fortuna. Vamos allÃ¡:
Los primeros cuatro minutos son los correspondientes a Fortuna Imperatrix Mundi, de los que los dos y medio primeros son el omnipresente O Fortuna, y en el minuto 4:05 comienza el canto a la Primavera, que dura apenas cuatro minutos mÃ¡s. Entonces, para poder irnos al prado a retozar, hay que cambiar de video.
Comienza el video con Uf dem Anger (En el Prado), que, en puridad, es tambiÃ©n parte de â€œLa Primaveraâ€, aunque tiene su propio encabezamiento en la obra. Tras mÃ¡s de once minutos disfrutando del buen tiempo, del cÃ©sped y de sus pobladores, hay que ir a celebrar a un sitio de mÃ¡s enjundia: en el minuto 11:10 comienza In Taberna (En la Taberna), donde durante nueve alcohÃ³licos minutos se hace exaltaciÃ³n de la amistad compartiendo un vaso de buen vino, como bien escribiÃ³ ya en el Siglo XIII Gonzalo de Berceo, considerado el primer poeta que escribiÃ³ en castellano en su monasterio riojano de San MillÃ¡n de la Cogolla.
Termina el cÃ¡ntico a la borracherÃ­a y, para acabar con la obra, debemos cambiar de video:
Video que comienza con Cours dâ€™amour ( Corte de Amor), donde a lo largo de sus trece minutos se hace un encendido elogio del amorâ€¦ del amor carnal, nada del platÃ³nico, quÃ© va. Los arrumacos y encendidos cantos de Â¡Ay, si te pillaraâ€¦! terminan en el minuto 13:15, en que comienza la penÃºltima parte de la obra,Â Blanziflor et Helena (Blanziflor y Helena, claro), que es en realidad la preparaciÃ³n para el triunfante retorno del O Fortuna inicial, dentro de Fortuna Imperatrix Mundi (Fortuna, Emperatriz del Mundo), que comienza en el minuto 15:00 y cierra la obra exactamente igual que la comenzÃ³: con la Rueda de las Fortuna girando y girando sin pararâ€¦ para dejarnos finalmente en el mismo lugar donde empezamos.
.
Disco Carmina Burana (versiÃ³n piano)
Ni que decir tiene que sÃ³lo existe una versiÃ³n de esta versiÃ³n de Carmina Burana, la grabada por el propio Eric Chumachenco en 1992 y publicada por Wergo. Hace unos aÃ±os era muy difÃ­cil de conseguir, pero deben haber reeditado el disco, por lo que sÃ­ ahora sÃ­ deberÃ­a ser posible hacerse con Ã©l.
.
En Spotify no estÃ¡ esta versiÃ³n. Como era de esperar. Es tan previsibleâ€¦
Y claro, dudo mucho que haya mucha gente que haya escuchado esta pianÃ­stica versiÃ³n en directo. Yo, desde luego, no estoy entre estos afortunados. Pero, de haber podido, con toda seguridad serÃ­a mucho mejor que el mejor enlatado. El directo es siempre mejor. Siempre.
Disfrutad de la vida, mientras podÃ¡is. A ser posible, escuchando mÃºsica. Chacal, de Fred Zinemann, a partir de la excelsa novela de Frederick Forsyth, es un buen ejemplo de una pelÃ­cula muy fiel al libro original.PÃ¡nico Nuclear, de Phil Alden Robinson, basada, o eso se supone, en la novela homÃ³nima de Tom Clancy, es un ejemplo paradigmÃ¡tico de tal destrozo. Lo que me extraÃ±a es que no hubiera sido dirigida por alguien llamado Alan Smithee. O sea, que es bastante mÃ¡s joven que yo. Sniff.No, nunca he oÃ­do esta pieza en directo. No sÃ© si habrÃ¡ mucha gente en el mundo que lo haya hechoâ€¦

post.title: 20 Essential Metal / Hard Rock Albums You Should Hear: Part One
post.summary: I know I do a lot of these lists, but here is another anyway. We all have those albums which have been with us for years like faithful companions. The albums which don't seem to age. As a long time reader of Metal Hammer, I have always read with great interest when they ask which album or albums would you recommend to a newcomer to metal or which album defines metal? Well, I am taking it further. These are the 20 (Yes, 20!) albums that I would recommend to anyone, be they a grizzled metal veteran or a relative metal virgin. If you haven't heard the albums on this list, well you should. Simple. Go on Spotify, download them if you must, but just give them a try. They are all bona fide classics in my, as always, humble opinion. I have tried to avoid anything from the last few years. This isn't due to falling standards of quality (quite the opposite is true in many ways), rather due to the fact that tastes change. "Favourite" albums come and go. An album I love and play to the point of wearing it away today, may be gathering dust in a year. No, these are albums that have had a long time to mature, albums that I have listened to more times than I've changed my pants and those which I could put on right now and listen to all the way to the end. As usual, I have split this down as not to overload your delicate brains too much in one go, and to allow you time to digest and appreciate the music on offer fully (if you decide to do so). So, here are the first 5 which came to mind. Raging Speedhorn - Raging Speedhorn (2000) First up are the hard bastards from Corby with their self-titled debut. And what a debut it is! This album is a Sludge/Hardcore monster. Simple but effective riffs, throat tearing (twin) vocals and all the groove you could ever want. It's a shame that they never came close to these heights again and sadly disbanded in 2008. But they left this brutal classic behind. Listen to: Thumper Â W.A.S.P. - The Headless Children (1989) After the controversy the band attracted/courted in the early days and the wonderful, but often tongue-in-cheek anthems such as "I Wanna Be Somebody" and "Animal (Fuck Like A Beast), in 1989 we were introduced to a more serious, darker W.A.S.P. through the medium of that most dreaded of beasts, the concept album. From the Maiden-esque guitars to Blackie's mournful wail, this is a truly classic clutch of songs. The title track still gives me chills to this day. This album should be in the collection of any self-respecting metal fan...even those who don't like W.A.S.P. It's that good. Listen to: The Headless Children Judas Priest - Painkiller (1990) Â This is almost so obvious that I shouldn't need to include it, but I will and definitely should. This album IS metal. It defines metal. It saw the band up their game in the face of the more brutal competition (Pantera and the like). The band needed to something to save their reputation and career after the woeful duo of "Turbo" and "Ram It Down". Well, they did that and so much more. They breathed new life into not only their own career, but into the ailing metal scene itself. Pounding drums, THAT twin guitar sound and Rob's inimitable vocal delivery all cement the place of Painkiller in any classic metal albums list. It is over 2 decades old now, but it hasn't and probably never will be considered "old". It was all downhill for Priest after this (although I liked a lot of the Ripper-era material), but how many bands could follow up an album like this? No wonder Rob quit the band. Listen to: Painkiller Hatebreed - The Rise Of Brutality (2003) Hatebreed are one of those bands. Always consistent, never releasing a weak album...but it is "Rise..:" that is the jewel in their crown. Jamey's voice is brutal on this album. He roars his way through the uplifting and empowering lyrics...espousing inner strength and self-belief, never letting up for a moment. Not giving the listener time to breathe or recover from the aural pounding. This is as hardcore as Hardcore gets. I'd go as far as to say genre defining. Listen to: Live For This Pantera - Vulgar Display Of Power (1992) Pantera had already managed to leave behind their humbe (and generally rubbish) beginnings as a Sleaze/Glam band when they released the brilliant and groove-laden "Cowboys From Hell" in 1990, but it was VDOP which really made the metal world sit up and take notice...influencing and attracting the attention of aÂ new generation of fans (me included) at the same time. This was revolutionary and was one of the albums responsible for keeping Metal alive in the face of the Grunge onslaught. It was as brutal an album to break the mainstream as it could have been at the time, with the unforgetable and instantly recognisable cover setting the tone. Phil stomped, spat and bellowed his way throughout, taking no prisoners and the band were tighter than an emo's jeans. This is an album which had such an impact on the scene that it can never be over-rated or under-stated. Listen to: Walk

post.title: READ. WANT. LISTEN.
post.summary: This month, I asked my sponsors to share what book they are currently reading//wanting to read, what's on the top of their want list, and what band they are currently listening to. :) My answers would be to read Gone Girl.Â I've heard it's good. My wish//want list item would be another trip to Disney and/or Universal; I've been in such a theme park mood lately! AND I'm listening to Mumford & Sons always. What about you? Feel free to share your answers below. :) - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Ashleigh of Love Stoned - Read//Â I've made it a silent goal this year to read more books (but really, who hasn't?!) and I'm really interested in reading J.K. Rowling's new book The Casual Vacancy. The reviews are amazingly hot and cold. It will definitely be on my list of books that I never got around to reading last year and ones that I'm excited to check out this year! The problem is picking which one to start with! Want//Â I am desperately in need of a new pair of eye glasses. My pup, Kennedy-Buttons, ate my last pair and I've been squinting at the television ever since! A few months ago I did a home try-on from Warby Parker, but didn't find a pair that really suited me. I'm excited to give it another try! Listen//Â I've actually been listening to Young the Giant a lot on Spotify recently. I knew a lot of their music before, but never actually knew who the band was. Once I put the pieces together, it's been on repeat ever since, and I'm loving it! - Find Ashleigh here; blog & instagram. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Megan of Freckled Italian -Â Read//Â Life of Pi. I just went to see the film this weekend and it blew my mind with all of its magic. I'm really excited to read the book that inspired it! Want//Â One of David Yurman's bracelets. I tend to wear a lot of gold and silver and love them both, but I always want to combine them and can't seem to figure it out. I think one of these pieces would tie everything together quite nicely. Listen//Â Mumford & Sons, Babel. I listened to this album non-stop for about a month when I first bought it, then took a break for a while, and am now back on it. I love every word. My favorite songs are Below My Feet and Not With Haste. - Find Megan here; blog & twitter. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Sophie of onetenzeroseven - Read//Â The book on my reading list right now is Eccentric Glamour by Simon Doonan who is the Creative Director of Barneys, New York. I read an interview with him on Etsy recently and fell in love with his views and attitude towards art and fashion. You can read the interview, here. Want//Â I'm a long time obsessee of Alexander McQueen and I have been lusting over their pashmina scarves since just before Christmas. The classic skull ones are fantastic, but there's also some gorgeous floral designs too! My boyfriend bought me an AM wool skull scarf when we first started dating and it's such a thoughtful, special gift that I dare not wear it!! :) I'm hoping to have another great successful year, with my handmade jewelry, like I was lucky to have had last year and perhaps I'll treat myself. Listen//Â Ever since I discovered his music last year I have been playing Young Hines practically non-stop. His album, 'Give Me My Change' was my favourite album of 2012 and it's full of passionate lyrics and great guitar riffs for dancing around the house and shouting at the top of your lungs ;) - Find Sophie here; blog & shop. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Leah of Unearthing Words - Read//Â This month, I'd love to reread an old young adult favorite entitled Sabriel by Garth Nix. It is SUCH a terrific book and it has been years since I've read it. Want//Â On my wishlist this month, I've definitely got the book Beneath the Surface. It's book 5.5 in Lindsay Buroker's Emperor's Edge series. So, so good! I can't wait to read this installment soon. Listen//Â I've been listening to the Gladiator soundtrack over and over again this month while writing and working. I'm a major fan of epic music to put me in productive moods. - Find Leah here; blog & twitter. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Leigh of Barberry & Lace -Â Read// I would love to dive into The Martha Rules by Martha Steward... I just need to find the time! Want//Â I'm pining over a new sewing machine! Maybe for my birthday??Â Hear// I cannot get enough of the song You Were Born by Cloud Cult. post.title: Roy Ayers â€“ Running Away
post.summary: Listen to Roy Ayers - Running Away (3,96 min) on spotify. Running Away can be found on the album Roy Ayers - Universal Masters which were released 2003, track nr: 1About Roy AyersRoy Ayers was born on September 10, 1940 in Los Angeles. Thanks to his trombone playing father and piano teaching mother, he became immersed in music from day one and the story goes that he was given his first set of vibe mallets by his hero Lionel Hampton at the age of 5. Constantly performing and recording since the 1960s, he is one of the most famous jazz vibraphonists. He has produced some of the most loved modern soul-jazz records of all time such as, "Everybody Loves The Sunshine", most influential afro-jazz with musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti (Africa - Centre Of The World) and the most seminal jazz-funk, such as "Running Away". And that's just the surface. 2004 saw the release of "Virgin Ubiquity: Unreleased Recordings 1976-1981" which were 'lost' sessions tapes that he had discarded. Gilles Peterson described this as the equivalent of finding a lost Beatles album. No doubt this helped him win the Gilles Peterson 2004 Worldwide Lifetime Achievement Award. Roy Ayers is ageless and evergreen and as per the title of another one of hits, remember "We All Live In Brooklyn Baby". http://www.royayers.com http://www.bassics.de/ayers.html http://www.discomuseum.com/RoyAyers.html last.fm Pictures of Roy AyersShow more imagesMore: Roy Ayers Roy Ayers's officiella homepageSoulsken pÃ¥ Filadelfia Lyrics for Running Away by Roy Ayers: Words and Music by Roy Orbison and Joe Melson Just runninâ€™ scared each place we go So afraid that he might show Yeah, runninâ€™ scared, what would I do If he came back and wanted you Just runninâ€™ scared, feelinâ€™ low Runninâ€™ scared, you love him so Just runninâ€™ scared, afraid to lose If he came back which one would you choose Then all at once he was standing there So sure of himself, his head in the air My heart was breaking, which one would it be You turned around and walked away with me.Music video with Roy AyersHere you can find videos from Youtube with Roy Ayers - Running Away... post.title: Nokia Music + : enhanced â‚¬3.99 music subscription service
post.summary:
In addition to the free Nokia Music service, Nokia will soon roll out Nokia Music+. This is a new â‚¬3.99 Â (prices vary per region) optional service that gives
Unlimited skips (you can only skip a few and then you have to listen to that track in the free version) Unlimited downloads (you can download on the free one, but limited to 4 playlists) Higher Quality Lyrics Desktop app.
Nokiaâ€™s VP for Entertainment said: â€œThis is for people who care enough about music to pay something for more quality and choice, but donâ€™t want to pay â‚¬9.99 monthly.â€ Dig into Spotify/XBox Music? Iâ€™d like my own playlists though.

post.title: Nokia Announces $3.99 Per Month Streaming Service: Nokia Music+ #MIDEM
post.summary:
(UPDATED) From Cannes by Stuart Dredge of UK consultancy and blog Music Ally.
Nokia is launching a premium tier for its Nokia Music streaming music
service, charging users $3.99 in the U.S. and â‚¬3.99 globally per month for extra features for the
personal radio service, including access on non-Nokia devices. Nokia Music launched as a preloaded application on Nokiaâ€™s first
Lumia Windows Phones in late 2011, providing Pandora-style customised
radio stations based on individual artists, as well as a range of
pre-curated playlists.
NEW FEATURES:
That service continues, but users will be able to upgrade to Nokia
Music+ to get new features, including the ability to stream on other
connected devices via an HTML5 site â€“Â including computers and tablets.
Other premium features include the ability to download an unlimited
number of mixes to listen to offline on a Windows Phone; unlimited track
skips when listening to the stations; optional higher-quality audio
when streaming over Wi-Fi; and lyrics displayed when â€œmanyâ€ tracks are
playing.
Music Ally talked to Jyrki Rosenberg, Nokiaâ€™s VP for entertainment,
who explained more about the companyâ€™s strategy with the new premium
tier â€“Â which will sit alongside the existing free, no-advertising Nokia
Music rather than replace it.
â€œFeedback from consumers has been overwhelmingly positive, including in the US, where we launched in September,â€ he says.
â€œThey understand the value they are getting from the service: no
registration, no payment and no commercials, just
straight-out-of-the-box streaming music. But based on this feedback, we
have also learned that a certain segment of the market have requests for
more features.â€
Hence Nokia Music+, although we suspect Nokia has also been getting
plenty of feedback from music rightsholders requesting a premium tier
for the service.
â€œThey really like the evolution, and in a way the fact that with this, our service is even more complete,â€ says Rosenberg. â€œThere
is a funnel of free users, and also a tier of people who are willing to
pay for unlimited skips, higher audio quality and the other features.â€
Thereâ€™s an interesting dynamic going on in the music industry at the
moment. The labels as much as anyone were responsible for setting the
price bar for mobile access to on-demand streaming music services at
â‚¬9.99 a month.
Yet at the start of 2013, theyâ€™re making more noises about a desire
for mobile music services sitting in between free and â‚¬9.99, to provide a
more graceful upsell curve for consumers.
â€œWhen we analysed the market, it was pretty clear from our research
that this â‚¬9.99 type of service is still targeting a fairly narrow
segment of the market â€“Â I would say less than 10%, initially,â€ says
Rosenberg.
â€œThatâ€™s why itâ€™s important with this new tier to still be
addressing a large part of the market, not limiting ourselves to less
than 10% of it. â‚¬3.99 is still affordable enough for us to be focusing on the massmarket.â€
The HTML5 site is also interesting. So far, Nokia Music hasnâ€™t merely
been a mobile-first service: itâ€™s been mobile-only, even if users can
still connect their Lumia (wired or wirelessly) to speakers and hi-fis.
Rosenberg says Nokia Music will â€œdefinitely stay mobile-firstâ€ even
with the new HTML5 site. Although it makes Nokia Music accessible for
the first time on, say, iPads, he politely bats back a question on
whether Nokia might launch a native iOS app for the service, as it has
done for its Nokia HERE maps.
â€œAt this point of time, our strategy is to differentiate Lumia,â€ he
says. â€œAt the point where the consumer wants more and is willing to pay
more, it is hard to argue that they shouldnâ€™t have access from
elsewhere. But we will definitely keep on innovating on the devices as
well.â€
Nokia Music+ will roll out to the 24 countries where Nokia Music is
available over the first quarter of this year. Users will be able to pay
in-app using a credit card, or operator billing in countries where that
is available.
Rosenberg says Nokia is avoiding an unsubtle hard-sell, suggesting
instead that when users come up against some of the restrictions of the
free service â€“Â theyâ€™ve used up their six skips an hour, for
exampleÂ â€“Â they may be asked if they want to upgrade.
Thus far, Nokia hasnâ€™t ever published figures for usage of Nokia
Music, making it hard to gauge how well the service has been catching
on. Rosenberg maintains that policy, which is in part dictated by a
reluctance to have Nokia Music compared to other services (Pandora and
Spotify, among others, presumably) at this point.
â€œOur usage is of course proportionate to Lumia,â€ he says. â€œIf we talk activation rates â€“Â how many people who bought a Lumia activate the service â€“Â that number is very big. The great majority of users activate it.â€
That gives something to work with: Nokia sold 13.3m Lumia smartphones
in 2012 according to its financial filings, and around 1m in 2011,
making a maximum possible install base of 14.3m â€“ although some keen
early adopters may be on their second Lumia by now.
For now, further stats arenâ€™t forthcoming, although Rosenberg says
Nokia Music is retaining users after that first activation â€œwell aboveâ€
the industry averages for apps in general, as well as music apps.
(We wonder if Nokia is using analytics firm Flurryâ€™s stats for this. In October 2012, it published some research
claiming that the average music app retains 43% of its users 30 days
after they install it, 30% after 60 days and 20% after 90 days.)
Rosenberg does have some stats on another part of Nokiaâ€™s music
activities though: the Nokia Music Unlimited service in India. The
service formerly known as Comes With Music was dropped in Western
countries, including the UK, but itâ€™s going strong in markets like
India.
â€œIt has been particularly successful in the Asha range of handsets in
India,â€ he says, in answer to a question about Nokiaâ€™s lower-end
smartphones.
â€œAsha users are currently downloading more than 1m tracks a day in India alone, and last year Nokia consumers downloaded more than 200m tracks in India.â€
Rosenberg adds that while Nokia sees an opportunity to bring Nokia
Music+ to Asha, for now the service will remain exclusive to its Lumia
Windows Phones.

post.summary: Det er sÃ¥ godt med helg! Det er bare synd at den gÃ¥r sÃ¥ alt for fort. Denne helgen har jeg virkelig bare kost meg. God mat, god drikke, herlige mennekser, gode treningsÃ¸kter, sovet lenge, koselige cafebesÃ¸k og masse sosialhygge. Jeg skulle gitt sÃ¥ mye for et par dager til med helg. NÃ¥ skal jeg jo faktisk bare ha en arbeidsdag her i Oslo, fÃ¸r jeg drar til sÃ¸rlandet for et spennende lite oppdrag. Jeg skal oppdatere pÃ¥ hva dette er nÃ¥r jeg reiser, jeg lover! I natt har jeg sovet i godt over ti timer, no som resulterte i en uthvilt og energisk kropp i dag morges. Jeg fant ut at det mÃ¥tte utnyttes og tok en liten tur ut pÃ¥ Magnat. 45 minutter pÃ¥ woodway-tredemÃ¸llen gav en herlig kickstart pÃ¥ denne sÃ¸ndagen. Det ble en svett Ã¸kt, og beina var litt tunge, men med ny musikk pÃ¥ spotify gikk det overraskende bra. NÃ¥ skal jeg bruke resten av ettermiddagen pÃ¥ Cafe sammen med sÃ¸te Isabell. Jeg elsker slike sÃ¸ndager, hvor man sitter pÃ¥ cafe i timesvis og bare slapper av og nyter livet. Vi sitter pÃ¥ koselige Bolivar, en cafe jeg var stamgjest pÃ¥ den tiden jeg bodde pÃ¥ Majorstuen. Det er en helt unik stemning her, med dempet belysning, tente lys og nydelig mat. Dette er sÃ¥ riktig pÃ¥ en sÃ¸ndag:) Jeg hÃ¥per dere fÃ¥r en deilig sÃ¸ndag, og koser dere sammen med noen dere er glad i;) Smiiiil Maren

post.title: Sunday Slaylist: Earacheâ€™s Metalizer Spotify App
post.summary:
The thing about all the ways that itâ€™s possible to listen to music these days is the paralysis of too much choice. We turn on Spotify some mornings and weâ€™re just overawed by the vast amount of music we can listen to. We bet a bloody great number of you have exactly the same problem â€“ thatâ€™s why you come and check out our curated Slaylists, right? Theyâ€™re the kind of thing that gives you just enough of a nudge to listen to new or unexpected things, right? Well, it seems Earache Records think that too, as this week they launched a bloody marvellous Spotify App by the name of the Metalizer.
Basically, the Earache Metalizer is an ace automated playlist generator. As you can see by the snazzy graphical interface below, you tweak the various sub-genre gauges to indicate what balance of tracks youâ€™d like between the four on offer (which at launch is â€œmetalâ€, death, thrash and grind), choose how many songs you want in your playlist and BOSH, thereâ€™s your playlist. Click the photo below and have a play around yourself.
So this week, weâ€™re not actually going to make you a Slaylist. We want you to go make one yourself using the Earache Metalizer App. And then drop us a link to it. Why? No reason. Weâ€™re just nosy. Apparently overÂ 23,000Â (bloody hell!) playlists have already been generated by the App on just its first day of releaseÂ (seriously, bloody hell!), so youâ€™ll be in good company. SpotifyÂ is available to most of Western Europe, the USA,Â Australia, New Zealand, and a few other placesÂ for free â€“ though obviously youâ€™re better off shelling out either Â£5 or Â£10 a month for one of Spotifyâ€™s premium packages, as then you can listen to ourÂ SlaylistsÂ without having them interrupted by adverts. For our readers in countries not currently serviced by Spotifyâ€¦.merry Christmas to you too. Maybe youâ€™ll get lucky and Spotify will come to your country in 2013.

post.title: "Madrigal" de Hiberia
post.summary: Hiberia es un grupo de Terrassa (Barcelona) formado por: JuanRa (bajo y voz), Edu (guitarras), Adri (baterÃ­a) y Luis Zubeldia (guitarra y voces). Un grupo de pop-rock y con algo de indie.Â  La bandaÂ naciÃ³Â en el 2008 y tras un tiempo escribiendo, grabando, mezclando y autoproduciendo todos los instrumentos en su propio local en el 2011 llego el EP Demoâ€“Gran Angular (con tres canciones). Un aÃ±oÂ despuÃ©sÂ llego el primer LP de la banda, Gran Angular (con 11 canciones). Y entonces en otoÃ±o llego yo que lesÂ conocÃ­aÂ de antes ya que les hice una entrevista para un programa musical y les pido hacer un tema para Yellow World, un tema para el Villarreal y en fin para los groguets.Â  Todo un reto para ellos, pero se pusieron manos a la obra y nos trajeron una maravillosa canciÃ³n llamada "Madrigal". AquÃ­Â podÃ©isÂ escucharla: Madrigal by Hiberia La letra de la canciÃ³n asÃ­ como el concepto de ella aquÃ­:Â http://www.hiberia.es/madrigal/ La canciÃ³n la puedes descargar aquÃ­: http://hiberia.bandcamp.com/track/madrigal-2Â pulsando en "Free Download" y una vez pongas mail, nacionalidad y cÃ³digo postal, te envÃ­an a tu correo un link donde le das y ya veras que gratuitamente se descarga. El EP (demo) se puede adquirir gratis: http://www.hiberia.es/audio/demo-gran-angular/ El LP loÂ podÃ©isÂ escuchar aquÃ­ gratis: http://www.hiberia.es/audio/granangular/ Y recordad que el LP esta disponible en Itunes, Spotify, Amazon, etc. A esto solo me queda recordaros que la banda tieneÂ Facebook yÂ Twitter, y que siguen trabajando para traer nuevos temas.

TreeniÃ¤ varten tekemÃ¤ltÃ¤ni soittolistalta lÃ¶ytyy melko monen sorttisia kappaleita (nyt tÃ¤ssÃ¤ varmaan paljastuu kaikkein pimeimmÃ¤t musiikilliset salaisuuteni) ja ylipÃ¤Ã¤tÃ¤Ã¤n musiikkimakuni on hyvin laaja.
