post.title: TRACKS OF THE WEEK - 27/01/13 - Night Engine, Alice in Chains, Wake Owl, Joe Gideon and the Shark, Mexican Institute of Sound
post.summary: Five tracks that laughed in the face of snow this week! Shell Hunter:-Night Engine - 'I'll Make It Worth Your While'Â A couple of weeks ago I stumbled across a Guardian tipÂ offÂ forÂ 'Ones to watch out for in 2013' and I saw a friend from my college days in the photo! I knew he was seriously into music so I had to look into them and wow, Night Engine totally float my boat! Being a big fan of 80's music but no particular genre, meant that as soon as I heard tracks like Seventeen, Treat Me Like A Baby andÂ this one, made me want to kick my legs out and break into a running man like frenzy. You can hand pick your favourite influences such as Bowie and Talking Heads but I'll Make It Worth Your While gives me a bit of Weird Science by Oingo Boingo! Believe me that's not a bad thing, and there aren't enough bands doing it now in my opinion! Catch them at the Borderline in London on 20th Feb if you are lucky enough to get a ticket or get their first single Seventeen / Treat Me Like A Baby which will be released on February 18th. You can catch them on Sound Cloud, Facebook plus Twitter!Â www.nightengine.net London Scouser:-Alice In Chains - 'Hollow' (2013) Once again they are back, and once again it sounds like they have never been away. I was absolutely gutted when they disbanded when Layne Staley died as they have been a huge influence on the heavier side of my musical taste. They returned in 2009 with the brilliant Black Gives Way To Blue album, and in March they are releasing an as yet untitled album. I for one cannot wait. They will be playing at 'Download' this year which has a great line up (click here) including Korn, Rammstein, QOTSA & Iron Maiden, but alas I'm working and won't be able to go. Hopefully they will throw in some other gigs in the South that I can go to.Â http://aliceinchains.com/ SFW:- Wake Owl - Gold (2013) As the "new folk" genre gains in popularity and more and more artists come to the fore, this week we have Wake Owl vying for our attention. Wake Owl is the project of singer/songwriter Colyn Cameron and "Gold" is the first single off the Wild Country E.P. His style is very similar to Ben Howard, (not a bad thing) and with sweeping strings and gentle touches, it is the perfect track to accompany a long winters day walk! Old Pa's Corner:- Joe Gideon and the Shark - The Insignificant Bullet(2013) Joe Gideon and the Shark are a brother/sister duo from London. The Shark (aka former Olympic ribbon gymnast Viva Gideon) are now on their second album release 'Freakish (2013)' released this January, is a concoction of blues, beats and spoken word. This track the 'Insignificant Bullet' (great title) really is a mish mash, I can hear The Velvet Underground, The Talking Heads, Pulp and even The Strokes, all in this one song.Â This is definitely an interesting one. I'll tell you what!, I like shark music. Â Flycasual:- Mexican Institute of Sound - 'Mexico' (2012) I've only just heard this despite it being released last summer, all thanks to last months Songlines CD sampler, I just love the horns! The excellent 'Mexico' is taken from Mexican Institute of Sound's (the name given to DJ Camilo Lara's creation) third album 'Politico'. Politically charged tracks on the state of the country (drug violence, contested election) all delivered with wit and humour (if a little sobering judging by the video), a spattering of Hip Hop/Electro and sprinkled with Mariachi trumpets, what's not to like! Checkout previous Tracks of the week here Listen & Subscribe to our 2013 Tracks of the Week Spotify Playlist

post.title: Where Does Myspace Stand After The Redesign?
post.summary: Myspace recently revamped its website completely. Unfortunately, the unveiling coincided with Facebookâ€™s big announcement about Graph Search. So obviously Myspace got overshadowed! It still managed to generate some buzz, but where exactly is Myspace heading with this? They took too much time to come up with a redesigned site and social networking domain has become too crowded now. Is there any hope for yet another social network to survive? Â The Redesign More than a year ago, Justin Timberlake bought a significant stake in Myspace. It was quite mysterious as to why he would invest in a dying company. But things are getting clearer now. Myspace was on its way to a major redesign and they are hoping to generate some revenue this year. Either that or Timberlake was not sure if people will care about his new single unless he shoves it in peopleâ€™s faces. If you have visited the new Myspace homepage, you will know what I am talking about. Myspace allows users to stream music in an always-present music player at the bottom of the page. It also allows musicians to track where there top fans are, determined by which Myspace user plays the artistâ€™s music the most. Seems like general social networking is not exactly the focus here, or may be they are just trying to mask it! Who is Myspace competing with? The new redesign is not exactly clear on who they are trying to compete with. On first glance, the site looks promising. It utilizes an attractive interface that melds the functions and appearance of sites like Pinterest, Rdio and Instagram. People say they are competing with Facebook, Spotify and Pandora in one go. Thatâ€™s just silly! Facebook is too big now to worry about Myspace. Facebook is doing big things and is competing in the big money market. Spotify and Pandora are music services with a lot of buzz and a dedicated user base. How is Myspace going to base its comeback by taking on those services? Myspace is to Facebook as Apple was to Microsoft 15 years ago Even though Myspace was one of the early players in the social networking game, it somehow lost its way. It has seen steady decline over the last few years, almost going to the brink of becoming completely irrelevant. So what exactly is it that Myspace should do? For starters, they should stop competing head on with Facebook. It is too small and too late to compete with the behemoth that Facebook has become. Instead, it should try to reinvent itself with something fresh. May be create a new segment! Thatâ€™s what Apple did when it found itself in this position. Myspace has been in the social networking domain for a long time, but they have been completely overtaken. So they should come up with a radically new thing that people will get hooked on to. . . . . . â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”-

post.title: The Sisters of Mercy
post.summary:
The Sisters of Mercy is my favourite Leonard Cohen song - and there are plenty of othersÂ competingÂ with it. Listen to it here.Â
A notorious perfectionist: Leonard Cohen Photo: Clara Molden
I think the test of a good song is when virtually any cover version of it has some (and sometimes much) merit. Emmy Lou Harris and Linda Ronstadt recorded it here Although I couldn't find it on You Tube there is great version by Dion if you happen to have Spotify. There is, of course, a greatÂ differenceÂ between lyrics and poetry but Leonard Cohen's lyrics can often be read as poetry: Oh the sisters of mercy, they are not departed or gone.Â They were waiting for me when I thought that I just can't go on.Â And they brought me their comfort and later they brought me this song.Â Oh I hope you run into them, you who've been travelling so long.Â Yes you who must leave everything that you cannot control.Â It begins with your family, but soon it comes around to your soul.Â Well I've been where you're hanging, I think I can see how you're pinned:Â When you're not feeling holy, your loneliness says that you've sinned.Â Well they lay down beside me, I made my confession to them.Â They touched both my eyes and I touched the dew on their hem.Â If your life is a leaf that the seasons tear off and condemnÂ they will bind you with love that is graceful and green as a stem.Â When I left they were sleeping, I hope you run into them soon.Â Don't turn on the lights, you can read their address by the moon.Â And you won't make me jealous if I hear that they sweetened your night:Â We weren't lovers like that and besides it would still be all right,Â We weren't lovers like that and besides it would still be all right.
The story, according to Leonard Cohen, is that he let a couple of girlÂ hitch-hikersÂ use his double-bed in a motel on a cold winter's night in Canada and, while they slept, he wrote the song in one go. He said that was the only time he wrote in that way.

post.title: CÃ³mo descargar mÃºsica de Internet
post.summary:
Hoy en dÃ­a Internet ha cambiado mucho la forma que tenemos de descubrir y escuchar mÃºsica. No tenemos suficiente con las radios locales o nuestra colecciÃ³n de CDs, y queremos esa canciÃ³n que nos alegra el dÃ­a en nuestro ordenador, tablet, smartphone... en este sentido Spotify se ha convertido en el principal referente en estos aÃ±os, permitiÃ©ndonos disfrutar de un gran catÃ¡logo de artistas sin necesidad de descargar las canciones... solo busca, elige, y escucha.
Â¿Pero y si queremos disfrutar de esas canciones sin estar conectados a Internet? Para esto existen programas que graban el audio que suena en nuestro ordenador, y que incluso permiten identificar las canciones por separado. Es el caso de Replay Music.
Replay Music
Replay Music detecta e identifica canciones.
Se trata de una aplicaciÃ³n de pago (aunque podemos probarla con su versiÃ³n de evaluaciÃ³n) que graba audio de nuestro ordenador. Lo que la hace especial son sus funciones para detectar canciones y grabarlas por separado en formato MP3, permitiÃ©ndonos ademÃ¡s en el proceso modificar la calidad de la captura.
Tan solo tendremos que descargar Replay Music, y tras ejecutar el programa, ir a "settings". AquÃ­ podremos elegir la carpeta donde se descargarÃ¡n los archivos, y asegurarnos de que el "Input Source" (fuente de entrada) estÃ¡ en "Audio Driver". En la pestaÃ±a "Output" podremos configurar la calidad de la grabaciÃ³n. Como la mayorÃ­a de la mÃºsica en streaming se emite de media a 160 kbps, grabando a 192 kbps mantendremos una buena calidad de grabaciÃ³n.
Tras esto, solo queda empezar a grabar dÃ¡ndole al botÃ³n "Start recording" e iniciar la reproducciÃ³n en cualquier web de mÃºsica como por ejemplo Jamendo que tiene un catalogo de mas de 370000 pistas con licencia Cretive Commons. Conforme vaya reproduciÃ©ndose cada canciÃ³n, el programa crearÃ¡ un nuevo archivo MP3 e intentarÃ¡ rellenar automÃ¡ticamente las etiquetas ID3 (tÃ­tulo, artista, Ã¡lbum...).
Alternativas a Spotify
Con el objetivo de facilitarnos la tarea de encontrar mÃºsica para descargar en Internet, tambiÃ©n Songr y Super MP3 Download rastrean la web y encuentran una gran variedad de MP3 gratuitos. Lo mejor es que su aspecto estÃ¡ tan cuidado que te parecerÃ¡ que navegas por iTunes. Lo peor es que aunque el catÃ¡logo sea amplio, puede no ser suficiente segÃºn nuestros gustos musicales.
Otra de las vÃ­as que se estÃ¡ poniendo Ãºltimamente muy de moda para encontrar mÃºsica gratuita por la red son los programas para descargar mÃºsica de Youtube. TambiÃ©n existen multitud de programas P2P, pero su aspecto negativo es que no son Ãºtiles para explorar y descubrir nuevos gÃ©neros de mÃºsica.
Spotify tambiÃ©n estÃ¡ disponible en Mac y como WebApp
Por eso, y pese a sus restricciones en el modo gratuito (2 horas y media de reproducciones a la semana) Spotify sigue siendo una de las mejores formas de escuchar y descubrir mÃºsica gracias a Internet. Sin embargo, en la actualidad existen muchas alternativas que se le acercan, como la web de mÃºsica en streaming Grooveshark, o radios libres como TuneIn... la variedad, como siempre, beneficia al usuario. Lee CÃ³mo descargar mÃºsica de Internet en MilBits

post.title: Mega con el cine, la mÃºsica y la publicidad
post.summary:
El futuro de Mega: Megavideo, Megabox y Megakey
Si te digo que Mega (el nuevo servicio de los creadores de MegaUpload) saliÃ³ esta semana, es difÃ­cil que no lo supieras ya. Millones de usuarios en los primeros dÃ­as avalan un gran Ã©xito, al menos en su comienzo. De hecho, es bastante posible que ya lo estÃ©s usando... y si no, desde nuestra web puedes acceder fÃ¡cilmente a Mega. Y si acabas de volver de un viaje por el desierto del Gobi y no sabes aÃºn que es Mega, pues no pasa nada, te lo recordamos y te enseÃ±amos a usarlo.
En estos dÃ­as el servicio apenas ha funcionado como se espera, debido a la gran demanda por parte de los usuarios. AdemÃ¡s, muchas funciones aÃºn no estÃ¡n implementadas y estamos a la espera de que vayan saliendo... pero mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de las futuras mejoras de Mega, todo un nuevo abanico de servicios se espera durante este aÃ±o. Una apuesta al todo o nada para dominar algunos de los sectores mÃ¡s populares de Internet. Â¿Quieres saber cuales serÃ¡n los prÃ³ximos productos de Mega?
MegaMovie
La captura que puso Kim Dotcom en su Twitter
Cuando todos los ojos estaban puestos sobre el lanzamiento de Mega, Kim Dotcom se permitiÃ³ un nuevo alarde publicitario presentando la imagen de lo que vendrÃ­a a ser un nuevo servicio de pelÃ­culas en Streaming... "Megamovie", una especie de heredero de Megavideo. Tras la imagen, solo una palabra, dirigida a la MPAA (la sociedad de derechos de autor de Estados Unidos): "Â¿Hablamos?".
Poco se puede intuir solo por esa captura, pero parece que MegaMovie esperarÃ­a contar con los estrenos mÃ¡s taquilleros de las grandes distribuidoras. Algo muy ambicioso si tenemos en cuenta la mala fama que se labrÃ³ Megaupload y sus servicios asociados como principal distribuidor de contenido pirateado. Â¿Que clase de trato espera hacer Kim con las distribuidoras...?
Ahora mismo el mundo del cine, convulso por el cambio que supone los nuevos modelos de negocio en Internet, apuestan por servicios de alquiler y visionado legal de cine en streaming como Youzee.
Megabox
Â¿Artistas con cuenta propia?
Pero antes se espera Megabox, que viene a conquistar la industria de la mÃºsica. A la espera de conocer mÃ¡s detalles, tenemos las caracterÃ­sticas que pudieron adivinarse hace unos meses en las primeras promociones de Megabox. Funciones de red social e integraciÃ³n con Facebook y demÃ¡s (como no), estados de Ã¡nimo, edad y otras estadÃ­sticas relacionadas con los usuarios que escuchan cada canciÃ³n... asÃ­ como un chat interno.
TambiÃ©n se espera que los artistas tengan sus propios perfiles, agenda de conciertos, etc. No en vano Kim vendÃ­a Megabox como un servicio revolucionario que eliminarÃ­a intermediarios entre los artistas y su pÃºblico. Por lo demÃ¡s, permitirÃ­a que los usuarios guardaran su mÃºsica en la nube y que estuviera disponible en dispositivos mÃ³viles.
MÃ¡s allÃ¡ de las pretensiones de Kim Dotcom, Megabox no harÃ­a si no seguir el camino allanado por programas de mÃºsica en streaming como Spotify o Grooveshark... aunque eso podrÃ­a cambiar si, como se rumorea, los servicios de pago se ofrecieran mediante el uso de Megakey.
Megakey
Algunos recordarÃ¡n esta ventana...
Con este servicio Kim Dotcom parece querer asaltar el mayor pastel del negocio de Internet (y no precisamente porque estÃ© desnutrido...). Hablamos de la publicidad, un sector donde Google domina ampliamente mediante AdSense y los ingresos de la publicidad integrada en su buscador.
Es un servicio que ya existÃ­a en su dÃ­a y que viene a querer recuperar como una alternativa para los usuarios que quieran los servicios gratis de Megabox o Megamovie. La idea serÃ­a que instalando este software los usuarios verÃ­an sustituidos en parte los anuncios de las pÃ¡ginas que visitan por anuncios de los patrocinadores de Mega. No solo eso, si no que ademÃ¡s se recogerÃ­an estadÃ­sticas de navegaciÃ³n de los usuarios, algo muy jugoso para las empresas que buscan cada dÃ­a como llegar mÃ¡s al consumidor. De momento son especulaciones, pero de tener Ã©xito seguro que traerÃ­a cola y mucho debate...
Sin duda, nos esperan unos meses moviditos en los que tendremos que estar muy pendientes del Twitter de Kim Dotcom... Â¿Vosotros que esperÃ¡is del futuro de Mega y sus productos? Lee Mega con el cine, la mÃºsica y la publicidad en MilBits

post.title: Jukebox: The Best of 2012
post.summary: Saw this on my travels Itâ€™s the new year and itâ€™s time for a new me. A lotâ€™s happened in the last year. So much so that I feel I need to acknowledge the changes and reflect on whatâ€™s been before I really look to the future. Iâ€™m not going to go into the details because frankly some things shouldnâ€™t be aired to the whole world. Letâ€™s just say Iâ€™m now on my own for the first time in a long time and living alone in my very own little flat for the first time ever. This is a positive step albeit a massive change for me. Really though, this post isnâ€™t about what has changed, itâ€™s about how great a year I had last year, despite all of the change. The people who surrounded me and loved me and made 2012 such a memorable year. So, of course (as itâ€™s a huge part of my life), Iâ€™ve turned to music to express this. At the Thekla in May for the Dot to Dot festival The Best of 2012 1. Once and for all â€“ Clock Opera 2. The drummer â€“ Niki & The Dove 3. I could go â€“ Oberhofer 4. Va fan gÃ¶r du â€“ Friends 5. Emmylou â€“ First Aid Kit 6. Marathon runner â€“ Yellow Ostrich 7. Rabbit hole â€“ The Temper Trap 8. Waitress â€“ Boy 9. Breathing underwater â€“ Metric 10. All eyes on you â€“ St. Lucia 11. Dark star â€“ POLIÃ‡A 12. Vampire smile â€“ Kyla La Grange 13. Forever â€“ Haim 14. Fiction in 4 moves â€“ Xylos 15. Holes â€“ Electric Guest 16. Five seconds â€“ Twin Shadow 17. White lie â€“ Jhameel 18. Oblivion â€“ Grimes 19. Default â€“ Django Django 20. Elephant â€“ Tame Impala 21. The mother we share â€“ CHVRCHES 22. Little talks â€“ Of Monsters And Men From the very beginning there were some amazingly catchy tunes buzzing around my head. The first five on the list are those which I found myself singing over and over (to some peopleâ€™s annoyance) or playing repeatedly at work. Then came the first time of change when I moved jobs. Itâ€™s been a real opportunity to learn. To prove to myself, and others, that dreams really can be fulfilled. The next few songs are a strong reminder of those first few weeks when I joined my new work family and was taken fully under their wing. These songs will always bring back fond memories for me. After that comes the newer music which I began to discover as the months went by. From going to gigs, from friends sharing their suggestions, from my work colleagues; these songs make up the latter half of the 2012 and go hand in hand with the majority of gigs I managed to go to. First Aid Kit at the O2 Academy â€“ rocking the stage. Music is such a massive part of my life for many reasons. But the one that resonates the most with me, is how it makes me feel when I listen to a song. Laughter or sadness, clarity or the itch to get up and dance. The emotion that goes with each song is the reason gigs and festivals remain such memorable events. So here a few of my fondest memories from 2012 formed into a playlist. It wonâ€™t mean the same to you as it does to me, but hopefully you can catch a glimpse of the great year I had and enjoy the music all the same. Signing off, Siany ^__^

Per tant, aparentment i biolÃ²gicament com nosaltres tot i la magnitud del seu art daurat.Â I avui sent diumenge, tot i la proclama al vent de l'espontani trencament de la ortodÃ²xia, seguirem sent fidels, per devociÃ³, a la tradiciÃ³ litÃºrgica dominical i parlarem de l'univers religiÃ³s de Mozart. PerquÃ¨ ell va escriure tota una enciclopÃ¨dia en aquest sentit i, el que Ã©s millor de tot, avui dia elsÂ melÃ²mansÂ empedernits tenim la fortuna impagable que tot el seu repertori ha estat editat. No poden dir el mateix d'altres autors clÃ ssics del XVIII que van fer de la mÃºsica sagrada el seu modus vivendi i que possiblement superarien, en nombre i de molt llarg, la producciÃ³ que Mozart dedicaria a la devociÃ³ catÃ²lica, apostÃ²lica i romana.Â Sigui com sigui, el cert Ã©s que Mozart, que pel que sembla tot allÃ² que musicalment tocava, literal o metafÃ²ricament parlant, ho convertia en or i platÃ­, va deixar un llegat impressionant de misses, motets, offertoris, vespres i tot allÃ² que la bona, pulcra i santa de l'esglÃ©sia demanava solidÃ riament. Mozart,Â espavilat i molt llest, va saber satisfer aquestes sagrades necessitats amb el fruit del seu immillorable talent innat de quÃ¨ disposava. Avui, a mode de recordatori i de celebraciÃ³ del seu aniversari de naixement, recuperarem una ediciÃ³, superlativament parlant, immensa. I ho Ã©s per dues raons. La primera, la interpretaciÃ³ Ã©s sublim, d'aquelles que posen els pÃ¨ls de punta, el galliner en commociÃ³ i provoquen talÂ terrabastallÂ que un no sap si embogir definitivament o comenÃ§ar a corre per la civilitzada geografia urbana tot cridant Mozart, Mozart... bÃ©, la segona raÃ³ Ã©s pels tresors que s'hi representen.Â De fet, obrirem el repertori amb el seu espectacular Te Deum K.141, de 1769 i, atenciÃ³, d'un Mozart de 13 anys... breu perÃ² impressionant. Poca cosa es pot dir al respecte, simplement escoltar-lo i deixar que el cos i esperit sant assumeixin aquesta catarsis explosiva i musical com bonament puguin. SeguirÃ una de les misses mÃ©s desconegudes del geni, la Missa longa K.262 per a cor, solistes i orquestra. De 1776, escrita en Do major i sota demanda de l'omnipotent i magnÃ nim Arquebisbe de Salzburg. Formal, tÃ­pica i tÃ²pica presenta els sis caracterÃ­stics moviment d'una missa tradicional en llenguatge musical clÃ ssic. Intercalats hi trobarem l'ofertori Inter natos mulierum K. 72, l'antÃ­fona Regina coeli K. 276 (amb un subtil perÃ² evident homenatge a HÃ¤ndel)Â i finalitzarÃ el conjunt el conegut motetÂ Ave verum Corpus K. 618. Aquest serÃ el meu homenatge a Mozart, espero que com a mÃ­nim sigui fidel, si fa o no fa, al seu esperit i sobretot a la seva essÃ¨ncia perquÃ¨ ell va ser Ãºnic. Per nosaltres la seva existÃ¨ncia Ã©s un d'aquells regals que la naturalesa, no sabem com, va decidir engendrar al mÃ³n i esperem, tant de bo, que el ressÃ² de la seva mÃºsica soni amb la forÃ§a suficient com perquÃ¨ tots els Ã©ssers animats d'aquest meravellÃ³s univers puguin celebrar que en un dia com avui de fa uns quants anys un geni de cognom Mozart va veure el Sol per primera vegada. Des d'aquÃ­, i no ens cansarem mai de repetir-ho, moltes grÃ cies Wolfgang! A la interpretaciÃ³ el cor i els solistes de la Tolzer Knabenchor, amb l'European Baroque Soloists i la direcciÃ³ de Gerard Schmidt Gaden. Gaudiu i compartiu! Font: (on trobareu informaciÃ³ addicional aixÃ­ com dels discs on podeu trobar aquesta obra) WIKIPEDIA:Â Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (Salzburg, 27 de gener de 1756 âˆ’ Viena, 5 de desembre de 1791)AMAZON:Â Mozart: Missa Longa; Inter Natos Mulierum; Te Deum Laudamus; Venite Populi; Regina Coeli IMSLP:Â Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791) YOUTUBE:Â Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart (1756-1791) - Te DeumÂ SPOTIFY:Â TÃ¶lzer Knabenchor â€“ Mozart: Missa Longa; Inter Natos Mulierum; Te Deum Laudamus; Venite Populi; Regina CoeliÂ Â Â Tant si us ha agradat, com si no, opineu, Ã©s lliure i fÃ cil!

post.title: Business News - Advice for US Entrepreneurs Who Move to Europe
post.summary: Spain - Madrid Many people have tried to start-up in UK, France, Italy and in Spain but have failed or given up. Some who survived are merely struggling along. It is not a secret that it is difficult to start up in Europe compared with US, Asia or Africa. Apart from tough regulations, there is the European mentality that everyone should be an employee and work for a 'big' company or for the government and the impression that the laws have been set up to keep people under control. If you are 'too ambitious', earn 'too much' or aim for lots of wealth, it is seen as vulgar or evil, friends and family see your entrepreneurial spirit as strange and doomed to fail, schools train you up to be average and can only succeed if you come from a 'connected' family. There is also the class system which differentiates, separates and never allows anyone to move up, a subtle superiority conditioning, uncompensated hard work and many more which stifle business growth in Europe. From statistics you will notice that the companies doing well globally are not European, why? Because of European mentality - the people in this region are the best skilled and qualified in the world but are not given room to be the best. New ideas are condemned by superiors, ignored or stolen because they can't stand someone else receiving the praise. The hidden agendas of big businesses often stand in the way of innovative ideas from young people and the race card doesn't help either.I found this article by Martin Varsavsky an American entrepreneur who came to live in Europe and his experience sums up the positives and negatives of doing business in Europe in a nutshell... The American European Dream While not all Americans love Europe, many do. Quite a few people in San Francisco or New York City dream of spending part of their life in Italy, France, the UK, Spain and other European countries, and some do make it over. This is what I did in 1995 when I left NYC and moved to Madrid. As a tech entrepreneur, I found Europe, in general, and Spain, in particular, to be very fertile ground for me. The European market is huge, bigger actually than the US market in terms of GDP. This has not changed with the crisis.Â Euopean AccomplishmentsWhile in Europe, I built Viatel: a company that I started in NYC, but later on moved to London and in which I invested a few hundred thousand dollars to start in 1991. When I sold my shares in a public offering in 1999 the company was worth $1.2bn. In Madrid, I built Jazztel: Spainâ€™s second largest publicly traded telco (now worth around $1.8bn), and Ya.com, in which we invested around $50M and sold for $700M to DT. I also co-founded Eolia Renovables, an alternative energy company now worth around half a billion. And for the last six years I have been building Fon out of Madrid and London and itâ€™s become the largest WiFi network in the world, still private. I also started one of the first European cloud computing companies called Einsteinet where I lost about $50M mostly for being too early in the cloud-computing world. Difference between Europe and USA So much for my credentials, now letâ€™s go to what itâ€™s like to build tech companies in Europe and how this is different from doing the same in the USA where I live now. Europe is great for an American tech entrepreneur because wealth is better distributed. More consumers can buy your products and services, people are more educated on the average so you can find very good employees and there are less competitors, less people wanting to be entrepreneurs (Europeans have ambivalent feelings towards entrepreneurs and being an entrepreneur is not as well regarded). But the European market is less homogenous than the American market. While in theory employees and goods can move anywhere in Europe and most of Europe has the euro as a common currency, cultures are very different and that in itself is a barrier to building a pan European venture. And there are also other pros and cons that I will now describe. Liability is not limited to your start up business There are very important legal and cultural differences that make it harder to work in Europe. The first one is the legal interpretation of business failure that gives entrepreneurs less of a limited liability. For example, in Europe, and this is everywhere in Europe, there are very high social charges associated to every job. While in the USA you have to add say 8% to a salary of $50K in social charges, in France, Spain, Italy a salary of $50K means at least $75K or more in costs to the entrepreneur. But if you fail to pay these social charges because your start up is doing poorly, and you are the administrator or person responsible for your start up, you are personally liable and indebted for the rest of your life for these charges should you fail to pay. Not paying them is considered a crime from which you are not protected. In most of Europe there is no concept of personal bankruptcy and unlimited personal liability, or even of shielding your home from personal bankruptcy that exists in some states of the USA. So beware of personal liability when you establish a start up in Europe and should it go badly give up before you run out of money to pay social charges and mandated severance pay. Redundancy and sick pay is costly Another legal obligation that is very common in Europe and unheard of in the USA is state-mandated severance pay packages. This is a direct impediment to start ups, the reason being that most start ups fail and in the USA there is an understanding of this. In the USA employees demand stock options as upside should the start up succeed knowing that there will be no severance package should the start up fail. But I have yet to find a place in Europe where employees or governments truly understand this. Not only are forced severance pay packages a problem because most start ups fail and they still have to pay them, but also because start ups are constantly trying out people and the concept of trying out people is very costly in Europe. In some countries like France, forced severance packages of people who have been with you say only half a year can be as high as double their earnings during that time. For most Europeans stock options are considered a scam to pay them less. Now the laws vary throughout Europe, Germany and Spain for example have lowered mandated severance pay packages. Start up face tough regulations When starting a company in the US, informality rules, we all know the story that HP was started out of a garage. Now in Europe work is so regulated that you canâ€™t start a company out of a garage because you canâ€™t legally work in a garage. I did not know this at the time and started Jazztel out of my garage in La Moraleja, Madrid, fortunately nobody filed charges against me and soon we had an office in La Castellana. But in general, the intense regulation of work is something that I found extremely annoying as a US-trained tech entrepreneur. In Germany, where I built Einsteinet, for example, there are rules that state how many meters an employee has to be from a window.Â Many of the workspaces that are used in NYC are illegal in Germany because these employees are far from windows and in very small desksâ€”prohibitively crowded environments by German law. In Berlin there are many start ups who break these rules but I donâ€™t know how long this is going to last. I hope Germany goes the way of Berlin in adopting further flexibility for start ups. There is no formal way to start a company and start ups in Europe have to live by the rules of old and established companies. This canâ€™t go on. Europe needs to deregulate companies with less than three years of age, less than 20 employees that are not yet profitable. While I am not against many of the European labor laws as applied to large profitable companies, they are a clear obstacle for start ups. Legal fees are cheaper Now on the positive side. There are two areas that I find wonderful in Europe compared to the USA. One is that lawyers cost much less and do much less. Especially in Continental Europe. The UK and Ireland are more like the US in this case, but in the rest of Europe legal costs for a start up can be 90% less, and I really mean 90% less than in the USA. Lawyers are needed less, are used less and charge less. Savings can be enormous. There is much less frivolous litigation. There are few legal minefields while operating in Europe. The rules are tough, but they are clear. Also there are less types of patents allowed. Healthcare pros and cons Another positive is in health care. Most Europeans have state sponsored health care or plans that make health care for start ups a non issue. In the USA a start up can pay up to $800 per employee for health insurance. Or not offer it, but that is pretty sad should anything happen to an employee. In Spain, France, Italy, health care is free. Employers generally provide no insurance. Now on the negative side: in many places in Europe, and I would say this is more common in Southern rather than Northern Europe, medical care is used as a bargaining tool in labor relations.Â Spain for example is one of the countries with the longest life expectancy and yet one of the countries with the most sick days in the world. You could argue that it is healthy to take sick days but unfortunately what happens here is that patients ask doctors for medical justifications for paid leave of absence. A friend of mine was fed up with an employee who worked poorly and told him that if he didnâ€™t work harder he would fire him. This employee went to see a doctor, told the doctor that work depressed him and he was declared a mental patient; as a result, my entrepreneur friend had to pay him for a year of doing nothing. So while health care is free or almost free by US standards, in many places in Europe, there is some abuse of the health care system to work less. In the USA, by the way, the opposite happens: many times there are employees who are truly sick, but continue to work because they fear for their jobs. This is just as bad. Tough tax rules Then there are issues related to taxation. In the USA the general concept is that people should be rewarded with lower tax rates when they put their savings to work or invest. And gains on investments have lower tax rates. This is the same in Europe. But in the USA it is also understood that the same is true of stock options, which are taxed at capital gains rate. In most of Europe (except recently in the UK), on the other hand, capital gains are taxed as ordinary income, and what is worse many times out of the money stock options are deemed as income, with both implications towards taxation and part of forced severance pay packages. So if an employee cashes out on stock options in one year it may become unaffordable for the company to fire him or her the following year. Forced severance pay packages in Europe are not based on average earnings but on the last year earnings of employees. This makes it hard to give stock options if only for that reason, the same thing happens with bonuses. European labour market id heavily regulated and expensive Bonuses in Europe are a very tricky subject. Again this concerns how incredibly regulated the labor market is. So, if you pay a bonus either you have a very specific contract that explains how that bonus was earned or the employee can demand the same bonus next year even if he or she did not do what he or she did the year before or even if the company is doing much worse. It was a shock to me to find this out and it cost me dearly. In the end what many European employers do is not give out stock options and give tiny bonuses. What these laws do is make employers go for low fixed compensations and not expect outstanding work. This is bad for the European economy in a world in need for excellence, but it is the way it is. Less overall pay and less overall results.Â Related to this are regulated work hours and forced vacations. In Europe there is a common belief that work is punishment and that the role of government is to protect people from overworking. As if working in a start up was akin to working in a coal mine. So there are many rules that make it hard to work the 12 hours per day that a start up may need in its initial months. To work hard, to work long hours, is actually illegal in Europe. Yes, I know, it sounds strange, but it is illegal not only for an employer to ask an employee to work long hours and not take vacations but it is illegal for an employee to do that even if this person truly prefers to be at work rather than at home or on vacation. Again there is a problem here between what start ups need and what Europe regulates. Without counting stock option earn outs, engineers in the USA earn between two and three times what they earn in Europe. So it is hard to see how engineers are protected by European labor laws, and especially engineers in start ups. Europeans focus more on academics and less on personal reward In the USA there is a great deal of conversation about equal opportunity, but Europe goes furtherâ€“in Europe equal opportunity is not enough, instead what Europeans expect is equal results. Surprisingly the educational system in European nations is highly competitive and discriminatory, based on grades. Much tougher than the US high school system for example. So, as students, Europeans are ranked and divided, but once they reach adulthood they are expected to mostly work the same and earn the same even if their performance is different. So from this perspective there is something anti-European about the Silicon Valley culture of personal reward. I experienced this at Ya.com where in two years we distributed around $70M in cashed stock options among 20 employees. Later on these employees told me that it was culturally tough to get rich. That being the richest person in your family, or among your friends created a backlash that affected their personal lives. So if being rich is frowned upon what is the driver of success?Â Fortunately in Europe there are many people who have a tremendous work ethic and pride in what they do. To me the best testimonial of this is the open source movement. Europeans were and are the major driver between open source software development, a work many times done for free but with enormous sense of pride.Â Never try to make your employees rich So, if you are an American entrepreneur going to Europe you have to understand that Europeans are different and learn to live with their mentality. Focus less on making your employees rich, which they will appreciate but rarely say that their aim in life is to get rich and, instead, focus more on creating an environment of excellence where people can be proud of what they do and get a higher than average but near average take home pay. And you also have to understand and respect that Europeans have a life outside work, and that may actually partly be why on average they live four years longer than Americans. And that may be why you, yourself, the American entrepreneur, may actually enjoy your life in Europe. I did not move to Europe from NYC looking for work. I moved there looking for a life. And I found one. And thatâ€™s why many Americans move to Europe. Even in the USA now I am not the person who left. Europe changed me for the better. Why Europeans don't succeed in the global market And lastly, there is the â€œcan-doâ€ attitude of Americans that is hard to replicate in Europe, that Europe truly needs but rarely gets. Americans believe that they can conquer the world with their products and services. Some Europeans do as well but that is less common. In all of Europe only one company has emerged among the most valuable in the world in the last 30 years and that is Spanish Inditex, the fashion company behind Zara. Other than that, most European companies among the worldâ€™s most valuable are very old. Contrast this with Google, Facebook, Amazon, all new companies among the worldâ€™s most valuable. And the problem with this is that it is harder to convince a group of Europeans that they are out to conquer the world in their field. It is cultural. That is why many world-class European tech companies like Skype end up in American hands. Spotify will probably soon follow. It is easier for Americans to believe and bet on them. Also, there are very few world-class European VCs (exceptions Index Ventures and Atomico); there are no European companies with piles of cash as Google, Apple and Microsoft have, thus providing a string of exits for start ups. The last company who did that and bought two of my angel investments was Nokia, now on the ropes. Bottom line is that a company in Berlin is likely to be worth less than an identical company in Silicon Valley. Sad but true. Doing business in European - Is it really worth it? So, if you are an American entrepreneur, should you move to Europe? Well some did and did quite well. My friend Zaryn Dentzel founder of Tuenti is one of them. But do not make a significant move before truly understanding how different Europe is from the USA. Other than France, which seems to be moving in the opposite direction, Europe is changing for the better. It is making it easier to be an entrepreneur, and in a Europe in crisis, entrepreneurs are finally getting more respect.

post.title: Jaren 80 alt country: More Than A Whisper
post.summary: Normal 0 21 false false false NL X-NONE X-NONE MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 Nanci Griffith Voor mij was de jaren 80 ook de periode dat ik country ontdekte. Ik ben begonnen met Grievous Angel van Gram Parsons. Ik had een paar jaar daarvoor The Last Waltz verzwolgen. En The Band heeft natuurlijk ook wel een sterk traditionele invalshoek. Maar Grievous Angel was de eerste echte country plaat. Mijn jaren 80 countryheldin is Nanci Griffith. Ik heb het voor het gemak maar even country genoemd, maar eigenlijk is Nanci Griffith meer folk dan country. Er zit in haar liedjes, en vooral in haar voordracht, een enorm gevoel van melancholie. Maar ook wel een prettige melancholie: het is het koesteren van je oude herinneringe. Bij Nanci Griffith is zelfs de actualiteit een vorm van melancholie. Neem bijvoorbeeld de manier waarop ze over de Woolworth store verteld in de live versie van Love At The Five And Dime. De scheidslijn tussen country en folk (en rock of popmuziek) is niet altijd even duidelijk. In de jaren 80 kwam er vooral vanuit Texas een behoorlijke stroom nieuw bloed in het toch flink ingezakte country genre. Begin jaren 70 was er de outlaw country met mensen als Willy Nelson en Waylon Jennings. Maar aan het eind van de jaren70 waren zij ook gearriveerde sterren en was hun output niet echt goed meer. Veel van de mensen die in dit lijstje staan zijn vooral beÃ¯nvloed door de country folk van mensen als Townes van Zandt en Guy Clark. Steve Earl heeft zelfs zijn zoon vernoemd naar Townes van Zandt. Punk komt hier ook om de hoek kijken. En dan met name bij Green on Red en Jason & The Scorchers. Joe Ely heeft ook nog enige relatie met de punk: hij speelde ook met de Clash, of beter gezegd The Clash speelde met hem. Ely had eind jaren 70 al enkele progressieve country lpâ€™s op zijn naam staan. Er is eigenlijk maar 1 naam die er wat mij betreft echt bij hoort en die ontbreekt en dat is Lee Clayton. Dat is zeg maar de mannelijke tegenhanger van Nanci Griffith. Hij heeft helaas maar enkele lpâ€™s gemaakt en verdween toen geruisloos van het toneel. Zelfs de wikipedia weet niet waar hij gebleven is. Luister overigens niet naar de nummers die volgens spotify van hem zijn. Dat zijn inferieure covers van nummers van hem. Hopelijk kan ik hem nog een keer aan deze lijst toevegen. Lee ClaytonNanci Griffith - More The A WhisperLyle Lovitt â€“ If I Had A BoatCowboy Junkies â€“ Sweet Janek.d. Lang â€“ Black CoffeeSteve Earl â€“ My Old Friend The BluesDwight Yoakam Iâ€™ll Be GoneThe Judds â€“ Why Not MeEric Taylor â€“ East Texas MoonJohn Gorka â€“ Branching OutRosie Flores â€“ God May Forgive YouRodney Crowell â€“ After All This TimePeter Case â€“ Put Down Your GunGreen On Red â€“ DrifterJoe Ely â€“ Row Of DominoesJason & The Scorchers - Broken Whiskey GlassNanci Griffith â€“ Love At The Five And Dime (Live)

post.title: Listen to Help
post.summary:
Turning Spotify into a donations platform. How it works:
Spotify pays an artist every time you listen to one of their tracks. We replaced the artist with a charity. Just by listening to this track, you are helping hearing impaired children hear again.
The Listen to Help Project started during my internship at BBH London. My creative partner, Anders Teigene, and me, where part of the BBH Barn, and were given the challenge to come up with an idea to make the world a bit better, and make it happen. So we did it. We used Spotify, the digital music-streaming service, to launch a fundraising initiative for Sound Seekers, a charity dedicated to helping deaf and hearing-impaired people in the developing world. Like many other people in the world, we love Spotify, and finding out its pay-per-play mechanic gave us an idea. In Spotify, artists get paid every time users play one of their tracks, so we decided to â€œhack the systemâ€ for a good cause. How? We replaced the artist with a charity, uploading a track that was both, the media and the message, since every time users played it a donation to help hearing impaired children would be automatically made. The result? We turned Spotify into a donations platform. Â Â Â Â Â No forms. No bank accounts. Just listening would help. Thatâ€™s why we called it Listen to Help. And it did. Even Spotifyâ€™s founder, Daniel Ek, loved it.
And so many other blogs. But most importantly, people from all around the world were listening and sharing the track. Supporters could easily place it on their blogs thanks to Spotifyâ€™s Play Button, making Listen to Help the worldâ€™s first global fundraising campaign on Spotify. The project, Listen To Help, aims to help those who can hear to raise money for those who canâ€™t. On Spotify, artists receive a royalty every time someone plays one of their songs. The team behind Listen to Help had the idea that if they could create a track with no artist to receive royalties, then the fees would go directly to the charity. The â€˜trackâ€™, called Just Listen, is a short 35 second audio clip of a man describing the project. Simply by listening to it, people can help support others who canâ€™t. To learn more about the project visit listentohelp.org Now it is your time to make it happen. Just listen and share the track to help someone hear again: Sound Seekers â€“ Just Listen Credits Creative Team: Pepe BorrÃ¡s & Anders Teigene. BBH Creative Director: Pablo Marques BBH Producer: Jeremy Gleeson BBH Creative Technologist: Luke Kidney

post.title: #MIDEM: Music for Everyone - Paul McGuinness, Michel Barnier, Axel Dauchez & More
post.summary:
From Cannes by Stuart Dredge of UK consultancy and blog Music Ally.
Early risers (i.e. 10am) at Midem today were treated to an appearance
by Michel Barnier, European Commissioner for internal market and
services, in a session entitled â€˜Music for Everyoneâ€™, with a keynote
from Barnier followed by a panel session.
Barnier kicked off by citing the music industryâ€™s importance to
Europe â€“Â a 6bn-Euro market that has spawned digital startups including
Spotify, Deezer, Last.fm and 7digital.
But he also talked about the challenges facing the industry.
â€œEuropeans are often frustrated at not being able to access online the
diversity of content offered in other member states, even though they
are prepared to pay for it,â€ he said.
â€œThe availability of some of the most popular online music providers
is still very uneven between member states. How can it be, for example,
that some of them are not available in Italy or Poland? And that only
three out of the 20 most popular operators may be accessible from
certain member states?â€
Barnier was keen to stress that there are challenges on all sides of
the digital music ecosystem: labels and publishers invest in artists
only to see their work immediately made available on pirate sites, while
startups trying to launch pan-European services are stymied by â€œthe
compartmentalism of national marketsâ€.
â€œWhether consumers, investors or entrepreneurs, it is
incomprehensible that Europeans are finding on the Internet obstacles
that we have been trying to break down in the physical world for more
than 50 years,â€ said Barnier.
â€œWhile it should not be a convenient scapegoat, copyright must no
longer form part of these obstacles. It is not a stumbling block, it
should be a modern effective tool for supporting innovation.â€
Barnier went on to talk about the European Commissionâ€™s Licences for
Europe initiative, aiming to get rightsholders and digital services
together to solve challenges including pan-European access to online
music services, and legal questions around user-generated content.
He also talked collecting societies, noting the importance of their
work across Europe, but also the complexity of a market with 30
different societies, all operating under different rules.
Barnier hoped that the ECâ€™s directive on collective rights management
will remove the barriers for digital music services looking to operate
across Europe.
â€œIt will mean a step forward not only for the 250-plus online music
service providers in Europe, but also for all those whose services
incorporate music, like TV channels and video-on-demand services,â€ he
said. â€œAll of these players need multi-territorial licences.â€
Barnier said the EC isnâ€™t ignoring the question of piracy: â€œCopyright
is an essential driver in the creative process, but a right which
cannot be respected is of little use,â€ he said, before moving on to a
pet hate of music rightsholders: piracy sites funded by advertising.
â€œIs it acceptable to tolerate advertising revenues being gobbled up
by a service provider who foster the free sharing of illegal music
files?â€ he said.
â€œBased on the results of a consultation we have launched, we will
decide whether improvements to the European legal framework need to be
proposedâ€¦ We must find solutions that protect and improve the domestic
market, stressing the fight against infringements on a commercial scale,
in accordance with the principle of â€˜follow the moneyâ€™.â€
Barnier also said that heâ€™s keen to drive the â€œre-legitimisationâ€ of
copyright through dialogue with the music industry and digital services,
as well as through new legislation if necessary.
â€œWe cannot give free rein to the illusion that everything is free,
and we cannot give the impression that in an age where file duplication
is infinite and instant, that unlimited sharing of protected content is a
natural right, particularly when profit is the objective [of the pirate
sites].â€
Songwriter and journalist Helienne Lindvall responded to the speech,
saying that â€œitâ€™s good to hear a voice from Brussels that understands
and supports authors and songwriters, because sometimes we fell a bit
left out in the cold.â€
She went on to say there are certainly unresolved issues on the
availability of music. â€œSome collecting societies are a lot better than
other collecting societies. I would welcome more transparency and
accountability,â€ she said.
â€œI would be happy if there were fewer collecting societies that would
be more efficient and transparent, or at least be accountable to
Brussels or to somebody.â€
She also talked about the â€œincredible successâ€ of Spotify in her
native Sweden, where it has helped the industry bounce back from its
sales lows in recent years.
But she also pointed out the need to â€œmake those services thrive by
doing something about illegal services â€“Â you cannot have a healthy
market if you have a part of that market which is unhealthy and freeâ€¦ It
doesnâ€™t matter how many great licensed services we have if we donâ€™t do
anything about the other side.â€
Lindvall also talked about the personal difficulties sheâ€™s
encountered trying to get songs sheâ€™s written taken down from unlicensed
services like Grooveshark, and the brick wall sheâ€™s come up against
when every takedown seemingly generates more uploads of those tracks.
â€œI was once told by a politician that I could tke them to court. With
what? Certainly not with the revenues that I make from YouTube,â€ she
said, raising a knowing laugh from the audience.
Andrew Jenkins from Universal Music Publishing gave a majorâ€™s
perspective, saying the infrastructure in Europe has to be gotten right.
â€œWe had 200 years of national licensing essentially, and then in the
last seven years weâ€™ve had multi-territory licensing in Europe,â€ he
said. â€œWeâ€™ve had to make a lot of changes.â€
Jenkins suggested that initiatives like the Global Repertoire Database (GRD) is trying to tackle these issues.
â€œThe best thing we can do for cultural diversity is to make sure that
everybody who does write works gets paid for writing works,â€ he said.
â€œWe have to as an industry solve those infrastructural problems.â€
Jenkins also addressed the costs of creating the GRD, saying it will
provide good value for money (unsurprisingly, of course â€“Â heâ€™s involved
in the project).
â€œSpending 50m Euros creating a database seems like a lot of money.
Actually, in the scheme of [industry revenues of] 3.6bn Euros a year,
itâ€™s tiny.â€
Music manager Paul McGuinness weighed in next, welcoming the thrust of Barnierâ€™s speech, and the work of the EC.
â€œThe truth about collection societies that no one really mentions is
that not only do their tariffs vary enormously around the world, but
also their standards of integrity vary enormously,â€ he said.
â€œWhen we talk about the availability of licences not being
sufficient, very often weâ€™re using that as a euphemism. Very often the
people seeking licences suffer from letâ€™s call it an â€˜integrity
deficitâ€™. Thatâ€™s the reason they donâ€™t get licences, and they should
not.â€
He also talked about the rise of legal services like Spotify and
Deezer â€œwhere thereâ€™s no question of integrityâ€¦ where there is a
question, and I include YouTube, these are the main distributors and are
going to become more important in the years to come.â€
But he echoed the criticism of other managers and artists about the
money coming from these services. â€œUp until now, even for very big
artists the sums of money passing through those services are quite
trivialâ€¦ theyâ€™re very small indeed,â€ he said.
â€œYou could say that these services are mainly a promotional medium. I
hope they grow and prosper, because they are legitimate, but weâ€™ll have
to wait and see about that.â€
And then McGuinness returned to a previous bugbear: Google.
â€œI donâ€™t want to engage in Google-bashing, but there is a sense of
unease across Europe, across the world about Google,â€ he said. â€œGoogle
have been making encouraging noises about restricting illegal sites or
directions to illegal sites for acquiring music. The noises are very
encouraging, but Iâ€™d like to see some action. Itâ€™s as simple as that.â€
McGuinness wasnâ€™t just Google-bashing, though, as he said. â€œGoogle
have brought so much to civilisation in terms of spreading knowledge and
informing the world. I know theyâ€™re ingenious, we all know theyâ€™re
ingenious,â€ he said.
â€œBut they are making money from directing people to piracy sitesâ€¦ I
wish they would apply themselves and their extraordinary ingenuity to
the micro-transactions that occur every time somebody listens to a piece
of music over the internet. They can do itâ€¦ There is a sense of unease,
and a feeling theyâ€™re not really doing what they could be doing in this
space. And I would like them to hurry up a level.â€
Barnier was asked about Google. Cue a long pause.
â€œWeâ€™ve said how important Google is and other operators â€“Â usually
American â€“Â theyâ€™re very important players, they have a positive role to
play in dissemination, in education,â€ he said.
â€œAnd in general terms, what I believe is that in the Internet
ecosystem we need to change how values are distributed. Whatâ€™s going on
today is not fair for creators, for authors, for writers. Theyâ€™re not
being paid, and when they are being paid, itâ€™s not properly for the work
which they have done. Theyâ€™re not protected.â€
Barnier also talked about the balance for sharing reveneus from the
digital ecosystem as â€œa new subject on the table in Brusselsâ€, appealing
for input from all quarters. Yes, in other words, he nimbly dodged the
Google question. But then worked his way back to it.
â€œIf we donâ€™t stick together [as Europeans] we will be lost. We will
be subcontractors, under the influence of the Chinese and American
economies.â€
Axel Dauchez, CEO of streaming service Deezer was next to speak,
professing himself as a big fan of the new EC initiatives, and of
copyright itself. â€œItâ€™s not only protecting the content, itâ€™s protecting
the platforms. We are not protected enough.â€
However, Dauchez said he was very optimistic about the evolution of
digital music services, but â€œvery pessimistic about the diversity of it â€“
the number of European platforms is decreasing month after month in
every countryâ€¦ The consolidation has already started, and the risk is
there.â€
He highlighted some key copyright issues that Deezer is facing.
First, complexity. â€œWe are now live in 180 countries, and we have to
deal with this mess of the publishing world, and it is very, very
complex,â€ he said.
â€œWe are dealing with publishers and collecting societies worldwide,
and they cannot even tell us what we are buying!.. The fees are not
clear.â€
Dauchez focused on the problems facing European digital music
services, as they try to compete against some of the big global players,
particularly Google and Apple.
â€œI think there is one cancer: itâ€™s been said about Google a little
bit before,â€ he said. â€œWhat I think the key word is is discriminationâ€¦
Am I a competitor to YouTube? Should I have the same deals as YouTube?
Of course. When I am discussing with collecting societies and publishers
can I say â€˜just give me the deals that YouTube hasâ€™? Of course not.â€
Dauchez said the same applies to iTunes, including the fact that
Apple makes its money from hardware sales rather than just from digital
music â€“Â yet a company like Deezer canâ€™t ask for the same deals Apple
gets when signing licensing agreements.
â€œThis will kill the innovation, this will kill the local players. We
are already under huge discrimination because of VAT, and because of the
size of our market compared to the USâ€¦ We need to be protected against
discrimination on copyright.â€
That, in 1,900 words, is the gist of the discussion.

post.title: Behold Eluveitie
post.summary: Note this is aimed at those who are new to this band like me.So I thought I would embed a few Eluveitie Tracks today. I discovered this band some months ago while browsing on spotify, this week I finally brought three of there albums on iTunes. Â I always make an oath to buy artists stuff once i know i like it, asÂ fresh air pie is not very filling.As you know my slogan for this blog is 'rejecting the herd', for me music herds are the worst, these are people that never listen to anything that doesn't fit with what they or their friends think is cool. I have never given a toss what people think about my musical tastes. There are those that will see Eluveitie as a musical abomination neither 'real' folk or true death metal, some will even reject them because they have no real pigeon hole. That my friends is one of the reasons why I like many of the bands on here, this blog salutes them for all their years of service challenging perceptions and pissing people in the herd off. There is little point me saying anymore so make up your own mind. If you enjoy these videos please support the band by buying their work. Â Eluveitie Website

post.title: Semana musical #7
post.summary: Esta semana ha sido increÃ­ble. De esas semanas tranquilas, sabÃ­a que era mi Ãºltima semana de calma, asÃ­ que aprovechÃ© los pequeÃ±os placeres a los que tengo que renunciar durante la rutina como despertarme a las 12 del mediodÃ­a y leer hasta las 5 de la madrugada o mirar peliculas compulsivamente. El domingo pasado fui a ver Django desencadenado, de Tarantino. Hay algo que forma parte de las pelÃ­culas de Tarantino que nunca me defrauda: LA BANDA SONORA; me parece que todas las canciones estÃ¡n calculadas milimetricamente y son ideales. Durante mis ratitos en casa, solo sonÃ³ esta lista en Spotify En fin, semana musical, seÃ±oras y seÃ±oras, que como veis, empezÃ³ con grupos de aquÃ­: Lunes 21: Sun Bay - La Pegatina Ãšltimamente cada vez que salÃ­a en mi aleatorio una canciÃ³n de La Pegatina la pasaba, no por nada en concreto, era como demasiada energÃ­a. necesitaba canciones mÃ¡s tranquilas. El lunes sonÃ³ esta canciÃ³n y no la pasÃ©, incluso mÃ¡s: la repetÃ­. Me transportÃ© mentalmente al verano, a estar rodeada de mis mejores amigos y a no tener nada mejor que hacer que bailarla como si fuera a terminarse el mundo. Se mire como se mire, tengo debilidad por esta canciÃ³n. Martes 22: Alma de Cantaora - Amparo SÃ¡nchez Me gusta, la admiro. Me acuerdo que de pequeÃ±ita me fascinaba como vestÃ­a en sus conciertos. Me parecÃ­a una reina en el escenario, hace poco la vi subida en el escenario junto a Bongo Botrako y sigue siendo la reina del escenario.Â MiÃ©rcoles 23: Benvolgut - Manel Lo repetirÃ© las veces que haga falta: ME ENCANTA MANEL. Me parece de lo mejor en catalÃ¡n. Cuento los dÃ­as para verlos en el Primavera Sound. ---------A mediados de semana pasÃ³ algo. QuedÃ© con alguien con quien me une mucho la mÃºsica, y como hacÃ­a bastante que no nos veÃ­amos y habÃ­a pasado navidad y las fiestas, pensÃ© en hacerle dos compilados de mÃºsica, subÃ­ las fotos a twitter y a instagram de las portadas: Lo mejor no fue esto, fue que esta persona habÃ­a pensado lo mismo y me trajo este precioso compilado, del que no he podido despegarme, y como no ha sonado nada mÃ¡s desde el jueves, aquÃ­ van algunas de las canciones que mÃ¡s me gustaron, la mayorÃ­a descubiertas por primera vez.Â Â Â Jueves 24: Dreams come true girl - Cass McCombs Viernes 25: The Quitter - Salim Nourallah SÃ¡bado 26: Today Knows - Â The Ladybug transitor Domingo 27: Beware, Oh Take Care - Chris Robinson Brotherhood -----Â¡Feliz semana!

post.title: Peer to peer recommendations - still important?
post.summary: A few years back (2007) I completed the CIPR's postgraduate diploma in Public Relations. Part of that was undertaking a dissertation, and my chosen topic was on the value of social media for peer to peer recommendations for PR. I kept up a blogÂ on the work at the time so feel free to check it out, although clearly no longer active. The premise I had at that time was the effects that marketing research had shown for Word Of Mouth (WOM) could be harnessed by businesses using social media. People like hearing what their friends value, what they are buying, reading, eating. Things have moved on a fair bit since 2007. According to the TripAdvisor website, there are now more than 75m individual reviews about hotels, restaurants or other travel-related guidance on their site. It's no longer just a small subset of in-the-know techies writing the reviews; it is you and me, your friends and even your parents. Amazon will prompt to you revisit and rate products you have purchased. Unlike 'review', 'rate' asks little of you as a customer, thereby further increasing the likelihood you will respond. Most ecommerce sites will also provide you with "share" options to tell all your friends about the service you have just used. Again, this is asking very little of you as a customer, and provides that business with a brand advocate without any investment of time or effort. Mashable recently posted a somewhat sceptical piece on the current value of a LinkedIn endorsement. It suggested that the service has made it so easy to just hit a button and endorse for skills that the reader - be they recruiter or potential business associate - has no way of validating whether those recommendations are genuine or just the result of someone logrolling (giving in expectation of the same favour in return). If you apply that same logic to the rating options on other websites, do brands still benefit from providing this as a way of showing peer to peer recommendations? Do we, as consumers, see this as valuable, and does it affect our purchasing decisions? I have begun to consider whether there is the same value in "peer to peer" review as I had originally suggested, and whether instead it's time to discuss the value of "friend to friend" review. Going back to the huge increase in users of peer to peer review sites such as TripAdvisor or TopTable or CheckATrade, do we (as potential customers) still hold these views of strangers to be valid? I know I'm not the only one to have been paralysed by checking out a hotel over and over on TripAdvisor then getting to the hotel and had a fantastic time anyway. Similarly with Amazon reviews: reading is subjective; just because one person hasn't enjoyed a title, why shouldn't you? I'm not saying I don't believe these review services offer value. There is always value in seeing crowdsourcing as a measure of popularity: if a restaurant gets 50 five star ratings, there is a good chance that it will be better than the restaurant next door with 50 one star ratings. What I am saying is could there be something even more valuable on offer if we start to look at a more granular level at who these people are? TripAdvisor already does this to some extent by allowing for filtering by type of review: romantic, business, family etc. This goes back to the original premise of 'peer to peer' social media WOM for PR, which was that you are influenced in purchasing decisions by 'other people like me'. This is intensified if those reviews are from the people we actually know are like us, in other words our friends. Consider for example services like SpotifyÂ where you are connected in with Facebook friends, seeing what tracks they are listening to. You are much more likely to only be connected to people you genuinely 'know' on Facebook. At least much more so than we 'know' our Twitter contacts, or know any of the people whose reviews we are reading on TripAdvisor. So how much more powerful could these recommendation services become when we start looking at what our genuine friends, with whom we know we share interests, are sharing? And could we begin to look at how to harness this network even further for brand advocacy? More to come on this topic over the coming weeks.

post.title: KÃ¶ksslyna #1
post.summary: Godmorgon, kÃ¤nns som att hela huset ligger Ã¥Ã¥ sover... Helt tyst, jag Ã¤lskar nÃ¤r det Ã¤r sÃ¥hÃ¤r lugnt, sÃ¥ drar pÃ¥ spotify i kÃ¶ket Ã¥Ã¥ gÃ¶r frukost. VÃ¤cker Banadness nÃ¤r jag kÃ¤nner fÃ¶r det, haha livet Ã¤r pÃ¥ topp ðŸ˜ KÃ¤nner mig som en kÃ¶ksslyna!

Well hello. So this is my first MMAAS blog. The aim of it is to generally chat about stuff that's going on in my/the world sprinkled with some poignant opinion. It is also going to be an insight to all of those in the mental health profession. If you can provide a diagnosis as a result of reading my ramblings then please get in touch. Topic 1: The art of surviving a 'wedding planning' event I have no idea on how I did this and lived to tell the tale. My ears have never witnessed so much shrieking, cackling and talk of favours. I now know that there are several grades of whites you can have for dresses, it is not a compromise for the mother of the bride to make a speech at the reception and fir cones can be used as bouquets...ish. How did I do it? Here it is folks: Evacuate the premises before the gaggle arrive Although unsocial, ensure you have an alternative place to be and ensure it is robust and can guarantee a safe haven. I, sadly, sought the safety of the office. There were a few advantages to this - no-one else would be there, I could do some arduous admin that wasn't completed during the week and I could listen to my Norwich City get beaten in the FA Cup 5th round by Luton Town. Also, I could stay there as long as I wanted. Ensure you say at least one thing My knowledge of weddings is limited so when I returned home and the girls were still present I couldn't sit like a lemon in the corner - after all, it was my flat. So I asked the following questions, all of which I knew would spark up a debate or at least a humorous "you pillock" remark.Â "HowÂ many guests are you having!?""I thought you were only allowed two bridesmaids?""What about a pink dress?""Are you going to show the [insert sport here] at the reception?"Pleased to say that all had successes in sparking a reaction Take control of the music selectionThey have taken control of the lounge, kitchen is a mess and you can't shut yourself in the room. You have made some silly remarks so they acknowledge your presence but you need to score some internal man points. Get the laptop, whack on spotify and take control. I'm a big advocate for Pitchfork and love to listen to the albums with the 8.0+ reviews. Therefore, if you stumble upon something a bit heavy don't worry. It's a small victory. Sit up smugly amigo, you're taking control. Offer to top up empty glassesSimply being a good host is always a great thing to be. Last thing: always stay positiveEven after a few hours of mind-numbing conversation, shrill noises and countless pictures of bouquets (including fir cone ones) keep positive. No-one wants a grumpy loner listening to random music on their own in the room. You will reap the rewards later. That is it. The full-proof guide of surviving a wedding planning event hosted in your flat. Now, just to wash all of the glasses, plates and cutlery used by the girls...There is no getting away from those. Until next time.

post.title: Jeg kunne ikke levd uten...
post.summary: ...kokte gulrÃ¸tter ...hvite korte sokker ...pepsi max ...sure cola slanger ...skjÃ¸nnhetsguruene pÃ¥ youtube ...spotify premium ...iphonen min ...twitter ...instagram ...gina tricot ...h&m ...one tree hill ...kosegensere ...svarte stramme bukser ...venner ...familien min ...facebook ...popcorn ...carmex ...macbook'en ...bik bok ...vezzano weekend bag ...Ã¥mot ...klesstativ ...nicki minaj - pink friday parfyme ...speilrefleksen min ...nelly.com ...rettetang Hva kan ikke du leve uten? :)

In the midst of it all there are moments when there's nothing else to do than to listen to old five (remember them?) songs on spotify and the shared soundtrack with a beautiful sparkling dear friend of mine, like a star far away but always there and who's been shining light on the moments I needed it most these past few days. Merci vilmal, my love. On another note, my head and heart wish to be able to travel seas in a snap and my thoughts and love will be with my amazing American family who I haven't seen in far too long these next few days. I have no words to add, except a cliche I love you all and I promise to come spend time soon. Words are hard to find these days, and when they do come out they seem to be more like a tsunami of frustration (quoting that one) and they are. So for now, it's strengthening the last bits of energy for unfair fights that will continue to be fought even if it's only out of principle. January has flown by, I can't believe we're entering the second month of this year in only a few short days. Maybe 2013 should be the year of adventures, and real adventures this time. The dreams that are only dreams. To kick down every limit we can, although it turns out even the strongest force aren't strong enough to break some. To stop thinking from a reasons we can't or won't work point of view and to look at all the (other) opportunities. Oh well, for now - it's back to attempts of gathering that energy and listening to old songs and shared soundtracks. xo

Det fÃ¥r inte bli fÃ¶r mÃ¥nga delar eller lÃ¥nga upprepningar, sÃ¥vida man inte gÃ¶r lÃ¥tar till Danny Saucedo *skratt*. FÃ¶rra Ã¥ret blev EDM (Electronic Dance Music) en folkhemsgenre tack vare hitlÃ¥tar med Swedish House Mafia och Avicii. En genre som Ã¤ven gick hem i Europa dÃ¥ Loreen vann Eurovision Song Contest. Hur ser du pÃ¥ modern musik?
Det Ã¤r det jag kÃ¤nner att jag gillar. Att ta energin frÃ¥n klubblÃ¥tar, behÃ¥lla trummor, det melodiska frÃ¥n popmusiken och lÃ¤gga en lÃ¥t pÃ¥ det. Det Ã¤r det som jag tror Ã¤r min grej och det jag vill fortsÃ¤tta gÃ¶ra och utveckla. Ã„r det nÃ¥gon DJ du influeras frÃ¤mst av?
Nej, dÃ¤remot Ã¤r det vÃ¤ldigt mycket svenskt. Jag tycker Eric Prydz och John DahlbÃ¤ck gÃ¶r jÃ¤ttebra grejer i sin genre, samtidigt som Swedish House Mafia gÃ¶r storslagna grejer fÃ¶r arenan.Â

Det Ã¤r lustigt att vi har den hÃ¤r stora kulturen av DJs men aldrig riktigt haft nÃ¥gra dansscener i Sverige. Under 1990-talet hade vi rejvfester men dÃ¥ var det inga DJs som kom fram pÃ¥ det sÃ¤ttet de gÃ¶r idag.

post.title: Django!
post.summary: On January 23 I marked Django's birthday with an impromptu, off-the-cuff selection of his recordings, and I posted it on Twitter. His guitar was one my early hooks in jazz, and his recordings remain special. So, without further ado, I give you my Django!. Recordings date from the mid-30s to 1953; if you hear a violin, it's StÃ©phane Grappelli. If there's a clarinet that'll probably be Hubert Rostaing, same goes for Alix Combelle and his tenor sax (on "Finesse" Rex Stewart is on cornet and Barney Bigard on clarinet). Depending on the date, Django's instrument maybe an acoustic guitar, an electrified acoustic, or a electric guitar proper. Enjoy the music on YouTube or Spotify! * LES YEUX NOIRS * IMPROVISATION SUR UNE DANSE NORVEGIENNE * SWING 42 * ALL OF ME * DINETTE * TIGER RAG * MANOIR DE MES REVES * DJANGOLOGY * WHEN DAY IS DONE * YOU'RE DRIVING ME CRAZY * CHARLESTON * FINESSE * MANOIR DE MES REVES ('53) * ROSE ROOM * NUAGES

post.title: Â¡Django!
post.summary: El pasado 23 celebrÃ© el cumpleaÃ±os de Django Reinhardt con una selecciÃ³n improvisada y de memoria de sus grabaciones, y la circulÃ© entre amigos y en Twitter. Su guitarra fue uno de mis primeros ganchos en el jazz y sus grabaciones siguen siendo especiales. O sea que, sin mÃ¡s preÃ¡mbulos, aquÃ­ tienen mi Django!. Las grabaciones datan de mediados de los 30 a 1953. Si suena un violÃ­n, se trata de StÃ©phane Grappelli. El clarinete es el de Hubert Rostaing, y el saxo tenor, de Alix Combelle (en "Finesse" la corneta es de Rex Stewart y el clarinete, de Barney Bigard). SegÃºn la fecha, Django toca una guitarra acÃºstica, una acÃºstica electrificada, o una elÃ©ctrica. Espero que disfruten esta mÃºsica (en YouTube o Spotify). * LES YEUX NOIRS * IMPROVISATION SUR UNE DANSE NORVEGIENNE * SWING 42 * ALL OF ME * DINETTE * TIGER RAG * MANOIR DE MES REVES * DJANGOLOGY * WHEN DAY IS DONE * YOU'RE DRIVING ME CRAZY * CHARLESTON * FINESSE * MANOIR DE MES REVES ('53) * ROSE ROOM * NUAGES

post.title: Spotify still crashes in Ubuntu 13.04, but Clementine can play Spotify!
post.summary: Indeed it can, but Ubuntus own version of Clementine canâ€™t due to licensing reasons. However I found a version supplied by kind soul Dave Lentz on his Ubuntu ppa: http://ppa.launchpad.net/dtl131/ppa/ubuntu/pool/main/c/clementine/ It works fine in Raring, even though itâ€™s meant for a stable version of Ubuntu. Now I can have access to Spotify in a somewhat nicer way than through Spotifys cluttered webbrowser based beta-player. Btw, Clementine is a very good audio player on Linux, it can access music from multiple sources and have extended search functionality. Mabe more of a librarian than a player. But it is a player too. It is based on Amarok, the KDE music player, but is more suited graphically to melt in with Unity or Gnome.

post.title: Song of the Day #7 - Stereophonics - Maybe Tomorrow
post.summary:
Sunday, and this song somehow seams to fit. Flowing and makes one thing about life a little.The last six months I have walked to work a lot and for me it's a brilliant moment to listen to good music. I love walking and listening and see the world glide by around me. Needless to say I have been listening to a lot of different stuff, and so far there is one song that beats anything else; Maybe Tomorrow by Stereophonics. The flow of the song and those beautiful harmonies that goes through the whole song just cuddles you a little as you wander into the world and has just the perfect pace to take in the morning rush hour and passing people. Try it yourself, you will love it too.
These great experiences made me want to look into the song a bit more. I had actually not seen the video until a few weeks ago. And it's quite lovely. Watching it and also really listening to the lyrics for the first time made me realize that the song is about being lost in the world and slowly finding your way home and yourself or having hope that some day you will. For me that made the song beautiful in a new dimension. "I've been the upper side of down and the inside of out, but we breath, we breath.."
Other blog posts about Stereophonics and Kelly Jones, the lead singer.Â
Maybe Tomorrow on Spotify
