post.title: FEATURE â€” Why Millennials are Forging a New New Liberalism
post.summary: The supposed death and rebirth of liberalism has been written about time after time. With each new Republican electoral win or through the republicanization of Democrats the media has tried to bury the fiery will to make progress; each time declaring that America just wants to return to its â€œtraditionalâ€ values, I suppose this is the natural position of the old guard in any era. But like the death and return of Superman has been ingrained in the cultural consciousness of America, the death and return of liberalism has been a topic of glee for conservatives and angst for liberals since The Great Society. My next statement is biased (what article isnâ€™t) and a reflection of all that is supposedly wrong with Millennials; but we are the generation of a new age. Weâ€™re a generation whose formative years had the backdrop of (now) three two-term presidents with each president governing in the shadow of another recent two-term president whether they liked it or not. While many Millennials like myself werenâ€™t even alive during the Reagan years (I personally was only alive for the last 7 days of Reaganâ€™s presidency â€“ you do the math) we grew up in the Ronald Reagan Era. A more apt description may be the Reagan narrative. The Political Backdrop Lower taxes, less spending, smaller government, strong military, traditional values. These are the rhetorical talking points that appears to have been ingrained into every republican since birth. For the rest of us, especially for the old guard liberals who have fought against these their entire lives we have been reactionaries instead of the articulators of liberal ideals and ideas. And as much admiration and respect we have for the old guard liberals, there are some truths to the conservative message that I think many Millennials have adopted into their own worldview. During the 2012 presidential campaign a lot was made of the fact that the top marginal tax rate was around 90% under Eisenhower and that was a period of economic boom for much of the country. But during the height of election season I never heard a single liberal commentator, pundit, writer, or blogger defend a tax rate of 90%, or even 70% for any bracket. The reason is that no single mainstream liberal supports a policy like that. The Reaganites have largely won the idea of lower tax rates but that argument has run itsâ€™ course, there is only so low taxes can practically go and weâ€™ve hit that point. The New New Liberalism, maybe we should call it Millenialism, is a vision of restoring balance to the economic classes. Not eliminating, or rendering class divisions completely meaningless through the tax code, like some liberals may have argued in the past; but of addressing the issue of income equality in a way that doesnâ€™t hinder the lifestyle of the few, or bar a lifestyle advancement to the many. And this is how I think Millennials view the issue of income inequality. Itâ€™s inane to disassociate the issue of income and salary from lifestyle; this is the inherent problem of discussing benefits/entitlements, because the conversation rarely veers towards the practical effect changes to these programs would have on the lifestyle of recipients. Millennials think about lifestyle a lot, Iâ€™d argue most of the choices Millennials make are about moderate lifestyle changes, itâ€™s the reason weâ€™re willing to accept lower salaries for increased benefits and flexibility more than previous generations. This is also the practical effect of more and more of us pushing off marriage and having children. We have taken the idea of living in the here-and-now to heart and want lifestyles that satisfy us and give us rich experiences instead of pursuing the dream of being rich. And thatâ€™s the inherent difference between Millennials and previous generations and why we are in fact forging a new political consensus. Our opinions are not so much about ideology anymore, as they are about opportunity to have a lifestyle filled with rich experience. We want tax rates and policies that allow better lifestyles for the poor and the middle class while not penalizing too harshly people at the top rates. We recognize that people at the top rates donâ€™t see any significant lifestyle reductions by increasing the tax rates on them by small amounts as was recently done during the fiscal slope battle. Millennialism is not about makers and takers, rich and poor, or the overlap these things often have had with racial politics. Millennialism is about ways of making everyoneâ€™s lifestyles a bit better than they previously were and the method of getting to that outcome is close to irrelevant to us. The Millennial Connection Reaganism won in a certain sense; we now collectively (at least rhetorically) dislike big government. But liberalism won as well because we now collectively (at least rhetorically) reject big business due to the unappealing chase after ever-more profit and ever-more extravagant lifestyles. This stems from a deep desire of my generation to reject inauthenticity, shallowness, and ruthlessness. Big business, especially publicly traded businesses primary goal is profit for their shareholders and thus long term responsibility is often shucked for short-term profitability. We grew up in the era of the Enron and Worldcom scandals and more importantly the era of the great recession caused by greed and the rejection of long-term responsibility on Wall Street. While previous generations distrusted big business but were eventually pulled in by it because there was no other way to make money, in our era, the Millennial era, we have alternatives and weâ€™re running with it. And the few big businesses Millennials flock to are those that are progressively changing how big business operates like Google and Facebook. What I propose as a paradigm through which to view the world is by looking at these two entities we distrust, big government and big business, as checks on each other. They are larger than life jaegers (Pacific Rim reference) doing battle with their heads in the clouds while the rest of us just try not to get stepped on. The Future of Millennial Entrepreneurship So, while the jaegers are battling it out amongst the clouds of ideology, what are Millennials to do? Where are we going as a nation when Millennials truly start to drive the narrative and changes we see in the country? If Millennials largely reject big government as well as big business, through what vehicle will they make an impact? The answer to this question, and the question of how we will address our unemployment problem, is through entrepreneurship. The traditional view of the entrepreneur was of someone who starts a brick and mortar store selling some sort of tangible product, the next evolution of the entrepreneur in the modern age was someone selling some sort of financial or real estate service. I argue that the next iteration of the entrepreneur is someone selling themselves. Get your mind out of the gutter, I am talking about selling themselves as a brand. Perhaps ironically I believe this shift began with Myspace but I think weâ€™re only now starting to see the model adopted more widely. Myspace was originally conceived as a platform for bands to do an end-around music publishers and reach their fans directly. As we all know it quickly devolved into a space for tweens and teens to post every unsolicited detail of their lives, and share so much multimedia content that a visit to their personal page would crash any consumer laptop of 2003. This was largely the reason of itsâ€™ collapse and I was no exception to the Myspace fad. Despite itâ€™s downfall, the model Myspace pioneered was taken up by other companies, namely Facebook. And today artists have continued the Myspace tradition by publishing their own content directly on the internet through sites like Soundcloud, Bandcamp, and their own personal sites. Not to mention the ability to publish content through Spotify, Mog, and Rdio. Musical artists are more entrepreneurial than ever before because they have had to be, and that spirit is being adopted by Millennials with other skill sets. The key point about social networks is that they allow anyone to post unsolicited writings, musings, art, opinion, movies, scripts, novels, and any other piece of material one can think of for the world to see. So what if all of this unsolicited material, which is unofficially solicited by social networks, became officially solicited content. Weâ€™re moving to a place where Millennials (like myself) are trying to take ownership of their content by leveraging what we produce. We are selling ourselves as content creators. Entrepreneurship in the web 2.0 and 3.0 era looks like Kickstarter projects, looks like WordPress blogs, looks like Twitter comments, and looks like Youtube videos. The truth is that many of us may have no choice except to become entrepreneurial, as traditional jobs just are not there anymore. Even after we â€œfully recoverâ€ to pre-recession unemployment levels there will still be millions of our generation chronically underemployed, working at jobs that donâ€™t utilize our knowledge, skills, and abilities acquired through college and graduate school. So what specific skill sets do liberal arts majors have to market? Well if I knew that then Iâ€™d be making money. The truth is that there is no clear path for any entrepreneur, thatâ€™s sort of the definition of being an entrepreneur but I will offer some key points. First, Millennials must support fellow Millennials. The website and movement Our Time, not to be confused with the dating website of the same name devoted to the complete opposite age demographic, has been pushing a Buy Young initiative for the past few years. The campaign aims to get young people to buy from businesses that are owned and operated by people under 30. Second, Millennials must change our mindsets from being consumers to content creators. Personally I didnâ€™t have this revelation until fairly recently and I kick myself in the butt whenever Iâ€™m not creating by reading this inspiringly candid article. I cannot say it enough, create content. Finally, on a related note, at many businesses and organizations content creation is currently supplementing traditional internships. I argue that in the near future the question businesses will ask wonâ€™t be how many internships one had but what sort of content did a young person create. The reason is that content and our brand is what will drive innovation and creativity at organizations. You know the old saying about Millennials being self-absorbed, well itâ€™s true, but weâ€™re only starting to realize how to market that. In a future article I will discuss Facebook and the road to attempting to monetize self-absorption. I believe it is marketable, weâ€™re all just trying to figure out how, and Millennials will be the ones to answer that question. So get out there and create something because your will to create is what will define the New New Liberalism. Agree, disagree? Are you an entrepreneur? Tell your story in the comment section below. Share this article with your social networks if you like it!

Lo que no he mencionado y e lo mas importante ( que esto fue lo que me echo paraÂ atrÃ¡sÂ para no empezar nada con el), IÃ±igo vive en Cantabria, sus padres estÃ¡n en Cantabria, aun que el ahora por motivos de trabajo esta en Madrid. Tomar un cafÃ© para descansar esos dÃ­as que estoy hasta arriba de trabajos yÂ exÃ¡menesÂ Y esos pequeÃ±os detalles IÃ±igo no losÂ entendÃ­aÂ No tenia la misma mentalidad que yo en ese sentido. IÃ±igo se fue a Madrid y yo me quede sin verle... Y ahora ya no creo que lo vea jamas. hace un par de dÃ­as me mando un watxap diciendome: " Zaida, sabes que siempre he sido sincero contigo, pero al decir verdad no creo que una relaciÃ³n a distancia entre tu y yo funcionaria, estoy conociendo a una chica deÂ aquÃ­Â de Madrid". En ese momento me quede...sin palabras la verdad. No sabÃ­a comoÂ tomÃ¡rmeloÂ si mandarle a la mierda, alegrarme por el, ponerme triste,... no sabÃ­a que hacer. Le dije que me alegrabaÂ mogollÃ³nÂ por el y me fui a comer. Estuve todo el dia pensando en el. Sabia que esa chica podrÃ­a haber sido yo hace un mes. Esa chica a la que ahora mismo esta abrazando y besando, esaÂ podrÃ­aÂ ser yo...pero ize caso a ese cachito de mi que me dijo que no fuera a donosti, y espero no arrepentirme jamas de eaÂ decisiÃ³nÂ Quiero mogollÃ³n a mi novio y el a mi tambiÃ©n, tenemos nuestros dÃ­as malos y nuestros dÃ­as buenos. Pero yo creo....yo creo que e tomado laÂ decisiÃ³nÂ acertada. No puedo estar con un chico que esta a 3 hora de distancia de mi. UnaÂ relaciÃ³nÂ duradera conmigoÂ asÃ­Â no... post.title: What do you think about Walmart?
post.summary:
In response to itsames.wordpress.comâ€˜s post titled: Why I BLEEP-ing hate Walmart: awkwardlist.com Walmart is a scary place, dudes. Iâ€™ve had my experiences there, but now I avoid it at all costs. For those of you who know me and have decided to pit stop there while driving somewhere, youâ€™ve encountered my resistance to go in there. At first I blamed the lights, the high ceilings, the smell, all the stuff, and the customer service.. and even though I still donâ€™t know what it is about that place that makes me feel super tired and angry, Iâ€™ve given up on trying to find out the reasons. Last week, my mother decided it would be a good idea to buy a new juicer that is exclusively available at Walmart. She convinced me to drive her to two Walmarts and search for the darn thing. No luck. So in order to avoid going into the stores, I decided to order it using their Site-to-Store system and I was to pick it up at a store near my home in one of their 893,123,143,121,214 and a half locations worldwide. I didnâ€™t put my name in the pick up order thing (so I could just say â€œOh sorry my name isnâ€™t on the pick up list thing.. oh no!â€). The next day I got an email saying my order was cancelled. So I called the store. Walmart 1: â€œHello balskdllkg lskdflskdf Walmart alsnf?â€ Me: Hi, I ordered something to pick up and it was cancelled, can you help me find it at another store? Walmart 1: One second. Me: Ok, no prâ€” beep. Walmart 2 (some other lady): Hello, how may I help you? Me: Hello, I ordered something online to pick up today, but it was cancelled. How can I find it? Walmart 2: Please hold. Me: But someone alreaâ€“ beep. Walmart 3: Site-to-Store, what do you need? Me: Iâ€™m wondering if you could help me find a Walmart that has an item that was cancelled by your store for pick up. Walmart 3: Have you tried other stores? Me: Other than Walmart? Walmart 3: Yes. Me: It is only available in Walmart. Walmart 3: One second please. Me: â€¦. Walmart 1: Hello, asdkvj walkdjs Walmart, asfvsdc? Me: Hello, how are you? Walmart 1: â€¦ Me: Hello? Walmart 1: Iâ€™m fine. Me: Great! Have a good day. So I decided to try calling a different Walmart, and I found the item in stock, ordered it and had it picked up by someone who came back with an interesting story himself. After talking to a manager and waiting in line twice, the juicer was picked up. A while back, I was in a friendâ€™s car when they decided to go to Walmart to pick up some stuff for a bonfire. Of course, I stayed in the car. Staying outside Walmart shouldnâ€™t be a problem, right? WRONG! Looking through my phone and finding songs on Spotify, I almost forgot I was in a Walmart parking lot. Out of the corner of my eye I suddenly see a guy struggling to pull something out of his pocket from my left side. He approaches a dark Honda parked right across my friendâ€™s car and pulls out a gun and shoots BBs all over the windows and makes a bunch of holes all over the car and then takes off running. What? About two minutes later, a younger Walmart employee comes out and inspects her car. Yeah, it was her car. We called the police, waited around, and then filed a report. Seriously, Walmart? Do you guys like that place?Â
Take Our Poll

post.title: How Facebook Could Give Its New Search the - Technology Review
post.summary: Facebook?s new Graph Search?a feature that lets you search through the data shared by your friends?clearly needs some work (see ?Facebook?s New Graph Search: Not Very Good?). It relies solely on the ?likes,? check-ins, and profile data provided by your friends ? signals that may be incomplete or unreliable unless you have friends all over the world who always faithfully check in wherever they go, and like products and brands honestly, not ironically. What?s more, queries must be structured in a way that often makes you feel like you?re talking to a database. Fortunately for Facebook, help is on its way. The social networking giant has two valuable data stores that it has yet to connect up to its prominent new search box (so large that it displaces the company?s logo). Accessing these data stores could change how people find information online?not to mention the fortunes of arch rival Google. First, Facebook could analyze the substance of user comments and other text people have added to the site, such as photo captions. That could help Facebook find many more recommendations not logged through check-ins or ?like? button clicks, and to sift out misleading likes. Second, Facebook?s search tool has yet to move outside the social network?s own borders (and into Google?s territory) by tapping into the Open Graph, a system developed by Facebook in 2010 as a way for it to understand the products, services, or other entities described on Web pages and in mobile apps. Open Graph allows Facebook to understand, for example, the artist, song, and album you are interacting with each time you click a song in a music service such as Spotify. That kind of knowledge could help Facebook search apply to more than just content from your friends. Both of these improvements were mentioned in a brief note at the end of last week?s launch, but the company has not said how soon they might arrive. But it is possible to predict what they might allow. A mostly overlooked upgrade made by Facebook?s partner Microsoft to its Bing search engine last week, which lets you search the text of friends? Facebook postings, provides a preview of how the first change might make Graph Search more useful. Enter ?Friends who like tequila? into Graph Search today and you?ll find only people who have joined groups dedicated to the drink. Connect your Facebook account to Bing and type ?tequila? into its new ?Friends? photos? search and you?ll find every photo that mentions tequila in a caption or a comment?so you?ll probably see a lot more images of people enjoying the beverage. Bing?s new ability to access the text of your friends? posts to Facebook is also on display in a sidebar on its main search page. When I searched for ?Virgin Atlantic,? it showed me comments mentioning that airline even when the airline wasn?t tagged explicitly. I could see that search?or one for any brand or product?being much more informative about what friends think or have experienced than anything Graph Search could show me. A small startup called Trove provides further evidence of the value of searching the full text of Facebook content (see ?A Better Way to Mine Your Facebook Past?). The company originally created a product similar to Graph Search, says cofounder and CEO Seth Blank, but after a poor response from trial users, it refocused on using clues found in comments and other text to answer more free-form queries. Trove has developed several tricks that underscore how much more useful inputted text can be than just like button clicks. For example, a search for ?puppy photos? might reveal an unlabeled Instagram photo of a dog because the photo elicited a tweet using the word ?dog? and a Facebook comment saying ?adorable!? More subtle signals like those might provide a better measure of which restaurants, products, and businesses friends really like?and why; far better than just ?likes,? says Blank. Trove is currently experimenting with a browser plug-in that displays its results when a person searches on shopping sites Amazon and Newegg. ?People buy stuff based on what they find friends like using Trove,? says Blank. Facebook is likely exploring how to encourage similar buying behavior around its own search, with a view to charging for ads that appear alongside search results. Facebook?s other untapped resource, the Open Graph, could also improve its power to recommend products?and hence offer new opportunities to position ads next to search results, as Google does. Folding it into Graph Search would also be a significant shift for Facebook, and it could change the way we use the Web. Open Graph is powerful because it?s as much a creation of other websites and apps as it is of Facebook itself. Companies contribute Open Graph metadata to describe the things?products, brands, movies, people, and more?on their pages or in their apps because they want attention from Facebook?s billion users. Those efforts enable Facebook to understand what exactly it is people are interacting with, or are interested in, providing a kind of index of the wider Web and world. The Open Graph is already big. Last year, entrepreneur Matthew Berk used five billion Web pages provided by the nonprofit Common Crawl (see ?A Free Database of the Entire Web?) to show that the Open Graph describes some 400 million objects (he also found that 22 percent of the Web?s pages link to Facebook in some way). Publishers would likely redouble their efforts to embrace the Open Graph if it were included in Facebook?s search, Berk predicts, making it an even more powerful index of what people care about online. ?People used to go out of their way to make it so that Google would find their content; now they look to Facebook,? he says. ?It?s like a redistribution of wealth.? Berk?s research into the Open Graph led him to found a startup called Lucky Oyster, a service due to launch this year where people can explicitly share and recommend products and content to Facebook friends. However, Berk predicts that Facebook will face challenges taming ?noise? that pollutes the Open Graph, because contributors don?t describe their content in a consistent way. It?s a problem that also troubles Graph Search, which has made it abundantly clear that on Facebook, ?like? doesn?t always mean you really like something. All the same, Facebook?s approach to organizing online information and making it searchable seems to make sense?as evidenced by Google?s enthusiastic efforts to build a social network (see ?The Man Building Google?s Social Network?) and a system that understands concepts mentioned on Web pages (see ?Google?s New Brain?). ?The big shift is to information being about things in the world and people, not just Web pages,? says Berk. ?At Google, you can see that social has become number one across the board.? Source: http://www.technologyreview.com/news/510041/how-facebook-could-give-its-new-search-the-edge/ monday night football SEC Championship Game 2012 kansas city chiefs Javon Belcher express kindle fire Jenny Johnson

post.title: Old Car Radio
post.summary: Iâ€™m only now starting to really utilize the feature Spotify initially used as itâ€™s major marketing point. PLAYLISTS! I remember all the annoying ads theyâ€™d send me about making playlists, but they actually are kind of useful. I have recently been contemplating the fact that, depending on which thoughts and emotions are salient, people can be vastly different people. This might sound like Iâ€™m making people out to be like nebulous, shifting blobs of personality, but I actually think itâ€™s more complex than that. I believe that when we experience a new environment, our psychologies form a specific response that puts us in the best situation possible in that environment while still utilizing your key psychological underpinnings. In this way, we become different versions of ourselves, but all of these versions are still classified under the same identity, that of the individual. The individual might be violent and belligerent in some environments, condescending in others, and caring and nurturing in others still. While this makes it difficult to establish an inherent value on a person, it does not make them identity-less, in my theory at least. I have recently been realizing how much this can be reflected in the music we choose to listen to, and when we choose to listen to certain songs. I recently hooked up with a friend of mine back home. Weirdly sheâ€™s a friend of Natalie (my ex/best friend) and we hadnâ€™t really talked since two winters ago, when she was suffering from crippling anxiety and depression, at times refusing to take her meds, at other times cutting herself. I had felt a very nurturing urge to protect and care for her that winter, and we hung out a lot, and did actually make out briefly when we first started hanging out, but then just became flirty friends (as we were both dating other people at the time). But this winter we were both single, though both of us are still very much friends with our respective exâ€™s. She stayed over at my place and we had a good time, though we didnâ€™t have sex, due to the source of her anxiety. The whole time we were hanging out, I pretty much wanted to play the trendiest music Iâ€™d found, especially since we hadnâ€™t seen each other in so long, and she had introduced me to many great artists the last winter weâ€™d hung out. But some of the music we really bonded over that first winter was the crappy cheesy music that would play on the radio and that we liked in middle school. We both had a live-hate relationship with these songs, and mostly it was fun to laugh over how much we liked them when we were younger, something we did again this winter using Spotify. In the context of bonding with overlapping experiences, this music was fun to listen to, and enjoyable. I didnâ€™t ever necessarily likeÂ the music my mom would play in the car whenever we were drivingâ€”which, being so far from town for most of my life, was a lotâ€”but being just about the only music I was exposed to other than Disney tunes, I didnâ€™t have much choice but to at least enjoy it while it was on. I would often even relate many of the lyrics to my life, so who knows what associations I was forming with those words and melodies. I have long sense condemned just about all of the music that used to play on those poppy, mainstream, family-friendly radio stations, the very fluff that suffocates creativity in music. But then something happened. My mom got rid of XM recently, and so a lot of this fluff was unavoidable. Luckily, I discovered that the radio was playing some pretty trendy stuff, along with, of course, the more repetitive, derivative phoniness that record companies churn out. But at a few points over break, while driving Natalie around, an oldie that I recognized from long ago car rides would come on, and Iâ€™d sing with it, kind of at her, for I knew sheâ€™d never heard these songs as a kid. No, her mom was true hippy, and had listened to and still listens to the likes of Kate Bush, Joni Mitchel, Tori Amos and the like, a platinum wall of alternative CDs blockading the radio. So I sang along with these songs almost tauntingly, but I began to realize that many of these songs not only represented a nostalgic, cherished time of my life, but they were actually rather strong musically and many had real depth and uniqueness. Think â€œLosing My Religionâ€ by R.E.M., â€œFast Car: by Tracey Chapman, â€œBreakfast at Tiffanyâ€™sâ€ by Deep Blue Something, â€œLandslideâ€ by Fleetwood Mac, â€œThe Logical Songâ€ by Supertramp and â€œSheâ€™s so Highâ€ by Tal Bachman. These might have seemed fluffy, over-relatable and poppy, but they were really just indicative of the times they were written in. Their melodic structure feels dated now, but I can imagine people my age hearing it for the first time when it first came out would have found it interesting and iconic. And many of these did turn out to be iconic in nature, which I think may sometimes be too quickly confused with cliche and phony. Old Car Radio I bring this up because itâ€™s a great part of that strange phenomenon of music fitting certain moods and states of mind. Iâ€™ve made a playlist for those songs, and Working Out/Washing the Dishes, one that I think would be great Trailer Music, and one called THC, which started out as a playlist to inspire the story I was working on â€œThe Hero Chroniclesâ€, but quickly became a music to smoke weed to for obvious reasons, and is now just pretty much all of my favorite music. It was really my first foray into playlists, but it lacked the kind of specificity of other states of minds, as it eventually just became another tier of quality in the eclectic mix I listen to. With these new playlists, Iâ€™m refining the different versions of myself, or at least distilling them to musical form. I think itâ€™s very important to remember all the kinds of people you can be, and all the kinds of people you have been.Â Identifying what we share is the best way to interact with people. Thereâ€™s no better social tool than the words â€œI know exactly what you mean.â€ And the more things you can say that truthfully to people about, the more you will connect, and the stronger those connections will be. It is a simple fact that as people age, they will have more and more overlapping experiences, and this is likely what is often referred to as â€œwisdom.â€ Itâ€™s a variety of experiences, and in turn, a variety of roles and performances, demanding different social skills, behaviors, and perhaps even philosophies. There is a very powerful drawing effect, a gravity, surrounding the people who have experienced the most, especially if they use those experiences to relate to people in positive ways, adding relevant anecdotes and exhibiting similar reactions to shared circumstances. I believe my recent job interviews went so well in part because of this. Not because I have a lot of experience, but because I made an effort to focus on the experiences I shared with people, and constantly trying to put myself in the other personâ€™s shoes, which is of course made easier with more experience. This also helps immensely in writing characters, since the ability to put yourself in othersâ€™ shoes is a requisite for writing good characters. One of the biggest uses of my playlists before my recent expansion was to get in the mood of movies Iâ€™m writing, with many songs representing specific charactersâ€™ arcs and attitudes. Itâ€™ll be interesting to see what kind of fruits the Old Car Radio playlists yields.

post.title: Passenger â€“ Let Her Go
post.summary: Listen to Passenger - Let Her Go (4,17 min) on spotify. Let Her Go can be found on the album Let Her Go which were released 2012, track nr: 1About PassengerThere are at least six artists and bands who have performed with the name "Passenger". The following order is loosely based on the last.fm statistics. 1. A Swedish alternative metal band including members of In Flames. 2. A Brighton (UK) based alternative folk band. 3. A San JosÃ©, Costa Rica hardcore/screamo band. 4. A Mesa, Arizona based acoustic rock band. 5. A rap artist from Texas. 6. An old alias of DJ TiÃ«sto. 7. A Chicago-based instrumental rock band. 8. A psytrance project of MFG's Guy Zukrel. ------------------------------ Passenger was formed in 1995 by Sten and Engelin. Both members wanted to do something that was not thrash metal or melodic death metal unlike the bands they played in. At its early stages the band was originally called "Cliff". Under the name Cliff they recorded two demos in Studio Fredman that were never released. After a break in the band and after Engelin was hired as a session guitarist for In Flames' Whoracle tour, Anders FridÃ©n, the vocalist of In Flames showed interest in Passenger and joined the band. In the year 2000 the band came back from its break and went on to record a demo. In 2001 the band recorded another demo in which early versions of the songs "Used", "In My Head", "Circus" and "Drowning City" were recorded. After a third demo the band finally recorded and released their debut album entitled Passenger. A video for "In Reverse" was also released. Sten noted in February 2004 on their official website that they were in the process of recording their second album. However, since then, FridÃ©n, lead vocalist of both Passenger and In Flames has been noted saying that he has very little time for the project, due to other commitments, and the group is currently on hold. In an interview with FridÃ©n he stated that as soon as he gets a break from In Flames, he wants to get all the group together to record a second album for early 2010. This did however not happen as Anders continued touring with In Flames until October 2010 when they entered their studio to record their next album. ------------------------------ The brainchild of 26-year-old Brighton born singer/songwriter Mike Rosenberg, Passenger is redefining the troubadour for the 21st century. Formerly a five-piece band, Passenger has now pared back to basics, quite literally bringing music to the streets on a series of lengthy busking journeys across Australia, America and the United Kingdom. A classic journeyman musician, cut from the same mould as Van Morrison, Neil Young and John Prine, Passenger has the unique ability to move from the humorous to heartbreaking with every song. After a year spent crisscrossing the UK and US with his debut album Wicked Man's Rest, Passenger's markedly stripped down and soulful second album Wide Eyes Blind Love was brought to the public as it was created: on the road. Setting up on street corners across the UK and Australia, Passenger halted passers by in their hundreds; all connecting to the mellifluous tones and powerfully hewn lyrics emanating from this lone figure and his guitar. This is music as Passenger means it to be, unvarnished and honest, just pure talent and powerful tunes that tap straight into the heart of the crowd. Struck by the dynamic freedom of the troubadour life, Passenger developed the grass roots method of Wide Eyes Blind Love into the germ of a new album. Impressively and entirely self funded through busking income, Passenger set about recording a series of collaborations with musical friends met along the way. Flight Of The Crow is the remarkable result of Passenger's intrepid journey, with Australian artists Lior, Josh Pyke, Katie Noonan, Boy & Bear, Kate Miller Heidke, Philadelphia Grand Jury, Brian Campeau and Elana Stone, Matt Corby, Jess Chalker and Dead Letter Chorus all lending their voices to this serendipitous creative venture. Flight Of The Crow was recorded in Sydney's famous BJB studios over February and March of 2010, and co-produced by Berkfinger (AKA Simon Berkleman from Philadelphia Grand Jury). As a second album born of the road, Flight Of The Crow speaks to the compelling quality of Passenger's music and the striking sincerity of his lyrics, both of which are matched by his dedication to this grass roots style of craftsmanship and collaboration. How utterly remarkable that a lone musician can travel the globe, and literally from the street, connect with some of Australia's finest musical talents to produce a self-funded album. This is the stuff of legend, with Passenger clearly evoking the humble, hardworking creativity of the troubadours of old. www.myspace.com/passengerofficial ------------------------------ Passenger or PSNGR is an active hardcore/screamo band formed in San JosÃ©, Costa Rica born in 2004. Their EP "Get OFF the Rails!" (tentative title) will be out in 20/01/09. Band members: Alejandro Pacheco[/bandmember] (vocals & guitar), Grego Rojas (guitar), Andres Moraga (bass), Jose Vargas (drums). www.myspace.com/passenger ------------------------------ Passenger the acoustic rock band was formed in late 2000. They have a large archive of both original music and cover songs. They released their first pressed album, entitled "Four Letter Word", in September 2004 on indie label Crop Circle Records. ------------------------------ Passenger is an Austin, Texas based MC. Born in Massachusetts, he spent most of his younger days growing up in New York and Houston, Tx eventually moving to Austin, Tx in 1996 attending college to try his hand as a sound engineer. During these years, his musical versatility had him playing bass in an alternative rock band, singing in another side project, DJing house, jungle and hip hop music at various venues in Austin. Eventually he became a full time DJ for the reggae/ska/hiphop/punk band, Indofin, which he was a member for years touring the country. His love for hip hop provoked him to purchase an MPC and has been making beats and rhyming ever since. "The Brick In A Glass House", his debut album, contains production from Nozebleed, Lazerbeak (Doomtree), amongst others as well as his own and has guests from Austin's own Emcee, Justin Cook, Weezel, as well as a few others. Currently, you can find him playing shows around the Austin area and will begin to venturing out to other Texas cities. He is also working on putting together a live band to back him at shows and working on new material. ------------------------------ Passenger is also an old alias of DJ TiÃ«sto. TiÃ«sto only produced 2 tracks under his old Passenger-alias: "Blackspin" and "F.A.H.", both appearing on a record released on Momentum Records in 1996. ------------------------------ Passenger began winter of 2002 when guitarist dustin covert and bassist/vocalist david mata collaborated on the bands first full length "alive" an 8 song full length about a disoriented and dark but intriguing view of love and romance. the album explored dissonant melodies and agonizingly slow chord progressions with the use of mark sampson on drums and sam billen on piano. in 2003 passenger progressed to a four person line up with michael oberlin on drums and james demis on keyboards and sound and began to play various rock venues in chicago, illinois and used silent film to accompany their live performance. numerous line-up changes took effect during the next year and a half, but in 2005 the concrete line-up of Dustin Covert and David D'Antonio on guitars, David Mata on Bass and Samuel Vincent on drums was achieved. In winter of 2005 Passenger recorded "The Owls are Restless", a 2 hour and 40 minute concept record about an ancient war between owls and rabbits and was recorded and engineered by Steve Whitney in a warehouse in Aurora, Illinois. Shortly after the recording drummer Samuel Vincent tragically passed away. Without his talent and with the grief of losing a dear, dear friend the band decided it was impossible to continue performing the material or anything that involved Passenger. These unfortunate events occurred before "The Owls are Restless" was able to achieve any sort of record label attention, and when it finally did it was too late. The remaining musicians have continued creating in their band White Devil, named after the vintage moog synth/organ that Sam would play in collaboration with his drums in Passenger. myspace.com/whitedevilchicago last.fm Pictures of PassengerShow more imagesMore: Passenger Norwegian Long Haul A/S Terms and Conditions for Boeing 787 First ...Music video with PassengerHere you can find videos from Youtube with Passenger - Let Her GoThe official video for new single 'Let Her Go' Directed and Produced by Dave Jansen. Amazing work Dave. www.theloop.com.au Taken from Top 10 album 'All The Little Lights' Available now from www.passengermusic.com. www.itunes.com/passenger itunes.apple.com (Netherlands) itunes.apple.com (UK) passenger.spinshop.com (UK) www.amazon.com/dp/B008B8AOQI/?tag=nettwerk-20 (US) www.amazon.ca/dp/B008B8AOQI/?tag=nettwerk-20 (Canada) www.amazon.de (Germany) "Let Her Go" [Lyrics] Well you only need the light when it's burning low Only miss the sun when it starts to snow Only know you love her when you let her go Only know you've been high when you're feeling low Only hate the road when you're missin' home Only know you love her when you let her go And you let her go Staring at the bottom of your glass Hoping one day you'll make a dream last But dreams come slow and they go so fast You see her when you close your eyes Maybe one day you'll understand why Everything you touch surely dies But you only need the light when it's burning low Only miss the sun when it starts to snow Only know you love her when you let her go Only know you've been high when you're feeling low Only hate the road when you're missin' home Only know you love her when you let her go Staring at the ceiling in the dark Same old empty feeling in your heart 'Cause love comes slow and it goes so fast Well you see her when you fall asleep But never to touch and never to keep 'Cause you loved her too much And you dived too ... post.title: bright eyes
post.summary: After the radio last night I am completely brain dead today. Iâ€™ve been intermittently doing homework (attempting homework) and staring off into spaceâ€¦ I decided music might help me focus, and the first song that played on the station I put on was this one^, The First Day of My Life by Bright Eyes. I fell in love with it immediately, and have already listened to it a few 1,000 times (haha not reallyâ€¦ >.>) Give it a listen, itâ€™s really nice and mellow for my poor mushy brain. If you liked the Juno sound track youâ€™ll love thisâ€“ itâ€™s super indie, acoustic guitary, sleepy guy singer, the works :] Iâ€™ll post about the radio soon!!! It went really well and was super duper fun [SW]

post.title: Simply Saving Saturday
post.summary: It's often hard to see the tangible savings from the simple things I do every day to save money and I sometimes find myself discouraged with my efforts. Writing down all those little things I do in order to live more frugally has helped me to see that all those little things actually can make a big difference! Here's how I was able to simply save this week: --Made chicken stock. --Made apple oatmeal muffins with apples that were getting too soft. --Received a free cat food sample. --Listened to music for free on Spotify. --Bought breadÂ at the bread store during their 5 for $5 sale. --Cut buttons off an old shirt of hubby's before throwing it away. --Downloaded a free ebook to my Kindle for PC. How were you able to simply save this week?

post.title: JSF #4: M.I.A - Maya - 2010
post.summary: ThÃ¨me du jour: Hangover Sound Avant d'en arriver Ã la gueule de bois, il faut bien qu'il y ait eu excÃ¨s. En clair, une bonne soirÃ©e passÃ©e en compagnie de Mr Jack D., Jim.B ou encore avec la vaporeuse Marie-Jeanne, cette verte Poison Ivy. Trop, trop vite, un verre, puis deux, un joint, musique trop forte, un autre verre puis encore un autre, black out, cuvette de chiotte, un joint, un verre, voiture, fossÃ©, black out, cuvette de chiotte et ainsi de suite. Si bien que leÂ lendemain on ne se souvient plus de grand chose, quelques flashs violents et Ã nouveau cette sempiternelle cuvette de chiotte. Soyons clair tout de suite, la musique je l'adore quand je fais la teuf' (ou la java pour les plus anciens, je connais vos Ã¢ges maintenant), et cet album est unÂ catalyseurÂ de Hangover en devenir. Du cyberpunk utra-jouissif, du rock taliban explosant tout sur sonÂ passage, attentat Ã laÂ bouteilleÂ piÃ©gÃ©e.Â TronÃ§onneuse,Â perceuse, electro-bruitiste, cette soirÃ©e sera une boucherie et "Steppin Up" ouvreÂ glorieusementÂ les hostilitÃ©s. M.I.A rÃ©ussit le tour de force d'amener des mÃ©lodies mainstream dans cette furia punk, parfois outrageusement dancefloor comme sur "Xxxo", mais toujours de maniÃ¨re ludique et insolente. Plus loin, "Born Free" sort Suicide et son "Ghost Rider" du CGBG pour lesÂ traÃ®nerÂ Ã toute blinde accrochÃ©s Ã la moto enflammÃ©e du Ghost Rider de Marvel. Le clip "anti-roux" rÃ©alisÃ© par Romain Gavras avait crÃ©Ã© la polÃ©mique; l'ensemble formait un tout indispensable, diablement moderne. "Born Free" est une bombe atomique sonore sans concessions. "Maya", un album toxique et violent, synthÃ©tique mais jamais artificiel, assurÃ©ment un grand disque. Et leÂ lendemainÂ de cuite dans tout Ã§a? PartagÃ© entre la vie et la mort, c'est le silence qui est de rigueur, dÃ©solÃ©. Lien SpotifyÂ Rejoignez lesÂ Chroniques de Toorsch' sur Facebook.

post.title: Sam & the Womp â€“ Bom Bom
post.summary: Listen to Sam And The Womp - Bom Bom - Radio Edit (2,9 min) on spotify. Bom Bom - Radio Edit can be found on the album Bom Bom which were released 2012, track nr: 1About Sam & the WompSam and the Womp are a British based eight piece music group who formed in 2009 and have created a unique alternative disco sound. Their music mixes traditional elements of Balkan music and Jamaican ska with modern electronic and dance elements. The band also have their own dance named, the "Womp", which is fairly idiosyncratic and uninhibited. Their music has been largely popularised by BBC Radio 1 with a heavy promotion of their single "Bom Bom". They released their debut single "Bom Bom" on iTunes on 19 August 2012 and the single went to the number one spot in the UK midweek charts and are firmly positioned for a first week number one. As of 2012 they are signed to Stiff Records, a record label rooted in the modern indie scene. The band's first single "Bom Bom" was released in August 2012 and features a euphoric and light hearted sound which seems to have universal appeal. The lead singer on the track is Bloem de Ligny who is also a solo artist. Other members of the band to feature on the track include band creator Sam Ritchie, who plays trumpet on the track and Aaron Horn who features as DJ and producer. last.fm More: Sam & the Womp Li tvingas skilja sig fÃ¶r att fÃ¥ byta kÃ¶n Music video with Sam & the WompHere you can find videos from Youtube with Sam & the Womp - Bom BomWatch the official video for Bom Bom by Sam and the Womp. post.title: Recollection: The Best of Concrete Blonde
post.summary: A few folks reading this might remember a band by that name and if not they might more easily recall the one single they were successful with on the pop charts, namely a song called Joey in the early nineties. There was much more to Concrete Blonde than that however. If you were around in the late eighties in Maine and were a rock fan it seems likely you listened at times to WBLM. This radio station which I still admit to tuning in on my trips to southern Maine, I could listen online anytime I want but forget to, dominated a segment of the market at that time. WBLM loved Concrete Blonde. Many of the songs that you will find on this Best of Collection were songs we all heard on WBLM long before this band ever broke nationally. From True, Still in Hollywood, Dance Along the Edge, God is A Bullet, Tomorrow Wendy, to Ghost of a Texas Ladies Man this band was making great, original, music all through the late eighties. For those who are going down this memory lane with me I wonder how many remember how often the band played at Raoul's Roadside Attraction on Forest Avenue. I remember seeing them a couple of times and I think that I missed them a few times. This was a band, loved and promoted by a radio station in a small market that created a hotspot of fans for them long before and long after their national success. Hearing Joey on the satellite today made all these memories come flooding back and I listened to this collection on Spotify. One could find much worse way to spend an hour than by spending this hour down memory lane.
post.blogName: What Johnny's Reading, Listening and Watching Today

post.title: Musique et Moi - Passenger
post.summary: Vandaag weer een Musique et Moi. Daar heb ik namelijk even zin in. Ik ben op het moment ongelofelijk veel bezig met school, omdat het eind van het kwartaal nadert (lees: nu is afgelopen) en zo ook de proefwerkweek. Op dit soort momenten is een muziekje erbij altijd fijn. En omdat ik Passenger gewoon een ontzettend toffe zanger vind, is hij het onderwerp van deze Musique et Moi. Ja. Zoals iedereen ken ik Passenger van het nummer Let her go. Maar toen ik even zijn hele album ging luisteren via Spotify kwamen er op mysterieuze wijze steeds meer van zijn nummers op mijn afspeellijst terecht en nu staat ongeveer het hele album erop. Wat vinden jullie van Passenger? En welke muziek luisteren jullie op het moment? Lots of Love, Jasmijn
post.blogName: Just a way to become Happy

post.title: It's OK UK
post.summary: It's OK UKWatching the news and checking my Twitter feed is getting gloomy.Â Even amongst Paris Fashion Week and Michelle O's inauguration dress choice, there is no escape down time from the news that keeps on growing inÂ disappointmentÂ and effect.Â This trend that is changing our culture, economy, high street face, is about the domino closures, Â the big names that are following to the dreaded tune of the Pied Piper's administration. In the space of just Â days I hear three big names going through the sad process including Jessops, HMV and Blockbusters - all have gone into administration. Jessops was not a huge shock, it's the results of ourÂ obsession, love and second nature behaviour of sharing, storing and viewing our photos online that has changed our attitude to the way we take that image in the first place.Â How many smart phone giants advertise the camera and sharingÂ functionalityÂ as core feature? As soon as I got my iPhone 4S, I gave my much loved but no longer needed Canon digital to charity (yes I got that from you Jessops). I knew really honestly, that I would never buy a digital camera ever again. I hadÂ separatedÂ myself into that category of an individual who loves capturing imagery and being able to share as easy as a swipe, from the actual photographer who would own a whizz bang beast of SLR type. It was a pivotal moment of being able to do more, with less. Just how this instant gratification society expects.Â I did wonder about the buyers market ofÂ professionalÂ cameras and equipment - surely that was an obvious gateway for Jessops e-commerce? But then how many online companies were doing this a few moons ago? Too late to play in that game. HMV sparkedÂ a lotÂ of debate on Facebook, it seemed that many people had some personal brand association with them whether it be that they brought their first album in store or the fact that it was a great place to hang out on a Sunday trawling through music and DVDs with like minded folk. It's sad to see the last high street music baron close it's doors. This sparked off a conversation at my agency about how we actually buy music. Do you still buy music?iTunes, Spotify and more, look no further it's all there and even better it feeds your smart phone or tiny gorgeousÂ aluminiumÂ device, plus it's smarter than that CD that stored 13 tracks. It seemed only natural that the business of buying music was changing it's financial landscape with very visible Â movements that I'm surprised HMV hadn't reinvented themselves to some degree. The rebranding was not the most crucial change I feel that it was crying out for. More the experience had to change, adapt and reflect the forward evolving consumer market and look to be at the forefront of technology where possible and therefore deliver something truly meaningful. I'm wondering what this all means and shudder at the thought of the British high street changing so much due to the Pied Piper's song that we might end up withÂ increasinglyÂ empty retail units and a feeling of abandoned hope in once prosperous towns. Is this changing the way we shop? But I have to say it can't be all that bad, I only have to think about Burberry on Regent Street and that is an excellent example of how shopping, buying, consumer behaviour has been integrated into the physical store it's self and purged out through digital mediums. The space within feels just like the crafted elegance of the Burberry brand offering, but its more of a marriage between store and Burberry.com. Â You won't lose out. The interactive mirrors transform into personalised screens, this means if you bring an item close by the screen transforms into a runway showcasing that product or may give a 360 degree overview. Global events are screened live on a mammoth of a digital screen, it's very much the feature of the store , notÂ necessarilyÂ a physical item of clothing itself. I was invited to watch new band talent play a gig as an exclusive ... but they weren't actually there if you see what they're doing ; ) The store can break into audio visual choreography at any time and suddenly your amid gushing rainfall ( trench anyone?) and they have intuitively created a space where shopping, culture and our digital needs are coming together, ready to playÂ together. Even if this feels too much or shoppers may not yet be fully ready for the whole experience? The remarkable factor is the adaptation and innovative moves the brand has made and the focus on key touch Â points of what online buyers love about shopping - bringing them together in the place where it all started. A shop. So I have a feeling that a future retail trend will see more of our high street favourites opting to include digital and social into the fibre of store experience. Changing how we shop, but still keeping stores open so the essence of 'shopping' is still exactly that.

post.title: MUSIC
post.summary: So, if you're following me on any other website, you've probably seen me ranting about these already. A friend told me a while ago to check out Haim after she saw Florence and the Machine, but I forgot all about it, then suddenly remembered it the other day when on youtube - and instantly fell in love. This came up on their youtube channel, so I checked out the whole album on spotify - and fell in love all over again! This album is just the best thing ever, and I have been listening to it all day, driving everyone mad with it. These are my 3 favourite tracks that I could find on youtube basically, but there are more that are really fab!

post.title: Unexpected Running Songs #11-15
post.summary: Itâ€™s been another week and by now you may getting a little tired of the first 10 unexpected running songs. Lucky for you itâ€™s time for another batch, and these 5 should keep you entertained for quite a while. At least until next weekend, of course. Hereâ€™s what we got: 1. Iâ€™ve Been Everywhere by Johnny Cash (3:11) I have to have an oldie on the list and I donâ€™t know if you can find a better â€˜oldieâ€™ than Johnny Cash. This randomly came on today and I had a blast running to it. There are probably quite a few other hidden gems for running from Mr. Cash. 2. Reboot the Mission by The Wallflowers (3:32) This is one of my favorite songs right now and I go crazy when it comes on the radio. That normally translates to the trail pretty well. I think everyone should give this a chance, regardless of your current opinion of The Wallflowers. 3. What? by Rob Zombie (2:46) Donâ€™t judge me too hard with this one. Itâ€™s Rob Zombie. Itâ€™sÂ inappropriate.Â Itâ€™s about dead people and what not, but itâ€™s about as metal/rock as you can get, and a power song like no power song before. I actually discovered this song a few months ago by Shazaming it from a sidewalk next to a guy in a Jeep that wasÂ blasting it, and itâ€™s been one of my favorites since. Just donâ€™t look too deep into the lyrics, of course. 4. Brimful of Asha, Norman Cook Mix by Cornershop (3:57) Fun song that randomly played the first day I got Spotify, and it may be why I still use it today. I have never heard this one until then and itâ€™s a song that you think you should have heard before. The Norman Cook mix is icing on the cake. 5. Tick Tick Boom by The Hives (3:26) In the past I have said my iPod plays quite a bit of country, but as you can tell, this week it was in a rock out kinda mood. I didnâ€™t complain one bit. If you havenâ€™t heard this one, you should. If you donâ€™t like it for running, youâ€™ll find some other times to play it. Great pump-up song. So there you have it! If you put all of 5 of these on in a row I wouldnâ€™t be surprised if you see a new mile time PR. I was pretty excited to share this weeks list with you all. Next weekend there will be 5 fresh songs, and if you have theÂ perfect one for the list, please let me know! Just comment below and let me know whatâ€™s your go-to power songs. Happy running!

post.title: Deutsche nutzen Facebook in Europa am wenigsten!
post.summary:
Deutsche verbringen die geringste Zeit in Facebook Wer hÃ¤tte das gedacht, das soziale Netzwerk ist auch in Deutschland sehr angesagt â€“ jedoch liegt Deutschland sehr weit hinten, was die tÃ¤gliche Nutzung des Dienstes betrifft! Zusammen mit Frankreich bildet Deutschland das Schlusslicht mit 2,3 Stunden tÃ¤gliche Nutzung! Danach folgt England mit 2,4 Stunden Facebook pro Tag!! Wer das nun fÃ¼r viel hÃ¤lt der hat die Nutzung von tÃ¼rkischen Nutzern noch nicht gesehen, welche mit 4,9 Stunden an der Spitze liegen! Doch dies ist noch nicht die Spitze des Eisberges, wenn eine weltweite Auswertung fÃ¤hrt! Denn die Bewohner von Indonesien und Saudi-Arabien erreichen hier einen durchschnittlichen Spitzenwert von 5,1 Stunden pro Tag! post.title: Franklin Vanderbilt Sings Unplugged for Sandy Hook + Great INFO on this artist!!
post.summary:
~IB~ continuing our 3 part series on Franklin Vanderbilt, bringing you right up to speed with the latest from this surprisingly multi-talented man! Â Just listen to the above beautiful performance of, â€˜Everybodyâ€™s Talking About Love,â€™ a song written by Franklin, dedicated to all those affected by the recent Sandy Hook tragedy. It is reflective of Franklinâ€™s belief in the power of love. When asked for a quote to go with the song, Franklin said, â€™LOVE IN THIS WORLD STILL EXIST.â€™ That is the truth. Whatever bad happens in the world we need to understand that love is ultimately the strongest force possible and will shine through.
Back to basics!
We have already checked out Franklinâ€™s larger than life personality, worthy of any superstar!! So, letâ€™s just observe a few facts relating to his musical roots so we can put all you new fans in the picture!
Franklin is a naturally gifted drummer, initially from the West side of Chicago, who was born into a musical family. Aged 5, Franklin was given a seriously good drumkit, a Ludwig, and went on to endorse his familyâ€™s belief in him by ultimately appearing on stage with world renowned artists such as legendary funk singer Chaka Khan- who whisked him off to drume in LA for two and a half years, Stanley Clarke- known for his brand of jazz fusion and guitarist/singer/songwriter Richie Kotzen.
Prior to this, I believe Franklinâ€™s personality must have shone alongside his talent, enabling him to receive tuition from many well known jazz and blues artists during his teenage years... check website link below for full details. Having played his part in both school and church musical events and having clearly thrived off the influence of his Uncle Robert Vanderbilt, Franklin grew up with a serious, dedicated approach to music which combined with his tremendous energy formed the foundation of his career. Franklin's efforts caught Greg Parkerâ€™s attention, (look him up!) a blessings as Greg helped young Franklin venture into new genres which included rock. This proved extremely beneficial enabling Franklin to play with one of the worldâ€™s greatest musicians, Stevie Wonder in 2005 and his great talent was soon spotted by Rock star Lenny Kravitz, whom he has supported since 2007- present.
Back in 2008 I remember Franklin telling me that he wrote his own songs and he has also learnt to play the guitar. These talents are now being put to good use as Franklin recently recorded 2 singles which are available on iTunes, Spotify, Amazon and Deezer. Â You have already heard the unplugged version of, â€˜Everybodyâ€™s Talking About Love,â€™- check out the full instrumental version... and his other song, â€˜ALIVE,â€™-WOW, Franklin just totally rocks it!!
Â â€˜This crazy place they call my brain.....Â I think Iâ€™m gonna go insane,â€™
we can all identify with these strong lyrics however, as I said to Franklin, if sanity ultimately rules.. weâ€™re OK!
Final thought, looking forward to our interview with Franklin!!! And equally to his first album, based on the promise which has been successfully delivered in Franklinâ€™s debut singles.Â
Big up to Royalprince!
Franklinâ€™s website: http://www.franklin-vanderbilt.com/index.php?id=45
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/franklinvanderbilt.tallguydrummer
Jaz McKenzie

post.title: BBC Radio 1 too many
post.summary: First of all, thanks for all the positive things being said about the blog. Â I didn't think anyone would actually take time to read through any of the posts so thanks for being here! Tonight, I'd like to talk about something that bugs me most mornings on the way into uni (when my flatmate isn't playing her McFly nonsense that is). Â That bug, is BBC Radio 1. I'll start on a positive note shall I? Â Radio 1 are on a constant look-out for up-and-coming bands. Â Last year, they unearthed acts such as Little Comets (who played the introducing stage at Leeds fest), Seasfire and Hey Sholay. Â It's a personal aim of mine to actually make a band one day and the 'introducing' scheme seems to be a good start. Â They offer loads of little tips online and you can upload onto their website - so well done radio 1, top job! But I want to talk about the other side of radio 1; the side that seems to play whatever music it bloody well wants. Â Well, its a radio station, I hear you say. Â They can do that, right? Well I was sat there the other day, when Walk came on, the super awesome track from Foo Fighters. Yeah, I said 'super awesome' what you gonna do about it?Â Radio 1 tend to play this song religiously, forgetting that the band actually have countless other hits that listeners would equally enjoy. Â Nevertheless, it still got me tapping my toes and smashing out my air guitar, making me look like a right d*ckhead at the lights. Â But thats just me, if a song is worth singing to, why not at the traffic lights? Anyway, next on the radio was my all time 'I want to punch that person' chart topper. Â To me, the anti-Christ. Â the bane of my life. Â The ultimate douchebag of music. Â The one, the only. Â Nicki Minaj, with, what I can only describe as an abomination- I was too busy moaning about it to realise what was playing. (Note: I haven't put her name in Italics... Â She doesn't deserve them, she's not an artist). Anyway, that finally ended after what seemed an eternity. Â Then after some chatting from presenter, Nick Grimshaw, he played some sh*tty track that just said the word 'Clique' about 500 times in a row. Â That was it for me, I went for the power button on the radio, before my flatmate slapped me and put it back on. Â Harsh times... Anyway, my point is people, why do radio 1 play such a variety of music in one show? Â They have designated hours when everyone is either out in town or in bed. Â The rock show, the surgery (where people ring up and tell everyone listening (in complete confidence of course) how depressed they are and ask how to deal with it). Â Hell, radio 1 even set up a completely new station (radio 1 xtra) for all those who like to listen to music while they go round looking for people to mug and houses to rob. Â Yeah, I said it. Â They even bloody invade radio 1 of a Saturday night! So they have these designated hours where a particular genre is played, but every other time they try to play a variety. Â Who in their right mind does this: Oooo yay, Foo fighters! Â I like to rock out to something that really gets the blood going, you know? Oooo yay Nicki Minaj! Â I like to listen to music that repeats itself and sounds like the last track released, you know? Oooo yay! Â Some random black music! Â I like to, well just listen to sh*t, init? Who? Â Nobody. Now, if you want to listen to Nicki Minaj, thats fine by me; i'll just stand about 5 miles away while you do. Â That's not what this is about. Â What my point is, is that it is hard to listen to radio 1 and enjoy a string of songs that are played consecutively. Â I wouldn't mind if radio 1 decided to play chart music, because, to be fair to Miss Minaj, some people actually like her, and yes she's in the charts. Â So go ahead and play her. Â But why try to play stuff that isn't in the charts with it? Â I just dont get it. It seems to me radio are trying to be that kid on the yard who tries to be a jack-of-all-trades; the one who wil try to blend in with every crowd in the class. Â The one who is always there, but never around. Â In some ways, they have succeeded in this- constantly gaining a lot of listeners. Â But its not all that simple. Â There was a big overhaul in radio 1 a couple of years ago, with 'older' DJ's being replaced with newer 'younger' DJ's. Â Those high figures are on the slide once again. And it's no wonder! Â How can you keep the masses happy by trying to play everything? Look at XFM. Â They play rock music. Â Simple. Â They have a steady following and dedicate themselves to (in my opinion) quality music. Â Classic FM. Â Are they going to play Beethoven's 3rd, followed by 'smack my bitch up'? Â Probably not. It seems to me Radio 1 try too hard to be 'cool'. Â They have a philosophy where they try to appeal to every young person out there, and that is just impossible. Â So why try? Â Why not identify the most popular genre and stick to that? Â I just don't understand it! Anyway, I'll carry on making my spotify playlists and listen to the stuff I want to. And from now on I'll be taking my earphones around with me at all times, just in case that horrible anti-Christ springs up on me. Â Evil doer! Thanks for reading! Adios Rob

The apps customarily lay in some asleep state when youâ€™re not in them, solely for apps that need to run in a background, like Pandora or Spotify, though infrequently apps can spin strict and donâ€™t act properly. Youâ€™ll notice this kind of function when we go into an app and it crashes often, or freezes. Sometimes murdering it during a wharf or tray solves a problem. To do this, double daub your home symbol to move adult a tray, press and reason any of a app icons, and theyâ€™ll start jiggling with small red buttons on a upper-left corners. Press those red buttons to kill a apps. Maybe nothing of a apps are spiteful your battery, a unequivocally expected case. But if weâ€™re articulate impassioned iPhone 5 battery life here, kill them all and kill them often. Iâ€™ve mastered this technique of fast drumming a mark where we can kill a initial app, and as a other apps come shifting in, theyâ€™re killed, too. we consider we can kill about 15 active/inactive processes in about 3 seconds now. Woot! 6. Stop regulating your phone! Youâ€™re substantially meditative what a reticent tip this is, right? Well, good, youâ€™ve come to a right article. After all, this is extreme, and infrequently there is customarily no surrogate for saving battery life than to not use it during all. Itâ€™s like saving gasâ€“did we unequivocally need to expostulate 4 blocks customarily to collect adult that fritter of bread? Or could we have walked, doing both your health and mom inlet a favor? If we wonâ€™t have entrance to a energy source for a while, maybe youâ€™re a helper operative a 16 hour change or a alloy about to perform a 10-hour medicine (you unequivocally shouldnâ€™t be checking your Facebook then), refrain from regulating your device when we can. Getting a day and a half to dual days of iPhone 5 battery lifeâ€“sounds crazy, though it unequivocally does happenâ€“is a ethereal change of being unequivocally impassioned and not regulating your phone when we donâ€™t have to. The misfortune box unfolding is that we buy an outmost battery pack. Unfortunately, there arenâ€™t unequivocally many charging cases, like a Mophie Juice Pack Plus for iPhone 4S, for a iPhone 5. post.title: Things I Loved / Hated This Week #16
post.summary:
LOVE: Vegetarian:
I wrote extensively about this in my film blog this week, so I wonâ€™t rapturously go on and on, but I love everything about being a vegetarian. There is such a simple joy in knowing that nothing youâ€™re eating had to die for you to do it. Instead, I have an entire world of new and exciting things to try. I used to think fruits and vegetables were unpalatable, but now, I find them full of flavor and thrilling. I eat grapefruit regularly as a dessert! Itâ€™s madness, (Itâ€™s carpet madness! Holla at the Ab FabÂ reference!)Â but itâ€™s wonderful. I know that many people might think that itâ€™s a restrictive diet, but that turns out not to be the case, I still eat way too much! When I decided to do this years ago, I thought it would be difficult and that Iâ€™d never be able to eat the things I used to love, like boeuf bourguignon ever again. I was wrong. You can make it much more simply with mushrooms and itâ€™s even more delicious than it is with chunked up cows!
I received Martha Stewartâ€™s latest cookbook, Meatless, in the post this week and I cannot wait to try out all the recipes. Give Meatless Monday a try, or just go vegetarian. I can go to almost any restaurant and find something to eat, itâ€™s not a difficult thing to do at all. Macarons in Convection Oven:
Ever since the first time I went to IKEA, I have been obsessed by this gigantic oven they used to sell. I donâ€™t think they do anymore, which is a shame. It was about $2000 and I lusted over it. I thought it would be the best thing to ever happen to me with its extra large oven, sleek stainless steel, and gorgeous gas cooktop. On one visit, I saw it in the discount section. Somebody had bought one and discovered a dent in it. Allegedly, that was the only issue, so I bought it for half price. I felt so clever. My father and I went up to pick it up and stopped for some delicious Indian food on the way home. Then, the oven sat for some time in my kitchen. I didnâ€™t know how to set it up, so a professional had to come out. It only kind of worked. I was pissed. The gas worked beautifully, but the oven, the part that I was most excited for, did not. Two Whirpool specialists came out several times and finally got it running. A wire had been loose. A single little wire! Now it works well. I havenâ€™t done as much baking as I expected to, so on Tuesday, I was excited to host Lollipopalooza, where Alison and I did a bunch of baking. We made challah bread and orange lollipops and grapefruit macarons. I am so ecstatic with the way the convection feature of the oven cooked the macarons. They puffed up beautifully, arenâ€™t brown at all, and are magnificently delicate. My old oven made them rather crispy and they took a few days to mature. Not in the convection oven. I think Iâ€™ll make my macarons exclusively on convection now. Simple things like that thrill me. Making Cocktails:
Pretty drinks are fun. Drinking them is fun. Putting them together is fun. Drinks! I bought a bottle of Campari last week to make a batch of grapefruit macarons and have been experimenting with it ever since. Iâ€™ve created a concoction that I call a Nicky on the Rock. (Nicky is the name Iâ€™d rather have and on the rock because I pour it over a single ice cube into an antique champagne glass.) In a cocktail shaker, I mix: blood orange syrup, lime juice, orange juice, and top it with Campari. Shake until the shaker frosts, pour out, and enjoy. Also, the word cocktail is hilarious for reasons any immature person will understand. Push Button Switches:
Iâ€™m immediately delighted whenever I see a home with push button switchesâ€“even if itâ€™s only in a magazine or on television. I donâ€™t think there is a more elegant piece of electric hardware in existence. I donâ€™t understand why we have moved to switches. Switches are plain and uninteresting and very demode. Push button switches are the very soul of fashion. Someday, the lighting in whatever home or apartment or cottage I end up calling my own will be exclusively controlled by the charming click of a pearly push button. Iâ€™ve never seen them for sale in stores, but you can easily find them on the Internet. Bless the Internet. New iTunes Color Schemes on Albums:
I donâ€™t know why it took me so long to notice this, but now that I have, Iâ€™m delighted. Iâ€™m really loving the latest release of iTunes, even though I donâ€™t use it nearly as much as I used to since I am using Spotify a lot now. Great service that I highly recommend. It can be annoying when you canâ€™t find the music you want, but you can discover a lot of new music that you never knew youâ€™d like. Anyway, the new iTunes is absolutely gorgeous and the way you browse your music is really very nice. All your albums are arranged by artist and then album title. When you click on one, the album expands into an attractive little window that lists the tracks and shows the artwork. A delightful thing it does, though, is the window takes on the color scheme of the album. So, if there is a lot of blue in the image, the background will be blue. Itâ€™s little touches like those that make me adore Apple more and more. HATE: â€œBucolicâ€:
I am so very tired of hearing this word. It seems to be in every single blog and magazine. People who become farmers love talking about living â€œthe bucolic lifeâ€ and rapture on endlessly about the delight of fresh eggs and greens. Shut up! There is nothing so fabulous about rummaging around in the dirt and picking up crap covered eggs. I am not knocking people who lead this lifestyle, not at all, but I hate the way that itâ€™s idealized with fancy vocabulary. I do enjoy gardening and fresh duck eggs, but itâ€™s not that great. Your fingernails get dirt under them and it never comes out, bugs eat your arugula, the ducks are filthy and relieve themselves everywhere, the days are long and youâ€™re always dirty and youâ€™ll probably die of skin cancer in the long run. So, farm all you want if you like it, I like to garden, but stop saying bucolic and stop trying to convince me that wild animals are singing and dancing around while you savor a fresh egg. Iâ€™m not buying it. Boxer Briefs:
I am very particular when it comes to underwear. Iâ€™ve never liked boxersâ€“what are they supposed to do exactly? Why wear them if everything is still going to swing about? Iâ€™ve always preferred briefs and jockstrapsâ€“they hold everything together quite nicely. My favorite brand by far is Andrew Christianâ€“fashionable, fun, and exceedingly comfortable. A few months ago they had a grab bag sale, so, of course I bought one. Inside was a mesh tshirt, (where am I going to wear that?) briefs and the lovely pair of boxer briefs you can see above. I sighed at themâ€“I donâ€™t ever wear them. So, theyâ€™ve been sitting on a shelf for a while until I finally put them on a few days ago. Did I like it at first? No. My thighs, which are not large by any means, felt like they were being cut off from my circulation. But, they stretched a bit during the day, so it wasnâ€™t dreadful. In fact, the leg rolled up a bit which made me wonder what the point is. Why not have the freedom of movement that briefs and underwear like them offer? But, later on, as I was getting undressed that day, I took a look at my posterior. Then I looked again. Then I stopped, moved to a larger mirror and studied what I saw. Somehow, and only the sweet baby Buddha knows how, those underwear gave me an ass. I donâ€™t have one. Yet, there it was, looking back at me alluringly. It was very dramatic, you must understand. I have been doing a new exercise regime that includes a lot of squats, but I havenâ€™t been doing it long enough to see results like that. If Iâ€™m ever going to walk around in my underwear in front of a crowd, those will be the pair I pick, if not in my everyday wear. I took a picture, and debated posting it. I thought no, then I said, whatever. Here you go.
Kidz Bop: I was browsing through the latest releases on Spotify last night to find some new music to fill the sadness in my life until BeyoncÃ© or Gaga or Britney releases some new music. I thought Justin Timberlake would help, but that new song of his is dumb. Itâ€™s starting to grow on me, but not fully. How do you dance to that? Letâ€™s try, shall we?
Â Did you figure it out? I didnâ€™t. Anyway, as I was scrolling, I came across Kidz Bop, listened to a track to laugh, and found myself getting pissed off. First off: Kidz. Really? We already have low literacy levels and youâ€™re going to misspell a simple word on an album for children? Second: what is with the singing? It sucks! Third: why does this exist at all? Children donâ€™t want to hear their peers slaughtering Rihannaâ€™s annoying â€œDiamonds,â€ they want to hear Rihanna. Avoid these albums. Pedestrian White Chocolate:
I have never ever liked white chocolate. I much prefer dark chocolate. Turns out, Iâ€™ve just never had a good white chocolate. Iâ€™ve always used Ghirardelli in my baking and thought that is the way it was supposed to taste. What a shock to discover that I was wrong. I hate that. During the holidays, Whole Foods was selling big chunks of Callebaut white chocolate and I picked some up out of curiosity. Alison and I used it for the grapefruit macarons and I was astounded by the flavor. It doesnâ€™t taste cloyingly sweetâ€“itâ€™s every bit as rich and delicious as dark chocolate with a hint of smokiness. That is an elegant chocolate and I shall never go back to common grocery store varieties. I hope Whole Foods will carry it throughout the year and if not, I hope they will special order it for me. Itâ€™s really a revelation to me. New Google Image Search: I rely on Googleâ€™s image search for the images that go on many of my blog posts, so I am very frustrated by the convoluted new system that they are using. Itâ€™ll grow with me in time, perhaps, but I doubt it. I donâ€™t like all the clicking and the pictures donâ€™t get bigger and when you click on the results you go to the actual page that hosts the picture. No me gusto.
