post.title: Premios (Personales) a la Mejor MÃºsica de 2012
post.summary: Ya estoy de vuelta con una de mis listas de canciones y la excusa de esta lista en concreto es el haber acabado ya el aÃ±o 2012 y poder poner lo mejor, en mi opiniÃ³n, de dicho aÃ±o. Aclaro que no serÃ¡n canciones o grupos solo de 2012, si no que YO haya descubierto ese aÃ±o, ya sea el mismo Elvis Presley (estÃ¡ incluÃ­do en la lista, sep) o un grupo nacido el mismo 31 de Diciembre de 2012. No voy a poner toda la lista entera, solo pondrÃ© los mÃ¡s destacado pero, al final de todo, habrÃ¡ un enlace a la lista de Spotify por si alguno quiere pasarse. Y sin mÃ¡s dilataciÃ³n, vamos al tema: Voy a empezar con un trÃ­o de canciones de un estilo similar entre ellos, algo de post-hardcore, otro algo de metalcorecillo sin llegar a serlo... Mezcla, mezcla. Los grupos en cuestiÃ³n son Issues, Fei Comodo y Write This Down, todos ellos con una canciÃ³n "nominada" del aÃ±o 2012: King Of Amarillo - Issues The Air Is Cold Tonight - Fei Comodo Red 7 - Write This Down Siendo Fei Comodo el grupo que antes conocÃ­ de los tres e Issues el Ãºltimo, los tres tienen un algo que les hace especiales por decirlo asÃ­. Fei Comodo, sobre todo en esta canciÃ³n, tiene una estructura alejada de la tÃ­pica de una canciÃ³n, asÃ­ como una baterÃ­a que podrÃ­a comparar con las de Protest The Hero (tambiÃ©n por otras canciÃ³nes del disco de Fei Comodo). Write This Down son un grupo que escuchÃ© por casualidad, solo por la portada y que este verano sacaron nuevo Ã¡lbum, el cual escuchÃ©, por supuesto, y de ahÃ­ cayÃ³ esa canciÃ³n en la lista. El disco entero es muy bien, podrÃ­a poner cualquier tema, pero esa se asemeja un poco mÃ¡s al estilo de los otros dos grupos. Issues resultan ser otro "descubierto-por-casualidad" en mi lista de mÃºsica, que acabaron por gustarme mucho y resaltar de entre todo el post-hardcore que tengo y que acaba por aburrirme (por escuchar demasiado junto, no porque sea una basura). La siguiente "categorÃ­a" es la de "Solo de 2012" que, como su nombre indica, es solamente para canciones que hayan salido ese mismo aÃ±o, aunque de dispares gÃ©neros musicales. King For A Day - Pierce The Veil feat Kellin Quinn Mulholland Drive - The Gaslight Anthem Do It Anyways - Ben Folds Five Friends Don't Do Like That - The Rasmus Gone Sovereing - Stone Sour Panic Station - Muse Para empezar, King For A Day me pareciÃ³ una de las canciones mÃ¡s entretenidas que hay para tocar brutamente la baterÃ­a porque tiene el suficiente equilibrio entre la velocidad de la canciÃ³n y lo que tocas con la baterÃ­a, no hay partes que te den un bajÃ³n (si no es para tener un subidÃ³n despuÃ©s), y todo muy bien enlazado. Si no sabes tocar la baterÃ­a, tambiÃ©n te gustarÃ¡ la canciÃ³n. The Gaslight Anthem son un grupo que descubrÃ­ este aÃ±o, a pesar de haberlos escuchado nombrar en bastantes webs y revistas. No sabrÃ­a como definir la mÃºsica que hacen, supongo que se etiquetarÃ­a en rock pero un rock como muy americano, de una Ã©poca mÃ¡s temprana. No sÃ©, no me sÃ© los tÃ©rminos adecuados para describirlos, pero es mejor escucharlos y empezar por Mulholland Drive es una buena forma. Mi querida fuente de inspiraciÃ³n, Ben Folds, volviÃ³ hace bastantes meses con su antiguo grupo, Ben Folds Five, quienes han sacado disco del que se mete en la lista el tema Do It Anyways, una canciÃ³n en la que todo suena a medias entre una coÃ±a y a medias entre "mejor que hagas eso" con momentos en los que Ben Folds se deja hasta la garganta. Una mezcla de piano baterÃ­a y bajo Ã©picamente acertada y, al menos en esta canciÃ³n, incluso graciosa. Friends Don't Do Like That es, posiblemente, mi favorito del Ãºltimo Ã¡lbum de The Rasmus (grupo del alma y todo eso). Habiendo cogido el disco con miedo por si me encontraba una mezcla de pop-electro o algo asÃ­, al final ha resultado que simplemente hay temas mÃ¡s lentos de lo normal, pero bastante distinto al bastante comercial Black Roses. Ese tema en concreto tiene un algo en las notas que la guitarra toca en el puente, como una melodÃ­a tirando a oriental, asÃ­ como unos breaks de baterÃ­a antes de cada estribillo que van subiendo gradualmente de velocidad cada vez. Por Ãºltimo y, con miedo a alargarme mucho, tenemos Gone Sovereing de Stone Sour, de su Ãºltimo Ã¡lbum House Of Gold And Bones (Parte 1), la primera parte de un Ã¡lbum conceptual. El tema en sÃ­ me encantÃ³ por, como no, la baterÃ­a. Realmente no tiene mÃ¡s ciencia mi explicaciÃ³n, es un temazo en si, pero me convence la baterÃ­a que a veces puede sonar como un terremoto controlado por dos baquetas. Se que me estoy alargando mucho, pero no pasa nada(?). La siguiente secciÃ³n es la mÃ¡s tranquila de todas, ya que bÃ¡sicamente hay post-rock o baladas, eso si, sin descripciÃ³n. Kiss Tomorrow Goodbye - Arms And Sleepers The Delicate Sound Of Silence - Slow Dancing Society Let Me Tell You About Her - Elvis Costello Glitterpony - Late Night Venture Une Ãˆpoque Formidable - Agora Fidelio Free The House - HalfNoise Rollercoaster Ride - The Whitest Boy Alive Y por Ãºltimo, porque veo que me alargo sin fin, una secciÃ³n dedicada a este verano pasado y titulada "EspÃ­ritu de Verano" (?). Story Of A Modern Child - We Are The Ocean Cheap Affairs - Write This Down Give And Take (Remix) - Forever The Sickest Kids I've Got Friends - Manchester Orchestra Right Where It Belongs - Nine Inch Nails Anthology - Thrice Todas las canciones de las dos Ãºltimas secciones las dejo para escuchar en la lista porque internet no me va muy bien que digamos y Youtube menos, asÃ­ que aquÃ­ estÃ¡ el enlace a Spotify: Lo Mejor de 2012 - Tonight We All Die Y eso es todo por este aÃ±o 2012 asÃ­ que hasta la prÃ³xima entrada!

post.title: No Way Josie FREAKNESS LP Out Now!
post.summary: YES! Itâ€™s been a while coming but our first full-length album is finally out everywhere! (iTunes,Â Spotify,Â AmazonÂ and pretty much everywhere else you can buy or stream digital music.) Weâ€™re gonna put up everything on our Youtube channel too, so check that in a few days! Itâ€™s kind of a new direction for us. We get a lot dirtier but also a lot cleaner. We got reacquainted with some classic drum machines, we got some nice new gear, we played it fast and loose with noise and distortion, we breathed fog machine juice til we saw the Magic Eye, Â we wrote songs like a Real Band, and we actually do some slow stuff now. Weird, huh? Also: dig the album cover? Thereâ€™s a lot of cool shit going on at lindalindalinda.com. But for now, the big news is our album release party, happening tonight at Cameo Gallery! Facebook event is here, buy your tickets here. Weâ€™re headlining a great bill that includes Brooklynâ€™s ownÂ DuckyÂ and Psychic Twin from Chicago. Itâ€™s a great venue for us: small enough for us to sweat all over ya but big enough to have a fucking amazing sound system and fit all of our friends! And for this show, weâ€™re bringing a live drummer, a rapper, (iLLspokinn, who blessed our track â€œHold My Handâ€ with a great verse), a tenor sax player, a shot-hot synthesizer-driven light rig andâ€¦andâ€¦weâ€™re giving away a download of the whole record to everyone who comes and dances with us!

post.title: Cool music player Tomahawk gets an API, making it easier for developers to support multiple services
post.summary: Tomahawk, the much-praised music player app that acts as a unified location to listen to music from sources as diverse as Spotify, SoundCloud, Rdio and YouTube, has announced the launch of an API designed to make life easier for music app and hack developers. Revealed at Midem in Cannes, France, where the startup is taking part in the annual Midemlab competition along with 29 other companies, the API lets developers add a simple, multi-source music player to their apps â€“ perfect for events like Music Hackday, where coders have limited time and want an easy way to support multiple music services. With a few of lines of code, a Tomahawk music player (which can be hidden from view if the developer chooses) can be added to any app, and it supportsÂ SoundCloud, Official.fm, Last.fm, Deezer, Jamendo, YouTube, Rdio and Spotify, with further integrations promised for the future. The player even respects any source preferences existing Tomahawk users may have set up already. Conveniently, there is a Midem Hack Day taking place in Cannes right now, and who knows, maybe the Tomahawk API will be put to use there. We plan to bring you our pick of the hacks from Midem in the coming week. Weâ€™ll also let you know which three startups end up winning the Midemlab competition on Monday, so stay tuned. âž¤Â Tomahawk API Image credit: Jupiterimages / Thinkstock

post.title: What hmv could have learnt from Tesco, Harris & Hoole
post.summary:
When it comes to retail, weâ€™ve all been conditioned to think that big retail chains are invading our high streets and killing off all that is good, local and independent.
One look at any shop within two square miles of a Westfield Shopping Centre will make the point abundantly clear but although we know we should use our local butcher instead of Sainsburyâ€™s and dark independent record stores instead of hmv, itâ€™s just easier to stick with the big names. To combat this, supermarkets especially have looked to create a more artisanal feel to what they do; from deli counters and different types of bread you can carry home under your arm in a brown paper bag like a real Frenchman, or perhaps some â€˜Weather Blemishedâ€™ apples from Waitrose. Most recently, Tesco found themselves getting unwanted attention from Daily Mail readers who felt â€œappalledâ€ and â€œbetrayedâ€ when they learnt that the retail giant owns up to 49% of the apparently independent Harris and Hoole coffee chain.
This pissed a lot of people off, not through a particular hatred of Tesco but the fact that Harris and Hoole didnâ€™t tell anyone. But then why should they? Times are hard for start-ups and with banks only loaning to profitable small businesses, why shouldnâ€™t the likes of Tesco boost the economy by supporting local projects? Itâ€™s certainly far better than planting trees or painting park benches to make people like them. Itâ€™s a smart piece of business for Tesco, spotting that independent coffee shops are growing in popularity and moving quickly to pick up a slice of that pie. Unfortunately hmv havenâ€™t displayed the same agility as they slipped into administration. In the same way that peopleâ€™s local butchers are closed when a giant like Tesco arrives on the scene, when the administrators were called into hmv, a lot of blame fell (unsurprisingly) on iTunes and Amazon. The download industry in the UK accounts for 25% of overall sales, which put increasing pressure on the sale of physical copies, whilst piracy would also have played its part, but the sad truth is that hmv simply no longer fits with how we want our culture in the 21st century.
The UK is Europeâ€™s most digitally aware nation and thatâ€™s reflected in how we consume media; glued to a screen from when we wake up to when we go to bed, weâ€™re constantly distracted by the limitless choice of the internet. When it comes to music, we want buzz blogs that tell us quickly whether or not we should like a single, album or artist, following a select few influential bloggers on Twitter from a host of thousands. Â In giving us free short preview bursts, the likes of iTunes and Amazon have made the most of this willingness to make snap decisions when buying albums, whilst streaming sites like YouTube, Spotify and Grooveshark give us more or less unlimited access to music for almost nothing. Hmv would admit theyÂ didnâ€™tÂ react quickly enough to this desire for digital and portable, but perhaps their biggest failing was in not capitalising on the fact that CDs and records have become retro. In much the same way that Tesco have done with Harris and Hoole, the opportunity was there to invest in independence and individuality,Â focusingÂ on the fact that everyone wants to hear about the next cool up and coming act, in the same way that Tesco spotted and invested in the fact that everyone wants to be seen in a trendy independent coffee shop.
Instead hmv storesâ€™ black and neon colour schemes, grey carpets and One Direction paraphernalia make them look cheap and uninspiring, with no in-store coffee tables to sit and be seen at, no free must-have tote bag and no personality. Hmvâ€™s struggle against the tide of adversity is coming to an end and much like the independent stores they help extinguish; their failure to tap into the current consumer psyche â€“ namely the relationship between format, feel and purchase platform â€“ was their ultimate undoing.

post.title: Matt Stevens Update
post.summary: Thanks loads to everyone who has paid for downloads this week, it means a lot to me.Â Today is the last day to download my albums and pay any amount, including free. A few people asked me why I was stopping.Â So here it is: Because I've done that. The whole idea was to use "pay what you want" to build an audience. 6000 downloads later we've done that. 3000 email address make make it easier to reach the audience for the next album.Â The music is all on Spotify and Bandcamp to listen to free anyway. There is no barrier to discovery.Â It's no longer remarkable. PWYW has been done. It doesn't feel fresh anymore.Â There will always be a free offer on my site - whether it's a sampler or just a few tracks. I believe you need to give something away to gain an audience.Â So that's it :)Â All downloads will be Â£3 - Â£5 (minimum) from tomorrow so why not grab one for free now?Â http://mattstevens.bandcamp.com/ Thanks loads for all your support :)Â Matt PS What do you think?

post.title: The last day....
post.summary:
Hello :)
Thanks loads to everyone who has paid for downloads this week, it means a lot to me.
Today is the last day to download my albums and pay any amount, including free. A few people asked me why I was stopping.
So here it is:
Because I've done that. The whole idea was to use "pay what you want" to build an audience. 6000 downloads later we've done that. 3000 email address make make it easier to reach the audience for the next album.Â The music is all on Spotify and Bandcamp to listen to free anyway. There is no barrier to discovery.Â It's no longer remarkable. PWYW has been done. It doesn't feel fresh anymore.Â There will always be a free offer on my site - whether it's a sampler like this oneÂ or just a few tracks. I believe you need to give something away to gain an audience.Â
So that's it :)Â
All downloads will be Â£3 - Â£5 (minimum) from tomorrow so why not grab one for free now?Â
http://mattstevens.bandcamp.com/
Thanks loads for all your support :)Â
Matt
PS What do you think?

post.title: Neuman (Sala BeGood, Barcelona, 25-01-2013)
post.summary: Neuman contra el frÃ­o. Parece mentira que hoy en dÃ­a debamos agradecer a una entidad administrativo-gubernamental la organizaciÃ³n y promociÃ³n de un concierto en nuestro paÃ­s, pero mientras el Circuito de MÃºsicas Populares GPS (Girando Por Salas) siga vivo y en vigor, puede que asÃ­ sea en mÃ¡s de una ocasiÃ³n. Se trata de una iniciativa del Instituto de Artes EscÃ©nicas y de la MÃºsica (INAEM), que pretende facilitar la actuaciÃ³n de bandas emergentes por todo el territorio peninsular, y en el cual, desde 2010, han participado ya mÃ¡s de 300 artistas y 200 salas en todas las provincias. Ayer en Barcelona, sin ir mÃ¡s lejos, algunos tuvimos la suerte (o el acierto) de ver a los murcianos Neuman en la pequeÃ±a sala BeGood, desarrollando el que ha de ser, en estos momentos, uno de los mejores y mÃ¡s intensos directos de del panorama nacional. Con un notable retraso, y tras una regular actuaciÃ³n de sus amigos y banda local PanorÃ¢mica, Paco RomÃ¡n y compaÃ±Ã­a sentaron las bases del buen rock alternativo. No es que los de MatarÃ³ sonaran tan mal, es que los Neuman se salieron. Expusieron con seguridad su voluntarioso pop, con leves reminiscencias yeyÃ©, pero con un planteamiento y unas fÃ³rmulas tÃ³picas y ciertamente trilladas. Luminosidad en Ã¡ngulo recto, de puertas bien abiertas. Todo lo contrario que los murcianos, que tienen en la oscuridad sus fuentes principales de luz; y, aunque no siempre lo consigan, buscan constantemente explorar caminos poco transitados. Son, en cierto modo y curiosamente, el paradigma de lo alternativo. Y precisamente bandas como Neuman son las que podrÃ­an y deberÃ­an estar marcando el camino de conciliaciÃ³n entre el pop, lo comercial y este sub-estilo del rock. El de anoche era el penÃºltimo concierto de una gira que ha durado prÃ¡cticamente un aÃ±o, de un disco, The Family Plot (Tsunami/Neuman, 2012), que, si bien no ha tenido la misma aceptaciÃ³n que su aclamado debut, Plastic Heaven (Loopside Records, 2010), sÃ­ consolida y aporta un corpus a la banda difÃ­cil de obviar sobre un escenario. Normal, porque RomÃ¡n lleva subido a ellos muchos aÃ±os, y se ha trabajado un estilo bien consistente desde el interior de sÃ­ mismo; madurÃ¡ndose, mucho antes de encontrar en Fernando Lillo, el pianista, un cÃ³mplice perfecto para aventurarse con el proyecto Neuman. David Manzullo al bajo y Alex Damdaca a la baterÃ­a completan el cuarteto, revistiendo con un caluroso torrente medido de ruido y distorsiÃ³n las composiciones y confesiones escenogrÃ¡ficas de RomÃ¡n, a quien es difÃ­cil dejar de mirar. El murciano, declarado fan del BarÃ§a y amante de la Ciudad Condal, habla pese a ser un tipo callado; tranquilo, serio y siempre erguido por dentro, parece de esos mÃºsicos meticulosos que no se pierden en aspavientos ni pretensiones de grandeza. Su presencia sobre el escenario asegura entereza, cierta solemnidad y un punto grande e importante de veracidad. Porque se nota que tanto el aplomo mostrado en los desarrollos de muchos temas como los arranques de melancolÃ­a, dignidad e (im)potencia de muchos finales, se deben y se conectan intrÃ­nsecamente al fluir interno de RomÃ¡n: la gran aportaciÃ³n del resto de la banda, a parte de una aptitudes musicales notables por sÃ­ solas, es haber sabido interpretar a su lÃ­der. Un poco es el Messi de Neuman; solo que, inmerecidamente, con infinita menos repercusiÃ³n mediÃ¡tica. Presentaron en un concierto relativamente corto pero muy intenso y denso sus dos Cd casi a partes iguales, mÃ¡s un tema inÃ©dito, Hell, que saldrÃ¡ en un Ep el prÃ³ximo mes de marzo. Pero ademÃ¡s lo hicieron como lo hacen los buenos: transformando un poco sus mejores canciones, hasta el punto de hacer que parecieran Ãºnicas e irrepetibles; jugando sus bazas: hincando bien las rodillas para cimentar himnos, y levantando el pie de vez en cuando para otorgar gravedad y fondo a su claroscuro constante. Empezaron enlazando Lovers, Jane y My Dad, tres ases fuertes de su Ãºltimo trabajo, y ya desde entonces nos descubrieron otras dimensiones del sonido de la sala BeGood. DespuÃ©s La Yo, Friends, I Have The Will, en plan acÃºstico romÃ¡ntico, Plastic Heaven y Doggy; para acabar, en un vendaval de rÃ¡fagas de elÃ©ctrica, con The Family Plot y Sil Fono, probablemente su mejor tema. Hubo cosas evidentes anoche: la forma dilatada en la que construyeron la intro de la Ãºltima, por ejemplo, con un piano que se intuye pero que no es, y una guitarra, que es la fuerza del viento controlado; o la manera en que ponen su directo sobre cualquier tipo de escenario como si fuera ese su estado natural, nos hablan claramente de un grupo con cuerpo de adulto, y calidad como para marcar tendencia. Lo que, en mi opiniÃ³n, sigue siendo incomprensible es que sus conciertos no registren una afluencia mucho mayor de la que vimos ayer. Lo tienen absolutamente todo para convertirse en un referente. Y por este tipo de injusticias son por las que empecÃ© a escribir sobre mÃºsica: porque estoy convencido de que a casi todo el mundo que los escuche les gustarÃ¡ Neuman. Pero, desde anoche, aÃºn mÃ¡s de que se enamorarÃ¡n de ellos al verlos en su estado natural: en directo. Â Fotos de Pablo Luna Chao. Escucha el setlist del concierto en Spotify.

post.title: Monday Morning Update 1/28/13
post.summary:
From Optumized: â€œRe: Optumâ€™s acquisition of Humedica. Confirmed by Lazard Capital Markets.â€ I appreciate that the update from Steven Halper, managing director of equity research, credited HIStalk as the original source (as I, in turn, should thank Embers and another couple of readers who tipped me off). A Boston Business Journal article says the acquisition is valued by an insider in the hundreds of million dollars. I interviewed Humedica President and CEO Michael Weintraub a year ago. I notice that the Boston paper is getting credit for breaking the news with its Friday afternoon article even though I ran and confirmed it Tuesday evening with the help of readers. From False Positive: â€œRe: Farzadâ€™s rebuttal that talks about â€˜cynical critics.â€™ Who are they? How does he know that they donâ€™t like paper?â€ The cynical critics, at least those constantly seeking attention, are easy to spot because they sing only one loud and sustained note. When I read an emotional, overwrought restaurant review on Yelp, I always click that personâ€™s profile to see if they have a mix of positive and negative reviews and ignore them if not. Likewise, I twit filter the monotonic EMR whiners and cheerleaders alike, placing a lot more value on the 80 percent who donâ€™t flaunt their blinders publicly. Farzad was right about the RAND study â€“ they said their original projections about EMR savings were wrong because EMR adoption was less than expected and payment incentives are still screwed up. The job of EMRs is to support reform, not to create it. Heâ€™s also right that those cynical critics havenâ€™t written smug and pedantic articles extolling the virtues of paper medical records, so theyâ€™re leaving us to breathlessly anticipate their suggested alternative. And if theyâ€™re intentionally avoiding EMR-using doctors and hospitals for their own care, they arenâ€™t blowing that horn either. What they should be criticizing is the healthcare system that created the current batch of EMRs that conform precisely to its ridiculousness.
From The PACS Designer: â€œRe: TPDâ€™s List. The recent update of TPDâ€™s List of iPhone Apps that added a HIStalk Sponsors section has created new interest amongst them to recognize their iPhone apps. Vitera informed us about an app (above) that provides healthcare providers access to their Intergy EHR solution enabling anytime, anywhere access to schedules, tasks, patient records, and e-prescribing. Humetrix alerted us to several iBlueButton apps they developed with HHS. These new apps will be added to the next TPDâ€™s List update.â€ From Ear-Ground Continuum: â€œRe: MEDecision. Huge downsizing â€“ they let 83 people go last month with another round this week and next.â€ Unverified. Recent comments on Glassdoor are certainly interesting. UPDATE: Verified by a readerâ€™s link. From Nasty Parts: â€œRe: Greenway reseller iPractice Group. Closed its doors today. Sources say cash flow problems despite strong sales, so the board pulled the plug.â€ Unverified. I e-mailed the company but havenâ€™t heard back.
Speaking of the RAND study, more readers think it was naÃ¯ve rather than biased (and yes, RAND should be capitalized, at least if you buy the idea that itâ€™s OK to make up acronyms solely to create a conveniently pronounceable word, in this case Research ANd Development.) Anyway, new poll to your right: if you had to buy a vendorâ€™s stock, which of the five listed would you choose? Several readers (me included) expressed an interest in hearing more from Robert D. Lafsky, MD, whose guest articles always contain an impressive mix of medical knowledge, wry cynicism, and grammatical excellence (he always e-mails me when he finds my mistakes, and the threat of incurring his gentle wrath caused me to double-check the spelling of RAND). He has agreed to elevation to regular contributor under the nameplate The Skeptical Convert, with his first installment running this weekend. Hereâ€™s a new Spotify playlist of what Iâ€™m listening to: new Aaron Neville, The Cardigans, 4 Non Blondes, Alabama Shakes, Imperial Teen, and a few more.
Welcome to new HIStalk Platinum sponsor The McHenry Group, an executive search firm focused entirely on the healthcare software and services vendor market. TMGâ€™s team of search consultants averages more than 11 years with the company, having placed over 2,000 candidates since 1991. TMG has developed the industryâ€™s largest candidate database of hard-to-find talent, including the hidden candidate market. The company conducts videoconference interviews with every candidate and forwards the videos of the strongest to the client for their review which moves things along faster and gives a better fit, enabling TMG to offer an extra-long 12-month replacement guarantee. TMG has filled positions for CEO, COO, CMO, CMIO, SVP, business development, sales VP, and informatics roles for companies such as RelayHealth, McKesson, Orion Health, and Health Language. They have conducted searches across the entire US as well as for non-US companies building their US operations. Featured business development stars are experts in clinical software, Meaningful Use, and payor technology, while project manager and implementation candidates are available in EMR, multi-hospital implementations, and client services. TMG provides well-screened candidates, ethical search consultants, and a promise to understand the clientâ€™s business needs. Thanks to The McHenry Group for supporting HIStalk. Athenahealth files notice with the State of Alabama that it will lay off 36 employees at its Birmingham office on March 6. The company has not announced what types of workers are affected, although Birmingham was the location of Proxsys, the care coordination systems vendor athenahealth acquired in 2011 to boost its athenaCoordinator product. Compuware turns down the $2.3 billion buyout offer of Elliott Management Corp and says it will instead spin off Covisint as originally planned.
Weird News Andy says this is better than die-alysis. A kidney patient in China who canâ€™t afford dialysis treatments has lived for 13 years so far by dialyzing himself three times each week using a machine he built from kitchen tools and old medical equipment. He recently declined the Chinese governmentâ€™s offer of free dialysis that was extended after his story was picked up worldwide, saying the hospitals are too far away and too crowded. Heâ€™s not worried that two of his friends died after trying a similar setup.
WNA also likes the RP-VITA iPad-controlled medical robot that just received FDA approval. Farzad Mostashari can bask in the knowledge that heâ€™s a big enough name to be featured in a CAP News parody (itâ€™s like The Onion, but not as well done). I think they probably chose him randomly for the article Toilet Sizes Expand to Meet Needs of Obese Nation, quoting him in describing a new HHS standard called â€œAss Cheek/Toilet Seat Ratio.â€
Gartner says Big Data has reached the Trough of Disillusionment stage of its ingenious Hype Cycle, of which Iâ€™ve been a long-time fan. If the author is correct â€“ and I would say she is â€“ the previously Big Data-fawning press will start running negative articles, which is OK since once that negativity has been purged, itâ€™s on to the Trough of Enlightenment, where organizations whose interest is more than fad-chasing start delivering results. A Wall Street Journal blog post on the Gartner item quotes Aurelia Boyer, CIO of New York Presbyterian Hospital, who says theyâ€™re using Hadoop with natural language processing to analyze millions of patient records to find, for example, how many of them have mentioned a gunshot wound. A study looks at why patients may think doctors who use clinical decision support are less capable. Apparently patients worry more about doctors using non-human tools rather than having a doctor who seeks external advice. New Hanover Regional Medical Center (NC) goes to paper downtime procedures for seven hours Thursday when its Epic system goes offline due to an AT&T regional outage. An online publication HITECH article elicited interesting comments. Granted some of them veer into death panel nut job territory, but theyâ€™re still fun to read and some are insightful.
â€œEMRs encourage doctors and nurses to cheat and lie. EMRs have made medical records inaccurate and unreliable. When I read medical records nowadays, I often canâ€™t tell what the hell happened.â€ â€œIn an EMR, every URI is an average URI.â€ On the use of surgical case templates: â€œâ€¦ worked out with the hospital risk management department to describe what should happen, and entered in the EMR with one click of a mouse. What actually happened? No one can tell.â€ â€œThe response calling this idiocy a step in the right direction apparently fails to get the point, which is that EMRs make crappy doctors look like decent ones by giving them the same well-written notes as the good ones.â€ â€œIt seems to me that this isnâ€™t exactly the unintended consequences of EMR; itâ€™s the unintended consequences of the government incentivizing bad EMR by incentivizing the wrong things:Â the ACA encourages rapid adoption of immature or awkward technologies without clear benefits; medicare, medicaid, ACA, and the employer-provided health insurance tax exemption incentivize egregious billing practices. EMR and provider companies respond to the incentives; the problem isnâ€™t the software per se, but the incentives. Thereâ€™s no inherent reason why an EMR system should require more data entry on the part of doctors, or why the data entry should take longer than updating a paper chart. Systems could be designed that work better and provide consumer benefits, but they arenâ€™t appearing because the system incentives really arenâ€™t designed to serve the customer. A physician on not customizing template-created notes: â€œI like to think most of us are pretty honest, and this doesnâ€™t feel like a lie, more like the best that can be done with the time available and the limits of the EMR. I donâ€™t know if I am only humoring myself about the honesty. I do know the job canâ€™t be done except by the copy and paste method.â€ â€œThis article misses a key point. If theyâ€™re fine falsifying electronic records, why wouldnâ€™t they be comfortable falsifying written records? Moreover, electronic records are easier to falsify, but theyâ€™re also easier to catch.â€ â€œI think physician associations need to reemphasize that documentation by exception is not appropriate for physicians, perhaps even take it a step farther and officially declare it outside the standard of practice. The great potential benefit of EMRâ€™s (along with the requirement that they be able to produce data in a standard format) is that medical charting will stop being primarily about stories and start being primarily about data. This will not only make treatment of patients more scientific, it will energize evidence-based medicine. Right now, about half of medical treatment is done despite no evidence of efficacy. Of course, if the data is unreliable, we have GIGO. So the use of charting by exception leading to bad data is a huge problem.â€ â€œEMRâ€™s are the vehicle for corporate and government direction of medical care. I predict that within 5 years, it will be illegal to provide medical care to a patient unless it is through an Electronic Medical Record â€¦ this idea will be advanced as important to preventing waste, fraud and abuse.â€ â€œSimply put, doing a thing, and documenting the doing of a thing, are two separate, and not particularity related skills (I would figure that journalists would understand this better than anyone), and it is unlikely that a person who is good at the former is also good at the latter, and when we ask him to do both, this is what we get. Cheer up, we could get the people who do amazingly good documentation to do the surgery. I suspect that would be much worse.â€
Iâ€™m scooping Weird News Andy on this story: a drunken Englishman is hospitalized after the paramedics he called found his frigid sexual partner dismembered in a snowy field. The partner was a snowman; the manâ€™s injury involved frostbite of his manhood, which nearly required amputation.
Itâ€™s NextGen Part 3 from Vince this week as he covers Opus Healthcare Solutions.
Sponsor Updates
SimplifyMD is running cartoons and videos looking at the humorous side of medical practice at â€œEasy Street Family Practice.â€ Nuance announces that the electronic medical records systems used by hospitals and clinics in the United Arab Emirates will be voice-enabled using Dragon Medical.
Contacts Mr. H, Inga, Dr. Jayne, Dr. Gregg, Lt. Dan, Dr. Travis. More news: HIStalk Practice, HIStalk Connect.

post.title: Medina â€“ DÃ¤r Palmerna Bor
post.summary: Listen to Medina - DÃ¤r palmerna bor (3,78 min) on spotify. DÃ¤r palmerna bor can be found on the album DÃ¤r palmerna bor which were released 2012, track nr: 1About MedinaThere are more artists using this name: 1) Medina Danielle Oona Valbak (born Andrea Fuentealba Valbak; November 30, 1982 in Risskov, Aarhus, Denmark), is already a huge pop sensation in her native country. The half Danish half Chilean songstress began working with the infamous production team, 'Providers' in the summer of 2008 and released the dance floor smash, Kun for mig (You & I) in September 2008. The track spent a phenomenal seven weeks at number 1 in the Danish Dance chart before national radio began to take note in January 2009. To date, "Kun For Mig" (You & I) is the biggest record of the year in Denmark. The single has spent an astonishing 6 weeks at number 1, selling 75,000 singles and reached double platinum status. She has performed over 100 shows since January 2009, including supports for Lady Gaga. Her busy live schedule over the summer was supposed to have included supporting The Pussycat Dolls in August, but the show was cancelled. Medina has now recorded "Kun For Mig" (You & I) in English and after a heated A & R scramble, the track will be released in the UK in mid September on Parlophone Records. Fierce mixes come from deadmau5, Spencer & Hill, Dash Berlin, Svenstrup & Vendelboe, Kim Fai, Havin Zagross and Luciano Vargas. post.title: UnoDNS frees you to stream from other countries
post.summary: I am writing these lines while listening to Pandora. If you're in the US, this probably doesn't sound very exciting. I, however, am not in the US--I'm in Israel, a country in which Pandora is not officially supported. I can also do all sorts of other US-only tricks, such as watch Hulu, enjoy Netflix video streaming, and jam to Rdio and Spotify. All of the computers on my home network can enjoy the same content, and I didn't have to install any software or flash my ADSL router with custom firmware for this to work. This is all thanks to innovative $5/month (eight-day free trial) service UnoDNS--and before you ask, no, it is not a VPN.

post.title: milestone morning: 30 weeks!
post.summary: photo & muffins currently of my muffin man, Adam.in love with our new glider. thanks Mom! xoxoToday is another day for celebration! Baby W and I made it to 30 weeks! and I'm still at home on the couch and not in the hospital...and most importantly, not in labor. High fives all around. Â To celebrate, Adam is in the kitchen making me a yummy breakfast and the dog keeps coming by to drool on me which I'm pretty sure is his way of saying, "this is great news!" Adam is even making a recipe for muffins I saw on Pinterest for Carrot & Peach muffins using Chobani*...fancy! I may or may not have spent the majority of the morning singing "yes, I know the muffin man, the muffin man, the muffin man..." totally legit. Don't they look delicious?! Which reminds me of this awesome website, featuring animated film shorts about muffins.Â *Â you're welcome. Our Spotify Blitzen Trapper station is killing it this morning. We've heard everything from Alexander, to Washed Out to Biz Markie (oh baby youuuuuuuuu, you got what I neeeeeeeeeeed), to Rusted Root, which Adam was super psyched about. And, for a change of scenery when I got up from bed I spent about an hour hanging out in the new glider we ordered for the nursery (that is currently parked in our bedroom) reading "The Family Fang" and relaxing while Baby W went to town kicking me. Thanks, baby! The Moose had kind of a rough night last night...with a lot of laughs at his expense. Adam got him a "thundershirt." Have you guys heard of them? They are essentially Spanx for dogs, as Elena put it. I guess they are meant to feel like a "hug" and the pressure around them helps with anxiety, which has been ongoing issue for the Moose throughout my pregnancy. Anyway, we put the thundershirt on the dog and while it may have "hugged" him...it also made him hate us. He spent the majority of the evening sulking, slouching, and looking severely depressed. He wouldn't even come over to me or make eye contact with me (that's always a bad sign, our dog is king of eye contact) he was so ashamed. Â And call me a bad person, but it was HILARIOUS. We always joke that the Moose feels feelings very intensely, and last night, let me tell you, the Moose was feeling some feelings. We eventually took it off him and he sprung back to life, but we're hoping we can get to a point where we can put the shirt on him and not actually kill his soul. Right now, we're very much in the soul killing phase of adjusting. Wish us luck here on the couch & have a great weekend! Bundle up! Multiple technologies tell me it's freezing out there. why won't you even look at me?Â *note this is a link.
